Africa News


December 1, 1996


South Africa;


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC NEC interim committee under leadership of Tito Mboweni into Free State affairs today, Sunday convened a meeting in Bloemfontein to discuss political developments and programme of action of the ANC in the province.

The meeting was attended by ANC members of the provincial legislature, ANC members now being redeployed in the Province, regional chairpersons, secretaries of ANC regions and national organisers. 

The meeting confirmed the NEC decisions on the free state and unanimously agreed to confirm the redeployment process.

In this regard, the meeting further agreed to rally behind and nominate Dr Ivy Matsepe-Casaburri as premier candidate of Free State.

The ANC Caucus will further propose her name for the premiership when the legislature convenes.

The full deployment list as follows:

Sakhiwe Belot - National Assembly

Dr Ivy Matsepe-Casaburri - Provincial Legislature

Zingile Dingane PL

Patrick Terror Lekota - Senate

Webster Nfebe PL

Ace Magashule NA

SN Malebo PL

Pat Maotsa NA

Gregory Nthatise ANC Organisation

Meeting further called on all ANC members, supporters, alliance structures and Free State people to rally behind and give unequivocal support to these decisions.

Issued by: African National Congress Department of Information and Publicity Po Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107

Africa News


December 1, 1996


Ethiopia;
Britain Supports Efforts Enhancing OAU Conflict Prevention


BYLINE: Kisut G/Egzibher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The visiting British Minister for Overseas Development and Africa said here yesterday that supporting the peaceful resolution of conflicts, the alleviation of poverty through sustainable development as well as sound governance and economic reforms are the guiding principles of her government s policy where this continent was concerned.

Addressing a large gathering of diplomats and other prominent personalities at the OAU headquarters, Baroness Lyinda Chalker said the UK, is playing a leading role through its African peace-keeping initiative in helping Africans to respond to regional crisis. The support, she noted, ranged from contributing to the OAU Peace Fund and the new Conflict Management Division to training senior officers from a number of African countries.

According to the Minister, Great Britain and Zimbabwe co-organised a workshop for senior officers from 17 African countries to examine peace- keeping practices and principles. Britain has since hosted two African peace- keeping map exercises most recently, she said. 

Mrs. Chalker revealed that the Zimbabwe Staff College has become the first regional "centre of excellence" for UN peace-keeping training, and said that her government assisted its development and in organising first peace-keeping course there. The Minister noted further that the UK is working on a similar centre n Ghana.

Stressing the essence of a disciplined military in maintaining stability, baroness Chalker said the her government has this year allocated 6.5 million pounds sterling fro these programmes alone.

"But the problems go deeper than technical fixes. All my experience tells me that poverty is a major cause of conflict. No only does it give rise to localised squabbles which then escalate. But more importantly in Africa, and else where, it leads to large people s movement, often across borders," the minister said, and went on: "The pressures these bring become a cause of conflict in themselves, as recent events in the Great Lakes region have demonstrated. An essential part of the British Government s task is to help reduce poverty and suffering by contributing to sustainable development.

"The rationale in doing so is understood to be that the carefully planned development assistance prevents natural and man-made disasters and so contributes to building stability."

Mrs. Chalker described good governance as the best guarantor of peace in any society and said that the UK government s assistance in this area is aimed at helping promote stability.

Recalling that her government last year spend 400 million pounds on direct support for economic reform in Africa, the Minister appreciated Ethiopia and Uganda's stride in this respect. "Rapid and sustained economic development as in Ethiopia and Uganda provide the only basis for reducing poverty," she noted.

Baroness Lyinda Chalker earlier visited the OAU Conflict Prevention, Management and Resolution Centre and met with secretary-general Salim A. Salim.

Meanwhile, the Ethiopian News Agency reported that Baroness Lyinda Chalker yesterday reiterated he government's support to build the capacity of the House of Peoples Representatives of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and the national regional states.

During talks with Ato Dawit Yohannes, Speaker of the House, Mrs. Chalker appreciated the way the Ethiopian Parliament was organized and the devolution of power to regional states.

During talks with Ato Dawit Yohannes, Speaker of the House, Mrs. Chalkier appreciated the way the Ethiopian Parliament was organized and the devolution of power to regional states.

Mrs. Chalker also told the speaker that the democratization in the country is in the right track and reiterated her country's support to the strengthening of the process.

Ato Dawit also said that more than 60 political parties are operating in the country out which most are organized representing nations and nationalities while few are national parties.

He said the international situation has facilitated conditions for Ethiopia and the United Kingdom to become development partners.

Africa News


December 1, 1996


Ethiopia;
Air Piracy Gone Awry


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Addis Ababa - The torrid drama surrounding the flight ET 961 disaster off the Comoros a week ago may now be said to be behind us. Not so the searing memory which it left behind for a horror-stricken public to ponder for quite some time yet.

Put aside for a moment the number of the innocent who were consumed in the cataclysm resulting from the plunge of the national carrier into the depths of the Indian Ocean, eve, though that rates among the highest in living memory. Forget even the anxiety undergone by families and friends of the 175 passengers and crew abroad the doomed airliner awaiting identification, however, almost indescribably unbearable it must have been. It was, rather, the cold- bloodedness of the whole episode that was so terrifying in its utter meaninglessness. 

Few incidents touch off spontaneous and massive outpourings of horror as do tragedies caused by callous disregard fro human life.

Such was the fate of flight ET961. The nation observed three days of mourning, with church and mosque joining in the bereavement. They were genuine and deeply felt; so deeply felt was the creation to the tragedy by a grief-stricken public. To the extent that the passengers - both the 125 who perished and 50 survivors - represented no less than 37 countries, it was natural that the grief should have been shared far and near.

The facts surrounding the tragedy have been dwelt upon at length already. suffice it to recall that the pilot, ordered to change course to Australia while en route to Abidjan via Nairobi, Brazzaville and Lagos, had made it clear that this was quite simply impossible as he was running out of fuel. The still unidentified trio of hijackers, desperadoes as it turned out, were not impressed in the least. And so the inevitable followed not long after, earring itself a secure niche in the dark annals of air piracy.

What, though, is the lesson to be derived from this grisly incident? It is unlikely that there will be an end to the litany of comments and suggestions that will keep pouring in. Streaks of lawlessness in the skies are in any case to be expected every now and then in this age of fast and casual air travel. Beyond renewed calls for still more stringency in international laws and conventions to curb air piracy, one thing would seem obvious: the need for tightening security not only at airports but abroad flights as well. Innocent passengers such as those who perished or nearly did so off the Comoros last weekend deserve no less.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December 1, 1996


Ethiopia;
Research Group Discovers Ancient Cave


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - the British University of Hudders field Caving Club in conjunction with the Oromiya Trade, Industry and tourism Bureau has discovered a complex cave system called Aynage.

The university said the recorded length of the new cave system stands at 3. 1 kms. making it Ethiopia s third longest cave. the total length of explored cave passage near Mechara, East Hararge, now stands at over 7 kilometre. 

Professor John Gunn of the Limestone Research Group, at Huddersfield, has been carrying out research into these caves, a release issued by the team of researchers said.

The caves have important scientific sediments and are estimated to be at least 4 million years old, making them possibly the oldest caves in the Horn of Africa.

The team are keen to continue their research into this interesting caving region the release said, adding this will provide further scientific data and will possibly increase tourist inflow in the region.

Farmers fail to pay debts

Nazareth (ENA) - Farmers in East Shoa Zone of Oromiya have not paid back 133 million birr they have borrowed from the Development and Commercial Banks of Ethiopia over the past eight years.

Head of the cooperative association section of the zonal agricultural department said that committees have been established at various level of the zonal administration to coordinate efforts underway to ensure debt clearance.

December 1, 1996


Ethiopia;
Live mortar shell killed three teenagers: Police


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Debre Birhan (ENA) - Police said three students were killed while bruising a live mortar shell in Debre Birhan town, 130 kms. north east of the capital.

Town police chief, Let. Admassu Abebe told the Ethiopian News Agency that the mortar shell was abandoned by the then retreating Derg army.

The teenagers were travelling to fetch water in a nearby river when the accident occurred, police said. Meanwhile, the West Hararghe zonal high court has sentenced a man to life imprisonment for manslaughthering and bullet killing.

The court passed the verdict after it had found the culprit Yousef Ahmed guilty of committing the crime.

The court said it has given a light sentence taking into consideration that the convict was a father of ten.

In a similar new, the high court in Jimma zone has sentenced a woman to 14 years of imprisonment for beheading a baby girl with a dagger.

December 1, 1996


Ethiopia;
Minister Calls for Participation


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Minister of Education Genet Zewdie called on teachers, professional associations and the society at large to contribute to the successful implementation of the new educational policy aimed at producing skilled manpower.

Speaking at a panel discussion organised yesterday by the Chemistry Society of Ethiopia at the Ministry of Education Woizero genet said the new policy would have a meaningful share in the national development endeavour only if it won the support of the society and professional associations. 

The participation of all, specially of teachers and educational professionals in devising the new education curriculum and in the preparation of teaching aid is imperative for the success of the education policy, she said and reminded members of the Chemistry Society of Ethiopia and other professional associations of their heaviest responsibilities in helping produce qualified manpower in the field of education.

In order to correctly and promptly respond to the national call of rebuilding the country and producing skilled manpower, it is very important that professionals get organized and create for at which they could exchange views on ways of improving the quality of education, she said.

The panel was jointly organized by the Addis Ababa University and the Meganet Corporation.

Africa News


December 2, 1996


Zambia;
President Chiluba Picks New Cabinet


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba today announced a new cabinet for Zambia with a promise to serve better the country so that at the end of his last five year term there will be something by which he will be remembered.

Most of the old faces returned to cabinet but quite a few were missing mostly because they had lost elections.

In remarks preceding the announcement and those made afterwards during a question and answer session with journalists at a State House press conference Mr Chiluba declared that he expected discipline and hard work from his new team of cabinet ministers so that after five years much of the poverty in the country will have been alleviated or drastically reduced.

He said he did not expect inconsistencies, bickering and the washing of dirty linen in public. He particularly admonished his colleagues in the ruling Movement for Multi-partyt democracy to desist from commenting on Zambia's foreign relations when they had no specialised right to do so. 

In the new cabinet the obvious omissions are Dr Kabunda Kayongo who has been replaced by Enock Kavindele as Minister of Science, Technology and Vocational Training.

Another face is that of Dr Luminzu Shimaponda who has been replaced as Minister of Legal Affairs by Mr Vincent Malambo who was an adviser to President Chiluba before he won an election last month. Lt-Colonel (retired) Patrick Kafumukache has also been dropped from the Works and Supply portfolio after he lost his Kabompo seat in the elections of last month. His position has been filled with Sipakeli Walubita, who previously was at Ministry of Mines and Minerals Development.

Another casualty is Gabriel Maka, who Minister of Tourism but lost the election to Lusaka businessman, Macdonald Nkabika for the Kapiri-Mposhi seat.

Other than these losses most of the cabinet has just been shuffled around to areas where their services are expected to be fully used.

The rest of the appointments are as follows: Vice-President - Brigadier- General Godfrey Miyanda; Defence - Benjamin Mwila; Finance - Ronald Penza; Health - Katele Kalumba and Prof. Nkandu Luo as his deputy; Foreign Affairs - Prof. Lawrence Shimba with Valentine Kayope as deputy; Home Affairs - Chitalu Sampa with Peter Muunga as deputy.

Agriculture Food and Fisheries - Edith Nawakwi with Ackson Sejani and Y Ngulube as her deputies; Education Dr Siyamukayumbu Siyamujaye with Dickson Matutu and Betram Membe as his deputies; Local Government and Housing - Bennie Mwiinga with Elizabeth Kalenga and Bernard Mpundu as his deputies.

Labour and Social Security - Peter Machungwa; Commerce Trade and Industry, Alfeyo Hambayi with Ackim Nkole and Jazzman Chikwakwa as his deputies; Tourism - Amusaa Mwanamwambwa with Piers Mambo as his deputy; Communications and Transport - Paul Kaping'a with Gilbert Mululu and Isaac Kalingeme as his deputies.

Energy and Water Development - Suresh Desai with Mann Muyuni as the deputy; Sport Youth and Child Development - Samuel Miyanda with E.K.Mutale as the deputy; Information and Broadcasting Services - David Mpamba with Enerst Mwansa as his deputy; Environment and Natural Resources - William Harrington with gibson Nkausu as his deputy; Lands - Dawson Lupunga with Dr Mathias Mphande as his deputy; Community Developemnt and Social Services - Newstead Zimba with Jane Chikwata and Stephen Manjata as his deputies.

Mr Chiluba also created a post of full cabinet Minister to be based at State House and this position has gone to his political and legal advisor Eric Silwamba who previously was only a deputy Minister. He has also appointed two deputy Ministers to be in charge of Church and youth affairs directly under his supervision.

To these positions he has appointed Reverend Peter Chintala (church affairs) and Josia Chishala (youth affairs). Mr Chiluba observed that he wanted to be close to the unemployed youth by dialoguing with them and getting first hand what they wanted the government to do for them so that they could engage in meaningful enterprises.

In the provincial administration Mr Chiluba has brought in some new comers too who include real estate tycoon Sonny Mulenga who takes over from Elias Chipimo as leader of Lusaka province. In the Eastern Province he has appointed Chikatula Banda who takes over from Hosea Soko. To the Western Province goes Michael Mabenga who is also a new comer to national leadership after having won the Mulobezi seat last month.

Africa News


December 2, 1996


Science and Health;
Poachers Decimate Buffaloes In Mozambique


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1049 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The population of buffaloes in Marromeu game reserve, in Central Mozambique's Sofala province, has been drastically reduced by poaching and indiscriminate slaughter, reports Monday's issue of the Maputo-published daily paper, Noticias.

Noticias quoted the Sofala provincial director of agriculture and fisheries, Antonio Semente, as saying that of the 45,000 buffaloes that once roamed the area, only about 4,000 are left. 

He attributed the "disastrous scenario" to factors such as the war that affected the area and poaching.

To reverse the situation, Semente suggested that hunting in the reserve should be prohibited for a period of one year, coupled with "intensified inspection" to prevent poaching.

"Safari operators and licensed hunters have already been made aware of the issue," he said.

Semente explained that these measures will protect not only the buffaloes but other animals as well, such as various species of antelopes which, according to research done in the Zambezi delta, are also threatened with extinction.

He said that the uncontrolled abuse of resources did not affect only wildlife, but also forests, which cover an estimated area of four million hectares in Sofala.

He pointed out that in the 1960s and 70s, Sofala provided about half of the country's entire timber industry.

"During the years between 1970 and 1975 forest exploitation was increased, reaching 400,000 cubic meters a year. This means that virtually all the accessible forest was exploited with no attention paid to the future," said Semente.

The northern region of Sofala has a wide range of biodiversity and natural resources, particularly fauna and forests, of local, national and international importance.

"We think that it is by preserving these resources that the timber industry can grow and the province would return to what it was before the war," Semente added.


LOAD-DATE: November 18, 1996

December 2, 1996


Ghana;
Commonwealth Observers Deploy For Polls Monitoring


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA - Twenty-three Commonwealth observers, including nine support staff from the Commonwealth Secretariat, to monitor the Dec. 7 Presidential and Parliamentary elections began deploying across the country Monday.

They are in the country at the invitation of the government and with the support of all the major political parties involved in the elections. 

The group said Monday in Accra that since their arrival in Ghana Nov. 27, they had been briefed by some senior officials from the main political parties, the Electoral Commission, lawyers and media representatives and diplomats from Commonwealth countries.

The chairman of the group, Paul Reeves, said the four-day briefing had been very useful as it had helped them prepare for the task.

Observers will be based in each of Ghana's 10 regions.

10 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1996


Kenya;
Kenyan Experts Endorse Use of Beetles Against Hyacinth


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - Leading Kenyan scientists have endorsed the proposed use of the beetle as a biological agent to combat the spread of the water hyacinth weed in Lake Victoria.

The decision was made last week by top researchers from the Kenya Medical Research Institute, Kenya Agricultural Research Institute, Moi University, the International Center for Insect Physiology and Ecology and the vector borne diseases division of the Kenyan ministry of health. 

The experts expressed confidence that the beetle would effectively control the menacing weed. The rapid spread of water hyacinth on Lake Victoria, Africa's largest fresh water lake, is gradually becoming an impediment to fishing as well as marine vessel transportation.

Backing the government's biological control method against the hyacinth, they said they were ready to assist in the multiplication of the beetles in readiness for their release into the lake in January 1997.

However, the researchers suggested that exhaustive research has to be conducted before the beetle is used against the weed.

"The use of the beetles should be cautiously undertaken since some biological agents are known to work well during experiments but fail when applied in the field," remarked one of the researchers, Dr. A.J. Oloo of the Kenya Medical Research Institute.


LOAD-DATE: November 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December 2, 1996


Science and Health;
Zimbabwe Considers Birth Control For Baboons


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

MUTARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's timber industry may consider introducing birth control in baboons to reduce their population in the timber- rich Manicaland Province. The acting general manager of the forestry commission, Edward Mutsvairo, said in an interview that the timber industry was losing millions of dollars to baboons which were destroying trees. 

Mutsvairo said the timber industry was already looking at ways of controlling the population which was growing at unprecedented levels.

He said there were only three alternatives which the timber industry could exploit to realize maximum benefits from their timber plantations and these were: killing the baboons, scaring them out of the forests using dogs and the introduction of birth control measures in the female baboons.

"The industry is currently losing millions due to the big baboon population that we have in the forests and we are currently looking at ways of how we can control them from destroying the trees. Maybe we will settle for the use of injections or something else...," Mutsvairo said.

Chimanimani district, which is one of the country's major forestry areas with major sawmills like the Charter and the Chinhokwe Sawmill, has a population of over 2,000 baboons.

In addition, there were also hundreds of baboons in such areas as Nyanga, Vumba and Chipinge.

LANGUAGE: English

12 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 2, 1996


Zambia;
Chiluba Names New Cabinet After Re-election


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - President Frederick Chiluba appointed a new cabinet on Monday, in which he retained his vice, Brig. Gen. Godfrey Miyanda and the ministers of defence, home affairs and finance.

But he moved Gen. Christon Tembo from the foreign affairs ministry to the mines and minerals portfolio, and replaced him with a university law professor, Lawrence Shimba, as the new foreign minister.

Others moved to new ministries include Edith Nawakwi, who swapped the ministry of energy with Suresh Desai of the ministry of agriculture. 

The new ministers include Enock Kavindele, who takes over science and technology, David Mpamba (information), Vincent Malambo (legal affairs) and Eric Silwamba, former junior minister in the president's office, who becomes a full cabinet minister.

Nawakwi is one of the two female ministers in the former cabinet who have been retained by Chiluba. Her colleague, Kabunda Kayongo, of science and technology was dropped from the new cabinet.

Also dropped from the new cabinet is former legal affairs minister Luminzu Shimaponda.

Announcing the cabinet, Chiluba said that he would demand loyalty and commitment from the new team to enable government make good its promises to the people. He added that the administration would continue to implement the country's current economic reform programme.

The Zambian president reiterated the ban on members of the cabinet and his ruling party from commenting on the country's relations with foreign countries, saying this would remain the prerogative of the foreign minister and himself as president.

The government was recently embarrassed by outbursts by several senior officials against some leaders of neighbouring states who were accused of " interfering" in Zambia's internal affairs.

Former foreign minister, Vernon Mwaanga had told off South African President Nelson Mandela for calling for a postponement of last November's elections to allow time for Chiluba's government to reconcile its differences with opposition parties.

Chiluba said Monday that his government will continue to maintain "warm and friendly" relations with the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA).

Chiluba was re-elected president for a second and last five-year term in the Nov. 18 polls. The following is the full cabinet list: President Frederick J.T. Chiluba

Vice-President Brig. Gen. (rtd) Godfrey Miyanda

State House Minister Eric Silwamba

Minister Without Portfolio Michael Sata

Defence Bennie Mwila

Finance Ronald Penza

Foreign Affairs Prof. Lawrence Shimba

Home Affairs Chitalu Sampa

Agriculture Food and Fisheries Edith Nawaki

Commerce Trade and Industry Alfeyo Hambayi

Mines and Minerals Development Gen. (rtd) Christon Tembo

Health Katele Kalumba

Education Syamukayumbu Siamujaye

Legal Affairs Vincent Malambo

Communications and Transport Paul Kaping'a

Labor and Social Security Peter Machunga

Tourism Amusaa Mwanamwambwa

Science Technology Training Enock Kavindele

Works and Supply Keli Walubita

Energy and Water Development Suresh Desai

Community Development Newstead Zimba

Local Government and Housing Bennie Mwiinga

Information David Mpamba

Environment and Natural Resources William Harrington

Lands Dawson Lupunga

Africa News


December 2, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Africa To Come Up With An Alternative To Boutros-Ghali


BYLINE: Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - In a week or so, Africa will come up with an alternative candidate or candidates for the post of United Nations Secretary- General now that incumbent Boutros-Boutros Ghali may not be elected for a second term, following a United States veto.

The Organization of African Unity (OAU) Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim said here Monday that "Africa should not lose the opportunity of having an African elected secretary-general by default".

Africa is expected to come up with another candidate or candidates before the selection process is thrown to the regions. 

Salim, on a tour of West African states, said in an interview with PANA in Dakar that he was consulting with African leaders on the issue and an alternative to Boutros-Ghali should emerge soon.

"But it is not necessary or desirable for Africa to have one candidate", he said.

"What we need is an African secretary-general and we should not allow ourselves to be divided on the issue."

Africans should not argue among themselves on an alternative to Boutros- Ghali because the decision of who gets elected ultimately rests with the Security Council.

African countries that so far have expressed an interest in forwarding candidates include Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana and Niger.

Boutros-Ghali was endorsed for re-election by the OAU summit in Yaounde, Cameroon, last July. But his re-election was vetoed by the United States who cast the only negative vote in the 15-member council.

However, the U.S. permanent representative to the U.N., Madeleine Albright, said that the U.S. did not have a candidate for the job but was "waiting for the African countries to come forward with a list of viable candidates...We will like to see a secretary-general from Africa.

The U.S. objects to Boutros-Ghali's re-election because, it claims, he has been unable to carry out measures to reform the world body. But the former Egyptian foreign minister has won overwhelming support from other members of the U.N.


LOAD-DATE: November 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

14 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


East Africa;
OAU Seeks Lasting Solution To The Great Lakes Crisis


BYLINE: Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) is seeking a durable solution to the crisis in the Great Lakes region that will be sensitive to both the territorial integrity and the legitimate rights of the people in the region.

OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim said in Dakar on Monday that the crisis in the Great Lakes region needs a holistic approach, confidence- building and prompt action to prevent tragedies from happening.

Salim, who is in the Senegalese capital to consult with President Abdou Diouf on a number of African problems and issues, said his meeting with President Mobutu Sese Seko in France last Friday "was very good" and the Zairean leader was "very conscious of the need to restore normalcy in the region". 

"I was impressed by his commitment to promote stability in the region and his understanding of the nature of the problem."

Salim said it was time to stop the "fire brigade" approach to African problems and step up measures to prevent calamities.

He appealed to the international community in the Great Lakes region to work with the OAU to provide the much-needed assistance and prevent problems from becoming tragedies. "They should not be concerned only when a crisis erupts. They should work with us prevent a crisis from becoming a human tragedy," he said

Salim said the creation of an African force -- to be deployed in crisis areas -- recently proposed by the United States was "fundamentally very sound" .

The proposal was not new as the idea of an African peace-keeping force had been endorsed by the 1995 OAU summit and in the next few months a consensus on the nature of the force should emerge.

"I think eventually it will take off, after consultations", he said.

Salim departs on Tuesday for Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, for a France-Africa summit in which he hopes to continue his consultations with African leaders.

After the summit he will travel to Lome, Togo, to consult President Gnassingbe Eyadema on African problems, including the territorial dispute between Cameroon and Nigeria over the oil-rich Bakassi peninsula. Eyadema has been mediating in the peace talks between the two countries.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

Business and Finance;
Nigeria Bourse Hooked To The Internet


BYLINE: Paul Okolo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Nigerian Stock Exchange has been connected to the Internet to make information of its activities more readily available to interested persons worldwide.

This will enable investors and market operators to receive the daily official list, company news and other information emanating from the market.

Foreign investors will also have easy access to the market, thereby giving the crucial visibility required to attract foreign investment, said an operator. 

A spokesman for the exchange said many quoted companies have already subscribed to the service by which they can send and receive messages from anywhere in the world. The Internet address is nse.ngra.com.

Meanwhile, the NSE All-Share Index bounced back last week from its near static position the week before, thanks to big price gains in the oil, food and breweries sectors.

The index rose 76.25 points to 6,775.61 against the 0.57 points appreciation in the previous week, when major shares tumbled on profit taking.

However, volume of transactions rose from 23.6 million shares to 27.6 million. The deals were worth 173.2 million naira against 198.9 million naira in the preceding week (80 naira= 1 U.S. dollars).

African Petroleum led the best performers with a 2.40 naira gain, which caused the shares to close at 41.00 naira. West African Portland Cement followed with 1.80 naira to close also at 41.00 naira.

Nestle Foods remained the leader in the foods sector, soaring 1.70 naira to 45.20 naira, while National Oil rose by the same margin to 43.20 naira.

Resurging Nigerian Breweries leapt to 15.60 naira, rising 1.60 naira in the week.

Leading conglomerate, Lever Brothers led the losers, sliding 1.30 naira to end at 22.30 naira, UAC also in the conglomerate sector, fell by 60 kobo (100 kobo = one naira), to 8.40 naira.

Guaranty Trust Bank, floated two months ago, slid by 40 kobo to close at 12. 80 naira.

Cadbury and Dunlop dropped 20 kobo to 24.70 naira and 10.30 naira respectively, on profit taking.

16 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Business and Finance;
French Company To Complete Maputo Hotel


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - A French construction company, Spie Batignolles, is to complete a luxury Maputo hotel, abandoned by Portuguese settlers over 20 years ago, at the time of Mozambican independence.

Sipie Batignolles signed a contract for completing the Four Seasons Hotel with Ecotur, A Mozambique-South Africa joint venture that now holds the concession on the hotel. 

The cost of the building work is estimated at 40 million U.S. dollars.

The French company will start work in January 1997, and the hotel should be completed in the second half of 1998, according to an agreement signed here Friday.

The hotel will have a 340-bed, five-star hotel complete with swimming pool, conference hall and casino.

The hotel will be managed by the Holiday Inn chain.

Ecotur was set up in 1994 by the South African East Coast Safaris, which has 74 percent shares, while the junior partner, Sismar, of Mozambique holds 15.6 percent. Two individuals, Stella Barbosa and Arlete Patel have 5.2 percent each.

Mario Sevene, a representative of the Mozambican affiliate of Ecotur, said that the negotiations leading up to the contract with Sipie Batignolles started in 1994.

He added that the hotel would boost tourism in Mozambique. During a recent visit to France, Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano discussed the hotel project with the management of Spie Batignolles.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
O.A.U. Asks Africa To Nominate Candidates for UN Job


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - Organization of African Unity Chairman Paul Biya has asked interested African countries to nominate candidates for the position of United Nations secretary-general.

"In order to preserve for Africa its chance at a second mandate, the African states should, should they desire, present other qualified candidates along with that of Dr. Boutros Boutros-Ghali," he said in a letter dated Nov. 29.

In it Biya, who is the president of Cameroon, said African states should present their candidates directly to the president of the U.N. Security Council and then inform the O.A.U. chairman. 

Biya's letter has opened the way for Africa to present other candidates for the post, along with Boutros Boutros-Ghali, whose bid for a second five-year term was vetoed Nov. 19 by the United States.

All the other 14 members of the council, upon whose recommendation the General Assembly elects a U.N. secretary-general, voted for the Boutros-Ghali.

Biya said that his request was to ensure that Africa filled the secretary- generalship if the U.S. continued to veto Boutros-Ghali's candidature.

Members of the council have agreed to reserve the first and second stages of their selection process to African candidates to give the continent a chance of winning a second term.

The current term of Boutros-Ghali, a 74-year old Egyptian diplomat, will expire Dec. 31.

At its 32nd summit in Yaounde earlier this year, African leaders endorsed his candidature.

At their meeting, African leaders also mandated Biya to consult with other U.N. member states to ensure that Africa would get a second mandate.

"I have carried out my mission as mandated and I officially presented this position to the General Assembly at the debate on the U.N. on Oct. 24, 1996," Biya said.

A two-term tenure has been the past practice when the citizens of other regions occupied the position.

Since the U.S. veto, the African group at the U.N. has said, consistently, that it will stick with Boutros-Ghali until the O.A.U. gives it further directives.

The Africans being mentioned as possible candidates include the foreign minister of Cote d'Ivoire, Amara Essy, the U.N. under-secretary general for peacekeeping operations, Kofi Annan of Ghana, the secretary-general of the O. A.U., Salim Ahmed Salim, and the head of the International Peace Academy in New York, Olara Otunnu of Uganda.

The U.S. says it opposes Boutros-Ghali's candidature for a second-term because he has not carried out enough reform of the U.N.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 3, 1996


Business and Finance;
Tumbling World Gold Market Affects Ghana Stocks


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Shares on the stock market began the week in sluggish trading Monday, dragged lower by the bearish gold market which has badly affected Ashanti Goldfields Company (AGC) issues.

The official GSE All-Share Index fell 4.49 points to close at 361.88 from the previous 366.37 points close. 

Gold on the world market has shed some 10 dollars (about 17,000 cedis) in one month with possible signs of a further loss as fears of future gold sales by European central banks loom large.

The equities of AGC, one of the world's modern gold mining companies with a production capacity of about one million ounces a year, has suffered on the local market recently.

The broader market closed Monday with AGC losing 1,800 cedis to 23,200 with two other decliners and a lone gainer on a light volume of 72,790 shares.

Unilever (UNIL) and UTC-Estates (UTC-E) were the other decliners, dropping five cedis each to close at 785 and 50 cedis respectively.

New market entrant Aluworks (ALW) extended its previous gain by five cedis to finish at 1,415 cedis.

The market looks generally sluggish with demand which stood at 624,330 shares, failing to keep up to supply pressure at 927,470.

Uncertainty on the political landscape was also unnerving the market which lacks the support of big buyers and off-shore players.

Market capitalization slumped to 2,663.18 billion cedis from Friday's 2,835. 19 billion cedis.

The following were the last prices of listed equities quoted in cedis at the close of business on Monday: ABL 550 AGC 23,200 -1,800 ALW 1,415 '5 CFAO 20 EIC 420 FML 404 GCB 701 GGL 242 HFC 127 KBL 645 MGL 135 MLC 50 MOGL 6,000 PAF 165 PTC 130 PZ 370 SCB 5,200 SPPC 112 SSB 1,050 UNIL 785 - 5 UTC-E 50 - 5

Africa News


December 3, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Iran Plans To Fund Dam Projects In Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Iran has agreed to provide 19.8 million U.S. dollars to finance the construction of the Gwayi-Shangani and Gwayi-Umguza dams in drought-prone Matabeleland north.

The total cost of the projects, expected to benefit up to one million people, in Bulawayo, Tsholotsho, Lupane and Bubi-Umguza, is about 36 million dollars. 

In an interview, the deputy minister of lands and water resources, Cain Mathema, said the funds, to cover 55 percent of project costs, would be in the form of a soft loan whose terms were yet to be discussed.

Mathema, who returned from a business trip to Iran on Friday, said the Iranians had also agreed to provide technical experts for the construction of the dams.

"The Iranians showed us their capacity to build most advanced dams in the world, and we met their syndicates in construction who showed willingness to come here and assist us," he said.

Mathema said construction of the dams, whose designs were now ready, would begin as soon as cabinet approved the deal with the iranians.

He said a delegation of Iranian experts would visit Zimbabwe in two weeks time to discuss with the relevant ministry and engineers details of the financial package of the project.

The deputy minister said government was also looking at the generation of hydro-electric power at the Gwayi-Umguza dam.

"The final project would cost over zd 1 billion (USD 100 million) and this would include costs for building water treatment works and construction of pipelines to Bulawayo," he said.

The Gwayi-Shangani and Gwayi-Umguza project is similar to the proposed Kunzwi dam in Harare, where the Harare City Council and government are jointly working together to provide adequate water for the capital city.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


20 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


United States and Africa;
EXIM Bank Loan For Ghana's Oil Fields


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - The Export Import Bank of the United States, Exim Bank, is to provide about 300 million U.S. dollars worth of American exports of equipment and services for the development of the Tano oil and gas fields in the western Ghana.

An agreement for the transaction was signed November 26 at the Ghana Embassy in Washington D.C. by Tsatsu Tsikata, chief executive of the Ghana National Petroleum Corporation (GNPC), and Rita Rodriguez, member of Exim Bank board of directors.

The corporation said Monday in Accra that the transaction represented the " bank's major commitment to supporting U.S. exports to the West African market" . 

The corporation said principal U.S. suppliers included Continental Engineering and Construction Services of Lafayette, Louisiana, and Westinghouse Electric International Company of Orlando, Florida.

It said the suppliers also included a number of oil and gas fields service companies in Louisiana and Texas.

The GNPC said it would use the funding to develop off-shore infrastructure for producing oil and gas in the Tano fields which was originally discovered in the late 1970s and early 1980s by the U.S. company, Phillips Petroleum.

Natural gas from the fields will be used to power a barge mounted electricity generating plant to be built and installed between Effasu and Mangyea on the western coastal area.

Speaking at the signing ceremony, Tsikata thanked Rodriguez and other personnel of the bank for their role in the negotiation and conclusion of the agreement.

He was confident that the GNPC would successfully implement the project for the benefit of Ghanaians.

Rodriguez said the bank's support demonstrated the continuity of U.S. support for the development of Ghana's energy needs.

GNPC said that Standard Chartered Bank, the guaranteed lender under the Exim bank facility, and the Private Export Funding Corporation of the United States, which is providing funding to back Standard Chartered Bank, were also signatories to the agreement.

LANGUAGE: English

South Africa;
Results Of Election For ANC Gauteng Province


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Johannesburg - The following are the results of the elections for the executive committee for the ANC Gauteng Province. Over 450 delegates went to cast their votes. The positions of Chairperson and Deputy Chairperson were unopposed. These two positions held by Tokyo Sexwale (Chairperson) and Prof. Mathole Motshekga (Dep. Chairperson).

The position for Secretary General was contested by Paul Mashitile and Kenny Fitla. Paul Mashitile will be serving another term as Secretary General, he got 242 votes.

The Deputy Secretary position was contested by Obed Bapela, Joan Fubbs and Mandla Nkomfe. Obed Bapela was elected as Deputy Secretary for another term, he received 218 votes.

The Treasurer's position was contested by Paul Maseko and Amos Masondo. Amos Masondo will take the position of Treasurer, he received 284 votes.

ANC gauteng Province Executive Copmmittee: Chairperson - Tokyo Sexwale Dep Chairperson - Prof, Mathole Motshekga Secretary General - Paul Mashatile Dep. Secretary - Obed Bapela Treasurer - amos Masondo

Issued by the Department of Information and Publicity Gauteng Province, P.O. Box 8299, Johannesburg, 2000 30 November 1996

22 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Kenya;
Journalists Group Protests Kenya Magazine Ban


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director of the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) to His Excellency President Daniel Arap Moi, November 26, 1996.

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) strongly protests the Nairobi High Court's decision on November 21, 1996, to ban Finance magazine from publishing allegedly libellous articles relating to Chairman Kuria Kanyingi of the Kiambu District. The ruling, which is effective until December 19, 1996, is in connection with articles published in the October 15 and November 15, 1996 issues of Finance magazine. 

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists committed to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ condemns this action against Finance magazine and it's publisher Njehu Gatabaki, who has on various occasions been charged with sedition, as a blatant violation of press freedom. We respectfully remind your Excellency that Kenya ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Article 19 of which guarantees the right to "seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kind." These rights are also guaranteed by Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights, to which we again respectfully remind Your Excellency, Kenya is a signatory.

CPJ condemns the use of seditious libel statues because they are used exclusively to silence dissent against governing regimes. These laws do not have any place in a democratic society because democratic societies do not criminalize critical reporting - they tolerate and protect it. The right to speak freely without fear of government reprisal is at the very heart of democracy.

CPJ considers the Nairobi High Court's November 21 ruling to be a serious infringement of press freedom in Kenya and calls for the immediate and unconditional revocation of the ban on Finance magazine. We urge Your Excellency to guarantee the protection of journalists' sources and the media's right to practice their profession freely and safely.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


23 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Zaire;
Amnesty Says Killings, Torture And Arbitrary Arrests Persist


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

KINSHASA -- Torture and arrests are taking place in the capital and massacres are taking place in areas of intense fighting in Zaire in the growing climate of insecurity and lawlessness, Amnesty International's Deputy Secretary General Herve Berger said today at the end of a two-week investigation trip to the country.

"Despite the authorities" tight control on travel to the country's trouble spots, reports of killings, torture and arbitrary arrest cannot be silenced," Mr Berger said.

"Zairian authorities have created a climate of intimidation, where questions demanding the truth about the role of the authorities in the current crisis are repressed. People are afraid to talk about recent events such as the persecution of members of Tutsi and Hutu minorities and the role of the Zairian Armed forces in Eastern Zaire. Meanwhile the armed groups in Kivu are committing deliberate and arbitrary killings of Zairians and refugees." 

The Amnesty International team has documented violent human rights abuses committed by both the Zairian armed forces and the armed group who control much of North and South Kivu in eastern Zaire in a report released today in Kinshasa, (Zaire:Violent persecution by State and armed groups).

"We have received reports about the slaughter of hundreds of Rwandese refugees and displaced Zairians by Tutsi-led armed groups last week," Mr. Berger said.

The organization has obtained reports of hundreds of deliberate and arbitrary killings of Zairian civilians and refugees by members of the Tutsi- led armed groups, now known as L"Alliance des forces democratiques pour la liberation du Congo-Zaire (AFDL) in Bukavu, Uvira and Goma as well as the forcible repatriation of refugees to Rwanda and Burundi.

According to Amnesty International's information, about 500 Rwandese refugees and displaced Zairians were massacred by AFDL members on or around 18 November. The massacre took place at Chimanga refugee camp, about 60 km south of Bukavu. The AFDL have also rounded up and forcibly expelled refugees from Burundi, handing them over to Burundi government troops at the border. Hundreds of the returned refugees have been slaughtered by Burundi government soldiers.

The AFDL has also attacked the refugee camp of Mugunga, near Goma, causing the mass exodus of refugees to Rwanda. Hundreds of bodies have been found and buried in Mugunga camp.

"Today amidst international indifference, hundreds of thousands of Zairian civilians and refugees from Rwanda and Burundi are fleeing violence in eastern Zaire; they are without food, water or medicines," Mr Berger said.

The delegation also fears that severe human rights violations, such as extrajudicial executions are occurring in Kisangani, north central Zaire, which has recently become an operational zone as a result of the conflict in eastern Zaire. The delegation requested authorisation to carry out research in Kisangani, and though the Vice-Prime Minister and Minister of Interior assured Amnesty International access, the authorisation was never delivered, raising questions as to whether the authorities had reasons to fear the delegation's presence in Kisangani.

"Reports have been received by the organisation about killings, raping and pillage being carried out by the Forces Armees Zairoises ( FAZ), including violent attacks on families including beating and raping women and girls as young as 12 in Kisangani," Mr Berger said.

Amnesty International has continued to call on the Zairian authorities to end continued human rights violations committed by its own forces.

The organization has called both on the FAZ and on the AFDL to adhere to the principles of international humanitarian law through the respect of vulnerable persons (civilians and other persons hors de combat) and by giving access to the victims to humanitarian organizations such as the ICRC.

Investigations carried out by the delegation during the last two weeks reveal that the Zairian authorities are responsible for detaining dozens of political prisoners in detention centres throughout the capital. The prisoners are held without charge or trial and are denied access to visits by lawyers, doctors or family members. Some of them are believed to have " disappeared".

Amnesty International is further concerned that the Zairian authorities continue to arrest persons exercising their right to freedom of expression. Over the last two weeks the delegation has interviewed dozens of victims including parliamentarians, trade unionists, lawyers, journalists and members of NGOs. They told us of beatings, rapes and imprisonment for exercising basic rights. The organization has identified 10 possible prisoners of conscience currently being held in Kinshasa alone. Three human rights activists, Floribert Chebeya Bahizire, Harouna Mbongo and Bashi Nabukili, members of a human rights group La voix des sans voix (VSV), Voice of the Voiceless, were held incommunicado for six days before being released.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


24 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Zambia;
Human Rights Watch Sees Flawed Zambian Poll


BYLINE: Human Rights Watch (New York)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2280 words


 

New York - In "Zambia: Elections and Human Rights in the Third Republic," released today (27 Nov 96), Human Rights Watch/Africa charges that numerous human rights violations before the November 18 vote seriously undermined the legitimacy of the elections themselves and set a negative tone for the country's development over the next several years.

In these parliamentary and presidential elections, the Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) won a majority and President Frederick Chiluba was returned for a second term. The vote marked the second multiparty election since 1991, when twenty-seven years of authoritarian rule under Kenneth Kaunda was ended.

Zambia had been heralded as a model for democracy in Africa after the peaceful transfer of power in 1991. The report details that although Zambia initially made overall progress toward respect for civil and political rights, with some liberalizing reforms, by 1993 the progress appeared to have stopped and the Chiluba government increasingly resorted to methods used under Kaunda rule to suppress criticism. 

"The result is that Zambian citizens are plagued by restrictions on freedom of expression and assembly, intimidation of those in the legal system and harassment of opposition parties," said Peter Takirambudde, Executive Director for Human Rights Watch/Africa and one of the authors of the report. " Some of these abuses are the legacy of the Kaunda years, but in many cases human rights violations are the results of new initiatives by the Chiluba government. We are particularly concerned at increasing government efforts to undermine the NGOs and the judiciary. They are essential foundations of any democracy."

In calling on The World Bank's Consultative Group for Zambia, the U.S. government and Southern African Development Community countries to continue to pressure the Zambian government to improve its record on human rights, Takirambudde stated, "The international response to the Zambia crisis has been impressive to date. Unity in pressing the government for improved human rights reforms is essential and general support for civic associations and in particular groups that lobby and campaign for human rights standards is needed."

The fifty-three-page report details how state intimidation of the opposition increased significantly in 1995 when former president Kaunda announced a formal return to politics. The runup to the November 18 elections saw a number of abuses. There is evidence that duplicate National Registration Cards were been issued to some voters, that the names of others have been omitted from voters rolls and that duplicate National Registration Cards appeared on the rolls. The ruling MMD also deliberately blurred the distinction between party and state. In Lusaka's Soweto Market the MMD conducted a voter registration exercise, with MMD supporters pressuring voters to confirm their affiliation to the MMD. Human Rights Watch/Africa also obtained documentation proving a government plan to augment the police with MMD supporters prior to the elections. Government officials also threatened to deny state services and programs to constituencies that did not vote for the ruling MMD.

The main opposition party, the United National Independence Party (UNIP) also engaged in electoral abuses in by-elections. UNIP sympathizers assaulted MMD supporters and villagers they suspected of backing the MMD. Such inter- political clashes in the by-elections restricted freedom of movement among villagers in several constituencies.

The government forced a radical amendment to the 1991 constitution through the MMD-dominated parliament in May 1996. Particularly controversial was a provision that imposed new requirements on persons seeking to become president. These included that a candidate be a Zambian citizen born of parents who are Zambian by birth or descent and that the candidate not be a tribal chief. These requirements appeared to be tailored to disqualify specific opposition leaders from running for president, including former president Kenneth Kaunda - who is partially of Malawian heritage - and UNIP's vice presidential candidate - a tribal chief. These restrictions violate the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Zambia is a party.

In June and July 1996, a shadowy group called the "Black Mamba" was blamed by the government for a spate of bomb blasts in Zambia that killed one person. Eight UNIP officials including its vice president were arrested in connection with the bombings and were committed to the Lusaka High Court charged with treason and murder. The trial provided little evidence to suggest that these UNIP members were involved in any violent conspiracy against the state. It appeared they were detained solely because of their political affiliation. They were acquitted of treason and murder charges by the High Court in November.

The independent press was also the target of government intimidation. "The Post" newspaper has been under particular attack. In February 1996 police arrested three of its editors and banned edition 401 before its distribution because it reported that the government was secretly planning to hold a referendum on the constitution without giving the public time to prepare. The day's on-line edition was also banned, making it the first act of censorship on the Internet in Africa.

RECOMMENDATIONS To the Government: Human Rights Watch/Africa calls on the Zambian government to: * Guarantee the independence of the judiciary as required by Zambian and international law. In particular, the government should not orchestrate the appointment or dismissal of judges solely because of their political affiliations or regional origins.

* Publicly dissociate itself from and condemn any efforts by public officials to undermine the independence of the judiciary.

* Facilitate debate of the Mwanakatwe Constitutional Review Commission proposals; call elections to a constituent assembly to review and as appropriate amend the 1991 Constitution

* Guarantee the right to a fair trial by a competent and objective judiciary in accord with international standards. In cases where this right has been violated, submit the case for retrial or release the defendant. No one should be detained solely for the nonviolent expression of his or her political beliefs.

* As promised by the MMD in its election platform in 1991 and in 1996, ensure that all Zambians may exercise their rights to freedom of expression and association, that the organizations of civil society may freely operate, and that checks and balances of the different branches of government are respected. Safeguards to this end should be enacted into law.

* Guarantee that people with diverse viewpoints are given appropriate access to state-owned radio and television.

* Ensure a strict division between the functioning of government and the MMD party.

* Stop providing state funds and facilities to support the MMD's political campaigns.

* Investigate allegations of police abuse and improper treatment of those in detention, and hold those found responsible accountable before the law.

* Guarantee that prisoners' rights are respected according to international law. This includes the right to be free from torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, and the right to adequate medical and sanitary facilities.

* Enact into law the Munyama Commission's recommendation that a permanent human rights commission be established. Ensure that this commission is objective and nonpartisan to avoid the possibility of political bias.

* Provide government officials and police with special training about human rights standards and protection, while instituting procedures through which violations of human rights are the subject of effective investigation and criminal prosecution.

To All Political Parties: Human Rights Watch/Africa calls on all Zambian political parties to publicly advocate protection and respect for human rights in their platform and promise to hold party members who commit human rights abuses accountable.

To the International Community: Human Rights Watch/Africa recommends that the international community:

* Continue to pressure the government to improve its record on human rights as integral to good governance, especially with respect to government transparency and accountability for its actions, through formal communications and other measures such as the conditioning of balance of payments support.

* Support the efforts of civic organizations to play an active role in civil society, and in particular their efforts to monitor, lobby and campaign for improved human rights standards.

Human Rights Watch/Africa calls on The World Bank's Consultative Group for Zambia ("Paris Club") to:

* Continue the Bournemouth meeting's agreed pressure on the Zambian government for "tangible progress on the governance issue," and include specific reference to human rights as integral to this.

* Maintain unity in the pressure for an improved Zambian government performance on human rights as integral to good governance.

Human Rights Watch/Africa calls on the United States to:

* Encourage new U.S. ambassador Arlene Render to act on her commitment to vigorously promote human rights in Zambia by meeting regularly with the Zambia human rights community, publicly denounce human rights abuses, and use U.S. bilateral assistance to Zambia to achieve maximum leverage on human rights.

Human Rights Watch/Africa calls on The Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) to:

* Continue to press the Zambian government to improve its human rights record.

* Send an investigative team from the SADC Organ on Politics, Defense and Security to Zambia to report back to the Organ about how its member states can improve the human rights record in Zambia.

* Malawi must clarify its position over accepting the forced repatriation of alleged "Malawians" from Zambia, several of these individuals being prominent members of the Zambian opposition who appear arbitrarily to have been stripped of their Zambian nationalities in violation of international standards.

Human Rights Watch/Africa calls on The Commonwealth Secretariat to send a fact-finding mission to Zambia to investigate human rights practices across the country.

Human Rights Watch/Africa calls on The African Commission for Human and Peoples' Rights to send a mission to investigate Zambia's current human rights situation.

For additional copies of "Zambia: Elections and Human Rights in the Third Republic," please send $6.00 (domestic) or $7.50 (international) to Publications Department, Human Rights Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10017-6104.

Human Rights Watch 485 Fifth Avenue New York, NY 10017-6104 TEL: 212/972- 8400 FAX: 212/972-0905 E-mail: hrwnyc@hrw.org. 1522 K Street, N.W. Washington D.C. 20005 TEL: 202/371-6592 FAX: 202/371-0124 E-mail: hrwdc@hrw.org


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Science and Health;
GABON: NEW OUTBREAK


BYLINE: World Health Organization (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Geneva - As of 25 November, 27 cases had been identified during the outbreak which started in late July. This includes 2 fatal cases detected through contact tracing of the Gabonese patient treated in South Africa in October. The total number of deaths is 19, and the last death dates back to 5 November. The declaration of the end of the outbreak will take place 42 days after the last death, i.e. on 17 December if no further deaths are registered.

The role of the Ebola virus has been confirmed by isolation of 2 strains by the WHO Collaborating Centre at the Pasteur Institute, Paris. These strains are very similar to those isolated from the blood of patients in Mayibout in February 1996. Serological results of IgG and IgM ELISA tests showed that infection without clinical symptoms occurred among the contacts. No new case has been diagnosed since 24 October in the Booue region.

Source: WHO Weekly Epidemiological Record, No. 48, November 29. 1996.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 47 on Eastern Zaire (12/03)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2014 words


 

Nairobi - Reports from Kisangani, in eastern Zaire tell of an increasingly unstable situation in the town. BBC radio today said Zairean rebels claimed they were in control of the town, but this could not be confirmed.

Zaire denied the rebels had taken the town and said its forces were in complete control. The situation however was rapidly deteriorating, according to NGOs who had recently arrived from the town. Aviation Sans Frontieres (ASF) are reported to be pulling out of the area after their aircraft came under fire yesterday. Crack troops from the Civil Guard and the Special Presidential Division were reportedly arriving in Kisangani and other parts of eastern Zaire to reinforce the Zairean army. Some 400 Zairean soldiers, who regrouped in Kisangani after fleeing the rebel advance in north Kivu, have remained in the town where shooting and looting are common occurrences. Soldiers apparently have not been paid and are said to be demoralised as the rebels consolidate their gains. Aid workers who left Kisangani yesterday, said a military plane had arrived from the rebel-captured town of Beni bringing bodies of soldiers killed in the fighting. This added to the tension, heightening fears that insecurity in Kisangani will escalate still further. 

The Kisangani area, home to some 500,000 people, also houses between 2,000- 3,000 displaced persons. Last Friday, WFP was granted a government permit to oversee a feeding programme, but due to the growing insecurity, staff are still in Kinshasa. In the meantime, WFP is arranging the transport of 500 MT of food stocks from Zambia by rail to Kindu, and then by barge to Kisangani.

A recent Amnesty International report also painted a grim picture of life in Kisangani, saying it feared extrajudicial executions were being carried out in the town. Authorisation was never received to visit the area, but reports spoke of violent attacks on families by Zairean troops, including beating and raping women and girls as young as 12. A field trip to Zaire undertaken by the organisation's deputy Secretary-General Herve Berge highlighted torture and arrests in Kinshasa and massacres in other parts of the country.

After routing the Zairean army in Beni on Saturday, the rebels were still said to be advancing northwards towards Bunia where the situation was described as very tense. Missionary aircraft, attempting to land in Bunia and nearby Nyakunde today, had to abort as both places were deemed too insecure, while another missionary flight at Rethi, northeast of Bunia, was boarded by a soldier carrying out a search. Soldiers are not normally based in Rethi, which may indicate they are fleeing Bunia, according to a source in touch with the area. Local people on the ground told missionary groups by radio that the rebel focus was now on Bunia. "We are told Zairean soldiers are fleeing in total panic," said one radio operator, quoted by Reuters. "The rebels are advancing along the road to Bunia, there is complete chaos in Bunia."

An article over the weekend in the Zairean newspaper "La Reference le Plus" points to the low morale of the Zairean army. According to the report, Butembo - which fell to the rebels on Wednesday - was an easy gain. The lack of a military confrontation was surprising, the newspaper said, as soldiers had a three-day warning of the rebel attack. It questioned how a force 60,000- 10,000 strong was unable to mobilise enough troops to meet the rebel challenge and criticised the government's delay in sending reinforcements. " La Reference" went on to predict the fall of the mineral-rich Kasai region, to the west of Kivu. Another newspaper, "Le Soft" reported on Saturday that forces from the Masisi Hunde and Ngilima militia had allied themselves to the rebels.

Despite the war looming on the Shaba-Kivu border, Reuters reports that the first private mining company to invest in Zaire since the 1970s signed a deal to mine copper and cobalt in Shaba. The Swiss-based Groupe Lundin, representing the Canadian company Consolidated Eurocan Ventures (CEV), won agreement from the Zairean government to mine the vast mineral resources at Tenke Fungurume in partnership with the state-owned Gecamines firm. Under the terms of the deal, signed Sunday, CEV will own 55 percent of the Tenke Fungurume project, and Gecamines 45 percent. Lundin chairman Adolf Lundin told Reuters the agreement signified the "rebirth" of Zaire's mining industry and he played down any risk of investing in the country. "Taking risks too much into account is like competing in a marathon with a broken leg," he said. Site studies have revealed that Tenke Fungurume could become one of the world's largest open-cast copper mines.

Kinshasa is reported calm at the moment, but its dependence on food supplies from the Kivu region threatens to destabilise the situation as prices soar. Red beans have become scarce, increasing in price by 124 percent, while white beans have have increased by 88 percent. The prices of vegetables, usually imported from the Kivu area, have also been dramatically hiked. Potato prices are up by 117 percent, and maize and manioc by 55 percent. Bas-Zaire, and to a lesser extent, Bandundu, are now the main suppliers for Kinshasa but the quality and qauntity are said to be poor. A shortage of beans is expected to create problems for Kinshasa residents who had already substituted beans following an increase in meat prices. This, coupled with inflation, has eroded the purchasing power of many low income residents.

The UN Special Envoy for the Great Lakes Raymond Chretien arrived in Nice last night, ahead of a planned meeting with Zairean President Mobutu. According to AFP he told journalists earlier in the day in the Senegalese capital, Dakar, that Mobutu was "the only one who can bring solutions" to the eastern Zaire crisis. France meanwhile demanded that the immunity of Zairean ambassador Ramazani Baya be lifted so that he could be tried for running down and killing two boys in the southern town of Menton at the weekend. Mobutu is scheduled to meet the mayor of Menton today to discuss the issue.

Reports from the Minova area, south of Sake, concurred that 40,000 refugees discovered in the region had moved on. The UNHCR Goma head of sub-office said they had moved westwards rather than towards Goma as expected. Aerial surveillance showed that the refugee camp at Minova was now empty. Fighting in the area had prohibited access for several days.

Interviewed by the Belgian daily "Le Soir", Rwandan vice-president Paul Kagame alleged the planned multi-national force in eastern Zaire was merely a "pretext" for propping up Mobutu. He denied that the Rwandan army had taken part in supporting the rebels, but added he was "not altogether unhappy about the events in eastern Zaire." He also rejected the idea that Rwanda wanted to revise its borders. "We have neither the ability nor the desire to modify our frontiers. We want good relations and safe borders," he told the paper.

The repatriation of Rwandan refugees from Tanzania could take place before the end of the month, UN sources said today. A UN official in Kigali said refugees seemed "resigned" to repatriation and it appeared the Tanzanian government was pressing for their departure by the end of the year. Of the approximately 500,000 Rwandan refugees in Tanzania, almost all from eastern Rwandan prefectures: 69 percent from Kibungo and 25 percent from Byumba/Umutara. Their return is likely to be through Rusomo in the southeast corner of Kibungo. NGOs said today there was no major movement from Ngara, but the trickle of returnees was increasing significantly and some refugees were selling their possessions. Doubts were cast however on whether a mass return would take place before the harvesting season in January, as many refugees had planted crops.

The Canadian airforce has agreed to move plastic sheeting from Uganda's Entebbe airport to Mwanza in Tanzania, bound for Kasulu and Kibondo districts where a huge influx of refugees from Burundi and Zaire has been reported, according to a UNHCR update yesterday. A total of 46 MT of plastic sheeting for 50,000 people will be flown in aboard two flights scheduled for today, and another one tomorrow.

UNHCR said registration of the estimated 500,000 Rwandan returnees was continuing in the communes without major disruption, according to the Office of the UN Humanitarian Coordinator for Rwanda. After this first major batch of arrivals in mid-November, another 50,000 had been recorded since then. Over the weekend, 1,475 Rwandan refugees arrived in Cyangugu from Bukavu bringing the total number of returnees on that route to some 8,000.

A two-day meeting in Nairobi on the Great Lakes crisis, convened by ActionAid, ended yesterday with agreement that NGOs should support processes which encourage reconstruction based on local people's initiatives. The conference, which grouped over 50 representatives of humanitarian agencies, the UN, African experts and academics, also believed NGOs should assist women, especially, to understand and enjoy their rights. It gave the example of Rwanda where the majority of households are headed by women, but under Rwandan law they are not allowed to own land, and therefore would have nothing to pass on to their children. The aim of the meeting was to identify the key implications for humanitarian work in the region and explore strategies for short-term relief.

Heads of state and government from 11 central African states met in Brazzaville, Congo, today to discuss regional problems, including the situation in the Great Lakes. The meeting included Burundi's leader Pierre Buyoya, President Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda and Zairean premier Kengo wa Dondo who were meeting for the first time since the crisis broke out in eastern Zaire. A BBC reporter said the gathering was likely to be "volatile".

The response to the UN inter-agency flash appeal for the Great Lakes region reached a total of $86,531,222 as of yesterday. The appeal, covering the period 1 November 1996 - 31 January 1997, is trying to raise a total of $259, 466,214. Other donations (mainly to international NGOs) reported to DHA bring the total response to the crisis up to $109 million so far.

Nairobi, 3 December 1996, 15:10 GMT (ENDS)
