27 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Zaire;
WFP Eastern Zaire Situation Report No. 31


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Rome - RWANDA: Over the weekend (30/11 - 1/12), 4,803 returnees entered Gisenyi from Goma. Approximately 1,000 crossed the border on 2 December, most having come from the direction of Minova.

1,475 returnees were registered in Cyangugu between 30 November and 1 December. Transit centres are still being used in Cyangugu for the distribution of WFP returnee food packages given the manageable level of repatriation through this prefecture. 

A significant number of 'old caseload' returnees are being forced to give up the houses they have been occupying, as families recently returned from Zaire re-claim their properties. WFP is exploring ways to assist the 'old caseload' returnees.

In anticipation of a significant influx of returnees from Tanzania, WFP is currently pre-positioning additional quantities of food in the prefectures of Kibungo, Cyangugu, Gikongoro and Butare.

An FAO/WFP crop and food supply assessment mission will begin work in Rwanda this week. WFP is also participating in a World Bank/UNDP jointly coordinated mission, which will focus on reintegration and rehabilitation.

GOMA: Distributions of WFP biscuits continue at road-side way stations, located at Sake, Mugunga, and Kulungu. Approximately, 0.7 mt was distributed on 2 December.

In spite of earlier indications given by aerial surveys, the UNHCR/WFP/NGO mission, which visited Numbi on 30 November, found few refugees in the area. The several hundred refugees remaining in Numbi reported that an earlier concentration of refugees had moved north-westwards.

UVIRA: A UN/NGO assessment mission departed Bukavu for Uvira at 10:00am on 3 December.

KISANGANI: WFP is still waiting for authorisation from the Zairian authorities to conduct an airlift directly from Entebbe to Kisangani. So far, clearance has only been given to fly via Kinshasa, an unfeasible route given the vast distances involved. 95mt of WFP food remains on standby at Entebbe airport.

WFP staff in Kisangani report that the security situation is highly unstable. A number of agencies have evacuated or dramatically reduced the level of international staff in the past few days.

TANZANIA: A meeting of the Tri-partite Commission (UNHCR, Governments of Rwanda and Tanzania) is likely to take place in Ngara or Kigali before the end of this week to discuss modalities for a repatriation of Rwandan refugees from Tanzania. This follows a statement by the Government of Tanzania that the Rwandan refugee problem in Tanzania should be resolved by 31 December 1996. It is likely that the meeting of the Commission will be followed by negotiations with refugee leaders.

BURUNDI: WFP is pursuing all possible solutions to move food and fuel to Bujumbura on Lake Tanganyika from Kigoma, Tanzania. Only by opening up this route will WFP be able to deliver the 2,500 mt authorised by the RSCC, which is needed to feed the growing number of IDPs and returnees.

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION, PLEASE CONTACT WFP EASTERN ZAIRE CRISIS SUPPORT FACILITY (CSF): International Fax Line: 39 6 5228-2828 International Telephone Line: 39 6 5228-2535 Electronic Mail Address: ezaire@wfp.org


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

28 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Zambia;
Rogue Elephant Kills Again


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Livingstone - The rogue elephant which killed a Zambian worker barely a week ago has again killed another man - this time a cyclist in the Zimbabwean tourist town of Victoria Falls.

The Zimbabwean was killed on Sunday as he was passing on a bicycle near where the elephant was grazing in front of tourists and cross-border traders from Zambia who all watched helplessly as the crazed animal charged after the cyclist, snatched him from the saddle and dashed him to the ground.

Then in full view of everybody it begun to trample on him until he was reduced to a mess of broken bones and tissue. Then as it went away it rammed several times into a stationery and unoccupied taxi. 

There were no further losses of life or injuries before the elephant escaped into the bush.

A week ago the same elephant killed a worker with the Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation as he and three other men were going to work in the morning.

After that the jumbo disappeared from sight and went to live for some days on an island in the middle of the Zambezi river, metres upstream of the world famous Victoria Falls.

Zambian game scouts talked to said the elephant has been provoked beyond reason and that was why it now considered every human being as its personal enemy.

After the incident in Zambia a bangling ranger is said to have shot at it three times but he only ended up wounding it and this has even heightened its temper towards human beings.

Before that some curio sellers and passersby are said to pelted the animal with stones and game scouts suspect that this was the start of its anger towards human beings as it used to live close to hotels in both Zambia and Zimbabwe happily before that.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZIS


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


29 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
Zambian Craftsmen Get Ready For 'Kuomboka'


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Mongu - The Barotse Royal Establishment in Mongu is making preparations for the annual migratory ceremony known as Kuomboka which might be held next year.

For three successive years the Lozi have not held their annual ceremony due to low water levels on the Barotse Flood plain due to the crippling drought years of the beginning half of the 90's. 

Ngambela at the Lozi Royal Court, Maxwell Mututwa, confirmed the hopes of the people saying craftsmen were now busy repairing the Royal barge, Nalikwanda, which has capacity for more than 150 paddlers, musicians and personal valets of the King whilst he is on his way from the flooded traditional capital of Lealui to the highlands of Limulunga.

Ngambela Mututwa said there were hopes that the rains will continue coming down steadily so that the annual ceremony can take place next year.

In another development the royal establishment is in the process of calling for a common meeting for all MPs from the province so that they can sit down and map out strategies of how to develop the area.

Ngambela Mututwa observed that the royal court has found it necessary to invite the MPs regardless of their political affiliations so that the two sides can discuss and map out strategieis which are aimed at developing the province.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zambian Copper Mine Resurrects From The Dead


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - Bwana-Mkubwa Mining Limited is to re-open the long closed Bwana Mkubwa copper mine near Ndola and bring it into production so it can bear profits for its new owners.

Director of Bwana Mkubwa Mining Limited, Kwalela Lamaswala, says the construction of the project will take 15 months and it is expected that the mine will start production by April 1998.

It will be the first privately owned copper mining project to come on stream in Zambia since more than 25 years ago. 

Bwana Mkubwa Mining Limited is a private company registered in May 1996 in Zambia and owned by First Quantum Minerals Limited of Canada and according to the feasibility study undertaken by the company it determined that there is a tailings reserve of 8.4 million tonnes at 0.73c percent copper. The Batement study concluded that the project will be viable at a production rate of 9,954 tonnes of copper per annum.

The project will have an estimated capital cost of US$26 million for plant construction, and a further US$3 million of working capital allowance.

Metallurgical tests indicated a conservative copper recovery by acid- leaching of 82.5 percent of copper. The project will consequently use sulphuric acid to leach the copper from the tailings.

Mr Lamaswala says the new mine is expected to earn Zambia US$21.8 million per annum from copper exports and one of the major innovations in the project design is the use of tanks made from local cement as opposed to imported stainless steel.

Bwana Mkubwa Mining Limited will also produce 100,000 tonnes of sulphuric acid per year. This will be a bonus increase on the sulphuric acid now coming only from Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines through its smelting of sulphide ores.

Previously the level of this acid production was low resulting in Zambia importing net requirements to meet domestic needs.

Of the amount to be made by Bwana Mkubwa Mining Limited 40,000 tonnes will be consumed in the company's metallurgical processes. The excess 60,000 will be sold to local consumers including ZCCM.

ZAMTODAY

31 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


East Africa;
OAU Seeks Lasting Solution To The Great Lakes Crisis


BYLINE: Peter Mwaura, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1061 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) is seeking a durable solution to the crisis in the Great Lakes region that will be sensitive to both the territorial integrity and the legitimate rights of the people in the region.

OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim said in Dakar on Monday that the crisis in the Great Lakes region needs a holistic approach, confidence- building and prompt action to prevent tragedies from happening.

Salim, who is in the Senegalese capital to consult with President Abdou Diouf on a number of African problems and issues, said his meeting with President Mobutu Sese Seko in France last Friday "was very good" and the Zairean leader was "very conscious of the need to restore normalcy in the region". 

"I was impressed by his commitment to promote stability in the region and his understanding of the nature of the problem."

Salim said it was time to stop the "fire brigade" approach to African problems and step up measures to prevent calamities.

He appealed to the international community in the Great Lakes region to work with the OAU to provide the much-needed assistance and prevent problems from becoming tragedies. "They should not be concerned only when a crisis erupts. They should work with us prevent a crisis from becoming a human tragedy," he said

Salim said the creation of an African force -- to be deployed in crisis areas -- recently proposed by the United States was "fundamentally very sound" .

The proposal was not new as the idea of an African peace-keeping force had been endorsed by the 1995 OAU summit and in the next few months a consensus on the nature of the force should emerge.

"I think eventually it will take off, after consultations", he said.

Salim departs on Tuesday for Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, for a France-Africa summit in which he hopes to continue his consultations with African leaders.

After the summit he will travel to Lome, Togo, to consult President Gnassingbe Eyadema on African problems, including the territorial dispute between Cameroon and Nigeria over the oil-rich Bakassi peninsula. Eyadema has been mediating in the peace talks between the two countries.


LOAD-DATE: December 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


32 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Business and Finance;
Nigeria Bourse Hooked To The Internet


BYLINE: Paul Okolo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Nigerian Stock Exchange has been connected to the Internet to make information of its activities more readily available to interested persons worldwide.

This will enable investors and market operators to receive the daily official list, company news and other information emanating from the market.

Foreign investors will also have easy access to the market, thereby giving the crucial visibility required to attract foreign investment, said an operator. 

A spokesman for the exchange said many quoted companies have already subscribed to the service by which they can send and receive messages from anywhere in the world. The Internet address is nse.ngra.com.

Meanwhile, the NSE All-Share Index bounced back last week from its near static position the week before, thanks to big price gains in the oil, food and breweries sectors.

The index rose 76.25 points to 6,775.61 against the 0.57 points appreciation in the previous week, when major shares tumbled on profit taking.

However, volume of transactions rose from 23.6 million shares to 27.6 million. The deals were worth 173.2 million naira against 198.9 million naira in the preceding week (80 naira= 1 U.S. dollars).

African Petroleum led the best performers with a 2.40 naira gain, which caused the shares to close at 41.00 naira. West African Portland Cement followed with 1.80 naira to close also at 41.00 naira.

Nestle Foods remained the leader in the foods sector, soaring 1.70 naira to 45.20 naira, while National Oil rose by the same margin to 43.20 naira.

Resurging Nigerian Breweries leapt to 15.60 naira, rising 1.60 naira in the week.

Leading conglomerate, Lever Brothers led the losers, sliding 1.30 naira to end at 22.30 naira, UAC also in the conglomerate sector, fell by 60 kobo (100 kobo = one naira), to 8.40 naira.

Guaranty Trust Bank, floated two months ago, slid by 40 kobo to close at 12. 80 naira.

Cadbury and Dunlop dropped 20 kobo to 24.70 naira and 10.30 naira respectively, on profit taking.

33 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Business and Finance;
French Company To Complete Maputo Hotel


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - A French construction company, Spie Batignolles, is to complete a luxury Maputo hotel, abandoned by Portuguese settlers over 20 years ago, at the time of Mozambican independence.

Sipie Batignolles signed a contract for completing the Four Seasons Hotel with Ecotur, A Mozambique-South Africa joint venture that now holds the concession on the hotel. 

The cost of the building work is estimated at 40 million U.S. dollars.

The French company will start work in January 1997, and the hotel should be completed in the second half of 1998, according to an agreement signed here Friday.

The hotel will have a 340-bed, five-star hotel complete with swimming pool, conference hall and casino.

The hotel will be managed by the Holiday Inn chain.

Ecotur was set up in 1994 by the South African East Coast Safaris, which has 74 percent shares, while the junior partner, Sismar, of Mozambique holds 15.6 percent. Two individuals, Stella Barbosa and Arlete Patel have 5.2 percent each.

Mario Sevene, a representative of the Mozambican affiliate of Ecotur, said that the negotiations leading up to the contract with Sipie Batignolles started in 1994.

He added that the hotel would boost tourism in Mozambique. During a recent visit to France, Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano discussed the hotel project with the management of Spie Batignolles.

LANGUAGE: English

34 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
O.A.U. Asks Africa To Nominate Candidates for UN Job


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - Organization of African Unity Chairman Paul Biya has asked interested African countries to nominate candidates for the position of United Nations secretary-general.

"In order to preserve for Africa its chance at a second mandate, the African states should, should they desire, present other qualified candidates along with that of Dr. Boutros Boutros-Ghali," he said in a letter dated Nov. 29.

In it Biya, who is the president of Cameroon, said African states should present their candidates directly to the president of the U.N. Security Council and then inform the O.A.U. chairman. 

Biya's letter has opened the way for Africa to present other candidates for the post, along with Boutros Boutros-Ghali, whose bid for a second five-year term was vetoed Nov. 19 by the United States.

All the other 14 members of the council, upon whose recommendation the General Assembly elects a U.N. secretary-general, voted for the Boutros-Ghali.

Biya said that his request was to ensure that Africa filled the secretary- generalship if the U.S. continued to veto Boutros-Ghali's candidature.

Members of the council have agreed to reserve the first and second stages of their selection process to African candidates to give the continent a chance of winning a second term.

The current term of Boutros-Ghali, a 74-year old Egyptian diplomat, will expire Dec. 31.

At its 32nd summit in Yaounde earlier this year, African leaders endorsed his candidature.

At their meeting, African leaders also mandated Biya to consult with other U.N. member states to ensure that Africa would get a second mandate.

"I have carried out my mission as mandated and I officially presented this position to the General Assembly at the debate on the U.N. on Oct. 24, 1996," Biya said.

A two-term tenure has been the past practice when the citizens of other regions occupied the position.

Since the U.S. veto, the African group at the U.N. has said, consistently, that it will stick with Boutros-Ghali until the O.A.U. gives it further directives.

The Africans being mentioned as possible candidates include the foreign minister of Cote d'Ivoire, Amara Essy, the U.N. under-secretary general for peacekeeping operations, Kofi Annan of Ghana, the secretary-general of the O. A.U., Salim Ahmed Salim, and the head of the International Peace Academy in New York, Olara Otunnu of Uganda.

The U.S. says it opposes Boutros-Ghali's candidature for a second-term because he has not carried out enough reform of the U.N.


LOAD-DATE: December 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


35 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Business and Finance;
Tumbling World Gold Market Affects Ghana Stocks


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Shares on the stock market began the week in sluggish trading Monday, dragged lower by the bearish gold market which has badly affected Ashanti Goldfields Company (AGC) issues.

The official GSE All-Share Index fell 4.49 points to close at 361.88 from the previous 366.37 points close. 

Gold on the world market has shed some 10 dollars (about 17,000 cedis) in one month with possible signs of a further loss as fears of future gold sales by European central banks loom large.

The equities of AGC, one of the world's modern gold mining companies with a production capacity of about one million ounces a year, has suffered on the local market recently.

The broader market closed Monday with AGC losing 1,800 cedis to 23,200 with two other decliners and a lone gainer on a light volume of 72,790 shares.

Unilever (UNIL) and UTC-Estates (UTC-E) were the other decliners, dropping five cedis each to close at 785 and 50 cedis respectively.

New market entrant Aluworks (ALW) extended its previous gain by five cedis to finish at 1,415 cedis.

The market looks generally sluggish with demand which stood at 624,330 shares, failing to keep up to supply pressure at 927,470.

Uncertainty on the political landscape was also unnerving the market which lacks the support of big buyers and off-shore players.

Market capitalization slumped to 2,663.18 billion cedis from Friday's 2,835. 19 billion cedis.

The following were the last prices of listed equities quoted in cedis at the close of business on Monday: ABL 550 AGC 23,200 -1,800 ALW 1,415 '5 CFAO 20 EIC 420 FML 404 GCB 701 GGL 242 HFC 127 KBL 645 MGL 135 MLC 50 MOGL 6,000 PAF 165 PTC 130 PZ 370 SCB 5,200 SPPC 112 SSB 1,050 UNIL 785 - 5 UTC-E 50 - 5

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


36 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Iran Plans To Fund Dam Projects In Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Iran has agreed to provide 19.8 million U.S. dollars to finance the construction of the Gwayi-Shangani and Gwayi-Umguza dams in drought-prone Matabeleland north.

The total cost of the projects, expected to benefit up to one million people, in Bulawayo, Tsholotsho, Lupane and Bubi-Umguza, is about 36 million dollars. 

In an interview, the deputy minister of lands and water resources, Cain Mathema, said the funds, to cover 55 percent of project costs, would be in the form of a soft loan whose terms were yet to be discussed.

Mathema, who returned from a business trip to Iran on Friday, said the Iranians had also agreed to provide technical experts for the construction of the dams.

"The Iranians showed us their capacity to build most advanced dams in the world, and we met their syndicates in construction who showed willingness to come here and assist us," he said.

Mathema said construction of the dams, whose designs were now ready, would begin as soon as cabinet approved the deal with the iranians.

He said a delegation of Iranian experts would visit Zimbabwe in two weeks time to discuss with the relevant ministry and engineers details of the financial package of the project.

The deputy minister said government was also looking at the generation of hydro-electric power at the Gwayi-Umguza dam.

"The final project would cost over zd 1 billion (USD 100 million) and this would include costs for building water treatment works and construction of pipelines to Bulawayo," he said.

The Gwayi-Shangani and Gwayi-Umguza project is similar to the proposed Kunzwi dam in Harare, where the Harare City Council and government are jointly working together to provide adequate water for the capital city.


LOAD-DATE: December 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


37 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 3, 1996


United States and Africa;
EXIM Bank Loan For Ghana's Oil Fields


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - The Export Import Bank of the United States, Exim Bank, is to provide about 300 million U.S. dollars worth of American exports of equipment and services for the development of the Tano oil and gas fields in the western Ghana.

An agreement for the transaction was signed November 26 at the Ghana Embassy in Washington D.C. by Tsatsu Tsikata, chief executive of the Ghana National Petroleum Corporation (GNPC), and Rita Rodriguez, member of Exim Bank board of directors.

The corporation said Monday in Accra that the transaction represented the " bank's major commitment to supporting U.S. exports to the West African market" . 

The corporation said principal U.S. suppliers included Continental Engineering and Construction Services of Lafayette, Louisiana, and Westinghouse Electric International Company of Orlando, Florida.

It said the suppliers also included a number of oil and gas fields service companies in Louisiana and Texas.

The GNPC said it would use the funding to develop off-shore infrastructure for producing oil and gas in the Tano fields which was originally discovered in the late 1970s and early 1980s by the U.S. company, Phillips Petroleum.

Natural gas from the fields will be used to power a barge mounted electricity generating plant to be built and installed between Effasu and Mangyea on the western coastal area.

Speaking at the signing ceremony, Tsikata thanked Rodriguez and other personnel of the bank for their role in the negotiation and conclusion of the agreement.

He was confident that the GNPC would successfully implement the project for the benefit of Ghanaians.

Rodriguez said the bank's support demonstrated the continuity of U.S. support for the development of Ghana's energy needs.

GNPC said that Standard Chartered Bank, the guaranteed lender under the Exim bank facility, and the Private Export Funding Corporation of the United States, which is providing funding to back Standard Chartered Bank, were also signatories to the agreement.

Africa-at-Large;
Belgium Gives One Million Dollars To OAU Peace Fund


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Belgium has donated one million U.S. dollars to the Organization of African Unity's Peace Fund for the prevention, management and resolution of conflicts in the continent. 

This was Belgium's second contribution since the fund was established three years ago.

The first contribution of 35 million Belgian franc (about 1.5 million dollars) was made in February, 1994.

An agreement on the donation was signed here Tuesday by Belgian ambassador to Ethiopia, Genot Alain, and OAU acting secretary general, Ahmed Haggag, according to a release by the continental organisation.

Commending the efforts of the OAU in peace-keeping in Africa, the Belgian ambassador said his government was determined to support the fund and work closely with the OAU.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


39 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Mugabe Admits Doctors Are Underpaid


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe on Wednesday conceded his country's doctors are poorly remunerated but said sick patients should not be used as sacrificial lambs in bargaining for higher wages.

Officially opening the 47th annual general meeting and scientific conference of the association of surgeons of east and central africa (Asea), Mugabe said doctors should not be allowed to go hungry.

"There is good cause in our circumstances of developing countries for surgeons to appeal, request and demand the most of comfort which will enable them to operate effectively. they should not be allowed to go hungry. 

"Our doctors are not well salaried and we should take care of them if they are going to take care of us well," he said.

However, he said the recent strike involving some junior doctors and nurses showed lack of concern for human life in the country.

"Surely it can never be right to use the sick patient as our sacrificial lamb in bargaining for higher wages. The medical profession's first responsibility is to serve as a trusted agent of and adviser of patients," said Mugabe.

Junior doctors and nurses in Zimbabwe went on strike on Oct. 21 to press government for a general improvement on their conditions of service and an increase in various allowances.

The striking nurses and doctors have since been dismissed, forcing the closure of some wards in major referral hospitals in Harare and Bulawayo.

The ASEA incoming chairman, Prof. Ignatius Kakande of Uganda's Makerere university, said the relationship between doctors and money was complicated and intricate.

"The relationship has been represented by triumphant aesculapius who appears as an angel when attending a patient, as a god when he cures and as a devil when he asks for payment for his professional fee," said Kakane, who took over from Prof. Josephat Mulimba of Kenya.

"Given the fact that medical practice is an integral interpersonal relationship between the patient, the society in which we live and the doctor himself, the patient and society have also a duty to ensure that the doctor is facilitated to be able to perform his work efficiently and in peace of mind.

"A hungry doctor is unlikely to perform his duties perfectly. however, since the health of the man is priceless, the surgeon should only demand for his efforts a payment which is adequate and suitable to his personal and family needs," he said.

He said payment should never be so high as to cancel or neutralize the feeling of gratitude and the spiritual link which should be existing between the patient and his surgeon.

"The profession should not be turned into a market reality causing its dehumanization."

The association is composed of seven countries - Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Prof. Godfrey Muguti, who is president of the surgical society of Zimbabwe, said the annual meeting of the association provided a forum for members to discuss issues of mutual concern and share experiences.

Zimbabwe's Bonnie Mauchaza was chosen to be vice-president of the association.

More than 150 delegates from member countries are attending the meeting which ends on Friday.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Mozambique;
Mozambican Judge Accused Of Murder


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - A judge in Mozambique has been accused of battering his domestic servant to death.

The Maputo daily newspaper, Noticias, reported Wednesday that the presiding judge of the Manica provincial court, Valentim Sambo, murdered the servant, only named as Joao, on Nov. 7, according to the provincial attorney's office. 

The office said the body of the dead man has not yet been found, but there are "credible reports" that it may have been buried or dumped somewhere in the districts of Gondola or Sussundenga.

Manica provincial attorney, Daniel Magula, told the press that investigations had brought to light evidence that Sambo did indeed murder his servant.

"From the investigations we have carried out, involving the competent authorities and statements from relatives and neighbors, there is no doubt that the judge killed the deceased," he added. "Whether he has hidden the body is irrelevant. What is relevant for us is that we have sufficient evidence to assert that the person was killed."

Magula expressed concern over the supreme court's delay in taking action. Despite pressure from the attorney general's office, the supreme court has not yet suspended the judge. Almost a month after the servant's death, Sambo is still in full power as the Manica presiding judge.

"There is a fight going on in Maputo between the attorney general's office and the supreme court, while the accused remains unpunished", accused Magula.

Africa News


December 4, 1996


Ethiopia;
Hijackers Identified As Unemployed Youth


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The three hijackers of the Ethiopian Airlines aircraft that crashed into the Indian Ocean close to the Grand Comoros on Nov. 23, were unemployed Ethiopian youths who had spent time in Djibouti, the Ethiopian News Agency (ENA) disclosed here Wednesday, quoting a government official.

They were identified as Alemayehu Bekele Belay, Matias Bekele Belay and Sultan Nur Hussein, the agency reported, without indicating whether the first two were brothers. 

The trio who were in their twenties, were said to have stayed in Djibouti, and returned to Addis Ababa recently.

The agency gave no information about their motives for commandeering the Boeing 767 flight 961, about 30 minutes after it left Addis Ababa for West Africa, and insisted on being flown to Australia.

Alemayehu and Matias were said to be high school drop-outs, while Sultan Nuru Hussein had completed training as a nurse in Djibouti. All three were unemployed.

Ethiopian flight 961 was heading to Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire, via Nairobi, Brazzaville and Lagos, when it was hijacked. It crashed into the sea when it ran out of fuel after a few hours, close to a resort beach in Moroni as the captain tried to ditch it.

A total of 125 passengers and crew of 37 nationalities perished in the plane crash Fifty persons survived, including the captain, Leul Abate, co- pilot Yonas Makuria and two hostesses.

The three hijackers were among the 125 victims of the crash.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December 4, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Women's Group Blames Traditional Healers For Child Rape


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean traditional healers who prescribe sexual intercourse with minors as an AIDS cure were blamed Wednesday by a women's rights pressure group for the increase in cases of child sexual abuse.

Nomsa Ncube, a female lawyer in Bulawayo, said cases of juvenile rape had increased by over 100 percent since 1995. 

"Traditional healers should be responsible, they are prescribing rapes of small children," she said.

However, a member of the Zimbabwe National Traditional Healers Association (Zinatha), Lettie Moyo, denied knowledge of such practices. She said that traditional healers who made such prescriptions were not genuine.

According to regional court records, 90 rape cases were heard between January and November 1995. However during the same period in 1996, 350 cases went through the same court over the same, 90 percent of them involving children under the age of 16 years.

Ncube said more cases were awaiting trial while others had gone unreported.

"This could just be the tip of the iceberg," he said.

In mitigation, some child rapists claimed to have acted on instructions of traditional healers.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Cote d'Ivoire;
The Plight of Workers With HIV In Cote d'Ivoire


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Employees who live with the HIV virus that causes the incurable AIDS face a precarious life in Cote d'Ivoire where tales of mounting discrimination against such workers have just emerged.

According to a document obtained by PANA in Dakar, the discrimination is practiced under the collusion of employers, trade union officials as well as doctors.

This type of exclusion, in Abidjan, the country's business capital, was revealed in a paper presented at a recent international symposium on Social Sciences and AIDS in Africa. 

The gathering, held from Nov.4-8 in Sali Portudal, Senegal, was sponsored by the French Overseas Organization for Scientific Research (ORSTOM) and the Dakar-based Council for the Development of Social Science Research in Africa.

According to the paper's author, Laurent Aventin of ORSTOM, the discriminatory practices include the illicit testing for HIV and abusive job dismissals. He wrote that these practices "probably" exist in other West African countries.

World Health Organization statistics indicate that Cote d'Ivoire leads other West African countries in terms of HIV seropositivity.

As at May 31, 1995, Aventin wrote, Cote d'Ivoire had reported 25,236 cases of full-blown AIDS. The general seropositivity rate is currently estimated at 13.7 percent.

He found that employers engage in discrimination against HIV infected people to guard their firms against absenteeism or AIDS-related deaths among their workers.

In his paper, Vantin says the root cause of the discrimination lies in the non-respect of the medical secret by the various AIDS-testing centers in Abidjan.

This lack of confidentiality, the document notes, arises from the fact that only between five and six doctors possess specialized certificates in occupational health studies.

As a result, most the occupation health matters is handled by doctors who reveal the HIV status of workers to the people who employ them.

The ORSTOM document quoted a study by a female medical student who discovered that out of about 30 doctors employed by firms, 30 percent confirmed passing the results of their tests to employers.

Employers also get information about workers from hospitals, testing centers and the blood transfusion center. The practice of pre-employment testing is also mentioned in the ORSTOM study, although the Ivorian legislation does not demand for it.

Once an employee has been identified to be living with HIV, some managers in Abidjan negotiated for his or her voluntary retirement, sometimes using some trade union leaders.

Other employers look for faults by the seropositive worker so as to eventually legally sack him or her on the basis of those mistakes.

In his conclusion, Aventin makes an urgent appeal on Ivorian work places to stress on AIDS information and education to dispel the existing myths about the disease as well as its modes of transmission.

He also stresses the need to sensitize labor inspectors so that they can mete out punishment to discourage the ongoing discriminatory practices.

The author further urges the Board of the Cote d'Ivoire Medical Order as well as the country's juridical organs "to play a role of prevention, surveillance and punishment especially in situation of non-respect of the medical secret."


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Boutros-Ghali Reacts To Biya's Message


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros- Ghali has no objections to other African candidates vying for the job he occupies, his spokeswoman said Wednesday.

"It's always been an open question that anybody can submit their own names to the Security Council," spokeswoman Sylvana Foa told UN correspondents in New York.

Foa was reacting to a letter from the chairman of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), president Paul Biya of Cameroon, urging interested African states to nominate other suitable candidates for the post, in addition to Boutros-Ghali. 

She said that Biya's letter did not represent a shift in the position of the OAU, which endorsed Boutros-Ghali for a second five-year term at its last summit in Yaounde last July. His current term will expire on Dec. 31.

"He (OAU chairman) is asking other heads of state within the OAU for their views on his proposal that other African countries be allowed to submit names directly to the Security Council while reaffirming that Boutros-Ghali is a candidate of the OAU," the spokeswoman said.

However, the U.S., which is opposed to another term for the secretary- general, interpreted the letter to mean that Africa has abandoned Boutros- Ghali and urged other African candidates to come forward.

"We were very pleased with the letter from president Paul Biya because in effect it now allows the Security Council to do its work," U.S. ambassador Madeleine Albright said Friday.

"It broke the logjam and we think now that we'll be getting names of African candidates," she said.

The council members have agreed to give priority to African candidates to ensure that Africa gets a second mandate like other regions which had produced a secretary-general in the past.

The process of selecting a candidate to be elected by the 185-members General Assembly has been on hold since Nov. 19, when the U.S. vetoed the candidature of Boutros-Ghali, who received the support of the 14 other members of the council.

Before the letter, the African group at the UN had consistently said that it was sticking by the secretary-general pending further instructions from the African leaders.

The group, after a three-hour closed-door meeting in New York Friday, reaffirmed its backing for Boutros-Ghali, in spite of Biya's letter.

Though no other candidate has emerged so far, several possible candidates, including the OAU secretary-general, Salim Ahmed Salim, the head of the International Peace Academy in New York, Olara Otunnu of Uganda and the UN under-secretary for peacekeeping operations, Kofi Annan of Ghana, are being mentioned.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


45 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Tunisia;
Tunisia News Update


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Tunis - Presidents Ben Ali and Moubarak Discuss Bilateral Relations, Regional Issues

President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali and Egyptian president Hosni Moubarak met yesterday in Tunis to discuss bilateral relations as well as regional and international issues.

According to the official presidential spokesman, Presidents Ben Ali and Moubarak agreed on the need to strengthen bilateral economic and trade relations and the exchange of experiences.

The situation in the region, particularly as regards the Middle East peace process, was also raised. The official spokesman indicated that both presidents reiterated their "deep concern about the threats facing the peace process", adding that the "international community must measure the consequences" of these dangers on the future of the region and on international relations. 

The official spokesman also said that the situation in Libya and the repercussions of the air embargo were raised by both presidents, who called for a settlement of the conflict opposing Libya to Western countries.

Presidents Ben Ali and Moubarak also discussed the situation in Iraq, expressing their "satisfaction following signs announcing the end of the suffering by the Iraqi people," the official spokesman stated.

President Moubarak, who arrived in Tunis mid-day, left to Cairo late in the afternoon.

Tunisia Calls for Closer cooperation Between European and Southern Mediterranean Countries

President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali called for closer collaboration between European countries and those on the southern shores of the Mediterranean in a speech at a conference of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE).

In a speech delivered yesterday by Interior Minister Mohamed Jegham, before the Summit Conference of the OSCE, currently held in Lisbon, Portugal, president Ben Ali said "it is our firm conviction that we should make use of the new world changes and of the possibilities they offer for communication, creative symbiosis and constructive cooperation, to favor closer relations among the partners in the Euro-Mediterranean region and to serve their goals with respect to stability and development."

"Tunisia will continue, from the position it occupies, to work responsibly and with determination to serve these goals, and to guarantee the future of coming generations in our region," he added.

Addressing cooperation between the OSCE and the Mediterranean Countries Partners for Cooperation, president Ben Ali said that it is "far short of expectations, for these countries cannot contribute effectively to dialogue on the subject of security and cooperation in the Euro-Mediterranean area if they do not participate closely ... in the mechanisms set up for that purpose. "

President Zine El Abdine Ben Ali said "the concept of security is an indivisible whole that is not limited to the military aspect alone, but extends well beyond that to encompass the political, economic, human, social, environmental, and cultural dimensions."

The heads of governments from 54 countries are taking part in this summit, including the US and Canada.

Electronic Quotation System Inaugurated at Stock Exchange

An electronic quotation system was inaugurated December 2 at the Tunis Stock Exchange.

Set up in collaboration with the Paris Stock Exchange, the system brings added transparency in transactions and market liquid assets in addition to increased credibility of the Tunisian market, especially with the creation of the Fund for Market security.

The system is run by a central computer which collates the demand and supply of shares introduced by brokers from terminals set up at the Stock Exchange.

The number of companies listed in the Tunis Stock Exchange increased from 13 in 1990 to 30 companies in 1996. The number of investment companies increased from 18 to 126.

Industrial Upgrading Program to Benefit 2,200 companies

About 2,200 Tunisian companies will undergo production and managerial restructuring in the next five years as part of the national industrial upgrading program, M. Slaheddine Bouguerra, Minister of Industry told graduating students at the High Institute of Management.

Mr. Bouguerra said that by ratifying the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in 1989 and becoming a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1995, Tunisia will have to adjust fully to the requirements of free trade and foreign competition.

He added that Tunisian companies must reform their financial, managerial, personnel and production systems to be able to compete globally.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Uganda;
Humanitarian Situation Report On Uganda (12/04)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 5227 words


 

Nairobi - INTRODUCTION: 1. The reality of life in Uganda today is that the northern one-third of the country is in a state of crisis. Rebels of the West Nile Bank Front (WNBF) and the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) are operating across the north of the country - from Arua, Moyo and Nebbi to Gulu, Kitgum and Apac. Their attacks against the population in the north constitute grave human rights abuses, while their activities are causing massive displacement of the Ugandan population and of Sudanese refugees, with very serious implications for their food security and health. Services such as health and education are in a state of collapse, while the rampant insecurity is undermining the efforts of humanitarian relief agencies to provide even basic emergency assistance.

2. This situation report follows a DHA fact-finding mission to Uganda which included visits to Gulu town and to the Kasese area in Kabarole district, scene of a recent rebel invasion from Zaire. It gives a detailed description of the current situation in Gulu district, as well as accounts of the situation in Kitgum and Arua. In looking at the Kasese conflict, it explores the links between this rebel attack and other rebel activities in Uganda as well as the situation in eastern Zaire. The report analyses the background to the current conflicts, setting them in their regional context, and concludes by looking at their implications for Uganda's wider development prospects.

GULU: EPICENTRE OF A GROWING EMERGENCY 

3. The hospital at Lachor, 5kms from Gulu town, has recently started to receive a category of patient hitherto unseen even in an area which has witnessed barbaric human rights abuses for several years - young people whose feet have been hacked off by rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA). Four people can be seen in one ward, deprived of their limbs as punishment for riding their bicycles, which the LRA seeks to prohibit on the grounds that bike riders can provide military intelligence to the Ugandan Army. 'It is a miracle they survived', says the doctor in charge, noting that these patients reach the hospital only with the help of other people who risk their lives by providing such assistance.

4. The hospital itself has 446 beds, each of which is in use, but every evening it is home to some 6,000 people who have left the countryside for the relative safety of the hospital grounds. They lie in the wards, on the concrete pathways which link them, and on every spare patch of ground in the garden and compound. In the morning they filter back to their homes and their fields, only to return again as dusk approaches. The same is true for every major public building in-between the hospital and the centre of the town; a recent census carried out by the local authorities and MSF-Holland found that 15,400 people enter the town each night and leave again the following morning. In addition, some 30,000 displaced people live in Gulu town on a semi- permanent basis.

5. Lachor hospital is currently feeding 60 severely malnourished children, many of whom were caught in the measles epidemic which afflicted the district earlier in the year. In 1995 the hospital registered 184 patients suffering from measles; by October this year it had already registered 744 cases. The epidemic reflects the fact that the authority's immunization programme has been totally undermined by the rampant insecurity. The same is true for the range of health services - whether for treatment of disease or for assisting pregnancies and births. Of the estimated 45 health centres in the district, between 6 and 9 are believed to be still functioning in some fashion. Qualified staff have fled to the relative safety of the towns, while resupplying centres with drugs and medicines is usually out of the question.

6. Education has also been drastically affected by the conflict; only a handful of the district's 180 primary schools function at present. The targeting of schoolchildren by the LRA is believed to be one of the prime causes, with UNICEF estimating that 3,000 schoolchildren have been abducted by the rebels during 1995 and 1996. The problem is growing not only in Gulu district but also in Kitgum, Arua and Apac - increasingly rebels appear to see children as easy targets in their search to find recruits.

7. Out of Gulu district's population of 390,000 people, between 100,000 and 200,000 are estimated to be displaced from their homes. The figures are guesswork, extrapolated from the levels of displacement observed in those parts of the district from which the local authorities still receive information. What is clear is that displacement, either on a daily basis for overnight stays, or on a semi-permanent basis further away from home, is a way of life for much, perhaps even most, of Gulu's population.

8. A major consequence for farmers who have left their plots is that they cannot harvest their crops just at the time they have become ripe. Although Gulu district received a bumper harvest this year, thanks to successful planting in August and plentiful rains, rice is rotting in the fields. Farmers fear to return to their land, in case they are attacked by the LRA, or find themselves caught in the midst of fighting between the LRA and the Uganda People's Defence Forces (UPDF). This has implications not only for their day-to-day survival, but also for the population's medium-term food security, as they are not selling surpluses and building up the reserves that would see them through future lean times.

9. Landmines are also a serious - and growing - problem. The LRA is using both anti-personnel and anti-tank mines, in fields and on major roads. Lachor hospital carried out 60 amputations on the victims of anti-personnel mines between 1 January 1996 and mid-November; in 1995 the total number was 20. The people who reach the hospital are the lucky ones, most people never make it. If mines are one of the major problems preventing people in Gulu from resuming normal lives, they are also one of the reasons why none of the international relief agencies is currently working outside Gulu town, with the occasional exception of the ICRC.

10. The attention of the international humanitarian agencies has recently been focussed on the question of 'protected villages'. The local authorities characterize these as places, often close to UPDF posts, where people have spontaneously gathered together for their own protection. Displaced people interviewed in Gulu, however, report that UPDF soldiers told them that they would be regarded as rebels if they stayed in their home villages. Leading politicians and soldiers are on record as saying that protected villages will be an important part of their strategy to isolate rebels and deny them food, freedom of movement and the ability to re-group.

11. Although a number of sites are reported each to have attracted several thousand people over the past few weeks, there are also reports that many of these people are already returning to their homes. Certainly, displaced people interviewed at a site designated by the authorities in Gulu expressed a reluctance to stay where they were; having found no food, water or sanitation facilities at the site they were talking about returning home. Several people said that they felt unsafe in the sites, one of which is already reported to have been attacked by the LRA.

12. Whether or not protected villages develop over the coming weeks will also depend on the ability of aid agencies to provide the services which are lacking, and certainly beyond the means of the local authorities. The LRA has already begun to issue threats against agencies working in the area, presumably aware that the protected villages would, if successful, make rebels much more vulnerable. If humanitarian agencies were seen to be working to the UPDF's agenda, they could easily find themselves the targets of rebel hostilities.

13. At present the World Food Programme is trying to supply emergency relief food to Gulu, and is currently planning a programme for 100,000 people in Gulu town and Kilak, Nyowa, Omoro and Awsa counties (as and when they can be accessed) as well as in the Masindi - Karuma area. In Gulu town the organizations distributing the food are World Vision, Oxfam/Acord, the Church of Uganda and the Catholic diocese. The local authorities have also distributed a certain amount of food. MSF-Holland is helping the health authorities to monitor the health situation, as well as assessing and assisting the water situation in Gulu town. UNICEF is funding vaccination activities in accessible areas and has provided tented schools for Gulu town, while the ICRC and ACF also have teams on the spot.

KITGUM

14. The LRA reportedly use Kitgum as a transit point into and out of Sudan, as well as a base from which to launch attacks in Gulu. Yet Kitgum is not merely an accessory to the conflict in Gulu, as the LRA is also carrying out abductions and killings there; in one incident earlier this year 106 Sudanese refugees were killed. Fighting between the UPDF and LRA is also a frequent occurrence. For these reasons Kitgum is experiencing many of Gulu's problems, notably population displacement and widespread disruption to agriculture, the latter manifesting itself in shortages of maize and millet. One international NGO estimates that half of the district's population, about 180,000 people, may suffer food shortages next year.

15. Kitgum's health situation is also of great concern, as insecurity allows only intermittent access to rural health centres by would- be beneficiaries and the district health teams upon whom they rely. As in Gulu, the authorities have found it hard to attract and retain qualified health staff. Kitgum has experienced two minor cholera outbreaks this year, one from January to March and another in September and October.

16. Growing insecurity has also prompted a major change in the way humanitarian agencies in Kitgum operate; while at the beginning of the year they were travelling around by road and carrying out routine activities, today they fly in and out of the district and focus on essential needs. 'The quality and coverage in terms of health care in northern Uganda, particularly in Gulu and Kitgum, has declined in a drastic way in 1996', says Dr Viviane Van Steirteghen of UNICEF.

THE WEST NILE

17. Arua has experienced insecurity for several years as it is the main district affected by the West Nile Bank Front's insurgency. At the beginning of this year, however, the situation was sufficiently stable for agencies working in the district to plan development programmes. Even until the end of September development agencies were working in rural areas, both with Ugandans and with approximately 190,000 Sudanese refugees (who are divided between Arua and the neighbouring district of Moyo to the east).

18. Yet during October and November the local population has found itself the target of a growing number of killings, rapes and abductions by the West Nile Bank Front (WNBF), whose modus operandi appears increasingly similar to that of the LRA. At the same time, attacks on Sudanese refugees and the agencies that are working with them have escalated dramatically. The result has been the large-scale displacement of the Ugandan population living close to the border with Zaire and the displacement from settled camps of tens of thousands of Sudanese refugees.

19. Sudanese refugees at Ikafe and Imvepi, camps which are home to 55,000 people, have been raped, abducted and killed. Their homes have been burnt to the ground and 25,000 people are known to be displaced. The agencies working with them have received threats and had their compounds repeatedly looted, while several Ugandan staff members have been abducted. Palorinya refugee camp in Moyo district has also been repeatedly attacked, while UNHCR's base at Pakelle was attacked and looted earlier this year.

20. The roads into and around Arua are increasingly difficult to use; anti- personnel and anti-tank mines are a major hazard, while one agency working in the district estimates that nine bridges have been blown in the last four weeks alone. The road from Pakwach which skirts the western edge of the district through Arua town and on to Koboko is described by WFP as 'very insecure'.

21. The message received by the Sudanese refugees has been plain, as this testimony from a Sudanese woman, displaced from her refugee camp, reveals: 'After the first attack, I moved from Point to Point; I was afraid to sleep in my own home. Sometimes I slept in the bush, sometimes with friends... My mind was badly disturbed. I had most of my things looted in the first attack, then when the rebels burnt Point J, I lost whatever was remaining. They told us that they didn't want to see anyone left in the camps; they said 'Even if you go to Bidibidi (transit centre), we'll chase you from there. We're giving you a warning. Go back to Sudan. I fear in my heart that I will be killed; any one with any responsibility is targeted. If I could find a way of going out, I would try... we didn't come here to die.'(1)

22. Observers of Uganda believe that one of the reasons why refugees have been targeted is that the WNBF is believed to suspect them of supporting the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), which is fighting a protracted war against the Islamic Government of Sudan. As the war rages on, many refugees fear that they will be conscripted if they return to Sudan. One young man, quoted in an internal NGO report said, 'Anyone aged 12-20 years, girl or boy, is handed a gun immediately they cross to the liberated areas; then young men up to 50 years are all called on to fight. It's the same in the government areas, except the age limit is 18 years.'(2)

23. Arua town's population has been swelled by the influx of about 25,000 displaced people, while Koboko town to the north is home to 20,000 Sudanese refugees displaced from their camps. Although trading continues across the border with Zaire, supplying any part of the district with provisions from southern Uganda is exceptionally difficult under the present circumstances. Meanwhile, aid agencies are confining themselves to Arua town, hoping that security will improve, thereby allowing them to resume their programmes. There are, however, very few grounds for optimism.

KASESE

24. On the morning of 13 November, residents of Bwera town suddenly heard gunshots around the UPDF's base in the town. Panic-stricken, they fled their homes, leaving possessions and relatives elsewhere in the town behind. They reported seeing 'rebels', dressed in rags and dirty military uniforms, and speaking Baganda, Bankole and Bakanjo, the former being Ugandan languages and the latter the language of the border area between Uganda and Zaire that centres on the Ruhenzori mountains. An elderly woman was told either to get away from the fighting or to go behind the attackers; they were looking for UPDF soldiers.

25. Bwera town fell to the rebels but was re-taken by the UPDF over the course of the following weekend. Mpondwe border post was also taken by the rebels, but recaptured by the UPDF early the following week. Meanwhile, some 25,000 people from around the area fled their homes and congregated in Kasese town and along and around the small road that links the main Kasese - Bushenyi road with Bwera and Mpondwe to its west. The displaced people were assisted by the ICRC and the Ugandan Red Cross, WFP and MSF-France.

26. The account from the Government-owned New Vision was that the UPDF death toll stood at 34 and that 'about 400' rebels had been killed. The UPDF response reportedly involved sending reinforcements from Mbarara and Mbale and soldiers from 4th Division, Gulu, as well as bombing the Zairean town of Kasindi which the UPDF alleged to be the rebel base. President Museveni visited the border area soon after security had been restored and was photographed on the spot with an AK-47 casually slung over his shoulder. As relative peace returned to the area, residents of Bwera began to make their way home, at first in small numbers and later with increasing urgency on hearing reports that their homes were being looted.

27. Throughout the duration of the conflict a series of conflicting reports and commentary made front page news on Uganda's leading papers - the New Vision and The Monitor. The rebels were described as being variously 450, 710 and 1,500 strong. They were said to be members of the National Army for the Liberation of Uganda (NALU), a small rebel movement that had caused skirmishes in the same area in the early 1990s, backed up by soldiers of the Zairean Army. Reports also emerged that the Rwandan Interahamwe and rebels from the West Nile Bank Front were involved. Later still there were reports that Salaf Tabliq Islamic militants had played a leading role and reference was made to a rebel group called the Allied Democratic Forces.

28. On 19 November the New Vision linked the attack with information received from surrendered LRA fighters who had reported that the LRA, WNBF, Salaf Tabliqs and other rebel groups had held a meeting in the main LRA camp at Aruu, about 50kms south of Juba in south Sudan, the previous week, and agreed to coordinate attacks on the UPDF beginning in November. Under this agreement, Joseph Kony, leader of the LRA, would be the overall commander of the Allied Democratic Forces. In broad terms this view appears to be shared by Museveni, who was reported to have alleged at a recent press conference that 'Joseph Kony, Juma Oris, the Muslim tabliqs have done their coordination supported by Sudan'.

29. The close proximity of the crisis in eastern Zaire is already making its presence felt in Uganda, with the arrival of some 8,000 mainly Zairean refugees into the Kisoro area and another 3,500 to Matanda. Yet if the Banyamulenge forces continue their advance northwards along the Zaire-Uganda border, it appears likely that, as in the case of Uvira, Bukavu and Goma, there will be substantial displacement of populations in the border area. As the area further north is the stronghold of WNBF rebels, this could affect security in Uganda's border areas.

BACKGROUND TO THE CONFLICTS IN THE NORTH

30. Certain points of comparison may be made between the two rebel movements now bringing insecurity to swathes of northern Uganda -the LRA and the WNBF. The north of the country was the major recruiting ground for soldiers in the Ugandan Army for several generations. While Milton Obote recruited his military elite from the Acholi and Langi ethnic groups in the Gulu area, Idi Amin favoured the Aringa and Kakwa people of Arua and many of his soldiers came from there. Both the LRA and the WNBF have drawn support from the defeated militaries of these previous regimes, and from two districts whose people feel they have lost power to the south.

31. The districts which form the heartland of the WNBF and the LRA - the West Nile (Arua, Nebbi and Moyo) and Gulu/Kitgum - are among the poorest in Uganda. Uganda's recent economic success has been first and foremost a southern phenomenon - its effects have barely been felt in the north, in part because of the catch-22 of the current insecurity. But in terms of services such as health and education, in terms of infrastructure and economic opportunities, northern Uganda has lagged behind the rest of the country. Its soldiers, defeated in battle and returning home after spells as refugees in neighbouring countries, came back to an impoverished countryside.

32. Yet while the WNBF appears to have the goal of restoring Idi Amin to power (its chief is Colonel Juma Oris, once Idi Amin's Foreign Minister), the LRA's philosophy is difficult to comprehend. Its leaders, first Alice Lakwena and now Joseph Kony, claim inspiration from a holy spirit claimed to be 'the spirit of an Italian who had died during the First World War, aged 95, near the sources of the Nile'(3). This reincarnated being is supposed to have taken possession of the two successive leaders of the LRA, impelling them to fight the war they are now engaged in. The LRA's belief system reportedly echos strongly traditional belief systems among the Acholi.(4)

33. The extent to which either the WNBF or the LRA receive the active support of the population in the West Nile and Gulu/Kitgum is a hotly debated issue. Neither group could have survived for the past ten years without a substantial measure of local backing - but to what extent is this the result of genuine support and to what extent the result of fear? The WNBF has, until recently, not resorted to abducting people as a means of recruitment, suggesting it has been able to find people in the area who are willing to join voluntarily (although there are frequent reports that WNBF recruits are offered money as an inducement to joining). The WNBF has not, to anywhere near the same extent as the LRA, targeted the civilian population in the West Nile; one of the main reasons why the Government of Uganda has consistently offered former WNBF fighters amnesty. The same offer has been extended to the LRA rank and file, but not to senior commanders such as Joseph Kony.

34. The LRA, however, has made abductions of children a central part of its recruitment strategy, and its killings and maimings appear designed to induce terror among the civilian population. One Ugandan employee of an international NGO, when asked whether people in Gulu support the LRA, said, 'the population is in a dilemma. They are very frightened. If they report on the rebels they fear the LRA will kill them, if they don't report they fear the UPDF will kill them. The army is near towns, people living out in the villages are unprotected. If the rebels come for food they have no way to say 'no'.'

35. Neither the WNBF nor the LRA could have survived without using neighbouring countries as bases for their operations. The WNBF has used Zaire, establishing camps along the border west of Arua and north to Koboko, as well as Sudan, and is alleged by Ugandan officials to receive the backing of the Sudanese Government. The LRA uses southern Sudan as its base, and people formerly abducted by the rebels report this is where they received their training. The LRA's operations have intensified during 1996 and their weapons have become more sophisticated.

36. At the same time, there are continued allegations that the Government of Uganda supports the SPLA. Reports of direct clashes between the UPDF and the Sudanese Army are not unheard-of. The Economist Intelligence Unit, in its third-quarter report of 1996, states that 'during an encounter with the pro- Idi Amin West Nile Bank Front (WNBF) rebels in the Uganda-Sudan- Zaire border region, the Ugandan army was drawn into an artillery exchange with the Sudanese army - a reminder of the continued hostilities between Kampala and Khartoum.'

37. Diplomatic efforts aimed at normalizing relations between the two countries, the most recent of which were mediated by Iran and resulted in an agreement on 8 September, appear to have made little difference to the realities on the ground. One of the central tenets of the agreement was that neither Uganda nor Sudan would allow its territory to be used to mount attacks on its neighbour. Yet, less than a fortnight later on 22 September, Sudanese Government aircraft bombed Moyo, apparently targeting the army camp there. Sudan at first denied the attack, then claimed it was the result of pilot error.

38. The growing crisis in the north currently dominates debate at the Parliament of Uganda, where the Parliamentary Committee on Defence and Internal Affairs is conducting an inquiry into the war. The Committee has been mandated to do this by the passage of a motion in Parliament in August calling for the committee to 'urgently look into all aspects of the war currently taking place in Northern Uganda with the aim of bringing it to a speedy end.' Among the issues which the committee is expected to address are the 'cause or causes of the war', the 'reason or reasons why the war has taken so long', the 'various solutions available to end the war' and 'allegations of external support or influence'. The committee is expected to report to Parliament sometime before Christmas, and its recommendations will then be debated. Meanwhile, observers point to the appointment of Museveni's half-brother, Major General Salim Saleh, to the position of overall commander of the military operations, and Museveni's stay in Gulu during October, as signs that the President takes the conflict seriously.

CONCLUSION

39. The northern war is now high on the national political agenda, but will also be of growing concern to donors and would-be investors. Uganda's economy has been transformed over the past decade and during 1995/96 GDP was estimated to have grown by 8.2%, with 'a notable 18% expansion in manufacturing (the best for ten years) and an unprecedented 16% in cash crop agriculture.' (5) Yet while these achievements are recognized abroad, there is also concern that, as the Economist put it, '(T)he northern rebels are responsible for causing unacceptable levels of military expenditure and the problem of instability is diverting government energies from important development problems.'(6)

40. These issues were raised by donors at the recent Consultative Group meeting in Paris, where donor countries failed to reach agreement on writing off part of Uganda's $3.3 billion debt. The problems in the north and rising military spending were cited as areas of particular concern, with a World Bank statement saying that donors expressed 'considerable concern' about the northern war and 'urged the Ugandan government to explore all possible initiatives which could bring a satisfactory resolution.'(7)

41. The crisis in the north is now receiving the national political attention it deserves. Quick-fix solutions are difficult to envisage, given the complex mix of military, political and economic issues at stake. The regional dimension to the conflict is another central issue, implying that Uganda's relations with its neighbours will continue to be a major influence on how the situation evolves. The Parliamentary Committee investigating the war and seeking to come up with solutions is a most welcome initiative and deserves the attention and support of governments worldwide. It is very much to be hoped that its recommendations will foster initiatives which bring the conflict, with all its attendant human suffering, closer to an end.

REFERENCES

1. Oxfam UK and Ireland, 'Ikafe and Imvepi Refugee Settlement Programmes, Current Situation', 20.11.96. 2. As for 1. 3. Heike Behrend, 'Is Alice Lakwena a witch?', in Changing Uganda, James Curry, London 1994. 4. As for 3. 5. Economist Intelligence Unit, Uganda Country Report, 3rd Quarter 1996. 6. As for 5. 7. The East African, 'No Debt Relief for Uganda as Donors Argue', 25.11-1.12.96.

(UNDHA/IRIN would like to express its thanks to WFP for providing the practical and logisticial support which made this mission possible.)

(ENDS)
