47 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 48 on Eastern Zaire (12/04)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

Nairobi - Ugandan military sources say rebels in eastern Zaire have captured the town of Bunia, forcing looting and rampaging Zairean soldiers to flee further north. Reuters quoted the sources as saying the town fell on Monday night, and that yesterday rebels were clearing pockets of resistance. Zairean refugees, arriving in the Ugandan border town of Kasese to escape the fighting, said soldiers pillaged Bunia, beat up residents and raped women before the rebel takeover. Missionary sources in the area appeared to confirm the reports, saying soldiers were looting from Sunday onwards and by last night all the FAZ troops had left. Some sources suggest the troops may head for Isiro, over 350km to the northwest.

Renewed clashes broke out in western Uganda yesterday after Zaire-based rebels crossed over the border, the "New Vision" reported today. It quoted fleeing civilians as saying there was fierce fighting between Ugandan soldiers and some 100 rebels of the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF), who entered via Bwera. Ugandan military sources said there were casualties on both sides. The rebels invaded Uganda last month, but were pushed back into Zaire after a week of heavy fighting. 

Zairean premier Kengo wa Dondo has accused Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi of aggression against his country, aimed at setting up a "Tutsi empire", and called for the rapid deployment of a multi-national force to help "a million Rwandese refugees" in eastern Zaire. Speaking at the Congo summit of central African leaders yesterday, he also reiterated Kinshasa's opposition to food airdrops and to the establishment of the force's HQ in Uganda, saying it should be set up in Kisangani. Burundian leader Pierre Buyoya, in comments broadcast by Burundi radio yesterday, told the meeting the economic embargo against his country was the main obstacle to peace. Burundi, he said, was waiting for the world community and regional leaders to show "active solidarity." "The international community cannot bring about peace among the people of the Great Lakes without us," he said.

>From Congo, Buyoya has gone on to Ouagadougou in Burkina Faso to attend a Franco-African summit due to open tomorrow. Rwandan foreign minister Anastase Gasana, who is representing his country at the meeting, lashed out at UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros Ghali yesterday accusing him of presiding over "failure after failure." According to a statement, issued in Ouagadougou, he said that "under his mandate, Africa went through a horrible genocide, and that tragedy took place in Rwanda."

UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali maintains that a military multi- national force is still required for eastern Zaire, despite the fact that prospective participants want to scale down or scrap plans for troop intervention. In a report to the Security Council, he said the humanitarian situation in the region was undergoing "dramatic changes" and was likely to evolve rapidly in the coming weeks. He warned there must be no return to the " status quo ante" and above all no re-creation of refugee camps in eastern Zaire. The immediate concern, he said, was the fact that hundreds of thousands of people were still facing hunger, disease and death in eastern Zaire and the only practical way to avoid a humanitarian disaster was to establish some form of international military presence in the region.

The head of the multi-national force Lt Gen Maurice Baril stressed that fighting in eastern Zaire was changing very quickly and could be "extremely dangerous" for any force attempting to aid refugees. Speaking from Uganda's Entebbe airport yesterday, according to Associated Press, he said 13 countries had promised air assistance to the multi-national effort and the force would be increased to 460 in the next 10 days, in addition to the 300 US troops operating separately from Entebbe.

A question mark remained over the status of Kindu after Zairean rebels claimed today they had taken the town. However sources on the ground dismissed the claim, saying Zairean troops were in control. The rising insecurity and tension threatens limited relief operations mounted in the area. An ICRC update yesterday said the Committee was setting up a logistical base in Kindu where a group of 300 displaced people had already received assistance. A Zairean Red Cross truck carrying ICRC relief supplies left Kindu for Shabunda and a small ICRC aircraft landed at Kalima, between Kindu and Shabunda, to hand over relief items to the local Red Cross which is assisting some 500 displaced people. ICRC also said a team had managed to get through to Rutshuru from Goma. Further south, ICRC delegates reached Kalemie where over 8,000 people have sought shelter. They will receive assistance from Lubumbashi. Meanwhile, a source in Walikale confirmed the presence of large numbers of former Rwandan soldiers and Interahamwe militia and their families in the area.

Reports continued to filter through of the unstable situation in Kisangani. UNICEF pulled its last two staff members out of the town on Monday due to insecurity, Reuters reported. Steven Allen, UNICEF representative in Kinshasa, said that before they left, the staff members reported shooting between different elements of the Zairean army, apparently triggered by the arrival of wounded and dead soldiers from the rebel-captured town of Beni. At least 1, 000 soldiers, plus their families, are reported to be in the town and that number may be swollen by soldiers who allegedly do not want to be registered for fear of being sent back to the front. However the situation was described as relatively calm last night.

WFP said it was still waiting for authorisation from the Zairean authorities to conduct an airlift from Entebbe to Kisangani, but so far clearance had only been given to fly via Kinshasa - which WFP regards as an " unfeasible route".

The first UN/NGO team to visit Uvira since aid agencies pulled out on October 22 arrived in the town from Bukavu yesterday to assess the situation there. WFP said the team - comprising representatives from UNHCR, DHA, WFP, UNICEF, MSF, ICRC, IFRC - stayed overnight. Checkpoints were reported along the roads, but the road conditions were said to be good. Aid agency compounds within Uvira had been heavily looted, but the hospital appeared to be functioning relatively normally. All the refugee camps seen on the trip were empty. WFP said a request to visit the Uvira port would probably be granted later in the week. The border with Burundi is still closed on the Zairean side.

Some 1,500 refugees from Zaire are reported in the Congolese capital Brazzaville, 85 percent of them ethnic Tutsis mostly from the Kinshasa area. There are 10-40 new arrivals each day and WFP is preparing an assessment mission to the city.

WFP has said it is preparing for a possible influx of Rwandan refugees from Tanzania by prepositioning food at commune level in and biscuits en route. Reports say the Tanzanian government has ordered all Rwandan refugees out of the country by the end of the year. WFP said a meeting of the tripartite commission (UNHCR, Rwanda and Tanzania) was likely to take place in Ngara, Tanzania, or Kigali before the end of the week to discuss modalities for repatriating the Rwandans. The multi-national force successfully completed four airlifts carrying a total of 10,000 plastic sheets to Mwanza in Tanzania. The sheeting will be used by new Burundian arrivals further south.

Nairobi, 4 December 1996, 15:40 GMT

(ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

48 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Zaire;
WFP Eastern Zaire Situation Report No. 32


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Rome - UVIRA: A UN/NGO team (WFP, UNHCR, DHA, UNICEF, MSF, ICRC and IRC) visited Uvira on 3 December to conduct a brief assessment. The team met with the de facto authorities and were able to visit the town. While some WFP local staff are still in place, the WFP Office has been completely looted, as have the temporary warehouses. Access to the port was denied; however, the two cranes are reported to be more or less intact. 

Uvira town is reported to be very calm: markets have re-opened and are quite well supplied.

Commercial traffic on the escarpment road is reported to be quite normal. No refugees were seen on the road.

A further mission is planned Friday 6 December for a longer period (2 or 3 days). It is hoped that this mission can visit Fizi.

TANZANIA: Tanzanian authorities have begun visiting the camps to inform refugees that repatriation must take place imminently. 275 refugees registered with UNHCR on 3 December for repatriation, the largest figure recorded on a single day in the region to date.

The Tripartite Commission (UNHCR, Governments of Rwanda and Tanzania) will meet shortly to discuss detailed plans for the return of the majority of Rwandan refugees. No firm date has been set for this meeting.

Concerns continue regarding the nutritional status of refugees arriving in the Kigoma region from Burundi. The malnutrition rate for children under five was recently recorded at almost 19 per cent in Mtendeli camp, which has received approximately 40,000 new Burundian refugees since the beginning of November. WFP is sending additional quantities of CSB to Kigoma region for supplementary feeding programmes.

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION, PLEASE CONTACT WFP EASTERN ZAIRE CRISIS SUPPORT FACILITY (CSF): International Fax Line: 39 6 5228-2828 International Telephone Line: 39 6 5228-2535 Electronic Mail Address: ezaire@wfp.org

49 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
Zambian Writers Win Prizes


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - Journalists dominated the two national competitions on poverty and related activities which were sponsored by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) as part of the events to mark 'International Year for the Eradication of Poverty 1996'.

UNDP Resident Representative, Gary Davis, named the deserving writers when he gave out details on the outcome of the two competitions.

In effect the National Essay Writing Competition on the theme 'Poverty: Causes and Solutions' was divided into two catergories with the first catergory being for students from universities, colleges and other institutions of higher learning in the country while the second catergory was for pupils from secondary schools. 

Then there was the National Media Competition which was open to all Zambian based journalists, both local and foreign, for the best coverage of poverty issues and this was won by Bwalya Nondo of the Zambia Information Services who is running the Kafue Bureau.

In second place was Joe Chilaizya while Ntachi Sikaona of the Zambia Daily Mail scooped the third prize. Kellys Kaunda of Voice of America came out fourth.

In the National Essay Writing Competition , universities-colleges category, first prize was scooped by Cephas Moonga while the second prize went to his colleague Wilcliff Sakala. Both are students of journalism in the Department of Mass Communication of the University of Zambia in Lusaka.

In the secondary schools category the First Prize was won by 15 year old Stacey B Mtika who is a Grade 10 pupil from Fatima Girls Secondary School in Ndola. He was followed by 16 year old Juliet Tumeo of Libala Secondary School in Lusaka.

Mr Davis says the prizes will be presented to the winners at a ceremony which will take place in the United Nations Common Premises Building on Alick Nkhata Road near Longacres on Friday - December 6, 1996.

"I wish to take this opportunity to congratulate not only the winners, but all participants for the interest they have taken in exploring the issues of poverty and its solutions in Zambia today. I also wish very much to thank the various sponsors whose generosity has made this competition possible," he declared.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


50 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Science and Health;
No Mandatory Uk Aids Tests For Zambians - After All


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Lusaka - Zambian travellers to Britain will not require to undergo HIV/AIDS tests upon arrival there, Chief Immigration Officer Philip Mutantika clarified today.

The explanation may bring relief to most Zambians but it still leaves a bad taste in the mouth especially after receiving further 'punitive' news that one time friend of Zambia, Lynda Chalker, is now on a campaign trail lobbying the International Monetary Fund and World Bank to cut developmental aid funds to Zambia.

Mr Mutantika observed that the earlier statement by departmental spokesperson, Catherine Poso, was a slight misrepresentation of fact in that it was based on the information outline at the back of the 'Application for United Kingdom Entry Clearance' form JM2A (Revised 6/92) which reads in part:

"An Immigration officer can ask anyone to be medically examined on arrival in the UK if he considers it necessary. If you intend to stay in the UK longer than six months you may be required to have a medical examination before your entry clearance is issued." It reads in part. 

Mr Mutantika explained that this requirement does not make any medical examination compulsory to Zambian travellers nor any other foreign visitor to the United Kingdom adding that this is standard practice in many countries around the world and should not be misunderstood to be meant for Zambians alone.

He also dismissed suggestions that his department could have adopted punitive measures against British teeanagers explaining that the requirement that children under the age of 16 acquire visas before they can enter Zambia was a reciprocal one which was equally applicable to Zambian youths.

Mr Mutantika observed that in order to allow for a smooth transition the department to give a grace period of seven days from Monday - December 2 to December 9 in which British Nationals wishing to travel to Zambia can obtain their visas on arrival at any point of entry.

He dismissed suggestions that application forms were in short supply at Zambian Missions Abroad saying since Zambia has been issuing visas all along to various nationals there can be no shortage of these forms at embassies abroad.

The Visa row, as it has come to be known by the Zambian press was ignited by Britain when the local office announced that with effect from this year it will be become a pre-travel requirement for Zambians to have visas enabling them even to transit through the United Kingdom.

Though it was explained that the requirement was purely a follow-up to dictates of European Union requirements many Zambians were not convinced that the move was driven by a lack of harmony over what the Zambians themselves desired politically and what the British government wanted them to have as part of their colonial legacy.

Matters came to a head last May when bowing to growing internal pressure President Chiluba signed a Constitutional amendment which restricted the presidency to second generation Zambians and which in effect buried the leadership ambitions of former state president, Kenneth Kaunda, who only months earlier had been resurrected from the archives of history by his party.

Kaunda was unhappy with his exclusion and so were the clutch of brief-case, 'one agenda' portfolios masquarading as political parties and which saw Kaunda as their last chance of amounting to something.

Now that the people have at last spoken through the ballot most Zambians were hopeful that bygones will be bygones and that the strained relations will be mended.

But to their amazement the reverse appears to be true and hence sthe acceptance that the British government now simply wanted to humiliate them for no apparent reason by demanding that they undergo AIDS tests.

ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Business and Finance;
Fuel Prices Go Up As Zambian Farmers Mourn


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia National Oil Company Limited on Monday announced a fifteen percent fuel price rise which on Tuesday provoked a sharp reaction from farmers who feel the burden on them is greater.

A statement from ZNOC gave the main reason for the increase as 'increased costs resulting from the depreciation of the Kwacha against international currencies and the increase in the international prices of petroleum products'.

The 15 percent price increase has been slapped on petrol, diesel and domestic paraffin (kerosene) and the new prices took effect at midnight on December 2. 

But Zambia National Farmers' Union reacted by calling on government to exempt them from the universal national fuel levy as one way of reducing the impact of the increased fuel prices.

ZNFU Executive Director, George Gray, observed that though farmers had anticipated the fuel price increase as far back as October the new prices will, never the less place an extra burden on farmers who use considerable amounts of fuel particularly at this time of the year when the rains are re- appearing and the farming season goes into top gear.

The cost of fuel will impact not only on farmers cultivating the land but also on transporters who move food from farms to storage facilities.

"The end result will be considerably increased upward pressure on the price of food," Dr Gray lamented.

As a result of this the farmers were then suggesting that they be exempted from paying fuel levies which are included in prices of automobile fuel from the pump and which money is used to pay for the maintenance of the roads in the country.

The argument advanced by farmers is that most of their machinery and implements rarely leave the farms.

''The tractors that farmers use to work the fields seldom drive on roads and it is not right that farmers should be faced with a heavy charge to fund a service which they do not use," Dr Gray pointed out.

If the fuel levy was removed then both farmers and consumers would benefit as there would be lesser costs on the production of food and this would result in stabilised prices for the consumer.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Zambia;
Chiluba Swears In New Cabinet


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - The new Zambian cabinet was on Tuesday sworn into office at State House with a message from President Frederick Chiluba that he expects hard work and collective responsibility from all of them.

"Collective responsibility is important for all of us and even if a minister holds a different view once a decision is taken in Parliament, there should be no contradictions or divisions because this would make it difficult to run government," he declared.

Mr Chiluba also disclosed at the ceremony that he had nominated hard working Lusaka Province MMD chairman, Christopher Chawinga, to serve as a nominated member of parliament. 

In addition he has also appointed Zambezi West MP David Saviye to the post of Deputy Minister in the office of the Vice-President. He was until a few months provincial information officer with the Department of Zambia Information Services.

The other promotion is that of Mkushi South MP, Abel Chambeshi, who becomes Central Province Deputy Minister. Like Mr Saviye, Mr Chambeshi is also a former journalist who many years ago worked for the Zambia News Agency before he resigned to join the Times of Zambia.

In his timely warning Mr Chiluba revealed that several times he had been embarrassed, in his first term, by the tendency by some ministers to dissassociates themselves from collective decisions which they should have supported both in public and privacy.

The President also warned his cabinet colleagues against reporting for work late saying this was not a sign of seriousness in the work of government and it must be stopped immediately.

Punctuality among cabinet minister, he emphasised, reflected the seriousness of the nation to achieve set goals.

At the swearing in ceremony three ministers out-did themselves when they reported late though the function had been delayed by 30 minutes.

Mr Chiluba, however, expressed confidence in his new cabinet saying it has the capacity to deliver goods. He is expected to preside over the swearing in of Deputy Ministers on Wednesday morning.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


53 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


United States and Africa;
White House Welcomes Sierra Leone Peace Accord


BYLINE: White House


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Washington - Text of statement on Sierra Leone by the White House Office of the Press Secretary on December 2.

The United States warmly welcomes the peace agreement signed by President of the Republic of Sierra Leone Ahmad Tejan Kabbah and the leader of the Revolutionary United Front (RUE) Corporal Foday Sankoh in Abidjan on November 30. We salute President Kabbah and Mr. Sankoh for this milestone achievement that opens a new chapter of hope for all the people of Sierra Leone. This agreement ends a five-year civil war in Sierra Leone and creates the conditions which will allow over one and a half million internally displaced people and refugees to return to their homes. We also commend the Government of Cote d'Ivoire and the U.N. Secretary-General's Special Envoy to Sierra Leone, Berhanu Dinka, for their constructive roles in support of the Sierra Leone peace process.

We encourage the rapid demobilization and reintegration of both RUF and Sierra Leone military forces. An arduous process of rebuilding the country's shattered infrastructure and economy lies ahead. The United States will remain engaged with Sierra Leone's rehabilitation and reconstruction program by providing food aid and other humanitarian assistance. In the spirit of national unity, we urge all Sierra Leoneans to support the Government of Sierra Leone's efforts to achieve reconciliation and economic development.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


54 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


United States and Africa;
Clinton Reports to Congress on Great Lakes


BYLINE: White House


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Washington - Text of President Clinton's December 2 letter to the speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives and the president pro-tempore of the U.S. Senate, briefing both congressional leaders on the current crisis in eastern Zaire.

The humanitarian situation in Rwanda and the Great Lakes region of eastern Zaire has been a continuing source of international concern. Although approximately 600,000 refugees have recently returned to Rwanda from Zaire, the situation remains uncertain.

An estimated 200,000 or more refugees and displaced persons remain scattered in eastern Zaire likely without adequate food, water, shelter, or medical care. Repatriation is expected to continue in the foreseeable future. Urgent action may still be required, however, to supply essential relief to refugees and displaced persons still located in eastern Zaire and to assist those refugees that have returned to Rwanda. 

In response to United Nations Security Council Resolution (UNSCR) 1080 (1996), the United States plans to participate in a multinational effort, led by Canada, to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian assistance and to facilitate the voluntary, orderly repatriation of refugees by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and other humanitarian aid organizations as well as the voluntary return of displaced persons. Pending final consultation with our allies, I expect the United States to contribute personnel and equipment to the headquarters, civil-military affairs and psychological operations units, and other support elements as required.

In furtherance of UNSCR 1080 and the aim of the multinational effort, the United States has already positioned personnel and equipment in furtherance of "Operation Guardian Assistance" (approximately 400 personnel are currently in the region) to conduct non-combat missions, including airlift, air control, and related services in support of ongoing humanitarian efforts by Rwanda and private relief organizations.

Part of the U.S. assistance to the region has been helping locate groups of refugees and displaced persons to ascertain their movement and condition. The United States has used aircraft and other means in an effort to gain accurate and complete information. Although there has been sporadic fire from unknown sources at aircraft over-flying the Great Lakes region, including U.S. Navy aircraft, it is not clear that this fire was intentionally directed at U.S. personnel.

This past weekend the United States also deployed an AC-130U aircraft to the area to facilitate this effort through the use of aerial surveys. Although its primary mission is aerial surveys, the aircraft is fully mission- capable and will be available for search and rescue or other force-protection missions, if required. The aircraft will be based in Entebbe Airfield, Uganda, and will conduct aerial surveys throughout the Great Lakes region. The aircraft will remain in the area as long as aerial survey efforts are required by relief efforts.

The United States recognizes that the return of peace and security to the region will ultimately rest on the resolution of long-standing political and social differences and an end to the fighting. The United States is actively supporting the United Nations and the international community to achieve those ends.

Humanitarian concerns, however, require that the United States take immediate action to relieve the suffering of innocent victims of the regional instability until those long-term political and social differences can be resolved.

I have taken this action pursuant to my constitutional authority to conduct the foreign relations of the United States and as Commander in Chief and Chief Executive. I am providing this report in accordance with my desire that the Congress be fully informed, consistent with the War Powers Resolution. I appreciate the support of the Congress in this action to assist the international community in its humanitarian relief efforts in Central Africa.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


55 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. 'Deeply Concerned' About Zaire Rights Charges


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Washington DC - Statement by spokesman Nicholas Burns at the department's regular news briefing on December 3.

The United States is deeply concerned about allegations of human rights abuses in eastern Zaire by elements of the rebel alliance. Recently, there have been reports by refugees repatriating at Gisenyi of killings by rebel forces in northern Zaire, allegations of slayings of refugees in the southwestern part of rebel-held territory, and rumors of executions of Zairian officials in Bukavu, as well as allegations that returning young male refugees are separated before reaching the border, and disappear.

We call on rebel leaders to act immediately to investigate all reports of human rights abuses, halt any ongoing abuses uncovered, and bring to justice those responsible. Finally, we urge all parties to allow the international community open access to eastern Zaire immediately so that these charges might be investigated directly.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


56 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Welcomes Start of Liberian Disarmament


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Washington DC - Statement by spokesman Nicholas Burns at the department's regular news briefing on December 3.

The United States welcomes the beginning of disarmament of the factions in Liberia's civil war. The surrender of arms, which began November 22 in accordance with the Abuja Peace Accord, is an important step forward. Disarmament is the cornerstone of the peace process and the key to ending Liberia's nearly seven-year civil war. The United States commends the leadership, performance and commitment of the West African peacekeeping force, ECOMOG, in beginning the disarmament exercise. The United States calls on all factions and their leaders to continue on the path to peace at this critical moment in Liberia's history. We urge the factions to disarm fully and quickly, even before the January 31, 1997, deadline set in the amended Abuja Accord.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Coordinator Analyzes Great Lakes Crisis


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2760 words


 

Washington DC - Text of remarks, as prepared for delivery, by Richard Bogosian, State Department coordinator for Rwanda and Burundi, before the Subcommittee on International Operations and Human Rights of the House of Representatives Committee on International Relations.

I appreciate this opportunity to discuss the situation in the Great Lakes Region with you. The fast changing events in the region caused by the sudden exodus of refugees to Rwanda has shifted the center of gravity from concern over the refugee situation to the crisis in Zaire itself. The turmoil in eastern Zaire is both a product of years of neglect by the central government and the destabilizing effect of the former Rwandan Army and government-in- exile accompanied by a million refugees. 

RWANDA: POLITICAL SITUATION

Zairian rebel advances have released refugees from the grip of the former Rwandan Army and Hutu militias (ex-FAR and Interahamwe). The estimated 600, 000 refugees from eastern Zaire have returned to their home communes relatively peacefully. A Rwandan Government (GOR) no-arrest policy has been in effect with the exception of some notorious alleged genocidists who the government claims would be attacked if left in the community. Ex-FAR have been given identity cards and remain at large in view of chronic prison overcrowding. Rwanda is expecting the imminent return of the estimated 535, 000 refugees from Tanzania, who have also been intimidated about returning home. The GOR is operating under the premise that Rwanda's security is less threatened by opposition inside the country than from across the border.

The Rwandan Government remains wary of foreign intervention. It has, however, agreed bilaterally to give certain U.S. military personnel the same immunities and privileges as "experts" under our technical cooperation agreement. Rwanda is reluctant to agree to a Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) for a Multinational Force, lacking a defined mission or clear rules of engagement.

Our principal objective in Rwanda remains to assist the government in making peace with its neighbors, reabsorbing refugees, and the reconstruction of civil society, as well as contributing to rebuilding a justice system that will help Rwandans cope with the past and adapt to the enormous challenges of political reconciliation.

HUMAN RIGHTS MONITORS IN RWANDA

The U.N. Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (HRFOR) currently has 107 Human Rights Monitors in Rwanda, at an annual cost of about $12 million. The monitors are stationed throughout the country and maintain regular relations with provincial government authorities and military units. They visit prisons, make regular trips through their provinces, organize human rights awareness meetings in local communities, and regularly file reports with the Human Rights Field Operation in Kigali. If human rights violations are discovered, the HRFOR raises them directly at a high level with the Rwandan authorities. The government has transferred military officers and brought others before military courts for such violations.

During the recent influx of refugees, the Human Rights Monitors have played an important role in monitoring the conduct of Rwandan Army (RPA) troops along the return routes. They have reported very few violations, indicating the Monitors' effectiveness or the discipline of the RPA, or both.

The High Commissioner for Human Rights plans to deploy an additional 27 monitors to Rwanda by December 8, and 30 to 40 more by Christmas to deal with the immediate crisis. The High Commissioner hopes to have a total of 300 monitors in Rwanda by mid-1997, at a total annual cost of $30 million. The additional monitors are needed because the returning refugees include many who may have participated in the 1994 genocide, increasing the potential for ethnic tensions.

In addition to the $3 million the USG has contributed to the HRFOR in 1995 and 1996, the U.S. has pledged $500,000 toward support of the additional monitors, to be paid upon passage of the 15-day congressional notification period for reprogramming ESF funds. Eight million dollars has been pledged by European donors for the HRFOR in 1997.

EASTERN ZAIRE: POLITICAL/SECURITY SITUATION

As the refugees have returned into Rwanda or have fled deeper into the interior of Zaire, the rebel alliance now claims to be focusing on a broader agenda to wrest political power from Zairian President Mobutu. Their capability to do so is uncertain and we remain deeply concerned about instability or worse in Zaire. The alliance has allowed humanitarian organizations access to eastern Zaire under controlled conditions. It has only agreed to allow a handful of military personnel -- U.S. or Canadians -- to assess humanitarian needs in the area under their control and has made it clear it would resist Multinational Force (MNF) intervention.

The Ugandan government reportedly sent troops into Zairian territory last weekend to the town of Kasinde, which has effectively secured Uganda's border from Lake Edward to Lake Albert. About 100 missionaries, many of them Americans, have just evacuated Rethi near the Ugandan border, because of the conflict in the area. We are pressing the Ugandans to restrain their forces, even in the face of possible provocation by Uganda rebels operating from Zaire.

We are deeply concerned about reports of human rights abuses in eastern Zaire by elements of the rebel alliance. Refugees repatriating at Gisenyi tell of killings by alliance forces of military-age refugees in the southwestern part of alliance-held territory. Reports from Bukavu allege executions of government officials there. Limited access to some parts of eastern Zaire makes these allegations difficult to substantiate, but we have sent a strong signal to the alliance that it must exert discipline and bring a halt to any such human rights violations.

ZAIRE POLITICAL SITUATION

The crisis in the Kivus has emerged against a backdrop of Zaire's difficult political transition to a post-Mobutu era. President Mobutu remains in France recovering from surgery. His health and his return to Zaire remain uncertain. Though far away, Mobutu still plays an important role. A succession of Zairian and international figures continues to seek him out in Nice. Political posturing and maneuvering continue in Kinshasa. Last week, after a meeting with Mobutu, opposition leader Tshisekedi announced he had a mandate to form a government of National Unity. This was disavowed by close advisers of Mobutu and denounced by Prime Minister Kengo, who remains in charge of the government and has been doing a fairly good job under difficult circumstances.

The FAZ -- the Zairian Army -- has been thoroughly discredited in eastern Zaire, having fled in the face of rebel attacks. Tension is rife in Kisangani, almost 500 km west of Goma, where the FAZ is regrouping. Some reshuffling has taken place in the FAZ leadership and the army has vowed to retake the Kivus. Generals still could play a role in the future political dispensation in Zaire. As the Zairian Government (GOZ) rankles at Ugandan and Rwandan border incursions, there are reports that the GOZ may be seeking to hire foreign mercenaries to help the Zairian military. The unstable security situation in the East could be prolonged and further deteriorate should the Zairian authorities mount a counterattack to dislodge the rebels or if the rebels continue their advance.

The democratic transition, with elections scheduled for mid 1997, is at risk of further significant delays as a result of the security situation in the Kivus. It is likely local political leaders will resist proceeding with the elections until central government authority is established in eastern Zaire. We can expect key reform-minded leaders to devote less attention and political capital to maintaining the elections on schedule. More money will go to buy military equipment, less to support elections.

U.S. policy is to promote a cessation of hostilities between Zaire and the alliance and assist the repatriation of all remaining Rwandan refugees. We recognize Zaire's sovereignty and territorial integrity and urge keeping the democratic transition on track, including granting citizenship to the Banyamulenge and their inclusion, with other rebels, in the political process.

Zaire remains opposed to an MNF headquarters in Uganda; instead it favors direct MNF intervention in the Kivus to restore eventually Zairian control of the region. Zaire took strong exception to U.S. and Canadian officials meeting with rebel leader Laurent Kabila, as we sought access for aid agencies and survey teams to determine the location and conditions of refugees in the East. Likewise it opposes the concept of airdrops as " undignified," but wants humanitarian aid to flow from the West toward the refugees.

BURUNDI: POLITICAL SITUATION

Although the situation in Burundi has been overshadowed by events in eastern Zaire, the fundamental problems remain. The Tutsi-led self-proclaimed interim government remains in conflict with the predominantly Hutu National Council for the Defense of Democracy (CNDD), a conflict whose main victims continue to be innocent civilians. Both sides are guilty of human rights abuses, although recent reports implicate the Armed Forces of Burundi (FAB) in recent gross human rights violations.

Our goals remain the same: a negotiated cease-fire followed by talks aimed at the restoration of constitutional government. The regional states have imposed economic sanctions on Burundi although their effect has diminished since the July 26 coup. Our position remains that sanctions again the Buyoya government need to be calibrated to the progress made towards the goals set forth in the latest Arusha communique.

While the Buyoya camp has made some progress in partially unmanning political parties and allowing the National Assembly to meet, there is no climate inside Burundi for the conduct of free political activity. The president of the National Assembly continues to be harassed and has been denied permission to travel overseas. President Ntibantunganya has been in our ambassador's residence since before the July 26 coup. We do not believe that the present authorities are capable of ensuring his security nor will they allow him to depart the country immediately and unconditionally ..

MULTINATIONAL FORCE

The administration supports the Canadian proposal to establish the multinational headquarters for a humanitarian mission to Central Africa with a watching brief on eastern Zaire. The MNF mission under UNSCR 1080 was to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian assistance and the return of refugees to Rwanda. Given the mass repatriation of refugees last month and the scattering of those remaining, the scope of the mission has become substantially more limited than originally contemplated. Canada has established the rear MFN headquarters in Stuttgart and is in the process of setting up the main command post in Entebbe, Uganda. The small U.S. task force in Kigali has just relocated to Entebbe.

We are in close consultations with Canada on planning for airdrops to vulnerable groups; final approval of airdrops would require a consensus agreement by the MFN Steering Board. Lacking agreement from the Zairian government and rebel leader Kabila, airdrops remain problematic. Kabila is reserving agreement until he is informed of a large concentration of refugees in need. There is concern that relief supplies would fall into the hands of the FAR/Interahamwe.

We remain open-minded to an MNF operation with a clearly defined mission. On the other hand, we do not want to commit to an operation without knowing, for example, the whereabouts of the target population, for the sake of "doing something." Resolving Zaire's internal conflicts requires attention, but it falls outside the mandate of UNSCR 1080.

DIPLOMATIC INITIATIVES

Various initiatives are being explored to resolve conflicts in Central Africa and mitigate the social, political, and environmental impact of such conflicts.

(The U.N. Secretary-General's) Special Envoy Chretien has just spent four weeks in the region seeking solutions. He will submit his recommendations to the (U.N. Secretary-General) next week. I have recently returned from Rwanda, where I was in close touch with (the) Rwandan Government and also met with rebel leaders in an effort to get access and safe passage for relief agencies to reach refugees in eastern Zaire. The parties all committed to providing access. Special Envoy Wolpe has also been in the region, attending the Nairobi Summit and presenting U.S. positions.

African initiatives include a conference on the situation in Zaire/Rwanda called by Congolese President Lissouba in Brazzaville this week, which provided an opportunity for high-level Rwandan and Zairian contact. Both Zairian PM Kengo and Rwandan PM Rwigema will be attending the Ouagadougou Franco-African Summit December 4-6. With strong support from OAU Chairman Biya, Kenyan President Moi is setting up a Nairobi II conference of regional leaders later this month to seek solutions to regional conflicts. It is important to get the government in Kinshasa and the rebel alliance talking to each other to find political solutions to their problems. We are trying to do so.

We support the French and other nations' call for a well-prepared U.N./OAU- endorsed diplomatic conference to resolve the myriad political, refugee, security, and other problems facing Rwanda, Burundi, and their neighbors. One long-term result of the current crisis in eastern Zaire is a heightened awareness of the need to put in place conflict response mechanisms such as the U.S.-proposed African Crisis Response Force (ACRF). At the recent OSCE Summit in Lisbon, Canadian Prime Minister Chretien told leaders from 50 nations that the international community had shown it was willing to cooperate on the eastern Zaire crisis but needed to be prodded by a more solid framework for reaction. We believe the ACRF proposal would provide a solid alternative to ad hoc solutions.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia: The Week in Brief


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Addis Ababa - House approves Proclamation -- The House of the Peoples Representatives during its 13th regular meeting held recently approved a proclamation for re-establishing the Ethiopian Telecommunications Authority and referred two loan agreements to the Legal Committee.

The proclamation stipulates the establishment of an authorised body which overseas the efficiency of Telecommunication services as well as the formation of an agency and contains basic rules and regulations of the authority.

Meanwhile, the General Manager of the Environmental Protection Authority, Dr. Tewolde Gebre-Egziabher, told the House that Ethiopia and the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) would begin negotiating on patents for improved seeds discovered by the Ethiopian farmers, Dr. Tewolde said Ethiopia is completing preparations for the formulation of a draft proposal prior to the negotiations. 

Several environmental laws are under preparation, he said, adding that due efforts are required so as to push these laws into force.

The general manager also said Ethiopia is one of the eight countries across the world which are recognised as the home to various seeds.

Message of condolence

Heads of state and government from different parts of the world, Ethiopians residing abroad and officials of international organisations sent messages of condolences to President Negasso Gidada, Prime Minister Meles Zenawi, the Ethiopian People and Families of the bereaved, upon disaster caused by the plane crash. They expressed deep sorrow over the tragic death of passengers of the Ethiopian airliner that crashed on November 23 in the Indian Ocean near the Comoro Islands.

Meanwhile, the Ethiopian Insurance corporation (EIC) announced recently that it would pay full compensation to the Ethiopian Airlines, crew and victims of the air disaster that killed 125 people. The Ethiopian airlines will get full compensation for its aircraft which was insured against 40 million dollars (more than 250 million birr), EIC stated.

IGAD summit

Prime Minister Meles Zenawi returned home earlier in the week after attending the IGAD Summit meeting in Djibouti.

Member states of IGAD which gave top priority to conflict prevention, management and resolution reaffirmed the mandate of the OAU to Ethiopia to coordinate peace initiative in Somalia.

In a communique IGAD issued at the end of the two-day summit it said the revitalised IGAD with mechanism for conflict resolution management should work with the IGAD ambassador to monitor and coordinate peace efforts.

Ethiop-British relations

Prime Minister Meles Zenawi and Britain s Minister of overseas Development Baroness Lyinda Chalker recently held talks on bilateral relations and the condition in the Great Lakes Region, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Meanwhile, ENA reported that Baroness Lyinda Chalker recently reiterated her government's support to build the capacity of the House of Peoples' Representatives of the FDER and the national regional states.

During talks with Ato Dawit Yohannis, speaker of the House, Mrs. Chalker appreciated the way the Ethiopian parliament was organised and the devolution of power to regional states.

In another development, the governments of Ethiopia and the United Kingdom latter in the week signed assistance agreement amounting to 110 million birr to be channelled towards the education and road sectors. The agreement was signed by Mrs. Lyinda Chalker, British Overseas Development Minister, Ato Girma Biru, Minister of Economic Cooperation and Development and Woizero Genet Zewde, Minister of Education.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


59 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian Air Says Safety Record Not Tarnished By Crash


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The survival of 50 passengers from the crashed airlines flight ET 961 is a proof to the calibre and efficiency of the ETHIOPIAN and its pilots, winning the admiration of papers around the world as one of Africa's most respected airlines, General manager Ahmed Kello said.

"It takes an extraordinary talent to save lives while receiving punches under threats of all sorts by the hijackers forcing the airbus to divert to Australia even after being told that it has ran out of fuel," Dr. Ahmed told journalists.

Earlier last week, Captain Leul, the pilot of the hijacked airliner said: " I have tried to exploit my know-how and experience. I have nothing to regret about". 

The ETHIOPIAN has as usual continued its international flights after the disaster with no looked passenger cancelling his/her flights, the General Manager of the airlines said.

The airlines has build up its reputation, free of technical failures, constraints common among many of the airlines, flying wide as one of the safest in Africa, he noted.

Dr. Ahmed said: "This accident was not brought about by Ethiopian Airlines as such and it does not call the safety record of the airline into question."

The New Vision, a Kenya newspaper, in its Nov. 26 issue said: "The African airline Association defended Ethiopian Airlines, arguing the crash had nothing to do with its safety record".

The airline flies to 40 cities located in Africa, the Middles East and Asia in addition to the 40 destinations in its domestic flight.

Pursuant to its objective "Bringing Africa Together," ETHIOPIAN has over two third of its flight routes in Africa.

Among its destinations are included Abidjan, Accra, Athens, Beijing, Cairo, London, Frankfurt, Rome and New Delhi.

The highly modern aircraft maintenance centre has helped the EAL to become one of Africa's most respected airlines.

The centre, with 1,400 ground technicians, is recognised by the US Federal Aviation Administration, the British Civil Aviation authority and aviation supervision agencies in Europe, Africa and the Middle East.

Meanwhile, the airlines Sunday said identification of crash victims is well underway and the corpses will be delivered to their families in a week's time.

In a telephone interview with the Ethiopian News Agency head of the ETHIOPIAN Medical Department Dr. Ayinalem GebreMariam who is presently in the Comoros said the medical team dispatched to the Comoros is engaged in identifying and preparing the bodies.

Asked about the delay in evacuating the corpses, he said "we were first preoccupied with recovering the bodies from the wreckage, which have to be identified and this has taken time".

He further said the process of identifying the corpses from such a place crash with documents like passports and identification cards mission is a painstaking job.

The absence of experts at the crash site has complicated the identification process, he said and mentioned that the airlines has employed additional foreign experts.

Identification demands patience and is time consuming as it includes cross- checking of personal data obtained from families with marks on the bodies, documents and cloths the victims have present at the prayer service, has also laid wreaths, the radio it added.

According to latest information obtained from the EAL, bodies of 40 victims of the air crash will arrive here tomorrow morning.

According to the spokesman of the ETHIOPIAN, the corpses have passed through the identification process being carried out in the Comoros by experts the airlines has deployed.

The spokesman urged the five persons from each family of the deceased to granted permission, to appear at bole International Airport at 8 a.m. tomorrow and identify the bodies.

The extreme care taken in identifying and preparing the corpses was also meant to fulfill requirements in line with regulations pertaining to life insurance, he said.

There will be a special reception ceremony at the airport organised by the Ethiopian government, he added.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


60 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Ethiopia;
Council Collects Eight mln. Birr from Rents Monthly


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The revised rental on government business houses in the capital has enable the Region 14 Administration to collect about 8 million birr a month, the regional council announced Sunday.

A report of the Executive Committee presented to the 4th regular meeting of the council said the return to government safe of the public fund which used to be taken by individuals, would help facilitate the efforts to mitigate the socio-economic problems of the region.

The report said the abuse of justice by letting some businessmen operate with government subsidy in the form of low rent while others rent houses at market prices has now been abolished. 

Appeal hearing committee were set up at cobble and woreda levels so as to accommodate requests of some businessmen who claimed to have been mistreated, the report said adding, however, that the work has not shown progress according to expectations.

It also said decisions regarding the complaints would be made public soon because the kebele administrations have finalised investigations.

It, however, warned to take measures which it said are appropriate against those businessmen who have not yet entered into the new agreement.

The meeting, the began Friday, is deliberating on reports of various bureaux in the region, it was learnt.

Meanwhile Regional Finance Bureau said it has collected a sum of 104 million birr in revenue from income taxes and other sources during the first quarter of this Ethiopian fiscal year.

In a report presented to the on-going 4th regular council conference of Region 14, it was pointed out that although the money collected during the reported period is below the target, it has excelled by 16.45 million birr from that of the past budget year same period.

The stated amount of money obtained during the reported period has decreased by 15 per cent from that of the target, according to the report.

The report attributed the decrease in the amount to failure in implementing land rented and housing tax among others.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa-at-Large;
Belgium Gives One Million Dollars To OAU Peace Fund


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 781 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Belgium has donated one million U.S. dollars to the Organization of African Unity's Peace Fund for the prevention, management and resolution of conflicts in the continent. 

This was Belgium's second contribution since the fund was established three years ago.

The first contribution of 35 million Belgian franc (about 1.5 million dollars) was made in February, 1994.

An agreement on the donation was signed here Tuesday by Belgian ambassador to Ethiopia, Genot Alain, and OAU acting secretary general, Ahmed Haggag, according to a release by the continental organisation.

Commending the efforts of the OAU in peace-keeping in Africa, the Belgian ambassador said his government was determined to support the fund and work closely with the OAU.

62 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Mugabe Admits Doctors Are Underpaid


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe on Wednesday conceded his country's doctors are poorly remunerated but said sick patients should not be used as sacrificial lambs in bargaining for higher wages.

Officially opening the 47th annual general meeting and scientific conference of the association of surgeons of east and central africa (Asea), Mugabe said doctors should not be allowed to go hungry.

"There is good cause in our circumstances of developing countries for surgeons to appeal, request and demand the most of comfort which will enable them to operate effectively. they should not be allowed to go hungry. 

"Our doctors are not well salaried and we should take care of them if they are going to take care of us well," he said.

However, he said the recent strike involving some junior doctors and nurses showed lack of concern for human life in the country.

"Surely it can never be right to use the sick patient as our sacrificial lamb in bargaining for higher wages. The medical profession's first responsibility is to serve as a trusted agent of and adviser of patients," said Mugabe.

Junior doctors and nurses in Zimbabwe went on strike on Oct. 21 to press government for a general improvement on their conditions of service and an increase in various allowances.

The striking nurses and doctors have since been dismissed, forcing the closure of some wards in major referral hospitals in Harare and Bulawayo.

The ASEA incoming chairman, Prof. Ignatius Kakande of Uganda's Makerere university, said the relationship between doctors and money was complicated and intricate.

"The relationship has been represented by triumphant aesculapius who appears as an angel when attending a patient, as a god when he cures and as a devil when he asks for payment for his professional fee," said Kakane, who took over from Prof. Josephat Mulimba of Kenya.

"Given the fact that medical practice is an integral interpersonal relationship between the patient, the society in which we live and the doctor himself, the patient and society have also a duty to ensure that the doctor is facilitated to be able to perform his work efficiently and in peace of mind.

"A hungry doctor is unlikely to perform his duties perfectly. however, since the health of the man is priceless, the surgeon should only demand for his efforts a payment which is adequate and suitable to his personal and family needs," he said.

He said payment should never be so high as to cancel or neutralize the feeling of gratitude and the spiritual link which should be existing between the patient and his surgeon.

"The profession should not be turned into a market reality causing its dehumanization."

The association is composed of seven countries - Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Prof. Godfrey Muguti, who is president of the surgical society of Zimbabwe, said the annual meeting of the association provided a forum for members to discuss issues of mutual concern and share experiences.

Zimbabwe's Bonnie Mauchaza was chosen to be vice-president of the association.

More than 150 delegates from member countries are attending the meeting which ends on Friday.


LOAD-DATE: December 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 4, 1996


Mozambique;
Mozambican Judge Accused Of Murder


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - A judge in Mozambique has been accused of battering his domestic servant to death.

The Maputo daily newspaper, Noticias, reported Wednesday that the presiding judge of the Manica provincial court, Valentim Sambo, murdered the servant, only named as Joao, on Nov. 7, according to the provincial attorney's office. 

The office said the body of the dead man has not yet been found, but there are "credible reports" that it may have been buried or dumped somewhere in the districts of Gondola or Sussundenga.

Manica provincial attorney, Daniel Magula, told the press that investigations had brought to light evidence that Sambo did indeed murder his servant.

"From the investigations we have carried out, involving the competent authorities and statements from relatives and neighbors, there is no doubt that the judge killed the deceased," he added. "Whether he has hidden the body is irrelevant. What is relevant for us is that we have sufficient evidence to assert that the person was killed."

Magula expressed concern over the supreme court's delay in taking action. Despite pressure from the attorney general's office, the supreme court has not yet suspended the judge. Almost a month after the servant's death, Sambo is still in full power as the Manica presiding judge.

"There is a fight going on in Maputo between the attorney general's office and the supreme court, while the accused remains unpunished", accused Magula.

Africa News


December 4, 1996


Ethiopia;
Hijackers Identified As Unemployed Youth


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The three hijackers of the Ethiopian Airlines aircraft that crashed into the Indian Ocean close to the Grand Comoros on Nov. 23, were unemployed Ethiopian youths who had spent time in Djibouti, the Ethiopian News Agency (ENA) disclosed here Wednesday, quoting a government official.

They were identified as Alemayehu Bekele Belay, Matias Bekele Belay and Sultan Nur Hussein, the agency reported, without indicating whether the first two were brothers. 

The trio who were in their twenties, were said to have stayed in Djibouti, and returned to Addis Ababa recently.

The agency gave no information about their motives for commandeering the Boeing 767 flight 961, about 30 minutes after it left Addis Ababa for West Africa, and insisted on being flown to Australia.

Alemayehu and Matias were said to be high school drop-outs, while Sultan Nuru Hussein had completed training as a nurse in Djibouti. All three were unemployed.

Ethiopian flight 961 was heading to Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire, via Nairobi, Brazzaville and Lagos, when it was hijacked. It crashed into the sea when it ran out of fuel after a few hours, close to a resort beach in Moroni as the captain tried to ditch it.

A total of 125 passengers and crew of 37 nationalities perished in the plane crash Fifty persons survived, including the captain, Leul Abate, co- pilot Yonas Makuria and two hostesses.

The three hijackers were among the 125 victims of the crash.

December 4, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Women's Group Blames Traditional Healers For Child Rape


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean traditional healers who prescribe sexual intercourse with minors as an AIDS cure were blamed Wednesday by a women's rights pressure group for the increase in cases of child sexual abuse.

Nomsa Ncube, a female lawyer in Bulawayo, said cases of juvenile rape had increased by over 100 percent since 1995. 

"Traditional healers should be responsible, they are prescribing rapes of small children," she said.

However, a member of the Zimbabwe National Traditional Healers Association (Zinatha), Lettie Moyo, denied knowledge of such practices. She said that traditional healers who made such prescriptions were not genuine.

According to regional court records, 90 rape cases were heard between January and November 1995. However during the same period in 1996, 350 cases went through the same court over the same, 90 percent of them involving children under the age of 16 years.

Ncube said more cases were awaiting trial while others had gone unreported.

"This could just be the tip of the iceberg," he said.

In mitigation, some child rapists claimed to have acted on instructions of traditional healers.

66 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Cote d'Ivoire;
The Plight of Workers With HIV In Cote d'Ivoire


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Employees who live with the HIV virus that causes the incurable AIDS face a precarious life in Cote d'Ivoire where tales of mounting discrimination against such workers have just emerged.

According to a document obtained by PANA in Dakar, the discrimination is practiced under the collusion of employers, trade union officials as well as doctors.

This type of exclusion, in Abidjan, the country's business capital, was revealed in a paper presented at a recent international symposium on Social Sciences and AIDS in Africa. 

The gathering, held from Nov.4-8 in Sali Portudal, Senegal, was sponsored by the French Overseas Organization for Scientific Research (ORSTOM) and the Dakar-based Council for the Development of Social Science Research in Africa.

According to the paper's author, Laurent Aventin of ORSTOM, the discriminatory practices include the illicit testing for HIV and abusive job dismissals. He wrote that these practices "probably" exist in other West African countries.

World Health Organization statistics indicate that Cote d'Ivoire leads other West African countries in terms of HIV seropositivity.

As at May 31, 1995, Aventin wrote, Cote d'Ivoire had reported 25,236 cases of full-blown AIDS. The general seropositivity rate is currently estimated at 13.7 percent.

He found that employers engage in discrimination against HIV infected people to guard their firms against absenteeism or AIDS-related deaths among their workers.

In his paper, Vantin says the root cause of the discrimination lies in the non-respect of the medical secret by the various AIDS-testing centers in Abidjan.

This lack of confidentiality, the document notes, arises from the fact that only between five and six doctors possess specialized certificates in occupational health studies.

As a result, most the occupation health matters is handled by doctors who reveal the HIV status of workers to the people who employ them.

The ORSTOM document quoted a study by a female medical student who discovered that out of about 30 doctors employed by firms, 30 percent confirmed passing the results of their tests to employers.

Employers also get information about workers from hospitals, testing centers and the blood transfusion center. The practice of pre-employment testing is also mentioned in the ORSTOM study, although the Ivorian legislation does not demand for it.

Once an employee has been identified to be living with HIV, some managers in Abidjan negotiated for his or her voluntary retirement, sometimes using some trade union leaders.

Other employers look for faults by the seropositive worker so as to eventually legally sack him or her on the basis of those mistakes.

In his conclusion, Aventin makes an urgent appeal on Ivorian work places to stress on AIDS information and education to dispel the existing myths about the disease as well as its modes of transmission.

He also stresses the need to sensitize labor inspectors so that they can mete out punishment to discourage the ongoing discriminatory practices.

The author further urges the Board of the Cote d'Ivoire Medical Order as well as the country's juridical organs "to play a role of prevention, surveillance and punishment especially in situation of non-respect of the medical secret."


LOAD-DATE: December 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


67 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 4, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Boutros-Ghali Reacts To Biya's Message


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros- Ghali has no objections to other African candidates vying for the job he occupies, his spokeswoman said Wednesday.

"It's always been an open question that anybody can submit their own names to the Security Council," spokeswoman Sylvana Foa told UN correspondents in New York.

Foa was reacting to a letter from the chairman of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), president Paul Biya of Cameroon, urging interested African states to nominate other suitable candidates for the post, in addition to Boutros-Ghali. 

She said that Biya's letter did not represent a shift in the position of the OAU, which endorsed Boutros-Ghali for a second five-year term at its last summit in Yaounde last July. His current term will expire on Dec. 31.

"He (OAU chairman) is asking other heads of state within the OAU for their views on his proposal that other African countries be allowed to submit names directly to the Security Council while reaffirming that Boutros-Ghali is a candidate of the OAU," the spokeswoman said.

However, the U.S., which is opposed to another term for the secretary- general, interpreted the letter to mean that Africa has abandoned Boutros- Ghali and urged other African candidates to come forward.

"We were very pleased with the letter from president Paul Biya because in effect it now allows the Security Council to do its work," U.S. ambassador Madeleine Albright said Friday.

"It broke the logjam and we think now that we'll be getting names of African candidates," she said.

The council members have agreed to give priority to African candidates to ensure that Africa gets a second mandate like other regions which had produced a secretary-general in the past.

The process of selecting a candidate to be elected by the 185-members General Assembly has been on hold since Nov. 19, when the U.S. vetoed the candidature of Boutros-Ghali, who received the support of the 14 other members of the council.

Before the letter, the African group at the UN had consistently said that it was sticking by the secretary-general pending further instructions from the African leaders.

The group, after a three-hour closed-door meeting in New York Friday, reaffirmed its backing for Boutros-Ghali, in spite of Biya's letter.

Though no other candidate has emerged so far, several possible candidates, including the OAU secretary-general, Salim Ahmed Salim, the head of the International Peace Academy in New York, Olara Otunnu of Uganda and the UN under-secretary for peacekeeping operations, Kofi Annan of Ghana, are being mentioned.


LOAD-DATE: December 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


68 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 5, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Education Minister Resigns Over Examination Leak


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's education minister, Edmund Garwe, resigned Thursday, two days after admitting his 14-year-old daughter was responsible for the leak of a Zimbabwe Junior Certificate (ZJC) examination paper at the Dominican convent high school in Harare.

Citing what he said was the "shame and tarnish" that the leak caused, Garwe said he had requested President Robert Mugabe to relieve him of his post to which he was appointed six months ago.

"I think it was only honorable for me to take this course," he said and stressed that it was a sole decision which he made on Wednesday night and no pressure had been brought to bear on him from any quarter. 

Garwe's resignation became the second incident since independence in April 1980 that a minister has left cabinet voluntarily after being involved in a scandal.

In the first incidence, three ministers resigned in 1989 after being implicated in scandal involving the abuse of a facility to acquire scarce new vehicles.

Garwe accepted that his resignation was necessary to save the integrity of the country's schools examinations, some of which were now being localized from British universities.

"Professionally, there's no other way," he said. "Even if it were not the exams, I...would have taken that course of action. But the question of exams is very important because we are going to localize these exams."

On Tuesday, Garwe admitted in an interview that his daughter had accessed a ZJC examination paper which he had taken home after a meeting to discuss printing errors in the paper.

After the leak was discovered, he voluntarily withdrew the girl from sitting the examination.

He made a public apology which he also repeated on Thursday, saying he deeply regretted the sham and tarnish the leak had caused.

He admitted that the pressure on his family was unbearable and that his daughter had been most remorseful and had to be put under guard to prevent her from committing suicide.

Garwe is a former envoy to Nairobi and Washington, chief of protocol in the president's office and governor for Mashonaland east province before his appointment.

Asked about his future plans, he said: "I will remain a member of parliament. I think I will survive."

He said after he came out in the open about the leak, he had received overwhelming expressions of sympathy from the public although there had been others who called to say "we got you."

"Some of them had racial overtones," he added.

LANGUAGE: English

December 5, 1996


South Africa;
South Africa To Adopt New Constitution Next Week


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The South African President Nelson Mandela will Tuesday sign into law his country's long-awaited post-apartheid constitution.

The signing ceremony will coincide with the International Human Rights day, which is annually observed on Dec. 10. 

This follows the order by the Constitutional Court Wednesday that the final constitution may now be certified, after amendments on the original text.

Mandela said the court's judgement signalled the end of a chapter which had been started under the most trying times.

He hailed the constitution as "a fitting tribute to the sons and daughters of our land, from all political parties, who contributed in making every South African a signatory to this magnificent piece of history."

"For me personally," said Mandela, "it brings the satisfaction of witnessing the irony of the summation of a democratization process which commenced under the most restrictive conditions -- in prison."

In his judgement, with which all 11 constitutional court judges concurred, Constitutional Court President Arthur Chaskalson said the Constitutional Assembly's amended draft met all 34 constitutional principles contained in the interim constitution, and so could be certified.

Originally, on Sept. 6, the Court had sent back the Constitutional Assembly's first draft after rejecting certain aspects. The Assembly finalized its amendments and presented the new draft in November.

Swaziland;
Swazi Prince Bans Night Church Vigils


BYLINE: Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland (PANA) - Alarmed by a spate of crime, a Swazi traditional chief, Prince Mnikwa, has slapped a ban on religious vigils and services conducted by various churches at night in his chiefdom at Helelhele in the kingdom's north-western mountains.

Announcing the ban, the chief said these night ceremonies were boosting criminal activities in the area including mugging, robbery, rape, adultery and sexual frolics, which was promoting AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. 

Chief Mnikwa told the area's priests that he was aware young people easily indulged in sexual intercourse under cover of darkness outside the large tents in which the vigils and service were being held.

He said that such tents will no longer be allowed to be erected in his chiefdom. Should any priests or other christians infringe the ban, he warned, "they will not know what hit them".

Chief Mnikwa said that those who ignore the ban would have their tents seized, their churches closed down and be evicted from his chiefdom or fined two heads of cattle.The priests said they would pray for the ban to be lifted.
