Africa News


December 5, 1996


Zaire;
Nyerere Blames Zaire For Crisis In The Great Lakes


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

NEW YORK, (PANA) - Retired Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere on Wednesday blamed the Zairian government for causing the latest crisis in the Great Lakes region by seeking to expel the ethnic Rwandans who have lived within its territory for centuries.

Speaking in New York, at a roundtable organized by the International Peace Academy, Nyerere said that the ethnic Rwandans, called the 'Banyamulenges', had been living in eastern Zaire since the time that region was a part of Rwanda.

"They have always been there before the partitioning (by colonialist powers- Germany and Belgium)," he told an audience of UN ambassadors, representatives of UN agencies as well as journalists. 

"No government has a right to deny them their right of citizenship", said Nyerere, who has been the chairman of the south center since 1990.

He said that the Banyamulenges, as well as another group of Rwandans who were recruited by the Belgians to work for them in Zaire decades ago, were Zairians.

"They can't go back to Rwanda...they don't know where their ancestors came from," Nyerere said, adding: "Zaire is a huge country, it can absorb them."

The ethnic Rwandan Tutsis, joined by other discontented groups in the region, have been fighting the Zairian forces since October, forcing the 1.2 million mostly Rwandan refugees in the area out of their camps and creating a humanitarian nightmare.

More than 500,000 of the refugees have since returned to Rwanda, with an estimated 750,000 others still scattered in the hills around the area.

The former president said that the priority of the international force that had been approved by the Security Council for the region should be to help the refugees, most of whom are Hutu who fled Rwanda after the 1994 massacre, to return home.

"The most important job for the international community is to help the refugees to go back," he said "as long as they are in Zaire, they will constitute a potential security problem between the two countries."

On Burundi, where he has been facilitating peace talks, the Nyerere said that only negotiations between the government and the Hutu opposition group could end the crisis in the country.

Nyerere, who led his country from 1961 to 1985, warned that the economic sanctions imposed on Burundi following Maj. Pierre Buyoya's military coup on July 25, would continue unless the minority Tutsis conduct "serious negotiations" with the majority Hutu.

"As soon as it is quite clear that they are willing to talk, I will be talking to the east African leaders about relaxing the sanctions," he said. " I don't like sanctions at all".

Burundi's ambassador to the UN, Terence Nsanze, who attended the session, had said that the sanctions were hurting the country's economy and urged the leaders to lift them immediately to alleviate the suffering of the people.

In introductory remarks, the president of the New York-based International Peace Academy, Olara Otunnu, said that the roundtable, on the theme " Responding to the growing crisis in the Great Lakes Region," was part of activities marking the 26th anniversary of the academy.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


72 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 5, 1996


Ghana;
Ghanaians Ready For Saturday's Polls


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - About 9.3 million Ghanaians go the polls on Saturday to vote for a President and 200 members of parliament in the second general elections since the inception of the Fourth Republic on Jan.7, 1993.

The elections mark the first time in 30 years that a constitutional government will have served its first full term in office and the electorate offered the opportunity to decide on who rules the country. All the previous attempts at constitutional rule were cut short by military coups. 

The electorate will choose from three presidential candidates and 739 parliamentary candidates.

Those vying for the presidency are the incumbent, President Jerry John Rawlings, 49, whose National Democratic Congress (NDC) swept the polls in 1992 in an alliance with the EGLE Party and the National Convention Party (NCP).

This time the Progressive Alliance, as the party of the president is known, includes the Democratic Peoples Party (DPP) following the withdrawal of the NCP.

Former boss of the Internal Revenue Service, Professor Joseph Evans Atta Mills, is running-mate of Rawlings.

John Agyekum Kufuor, 58, is presidential candidate of the Great Alliance which comprises his New Patriotic Party (NPP) and People's Convention Party (PCP).

A lawyer and politician, Kufuor's chances seem to have been enhanced by the alliance with the PCP, a long-time political rival of the NPP. By that deal Kow Nkensen Arkaah, the estranged vice-president, is Kufuor's running-mate.

The third Presidential candidate is Dr Edward Mahama, 51, a medical doctor, who will be contesting on the ticket of the People's National Convention (PNC) which was founded by former President Hilla Limann.

Ms Dedo Mate, a broadcaster who was deputy minister of Health in Limann's government, is Mahama's running-mate.

The Electoral Commission (EC) has distributed 40,000 transparent boxes and about 10 million ballot papers to the constituencies.

In all, 136,000 agents of candidates will be manning the 20,000 polling centers.

Observer missions including those from the United Nations, the Commonwealth, the U.S-based National Democratic Institute, OAU and about 5,000 local ones will be monitoring the elections. John Larvie, Public Relations Officer of the EC, said that full results could be known within 72 hours of the close of polls.

"Hopefully, by midnight of the seventh, we would have known about half of the total results," he said.

It is expected that the election will be a straight fight between Rawlings and Kufuor.

A winner will have to win over 50 percent of the total ballots cast. Should any of the candidates fail to make that mark, a second ballot between the two top candidates will be held on Dec. 28, the EC said.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

December 5, 1996


Zambia;
Zambia Extends Visa Deadline For Britons


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - British nationals visiting Zambia have up to Dec. 9 to obtain a visa at points of entry, following the imposition of visa requirements for Britons. 

After that date they will be required to obtain a visa from Zambian missions abroad.

As members of the Commonwealth, British nationals did not require a visa to enter Zambia. But last week Lusaka imposed the visa requirement as a retaliatory measure when London issued an order requiring Zambians to obtain visas to enter Britain.

Zambian immigration officials were Sunday reported to have turned back some nine British nationals who arrived at the Lusaka international airport on a South African airliner without visas.

Africa News


December 5, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zambian Mining Company Has Big Loss Over Copper Sales


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines made a staggering loss on both sales of copper and cobalt resulting in a combined operating loss of K55, 539 million for the quarter ending September 30, 1996 against a profit of K40, 744 million in the corresponding quarter of 1995.

The major loss has resulted in the Board of Directors not declaring a dividend in respect of the quarter ended September 30 1996.

A statement issued by the company in Lusaka says the average sales realisation at K2.032 million per tonne for copper was 23 percent lower than the K2.649 million per tonne realised in the corresponding quarter of 1995. 

This means that total sales revenue for the quarter was K290, 125 million against K397, 364 million achieved in September 1995 representing a decrease of 27 per cent.

Sales from the ZCCM production amounted to 73, 575 tonnnes against 79,414 tonnes sold during the same and this represented a deficit of 5, 839 tonnes. Much of the problem has been placed by the company on troubles experienced by Tanzania-Zambia railway line which included a prolonged strike by workers.

Sales, including metal bought-in, were 94, 292 tonnes for the qurter compared with 133, 305 tonnes in the corresponding period of the previous year.

On the other hand cobalt production at 1, 155 tonnes for the quarters was 73 percent higher than the 667 tonnes produced in the corresponding quarter of the previous year due to the availability of high grade Nchanga cobalt concentrate.

Sales of coabalt at 1146 tonnes were also 125 percent higher than the 509 tonnes sold in the same period of 1995 reflecting improved demand for the metal.

Similarly the company chalked up results in revenue from sales of precious metals which amounted to K1, 491 million during the quarter, compared to sales of K448 million during the same period of 1995.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


75 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 5, 1996


Zambia;
Parliament To Start Business On Friday - December 6


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambian parliament starts its five-year journey tomorrow, December 6, following the controversial elections of November 18 which saw the ruling Movement for Multi-Party Democracy returned to office with a resounding majority.

Clerk of the National Assembly, Mwelwa Chibesakunda, gave out notification of the date last week and since Monday the new Members of Parliament have been milling around parliament motel for their registration, identity cards and other vital procedures.

The new national assembly, which is the second under resurrected multi- party rule, has by far the biggest number of political parties represented since Zambia gained political independence from colonial master, United Kingdom of Queen Elizabeth the second on 24 October 1964.

Other than the ruling Movement for Multi-party Democracy, which has 129 seats in the new assembly, the National Party too is represented with five seats and the Zambia Democratic Congress and newly formed Agenda for Zambia each of which has two seats in the assembly. 

Then there are also the independents, the ambitious politicians who defied their parties and stood for votes on their own 'recognisance' and who represent political inclinations ranging from MMD down to United National Independence Party, who in their wisdom had decided to boycott the November 18 elections.

But the combined total of these interest groups, which are against the MMD, is still less potent than it was in 1991 when there was only UNIP in opposition.

That time UNIP had 27 seats in parliament when parliament met for first business on 19 November 1991 against 123 seats for the MMD. Two years later oppositon seats rose to 32 after National Party picked five seats from the by- elections which followed its formation.

But by October this year when elections were being announced there were only about 30 seats in opposition hands after the see-saw competition for seats.

Political pundits in Lusaka are convinced that the total number of seats in political hands and those of the independents would have been higher had opposition UNIP not listened to the out-dated strategies of its leader, Dr Kenneth Kaunda, that they boycott elections.

With UNIP fielding candidates at least for the position of Member of Parliament it is assumed that many of the seats which the party had clung to over the past five years would have been returned to its grip while others which went the way of the ruling party could have gone to its collection.

Among the pressing business to be resolved tomorrow is the administration of the oath of office on all MPs. Then this will be followed by the election of the Speaker of the National Assembly who is the de facto president of the institution and his deputy.

Thereafter the MPs will be divided into their respective committees - each of which will take care of affairs of state. The new MPs will also be given some lessons on how they are expected to conduct themselves whilst in boundaries of parliament and at their living quarters - Parliament Motel.

After that they may break up for Christmas and the New Year holidays before reconvening for serious business in the New Year.

As the National Assembly meets tomorrow it will be doing so with a down cast face following the death of Itezhi-tezhi Member of Parliament, Dr Lumizu Shimaponda, who died in a South African hospital after an illness.

The Assembly will also be wondering which way the altercation over whether Zambia Democratic Congress should surrender its hard won seats in Western Province or not.

Incumbent Members of parliament for ZDC, party vice-president Dr Kasuka Mutukwa and Mr Walusiku Situmbeko of Nalolo and Nalikwanda seats respectively are adamant that they cannot surrender the seats on moral grounds.

After all, they argue, they were voted in all fairness and to deprive the people of these two areas out of childish party stands will be detrimental to the very foundations of democracy.

"It is therefore totally unacceptable and extremely dictatorial for any party member or a clique in the leadership of our democratic party to force eleceted MPs to abandon the people of Nalolo and Nalikwanda now or in future," Dr Mwauluka declared recently.

ZDC deputy secretary, Azwell Banda, had astounded the nation with his childish declaration that the two MPs should abandon the two seats won in elections because those November 18 elections were allegedly rigged.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


76 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 5, 1996


Zambia;
'It Is All Lies' - Elections Commission


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The Electoral Commission has reacted sharply to the decision by the independent newspaper, the Post, to credit unverified material to its name when opportunities were there for the newspaper to publish correct government records.

Electoral Commission Public Liaison Officer, Differ Mulimba, says there is absolutely no justification for the Post to publish falsified information when accurate figures were available. 

He observed that even during the peak electoral period most media organisations had found it necessary to send reporters to the Electoral Commission offices so that they could get first hand receipt of results from the field.

In this way the Post could have had accurate and verified provisional results which could have been supplemented by the actual results which are now on display.

Mr Mulimba suggests that political parties which are in doubt together with their candidates and members of the general public can inspect the results from the electoral offices in districts and compare them with those at the Commission's office to prove for themselves that the allegations by the Post were either genuine or not.

"The Commission will soon advertise the provisional results of the elections for inspection by political parties, candidates and general members of the public," he pointed out.

Mr Mulimba further observed that it had not been one of his organisation's wishes to reply to allegations from the Post on the provisional results of the November 18 presidential and parliamentary elections.

He maintained that at no time did the Commission change any results but merely verified them as received from the source.

In its lead story for Thursday the Post is claiming that the Commission had changed some results to please the government a thing which Mr Mulimba strongly denies.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


77 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 5, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Taiwan Loses 1 Big African Nation But Still Has 8 Little Ones


BYLINE: David Hecht, ENDA Press Service (Dakar)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

Dakar - While this month Taiwan lost the recognition of Africa's most powerful nation, South Africa, Taiwan and mainland China are conducting a diplomatic war not just about powers but numbers, in which the world's weak nations also count. And they are likely to continue to play one China off against the other. They stand to gain millions.

Many nations may think that China's claim to Taiwan is little more than brute expansionism. Yet eager to increase their exports, industrialized countries now recognize China and its huge markets. Not so, however, the 29 mostly impoverished countries of Africa and Central America. They have few exports. For them Taiwan has something more enticing than markets -- money. 

Between 1990-95 Taiwan provided $400 million in official overseas development aid, not to mention military assistance, technical cooperation and plenty of unofficial kickbacks. China calls Taiwan attempts to win recognition 'dollar diplomacy.' For Taiwan it says it just wants to be accepted back into United Nations.

This month saw two fresh blows to Taiwan's diplomatic dream. One, the announcement that the US and China will exchange presidential visits over the next two years. The other, that South Africa, one of Taiwan's oldest supporter (but also Africa's largest exporter) slipped into the China camp.

Eight African countries do still recognize Taiwan, some having only switched in recent months. Liberia is one that maintains relations with both Chinas with the various rebel governments each recognizing one or the other.

In the Gambia, Chairman Captain Yahya Jammeh recognized Taiwan soon after coming to power in military coup in 1994. In exchange he got funding for his tiny country's revolution, to the tune of $30 million, which is about a third of his government's annual expenditure.

Ironically, while capitalist governments flirt with communist China, revolutionary governments seeks support from capitalist Taiwan. Taiwan even funded Gambia's new July 22 revolutionary arch, which looks like a throwback from China's cultural revolution.

In nearby Guinea Bissau, the once staunchly Marxist government also recently switched from China to Taiwan but only after dropping most of its ideological rhetoric. In Burkina Faso too, the revolutionary military government only made the switch a few years ago after assassinating its charismatic leader.

Some African countries, trying to cut the best possible deals, have switched sides several times. Earlier this year Senegal flipped back to Taiwan for the third time. Senegalese officials are reported to have received millions of dollars in their foreign bank accounts. The government will also receive at least $50 million for two projects the government had been promising its people for decades.

In Senegal and The Gambia the move to Taiwan came at a particularly unfortunate time for China. It had invested heavily in both countries, in each case donating giant sports stadiums just before storming out.

But while Chinese diplomats all left, Chinese business has quietly stayed. China donated the buildings to gain diplomatically but, at the same time, it also set up commercial construction companies to gain financially as well. The companies employ mostly low paid Chinese workers and can often outbid African and Western companies. ''They may no longer have diplomatic relations with us but they are winning all the major public and private contracts,'' said an unemployed Senegalese architect.

Also, China has developed its own form of 'dollar diplomacy' and it is effective, particularly with governments of questionable repute like Nigeria, Sudan and Zaire. China is reported to have given a 'gift' of $3.6m to Zaire in September and offered $10 million for a joint mining venture. In Sudan it also announced an investment of $24 million in gold mining, despite UN Security Council sanctions to counter that country's terrorist activities.

Taiwan is certainly feeling China's pinch. This year Niger also went back to China after only four years with Taiwan and, according to Andrew Yang of the Taipei-based Chinese Center for Advanced Policy Studies, Botswana and Swaziland, which currently recognize Taiwan, may not do so for long, implying that other African countries may also follow South Africa's lead.

But not all analysts agree. Some even question whether improved ties between Washington and Beijing automatically mean Taiwan's interests will be sacrificed. They say China's president, Jiang Zemin, is so anxious to have a state visit with President Clinton to shore up his standing within the Chinese Communist Party that he will try to reduce conflict with Taiwan for fear of jeopardizing the meetings.

Taiwanese officials like to point out that the number of countries that recognize it has been growing. In 1971 when Taiwan was first excluded from the UN ''South Africa was the only African country,'' said Hein-Sheng Hsu, a senior Taiwianese official in the Senegalese embassy. ''Yes we have now lost South Africa but there are plenty of other African countries and we fully expect many to look our way,'' he said.

Mr. Hsu claimed that while ''China has markets, Taiwan can show poor countries how to create the exports for those markets,'' pointing out that his country, not China, is what most developing countries hope to emulate. ''Our technical assistance is far more valuable than markets or money,'' he said, though asked whether these poor countries may go back to China once Taiwan helps them develop, he admitted that ''No man knows what the future holds.''

The Gambia's young president visited Taiwan for the first time this month. He pledged to strengthen bilateral ties between the two countries while Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, announced further aid packages to The Gambia. President Jammeh, who said that American-style democracy is not suited to African people, also said it is unfair for Taiwan to be excluded from the United Nations because, unlike China, it is ''a model democracy,'' and because it is so willing to assist developing nations build their economies.

Jammeh stressed that his country's friendship with Taiwan is not based on money. "Friendship comes from the bottom of the heart and not from the pocket. Friendship based on money will be short-lived," he warned.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


78 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 5, 1996


Zaire;
Dateline No. 9 on Eastern Zaire.


BYLINE: Action by Churches Together(ACT)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Geneva - Tanzanian authorities late today announced that Rwandan refugees would have to return by the end of this month. The Tanzanians also stated that they would not send anybody back by force.

In preparation for a major return of refugees from Tanzania ACT has been propositioning food, plastic sheeting and other relief items along with transport vehicles in Kibungo, Rwanda. ACT/LWF is aiming at being able to assist up to 100.000 returnees in way stations and transit camps in Rwanda across from major refugee camps in Tanzania. Tanzania is currently host to some 530.000 Rwandan refugees (UNHCR figure). 

By Wednesday UNHCR in Kibungo had registered only 618 returnees from Rwanda but the likelihood of a major return has increased dramatically with the announcement today. >From Tanzania ACT has learned that officials there have been informing the refugees informally about their return for quiet some days already. A cancellation of the "group determination" under which most were automatically regarded as refugees in Tanzania, will probably "trigger" a major return as this will seriously affect the service to the refugees in the camps by UNHCR and NGOs. A large proportion of the refugees now living in Tanzania are from Eastern parts of Rwanda e.g. Kibungo Prefecture.

In several parts of Rwanda ACT partners continuously work with facilitating the return of the refugees who have arrived from Zaire. In all together 19 communes of Kibuye, Gitarama, Umutara and Kibungo Prefectures ACT is doing distributions of one months rations of food (maize, peas, biscuits, oil & vegetable seeds) along with plastic mats & sheeting, hoes, blankets, jerrycans, kitchen sets and soap to returnees. In Gitarama ACT is also involved in construction of houses for either refugees or people having to evict homes belonging to returnees. As of today there are 8.000 returnees in Kibuye, 20.000 in Gitarama. Kibungo has seen 4.184 returnees from Zaire apart from the recent Tanzanian arrivals mentioned above. UNHCR reports that 800 refugees returned to Rwanda through Goma Wednesday.

ACT continue relief efforts for Zairian displaced in Kivu Despite press reports to the opposite ACT sources today report the Eastern Zairian town of Kisangani calm. ACT partners there are planning to part take in a larger convoy tomorrow to the town of Lobuto south-east of Kisangani. 25.000 internally displaced Zairians and some Rwandan refugees are assumed to be in and around Lobuto. ACT partners NCA and CEPZa/CELPa is preparing to take food and medicine to Lobuto for immediate emergency work to be implemented now and followed up by further supplies in coming days. Elsewhere in Eastern Zaire the rebel forces apparently are still on the advance. The rebel Alliance claim to have taken Kindu as well as being on the outskirts of Kisangani. This has not been confirmed by sources on the ground. If they were to take over control of Kindu they would control part of the important Zaire river - a major supply and trade line to Eastern Zaire. Kisangani too would be of major importance - not least from a military and morale point of view.

ACT partners have assessed the situation in and around Bukavu with local churches there and are preparing to step up work for displaced in near future. One ACT partner is already involved in running a basic health clinic in Bukavu for the local population.

Additional information

In addition to our chronology on activities in Rwanda in Dateline no 8 it should be mentioned that ACT partner NCA/Nairobi contributed 128.5 metric tons of emergency biscuits, 10,000 collapsible jerrycans, 720 rolls of plastic sheeting and 12.000 blankets from stores in Nairobi and Kampala for use by ACT partners in Rwanda. ACT regional and local co-ordination is taking place in both Kigali and Nairobi. The meetings are attended by ACT partners like LWF, WCC, AACC, Conseil Protestant du Rwanda, CEPZa/CELPa, UMCOR, CWS, DDW, NCA, CA and CSA. Coordination is also taking place with Caritas and CRS as well as the UN system and NGOs working in the Great Lakes region.

Action by Churches Together(ACT) is a worldwide network of Churches and their related agencies meeting human need through co-ordinated emergency response and common identity. The ACT network is organizationally based in the Lutheran World Federation(LWF) and the World Council of Churches(WCC) and is a co-ordinating rather than operational office.

Ecumenical Centre / 150, route de Ferney / P.O. Box 2100 / 1211 Geneva 2 / Switzerland. Phone: ++41-22-791.60.33 / Fax: ++41-22-791.65.06 / E-mail: act@wcc-coe.org / Telex: 415 730 OIK CH.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


79 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 5, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 49 on Eastern Zaire (12/05)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1814 words


 

Nairobi - Despite rumours that Kindu had fallen to the rebels, residents said yesterday it was still in government hands. According to Reuters, local people described Kindu as a "virtual military fortress" with large numbers of soldiers in town.

There is speculation that rebels are announcing the capture of towns to throw Zairean troops off balance and frighten them out. ICRC pulled its last two staff members out of Kindu for security reasons yesterday. In a statement, ICRC described the situation as "precarious" and said it had been the only international aid organisation working in the region for weeks.

Displaced Zaireans arriving in Kindu to escape fighting were reported to be in extremely poor health. The statement cited the example of an exhausted nineteen year-old girl who arrived from Bukavu with her six-month old baby too tired to speak and suffering from malaria, dehydration, malnutrition and shock. She had wandered around without help for weeks. The statement also expressed concern over tens of thousands of civilians, displaced people and refugees in the Shabunda area who have been deprived of humantarian assistance for weeks. 

The situation in Kisangani is still unclear, but some media reports say the local military authorities have begun disarming soldiers who arrived from the Kivu region. These soldiers have been creating insecurity in the town due to food-related problems. More soldiers are said to be arriving from the direction of Walikale, along with their families, and attempts to disarm the Kivu soldiers appear to be increasing tension in the town. Reports say that until the Kivu soldiers have been definitively disarmed and fed, humanitarian aid in the area risks being looted and security for international staff cannot be assured.

Zaire has called on the UN to stop what it describes as Uganda's armed incursions into Zairean territory. In a statement to the Security Council, dated 1 December, it accused the Ugandan army of "involvement in the war which Rwanda is imposing on Zaire". The statement, signed by Zairean deputy premier and Interior Minister Gerard Kamanda wa Kamanda, said Ugandan troops entered Zaire on November 30 by way of the Kasindi border point. The incursion followed repeated attacks against Zairean territory by the Ugandans earlier in the year, the statement added. It denied Zaire was backing Ugandan rebels of the Allied Democratic Front (ADF). The statement said that because of its "involvement", Uganda should be disqualified from serving as a base for the multi-national force (MNF). It urged the Security Council and Secretary-General to take "energetic measures" against Uganda's "incursions". In Kinshasa, the authorities have reiterated that the MNF should be stationed on Zairean territory and that any aid flights should go via Kinshasa for reasons of cargo verification.

A report in the Ugandan 'New Vision' newspaper today said 50 rebels were killed in the mountains of Kasese province during heavy fighting yesterday. Rebels of the Allied Democratic Front infiltrated from Zaire on Monday night and rampaged through the Kanyansi area, setting houses on fire, the newspaper said. It quoted military sources as saying the rebel "remnants" fled back to Zaire and Ugandan soldiers were conducting mopping up operations. Hundreds of exhausted displaced people trekked to Bwera trading centre, about 10 kms away from Kanyansi, the paper said. Three civilians were reportedly wounded in the crossfire. Five Ugandan soldiers were also injured. Meanwhile, presidential adviser Maj Gen David Tinyefuza resigned over remarks criticising the government's handling of the rebellion in the north, the independent daily 'Monitor' reported today.

UN Special Envoy Raymond Chretien, who met President Mobutu in the south of France yesterday, said the Zairean leader was "the only one who can deal with the situation" in eastern Zaire. According to Chretien, Mobutu himself wanted to return home. "Zaire is ready to play its role again and does not intend to use an 'empty chair' policy, Mr Mobutu has assured me," Chretien added. He said Mobutu was in charge of all important decisions concerning the country and that the Zairean leader had stated his readiness for talks with Rwanda.

Rebel leader Laurent Kabila called on Mobutu to resign. In a 27 page open letter, he claimed that the "incompetence" of the Mobutu regime was comparable to "natural disasters such as droughts, floods and earthquakes." At least the bombing of Hiroshima, Nagasaki and Nazi Germany did not destroy the sociological basis on which their societies were founded, AFP reported him as saying. Meanwhile, the rebels yesterday announced the defection to their side of a senior Zairean officer. According to AFP, rebel security adviser Jean Kabongo said Lt Col Lokilo Nene Boseka had gone over to the rebels and was preparing an appeal to fellow officers to follow suit.

There are indications that life is inching towards normality in rebel- captured territory. An Associated Press article yesterday spoke of crowded markets, the sale of farm produce and businesses re-opening their doors. The report gave the example of Goma, where there was a "growing sense of optimism" . Water was again being supplied for part of the day and electricity would soon be restored.

The Franco-African summmit, opening in Burkina Faso today, has prepared a draft declaration on the Great Lakes crisis, although the topic is not officially on the agenda. The declaration stresses the inviolability of Zaire's borders. AFP said the declaration was drafted during 12 hours of preparatory talks late Tuesday which were peppered by charged encounters between the representatives of Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi and Tanzania. A regional meeting in Brazzaville, Congo, on Tuesday appeared to yield few results and was boycotted by both Rwanda and Uganda. A final communique called for lifting regional economic sanctions against Burundi "noting steps taken by the Burundian government towards re-establishing democracy."

Rwandan President Pasteur Bizimungu warned that the road ahead would be difficult and that the emphasis now must be on rebuilding Rwanda, both materially and psychologically. In a presidential message, broadcast by Rwandan radio last night, he said there was no alternative to "unity to write our country's history afresh". Bizimungu announced that committees would be set up at all levels, in which the church would be involved, aimed at reconstructing the country.

UN human rights monitors in Rwanda say they have received reports of Rwandan returnees killing genocide survivors. A UN spokeswoman on Tuesday, quoted by Reuters, said the head of the UN Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda Javier Zuniga had called for a thorough investigation into the incidents and for follow-up action. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Jose Ayala-Lasso, is due in Kigali today for a three-day mission. So far, some 2,000 ex-soldiers have been registered and 38 people arrested.

A UNHCR nutrition survey indicated that the refugees who have returned to Rwanda are generally in good health, but they are worried about food shortages and housing issues. The UNCHR's daily update pointed out that the next harvest will be in February and local authorities are predicting difficulties ahead. A seven-day food ration, which returnees collect after registration, consists of 400 grams of flour, 120 grams of peas or beans, 20 grams of oil, 5 grams of salt and some biscuits. The Rwandan government has offered new plots of land to people who have to leave their houses so that returning owners can move back in, Reuters reported. The authorities have set a 15-day deadline for families to move out after registration by the rightful owners, but the government was due to initiate a housing programme today to lessen the impact. "The aim of the house-building programme is not for people to wait for government to build them houses, but to foster a spirit where people will not leave vulnerable groups stranded on the hillside," said Christine Umutoni, deputy rehabilitation minister.

UNHCR has urged Rwandan refugees in Tanzania to start making preparations to return home as soon as possible, after the Tanzanian government's demand that they leave the country by the end of the year. The government had informed UNHCR it was confident the refugees could return to their country in safety and that the repatriation would be conducted in an orderly and humane manner under the aegis of the Home Affairs Ministry. WFP said the Tanzanian authorities had begun visiting the camps to inform refugees that repatriation must take place imminently. On Tuesday, over 230 refugees were repatriated to Rwanda, which UNHCR described as the biggest figure in a single day. It said the figure almost equalled the number of returnees for the whole of October. More refugees were expected to return today. The Rwandan government, in conjunction with UNHCR, was making preparations for the returnees. Unconfirmed reports cited an NGO as saying yesterday that refugees from the Ngara camps were gathering at the border waiting to cross to Rusomo.

Nairobi, 5 December 1996 15:40 gmt

(ENDS)

UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


80 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 5, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Prepared to Help in Zaire Crisis, Official Testifies


BYLINE: U.S. Department of Defense


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Washington DC - Following is the prepared text of Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for African Affairs Vincent Kern, in testimony December 4 before the House of Representatives Subcommittee on International Operations and Human Rights.

Thank you for the opportunity to be here today to discuss the refugee situation in eastern Zaire and Rwanda.

After several weeks of massive refugee repatriation, we see many signs of progress and hope. More than 620,000 Rwandan refugees have returned home over the past month. U.N. humanitarian agencies and NGOs/PVOs are slowly re- establishing their operations in eastern Zaire and now have access to a 70 KM area around Bukavu and 30 KM radius around Goma. Earlier this week, for example, UNHCR organized the successful return of about 15,000 refugees from a remote site north of Bukavu. Nevertheless, after nearly a month of continuous, extensive aerial reconnaissance, we have located three large concentrations of refugees and internally displaced persons that may number up to 240,000. Although we do not have evidence to support it, several international groups insist that an additional 250,000 may be unaccounted for. We continue to conduct daily reconnaissance missions in a thorough attempt to locate refugee concentrations in eastern Zaire. 

When the humanitarian crisis initially exploded in late October, the United States quickly took the lead and helped to organize an international response. Our efforts culminated in UNSCR 1080 that authorized the establishment of a multinational force (MNF) with the mission to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian assistance and the voluntary repatriation of Rwandan refugees and Zairian internally displaced persons. For its part, DoD played an important role. Anticipating a major humanitarian relief operation under UNSCR 1080, we promptly prepositioned assets and personnel to the region in order to establish an airbridge and facilitate repatriation. We quickly initiated extensive aerial reconnaissance and passed this information to locally based humanitarian agencies and to UNHCR. We also quickly deployed to the region our Humanitarian Assistance Survey Team (HAST) from the European Command that immediately engaged regional governments and humanitarian organizations. When the President agreed in principle to participate in the U. N.-authorized MNF, DoD earmarked units and prepared to dispatch nearly 4,000 soldiers to eastern Zaire in order to secure regional airfields and maintain a humanitarian corridor. Then, we joined military planners from more than twenty-five countries and international organizations at our European Headquarters in Stuttgart last month and developed a general framework for a military concept, a mission statement, and five possible response options to the crisis.

Last Friday in Ottawa, the Canadians hosted the first meeting of the MNF Political Steering Board. In addition to standing-up the MNF HQ, the Board agreed to include planning for the aerial delivery of emergency humanitarian food supplies, or airdrop, in eastern Zaire as a possible MNF mission. As Secretary Perry stated publicly last week, if airdrops are necessary and if the Steering Board agrees, DoD intends to play a significant role. Some in the international community have expressed doubts about the usefulness of airdrops and urge them only as an absolute last resort. Based on earlier experiences, they indicate that airdrops are inaccurate, present serious physical risks to target populations, and will serve only to strengthen the control of ex-FAR/Interahamwe over vulnerable refugee groups. While we share many of their concerns, DoD is actively looking at the feasibility of performing airdrops as part of our ongoing efforts to support international relief operations in the region.

Meanwhile, the MNF Force Commander, Lt. Gen Maurice Baril, consulted with regional governments and received approval to establish his MNF Headquarters in Uganda with a forward Headquarters in Kigali and a rear HQ in Stuttgart. He is also working with regional governments to obtain a Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) and with us and other international troop contributors to develop appropriate rules of engagement (ROE). The Joint Staff has been working actively with the Canadians to develop comprehensive command and control arrangements. While we await a final decision on U.S. military participation, I can assure you that our forces will remain under the command of a senior U.S. military officer. Once Gen. Baril concludes these negotiations, we stand ready to participate in the MNF.

Today, we have 446 personnel in the region, including 328 in Entebbe, 22 in Kigali, and 96 in Mombasa. We have a Joint Task Force headquarters staff, a TALCE, three reconnaissance aircraft, and force protection units in Entebbe; a small forward headquarters, a Civil-Military Operations Center, and a media information team in Kigali; and a TALCE in Mombasa. With an airbridge and civil-military elements in place, our forces are ready to assist with humanitarian relief operations and to fashion a comprehensive media campaign message with UNHCR that will facilitate refugee repatriation and resettlement.

We will continue to consult with Congress as details of the mission are finalized. Pending your questions, I thank you.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


81 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 5, 1996


Ethiopia;
Investors import goods worth over 30 million birr


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

MAKALLE (ENA) - The Tigray Region investment office says investors in the regional state have imported goods worth over 30 million birr free of tax over the past three years. 

Production and construction machineries as well as spare parts were among the tax exempted goods imported by the investors.

Efforts are being made to ensure that the goods are used for the desired purpose, but such control has not been effective due to shortage of man power, the office said.

Most of the 330 investors in Tigray Region are engaged in the agricultural sector while others in the areas of engaged in the areas of hotel, mining, construction and industry and transport.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


82 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 5, 1996


Ethiopia;
ERO , ESRDF sign aid agreement


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 133 words


 

BAHIR DAR (ENA) - The Ethiopian Relief Organisation (ERO) and the Ethiopian social Rehabilitation and Development Fund (ESRDF) signed an aid agreement on Monday involving one million birr to be expanded on safe water projects to be carried out in 1997.

The fund would go to sinking 30 hand bumped water wells and developing 11 springs in south and North Gondar and Semen and Wag Himra zones, according to ERO s public relation officer Belisti Fente.

Over 18,000 people will have access to safe water upon completion of the projects, he added.

Africa News


December 5, 1996


Ethiopia;
Police apprehend escaped forger


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Police disclosed here yesterday the apprehension for the second time of a forger who allegedly held senior positions in various offices under false documents and names.

According to the Harari and Region 14 police, the culprit known by three different names had been under police custody on charges of forgery he got away on Nov. 15 this year from a hospital where he was under medical care. 

"He was detained while preparing to apply for vacancy notice by the Nation Contractors Enterprise for a post of administrative and finance head," police added.

Fake degrees, diploma and work experience documents as well as stamps allegedly belonging to the individual were also held by the police as exhibits.

Police captured the individual acting on a tip-off from a certain woman whom he was living with.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

84 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 5, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia hosts over 375,000 refugees


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Immigration and Nationality Affairs Department of the Ethiopian Security, Immigration and Refugee Affairs Authority said it gave passports and visa services to over 142,000 Ethiopians last year while the Administration for Refugees and Returnee Affairs revealed that Ethiopia hosts over 375,000 refugees.

In his report to the House of Peoples' Representatives yesterday, Ato Hailu Berhe, head of the Immigration and Nationality Affairs main department said the efforts of the department during the past years to give efficient service to the public were successful.

Ato Hailu said 30,000 people on average were given passport and visa service annually during the past regime and the figure reached 170,000 annually in the past five years. He added that it took one to two months for an individual to get passport or visa service during the past regime and such unfavourable working system has now been avoided to the extent that it takes only three days to obtain passport and only one day to obtain visa now provided that the person submitted the required documents. 

Ato Hailu told the parliament that his department is giving visa services to 20,000 to 30,000 foreigners and gave new residence permit to 834 people last year.

Moreover, 474 foreigners whose residence permit expired were made to pay fines amounting to about half a million birr by court verdict for illegal movement in the country.

He added the department is also giving services to travellers through its newly opened stations at Moyale, Dewele, Zalanbessa, Rama and Humera. The department collected 26.8 million birr from passport and visa services last year, he added.

Outdated but still operational nationality and immigration laws issued in 1992 and 1961 E.C. have adversely affected the attempt to render fast services for they do not commensurate with changes witnessed both world wide and at home.

The Administration for Returnees an Refugee Affairs (ARRA) said on its part that Ethiopia currently hosts over 375,000 refugees from neighbouring countries.

ARRA programme execution and coordination department head, Ato Ayalew Aweke told the House that of the refugees 276,000 are Somalis, over 72,000 Sudanese 18,000 Djiboutians and over 8,000 Kenyans.

Ato Ayalew said the expense to host the refugees is fully covered by foreign assistance including the food aid from the World Food Programme and other necessary expense by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR).

He said over one million Ethiopians who fled the war during the Derg regime were repatriated since 1991 and were provided with rehabilitation assistance.

Meanwhile, legal experts say the draft proclamation of the federal government on financial administration is instrumental in facilitating revenue collection and utilisation.

At a public discussion at the House of Peoples Representatives Monday Woizero Atsde Kidane legal service team leader, in the ministry of Finance, said, the proclamation provides new working system and enables the correct, smooth flow of finance.

Ato Mesfin Lemma, head of Legal Affairs Bureau in the Office of the Prime Minister, explained about the significant contribution of the proclamation to financial in revenue collection and utilisation.

Although the proclamation introduces strict control system it will not be an obstacle to financial administration for the proper utilisation of revenues, they said.

Controversial were articles 49 and 7, sub article 3 of the proclamation to which the experts dedicated more time, it was learnt.

The discussion was organised by the Budgetary, Economic and legal Standing Committee of the House.

LANGUAGE: English

December 5, 1996


Science and Health;
High Yield Corn Varieties Discovered


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Ambo - The Bako Agricultural Research Centre announces that it has discovered two high yield varieties of corn. National Corn research coordinator, De. Benti Tolossa said the new varieties yield 100 to 110 quintals per hectare, ten per cent more than the harvest of improved varieties discovered so far.

The centre has submitted the research results to the National Seed Species Approving Committee, he added.

Dr. Benti said improved maize seeds have been distributed farmers and the country expects corn harvest of 20 million quintals this year, four million quintals greater than last year s output.

He added that locally discovered corn seeds are now substituting the imported select seeds.

Africa News


December 5, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian Hijackers Identified


BYLINE: Yeshitla Kokeb, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Addis Ababa - The identity of the three hijackers behind the tragic crash EAL 767 jet liner resulting in the death of 125 of the 175 passengers and crew members on board on November 23, is already identified, according to a police officer here.

Major Alemseged Gebre-Yohannes, Deputy Head of the Federal Police Crime Prevention Department, said at a press conference in his office that the since roundly condemned trio comprised of three Ethiopian: Alemayehu Bekele Belay, Matheas Solomon Belay and Sultan Nur Hussien. Al of them were killed in the crash. 

Major Alemseged said that there was no political purpose in view. their intention to force the plane to change course to Australia, according to findings of the investigating team, two of the hijackers, Alemayehu Bekle and Matheas Solomon were jobless high school students and were in Djibouti for some time. The third Hijacker, Sultan Nur Hussien, is know to have joined a nursing school there. He lived in Djibouti for eight years. The trio boarded the plane at Bole International Airport, according to the deputy police commissioner.

Asked about how the two survivors who were late held suspected hijackers were declared innocent by the investigating team, Major Alemseged said they were kept under custody by the Comoros Government security forces were found to be a Djibouti citizen and another Kenyan. Neither spoke Amharic. The former was chairman of the teachers association on his way to attend an international meeting while the Kenyan was said to be a respected businessman, on one of his routine business tours.

"The Comorian police detail on duty arrested the individuals", said the officer, "Because they observed nervousness on them and also the co-pilot, although by mistake testified against them." The co-pilot later refuted his work, it was learnt.

The deputy commissioner pointed out that they were "armed" only with a hammer made available for emergency use and a bottle of whiskey they snatched from serving hostesses. Asked whether or not the hijackers knew anything about flying aeroplanes, Maj. Alemseged said that he believed they knew nothing except some that garnered up from the EAL's magazine-Selamta.

The flight recording black-box has been recovered and further investigation results will be made public in due course, he said.

ENA reported that the Federal Police Bureau, in a statement it gave late in the afternoon said Sultan Nur Hussen was issued with a passport from the Ethiopian Embassy in Djibouti and has learned, French during his eight years stay in there. The other two hijackers had received passports under pseudo names and using fake identification cards, as proved by the investigation team, it added.

They were issued with the I.D. cards through Ato Solomon Belay Haile, Ato Bisrat Solomon Belay, Ato Ambaye Belay Ambaye, Woizero Askale Demissie Bedane and Ato Imiru Kifle Kebede who are now under investigation.

Every care and measure necessary to control any such hijacking will be taken, according to major Alemseged.

The hijackers were identified on tip offs from survivors, pilots and stewardesses as well as passports found in their pockets and documents here, he said, adding the black box has been found.

LANGUAGE: English

Ethiopia;
Bodies Of Crash Victims Delivered To Families


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Addis Ababa - Bodies of victims of the crash off the comoros arrived here yesterday and were delivered to next of kins.

A solemn reception was made for the corpses here at Bole International Airport in the presence of President Negasso Gidada. 

President Negasso has on the occasion laid a bouquet of flower after the Military brass band played a mournful tune.

A minute of silence was observed at the airport after which the president took leave off the breaved families.

Present of the occasion were Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence Tefera Waluwa, senior government officials and members of the diplomatic corps.

Spokeswoman of the Ethiopian Airlines, Woizerit Liya Belay told ENA the arrivals included among others corpses of 13 Ethiopians, two Indians, one Canadian, two Britons and a Kenyan with eight an identified bodies.

The bodies delivered to their next of kin were buried here at various cemeteries with the rest to be flown to their respective countries, she added.

She said the remaining bodies in the Comoros would be flown to Addis Ababa immediately after the completion of identification and preparation of the corpses.

December 6, 1996


Zambia;
Law Group: Polls Lost Legitimacy


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - The November 18 elections have been robbed of legitimacy because of the evidence of rigging which continues to surface, declared Law Association of Zambia (LAZ) vice-chairman, Albert Wood, yesterday.

And rigging has at least been proved by the recent evidence produced and published by The Post, observed Father Ignatius Mwebe, secretary general of the Catholic's Zambia Episcopal Conference (ZEC), yesterday.

Wood, after examining the two voters' cards of a person who voted twice in Lusaka, demanded for a thorough analysis and investigation of the whole electoral process. 

"Such revelations give credence to the view that the elections and the electoral process have been robbed of legitimacy," Wood said in an interview yesterday. "We are not sure whether the case of Zgyambo is an isolated incident or not. If this is a general trend then it is a sad development for our fledgling democracy."

The recent evidence shows that one Tenson Edson Zgyambo voted at two polling stations in Munali and Mandevu constituencies using two different voters' cards.

And Wood added that the evidence adduced so far clearly shows an element of multiple voting which is contrary to the provisions of the Electoral Act.

Father Mwebe, in an interview yesterday said The Post newspaper has at least proved a point with its recent evidence of rigging.

"The recent evidence which you have brought out, you have at least proved one case of rigging,"Father Mwebe said.

But Christian of Council of Zambia (CCZ) secretary general Reverend Violet Sampa-Bredt refused to look at the cards.

"As far as CCZ is concerned the issue of elections is a dead one," she said in an interview yesterday. "We monitored elections in ten polling stations and made our report that the elections were free and fair. The elections issue to us is a closed chapter and we don't want to be drawn into it."

And Lusaka Province MMD chairman, nominated member of parliament Christopher Chawinga, also said the issue of elections was "out of taste".

"Why should we keep on talking about something which is already out of taste?" Chawinga asked in an interview last night. "People have already decided. All we want now is progress."


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


89 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 6, 1996


Zambia;
We Won't Be Intimidated


BYLINE: Fred M'membe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Lusaka - No amount of government intimidation or harassment will deter the Committee for Clean Campaign (CCC) from performing its duties, warned the Committee's General Assembly yesterday.

The CCC General Assembly, which comprises 17 representatives from various Non-Governmental Organisations, among them Women for Change, Women's Lobby, Afronet, NGO Co-ordinating Committee, Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace, World Vision International, FODEP, Zambia Youth Federation and Youth Federation for World Peace, in a press statement released in Lusaka yesterday, maintained its support of the verdict on the November 18 presidential and parliamentary elections announced by the Committee's chairman, Ngande Mwanajiti.

"We shall, thus, not sit back and watch the unnecessary individualisation of decisions which are taken collectively," the CCC General Assembly statement read in part. "Our verdict on the just ended elections are based on a thorough analysis of the whole electoral process." 

The General Assembly reiterated the Committee's observation that the November elections were fraudulent.

"While the November 18 polling day was very peaceful, the whole electoral process was fraudulent from the very beginning," the CCC General Assembly maintained, adding: "We will not for a second compromise our position and the internationally recognised principles and democratic ideals for which we stand in exchange for non-harassment."

But Lusaka Province MMD chairman, nominated member of parliament Christopher Chawinga, dismissed CCC's charges that the elections were fraudulent.

"We are now tired with the people claiming that the elections were not free and fair," Chawinga said in an interview last night. " The people have decided. That is all I can tell CCC."

CCC also accused the ruling MMD of abusing the police.

"We wish to express our deep concern at the manner in which the ruling party and its reckless cadres are using the police and other security wings of the government to harass perceived political adversaries and those holding opposing views," the CCC General Assembly charged. "We, therefore, demand an immediate stop to the unwarranted harassment and victimisation of our members. As part of the civil society, we will continue to speak against acts of oppression and any other forms of injustice that threaten to undermine democracy."

The CCC General Assembly complained that the searches of Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) and Inter-Africa Network on Human Rights and Development (AFRONET) offices, the freezing of the CCC bank accounts and the false imprisonment of ZIMT president Alfred Zulu and Mwanajiti are evidently aimed at clamping down on dissent in order to undermine the development of a democratic culture.

Police on Sunday, November 24, 1996 and Monday November 25, 1996 picked up Mwanajiti and Zulu, searched their respective offices and confiscated documents.

CCC has contested the matter in court questioning the powers of the police to freeze their accounts and police's refusal to abide by a court order to hand over the confiscated documents.

High Court judge Peter Chitengi will make a ruling on Monday.

The CCC General Assembly also expressed concern at the "unprofessional manner in which the state owned media are being used to peddle and promote hate propaganda".

"We urge the media to recognise the vital role it plays in fostering democracy," the CCC statement advised.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


90 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 6, 1996


Zambia;
Polls Had To Be Rigged (EDITORIAL)


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Lusaka - It seems all Zambians are now by presidential decree required to sing praises to a President and for a government that has emerged out of the November 18 fraudulent elections.

But how else can a fraudulent government maintained itself? A crook's reign is judged by terror.

True to Proverbs 28; 12: "When good men come to power, everybody celebrates, but when bad men rule, people stay in hiding."

And verses 15 and 16 add: "Poor people are helpless against a wicked ruler; he is as dangerous as a growling lion or a prowling bear. A ruler without good sense will be a tyrant." 

Since MMD rigged the elections and President Chiluba, a wicked ruler who rejoiced and celebrated the stoning of a British Airways crew by University of Zambia students, was sworn in for a fraudulent second term, a number of people could not sleep in their homes for fear of harassment.

Zambia Democratic Congress leaders - Dean Mung'omba, Azwell Banda, and Andrew Banda had to go underground.

Liberal Progressive Front chairman Rodger Chongwe couldn't enjoy the comfort of his home fearing continued police raids on his farm.

Zambia Independent Monitoring Team(ZIMT) president Alfred Zulu and Committee for Clean Campaign chairman, Ngande Mwanajiti have their own stories to tell about the rule of men who rig elections.

The crooks who rigged the elections would want all Zambians and the country's cooperating partners to keep quiet about their wicked deeds, thereby imposing a culture of silence over the whole nation in the way they have carved themselves another term of office.

Harassment and all sorts of lies and framings befall those who refuse to be silenced, especially those who dare to expose the crime of their leaders over the polls.

But dishonest men will never rule for a long time.

"If you get more stubborn every time you are corrected, one day you will be crushed and never recover," reads Proverbs 29; 1, adding in verse 16: "When evil men are in power, crime increases. But the righteous will live to see the downfall of such men."

Bloodthirsty rulers hate anyone who is honest.

While admitting the fact that all humans do err, there is need to distinguish between honest people who make wrong judgements and outright crooks who create elaborate schemes to rig elections.

But no matter how often the wicked bring down an honest person, he or she will always get up again; but disaster destroys crooks.

We are aware that President Chiluba, through cash 'donations' and job offers or promises thereof, has corrupted the souls of many weak men and women to sing praises for him.

He has PAREMO, Rainbow monitors, and Dixon Konkola to provide the chorus and the Christian Council of Zambia - through Reverend Violet Sampa-Bredt - to provide the verses.

Sampa-Bredt is a new convert. In fact she appears to have surprised her church colleagues by her turn-coat behaviour.

However, the refusal by Sampa-Bredt, Electoral Commission chairman, justice Bobby Bwalya, Lusaka Province MMD chairman and nominated member of parliament Christopher Chawinga, and others to examine the growing evidence of rigging does not surprise us.

What worries us about the treachery of these people is that Sampa-Bredt, as a person of God, is abusing the trust people have placed in her as an example of moral uprightness.

Another worry is that it appears that it is the very people who shout loudest about their faith in God who are the least upright and who will easily delve into deceitfulness.

President Chiluba himself declared this nation Christian but has proceeded to hold fraudulent elections.

President Chiluba told his party convention last December that it would be criminal for him not to have a second term of office. How can losing an election be a crime for a democrat in a democracy?

Well, he asked the convention delegates, in front of television cameras, what would happen to the government houses and offices they occupy and the cars they drive if the elections were lost.

This alone speaks volumes as to why the polls had to be rigged.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 6, 1996


Zambia;
Miss Zambia Fails To Capture Pageant Title


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia yet again failed to make her beauty power felt at the pretigious heavily contested Miss World Beauty pageant held in India last week which saw the crowning of Miss Greece as world champion.

Despite having failed to sail through to the semi-finals of the contest, Zambia's Alice Banda feels she contributed a great deal to selling Zambia's image to the outside. 

"We distributed a lot of tourism literature from Zambia National Tourist Board and gave out information of the country and I think this was a great contribution," Banda said in an interview on Tuesday adding: "It was just an experience of a lifetime."

"She looked great and was composed. At least confidence was among her strong points during the introductions," said one of the viewers, a Lusaka cosmetics sales lady, Mubanga Mwansa.

The pageant that saw the participation of 88 contestants drawn from all over the world had staked US$65,000 prize money for the winner, 12 nights stay at any of the Sheraton Group Hotels, free travel and a three nights holiday in Seychelles including several other generous packages.

When asked about how she fared in the contest, Banda said it was difficult to tell because of the manner in which the participants were judged.

"Its really difficult to tell how they were judging us because all the contestants only spent 30 seconds with the judges and its very difficult to tell what they based their judgement on as there was little time for them to get to know the contestants," she said.

Banda has however pledged to continue charity duties which her predecessor has left and has assured the business community that they can call on her if at all they require representation.
