Africa News


December 9, 1996


Science and Health;
Vaccination Meeting Opens in Dakar


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - A consultative group meeting of the Children's Vaccine Initiative opened Monday amid concern over Africa's low accessibility to existing and new vaccines.

Opening the meeting in Dakar, Senegal's health and social action minister, Ousmane Ngom, said that although hopes were being raised for new vaccines, the major worry remained whether the vaccines would be readily available to the African public.

He cited the case of the vaccine against hepatitis B which, although now in its third generation, "is still inaccessible" to most people. 

"Our responsibility over the next two days will be to see how the countries of the world -- including the countries in Africa -- can benefit from existing and new vaccines without delay," the Children Vaccination Initiative executive secretary, Dr Jong-Wook Lee, added.

The initiative was launched in October 1990 during the World Children's summit in New York. The effort brings together diverse organizations and experts to help provide better protection of children against diseases through the development of new and Bimproved vaccines.

The World Health Organization's regional director for Africa, Dr Ebrahim Samba, urged African governments to budgets for effective vaccination programmes.

He called, particularly, for an onslaught against measles, which kills up to 5.55 million African children annually. He said measures should equally be extended to defeating neonatal tetanus, which causes 250,000 deaths each year and polio, which cripples at least 12,000 children each year.

Samba noted that a new awakening was developing among African countries to vaccinate as many children as possible.

"Even in countries in conflict like Angola," he said, "the warring factions temporarily stopped their fighting so that children could be vaccinated."

However, he said that the high cost of vaccines remained an impediment to implementation. While 14 vaccines were available worldwide, he said, African countries have access to only six.

Speaking later at a press conference about the Ebola virus, the WHO director-general, Dr Hiroshi Nakajima, said it was one of the new viruses that was bound to emerge with the ongoing climatic changes.

Dr Maxime Shwartz of the Paris-based Pasteur Institute noted that the Ebola virus was more deadly than AIDS because it kills 90 percent of the infected persons within a few days.

Ebola cannot cause an epidemic as it only infects people who were in direct contact with the fluids of a patient.

Nonetheless, Shwartz said, more research was required to find the animal reservoir of the virus so as to find ways of protecting humans.

Concerning the dismal performance of the Colombian-discovered synthetic anti-malaria vaccine, he a more effective vaccine could be discovered, easily, since a good number of Africans already have immunity against the disease.

Monday's highlight at the Consultative Group meeting will be an event to be hosted by Children's Vaccine Initiative. This will show how the vaccine industry is a partner in the fight for children's health and in the eradication of polio.

On Tuesday, the initiative will honor individuals and organizations who have made outstanding contributions to protecting children through vaccinations.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


178 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Business and Finance;
Singapore Premier Opens World Trade Meeting


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

SINGAPORE (PANA) - Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong opened the first World Trade Organization (WTO) biennial ministerial conference Monday, with an appeal for help to developing countries so they could integrate their weak economies with the multilateral trading regime created by the WTO.

He said that developing countries must be given time to adjust to the changes brought about by the Uruguay Round of trade talks, both in the rules and the pressure of market opening measures.

"The concerns of the less developed countries that they are being marginalized in the emerging global trading environment must, in particular, be addressed," Tong told the estimated 5,000 delegates attending the meeting. 

"Realistically, global trade liberalization has to progress in an incremental manner, even though some of them prefer quantum jumps," he added.

The WTO, he said, had a crucial role to play in this process, so as to maximize the mutual benefits of the new global economy and enable the WTO create a strong, effective and credible multilateral trade regime.

"If protectionist sentiments surface and roll back the significant goals the WTO has achieved, then global economic prospects for the future will become dimmer, instead of brighter," he said.

So, he said that developing countries must be assisted to fulfill their commitments and obligations to the WTO. With the creation of this trade body income is expected to increase by at least 500 billion U.S. dollars by the year 2005.

"The WTO should bind together and help the less developed members catch up and benefit from the vast opportunities of the global marketplace," he said. " Together, WTO members must put full and faithful implementation at the top of their agenda, critically study the progress we have made so far and ensure that the considerable gains of the Uruguay Round are maximized."

Tong said among other initiatives, the WTO must ensure that member countries continued to reduce tariff and remove non-tariff barriers so as to stimulate global trade.

"If the WTO system is to be held together, it is critical that it is not polarized by any north-south divide, putting developing and developed members against each other," he said. Rather, he added, "effort should be made to ensure that there are equal opportunities to benefit from the process of global trade liberalization."

Tong also questioned the wisdom of discussing at this meeting the so-called "new issues" concerning labor standards and investments.

He said labor standards, particularly in the poor WTO member countries, should not be "used a disguised protectionist measure" by the industrialized countries to stem imports.

"As for investment, no-one disputes the link between trade and investment but there is no agreement on when and how best to address the issue within the WTO," Tong said.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 9, 1996


Zambia;
Opposition Party Leader Calls For Peace


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Mkushi - THE ZAMBIA Democratic Congress leader in Mkushi has appealed to all political parties in the country to meet and solve their political differences amicably than resorting to violence.

ZDC Mkushi North constituency vice-secretary, Fabius Mulusa, said today all political parties should sit down and resolve their differences peacefully. 

Mr. Mulusa said his party in Mkushi does not want leaders who are longing for violence which might plunge the country into chaos and unnecessary loss of life.

He condemned some Zambian political leaders he did not name but whose comments have always advocated for violence saying these people have no heart for the Zambian people adding that losing an election should not lead many to violence but that the losers should respect the winners as all in the election was done fairly and democratically.

Ever since UNIP decided to boycott last month's elections its leader, Kenneth Kaunda, has been talking about civil disobedience and other acts which might bring instability to the country.

After the elections the ZDC national leadership also joined the band-wagon claiming that the elections were not freely and fairly conducted.

But both local and international monitors have came up with a definite conclusion that the presidential and parliamentary elections had been held in a free and fair atmosphere and those losing had lost simply because they were not popular.

Source: ZAMTODAY

December 9, 1996


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (12/02 - 12/08)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association (ARSO)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

The Moroccan Minister of Economy precises, the day before signing of a so- called "experimental" agreement with Spain, that the amount of the first part of the debt to be reconverted is of 50 millions of $ (not 500 millions as mentioned on 29.11.96).

03.12.96 Mr. Boutros Ghali exposed to criticism

In a memorandum distributed to the press at the Franco-African Summit of Ouagadougou, Rwanda speaks of the multiple failures of Mr. Boutros Ghali. This document blames his inability to manage the bloody conflicts in Africa, especially Rwanda. The document shows also the examples of Angola, Liberia, Mozambique, Western Sahara, "where M.B.Ghali does not hide his complicity with Morocco", Somalia, the Balkans, Cambodia and Haoti. 

04.12.96 Morocco-Polisario: a new spirit

The weekly newspaper Jeune Afrique underlines, under this title, the fact that Morocco and the Polisario Front, even if the discussions are suspended untill a neutral place for the meetings is found, demonstrate their will to find a solution by common consent.

05.12.96 Polisario urges Spain to mediate talks

Mahfud Ali Beiba, prime minister of the Sahrawi Republic, told at a news conference in Sevilla that Spain had a responsiblity as the former colonial ruler to help settle the dispute. "The two parties need someone to support and push talks, and Spain has an important responsibility in the matter since it left the problem unresolved," Beiba said after talks with Spain's regional government in Andalucia. He added that the Polisario Front was ready for mediated talks in a neutral country, and it was simply waiting for Morocco to give the sign that it was willing to participate.

On Monday 09.12.96, the first meeting of the Averrohs Committee will take place at Sevilla. This organism, created in February 1996, wants to promote the relationship between Spain and Morocco. The meeting will be presided by Moroccan Prime Minister and the Spanish Foreign Minister.

07.12.96 Solidarity

The flamenco singer Enrique Morente and other well known Spanish artists produce a CD in aid to the Sahrawi children in the refugee camps. The writer Manuel Vazquez Montalban wrote a text joined to the disc which will be sold from 20.12.96.

Prepared by ARSO (Association de soutien a un referendum libre et regulier au Sahara occidental). CP 2229, CH-2800 DELEMONT 2. Tel./Fax: 0041 32 422 87 17. E-mail: arso@hei.unige.ch. WWW: http://heiwww.unige.ch/arso/.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


181 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Zambia;
Zambia: After Elections What?


BYLINE: Sam Gonza, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Lusaka - The elections are over in Zambia, and the diminutive Fredrick Chiluba 55, has been sworn in for a second term as president of the southern African nation of Zambia.

Chiluba, who horned his political skills in the rough and tumble of the trade union movement in Tanzania, Mozambique and Zambia before ascending to the presidency in 1991, appears little concerned by opposition-fanned reports that a military coup is in the offing in Zambia. Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy, MMD, won a landslide victory in the presidential and parliamentary polls, taking 131 of the 150 seats parliament. He says it was an honest victory and has credited his faith in God for it.

His MMD party says the heavy turn out - 1.3 million out of the 2.2 million registered voters - was an indication that the people of Zambia supported the ruling party. 

Not so, say the opposition. The elections were boycotted by seven political parties including the top potential contender, the United National Independence Party (UNIP) of Dr. Kenneth Kaunda. Kaunda ruled Zambia for 27 years, before losing to Chiluba in the 1991 elections. Kaunda, 72, was barred from contesting as a person on the basis of a controversial constitutional amendment that bars presidential contenders whose parents were born outside Zambia. Kaunda's parents were born in today's Malawi though he himself was born in Lubwa parish, northern Zambia. A bitter Kaunda, who was Zambia's first President after independence in 1964, said of the May 15,1996 Constitutional amendment: "I am a Zambian and I am ready to defy this discriminatory law."

From the basis of traditional lore he argued: "My umbilical cord was buried at Lubwa and my parents are buried there too. Culturally, it is held in Africa that where one's umbilical cord is buried is proof of his origins and therefore roots."

Guy Scott, a former Minister of Agriculture and now leader of a farmer's party, the National Lima Party, attributed MMD's victory to the work of mammon. Scott said while there may have been no outright rigging, the cumulative effect of a series of electoral malpractices has led to Chiluba's disputed victory.

He cited the case of a polling assistant who openly boasted he had been paid to mark balloting papers in favour of the MMD. "In rural Zambia many people are illiterate. If the ballot papers are marked for them by biased officials, victory may go the opposite way."

The MMD also had the advantage of incumbency and used government resources flagrantly, charged Scott. "In one constituency we counted only two vehicles for the opposition while the MMD had 25."

Scott is fully convinced the MMD could not have won seats in rural Zambia on the basis of their agricultural track record which he described as dismal. "They must have won on the basis of something else", said the leader of the farmers body.

But Vernon Mwaanga, chief campaigner for Chiluba and a former Foreign Minister in both Kaunda's and subsequently Chiluba's administrations, dismissed opposition charges that the polls were rigged. "We did not enjoy excessive advantage. Incumbency alone will not necessarily guarantee victory."

Mwaanga pointed out that when UNIP of Kaunda lost power five years ago they were the incumbents, but that did not stop the MMD from winning. "The elections are about winning and losing and the opposition should accept it all in good spirit."

Analysts say the biggest test for Chiluba will be in the weeks ahead. Kaunda has vowed not to rest until the Chiluba administration is brought to account for what he considers to have been fraudulent elections. Kaunda has called for a national strike sometime this December. However, judging by the poor turn out of about 3,000 at a demonstration he organised in the capital on December 1, most Zambians appear to believe that having ruled Zambia for close to three decades, Kaunda already had his chance.

The coalition of opposition parties in Zambia called Opposition Alliance, which includes Kaunda's UNIP, appears ready to dice with danger as well as unconstitutional means to have their way. The independent Post newspaper whose editor Fred Membe is vehemently opposed to Chiluba, reported two weeks ago that the alliance had written to South African President Nelson Mandela warning him and other regional leaders of a possible military coup in Zambia.

Roger Chongwe, leader of the Liberal Progressive Front who wrote the letter on behalf of the Alliance, warned that if no "timely action" was taken, a military coup could not be ruled out in Zambia due to the "fluid situation."

The letter urged the South African Development Community SADC comprising regional southern African nations not to sit back and watch. Mandela is the current chairman of SADC.

The Alliance appears to believe that some sort of economic sanctions should be imposed on landlocked Zambia along the lines of the sanctions imposed on Burundi by the Eastern African regional Heads of State after the military coup that brought Major Pierre Buyoya to power.

Mandela is inclined towards Kaunda because when Kaunda was in power he gave a lot of support to the African National Congress (ANC) whose guerrillas fighters had a base in Zambia during the bitter years of conflict against the apartheid regime in South Africa. Indeed Zambia's impoverished economy has sometimes been blamed on Kaunda's pre-occupation with wars of liberation in Southern Africa when he was in power.

A week before the Zambian elections on November 18, Chiluba paid a short trip to South Africa where Mandela urged him to postpone the elections until the contentious issue of the Constitutional amendment affecting Kaunda had been sorted out. Chiluba rejected Mandela's plea out of hand and state media in Zambia asked Mandela to keep off Zambia's internal affairs.

A victorious Chiluba is unfazed by accusations that he is resorting to strong arm tactics to silence his opponents. Ten days after the elections he ordered the bank account of a coalition of independent election monitors frozen after they had slated the elections "unfree and unfair." His government also sacked six journalists working for state media on allegation that they were sympathetic to the opposition.

All this has not gone down well with the western donor community. Zambia's economy is over dependent on the export of copper which is in glut on the world market. The country can ill afford to annoy providers of western largesse. Chiluba knows this fact well and has kept it in cognisance while choosing his new cabinet; all the names that western donors had said they did not want in the cabinet were kept out. These include Vernon Mwaanga, his chief campaigner who was forced to resign from the cabinet in 1993 after accusations that he and others in the government were involved in trafficking the drug "Mandrax".

At the moment the United States, Britain, Sweden and Japan are not happy with the whole electoral process and the Constitutional amendment that preceded it. As early as June, Britain said it would curtail its 20 million pounds aid programme to show displeasure over undemocratic trends in Zambia.

Chiluba will have to tread cautiously. Failure to win donor support could result in the collapse of the economy and widescale civil strife in one of Africa's most peaceful countries.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


182 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Rwanda;
Handicapped Rwandan Children Return Home


BYLINE: Luke Odhiambo, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1654 words


 

Bukavu - A group of 52 handicapped Rwandan refugee children, saved by dedicated Roman Catholic priests from fighting in eastern Zaire last October, have returned to a home for the handicapped in Rwanda, the missionary order said on November 28. This ends their nearly 2 years of exile.

Most of the handicapped children were carried by the priests on their backs through mountains to safety at the height of the fighting between Zairean forces and Zairean Tutsi rebels, known as the Banyamulenge.

As shells rained down around their mission and Tutsi rebels advanced on the regional centre of Bukavu, eight priests -- six Belgian and two Zairean -- decided to escort their charges, aged between 11 and 18, to a safe refuge in the hills, Brother Bernard of the Brothers of Charity explained.

The children, mostly physically handicapped but including two who were visually impaired, one blind and three mentally handicapped, were showing increasing signs of panic as the fighting neared, he said. 

"We decided to leave. There was savage fighting in the region. It was the safest thing to do. Half the town's population had already left. We could see them passing by, so we joined them. We must have been the last to leave.

"Four priests stayed behind and the rest of us took the children. We were helped by some of our local novices and we formed a group of about 100 people altogether," Brother Bernard said.

"We found ourselves caught up in the human tide of people fleeing to the hills. It was a miracle that we even managed to stay together. In the end it took us four days to cover the 15 kilometres to Kabare, west of Bukavu."

Some of the handicapped children were able to move unsupported or with the aid of sticks, but most needed regular attention to keep them marching, and many had to be carried.

The ragtag cohort of children, novices and priests slept rough the first night in pouring rain, and in a small hut and an abandoned church the following night.

They spent a total of 10 days away from Bukavu at what they considered was a safe distance, waiting for a clear picture of the situation to emerge.

"Talk about a calvary, it was literally that. So many of the children had to be carried. Everyone was exhausted. The road was uphill all the way. We must have climbed 400 metres," Brother Bernard said.

Despite the heavy fighting during that first day of flight, there were no casualties among the priests and children, though one brother tore a ligament climbing the hillside and is still limping a month later.

One child was lost. "It was on the first night. We were still mingled among the thousands of other people fleeing," the mission chief said.

"Joseph, the blind child, somehow lost his guide in the confusion. It was only when it got dark that we realized we had lost our Joseph. Apparently he was later seen in Kisangani, but we've had no news of him."

The children had arrived in Zaire from Katagara in central Rwanda two years ago, following the 1994 civil war and genocide of more than 500,000 Tutsis and moderate Hutus.

They formed part of a larger group of around 80, some of whom earlier returned to Rwanda and reunited with their families.

But the latter group returned on November 28 to Rwanda and to Katagara, where the Brothers of Charity run a well-equipped home for the handicapped.

Most of them appeared happy to be returning to Katagara, which they fled in 1994, though it was unlikely they would find parents or other family to welcome them once they got back.

Thomas, 15, said he had no idea whether his parents were alive, and expressed no interest in looking for them, while Gratien, 17, from Cyangugu region, said he intended to make enquiries about his.

Thirty handicapped children who had also formed part of the refugee group had already returned to Rwanda because members of their families applied to have them brought back. The present group were those who either had no family or whose relatives had not inquired about them.

The Brothers of Charity is a Rome-based religious order with missions in 17 countries around the world. Its 700 priests working in Europe, Africa, Asia and Latin America specialize in teaching and psychiatric work, particularly with handicapped children, both physical and mental.

In Zaire, the organization has five missions: at Bukavu, where they have been present since the influx of Rwandan refugees in the east of country two years ago, and at Kinshasa, Kanaga, Katwambi and Lufhambo.

In Rwanda they have missions at Katagara, near Kigali, where they run a home for the handicapped, and at Butare.

Brother Bernard, one of six Belgian and two Zairean priests teaching at Bukavu, has lived and worked in the region since 1962. Trained as a missionary in Belgium, he spent six years in Rome, and has travelled widely.

He helped organise the flight of the handicapped Rwandan children during the civil war and genocide of 1994.

During his years teaching at Butare, moreover, he helped educate the great majority of Rwanda's present leaders. "All the Rwandan elite passed through our hands. Butare became a centre for the teaching of leaders," he said.

Meanwhile, a group of 39 children lost in the human tide which swept in from Zaire last month also returned to their mountain-top village in central Rwanda on December 2 with uncertain prospects for resuming their former lives.

Villagers at Bushoki, 50 kilometres north of Kigali, turned out by the hundred to see the children return, ferried in by workers of the International Committee of the Red Cross after spending two weeks in an orphanage in the capital.

There were no effusions of emotion, either from the parents, family members and friends or from the returnees themselves, aged between four and 14. " Rwandans aren't like that," a local official said. "They keep it bottled in."

The children had been away for more than two years, having fled to eastern Zaire in the closing stages of the 1994 civil war. They had become detached from their parents or escorts during the mid- November exodus that saw more than half a million refugees flood in from the camps around the eastern Zairean border town of Goma.

Many have reasonable hopes of being reunited with one or both of their parents or at least with members of their family.

Others face an uncertain future. Nine-year-old Elias lost both his parents during the war and was taken in hand by a neighbour during his time in eastern Zaire.

He trudged the 50-kilometre journey from the Kahindo refugee camp to Gisenyi, in Rwanda, on foot, but lost his escort. He had no idea who was on hand in Bushoki to greet him, but he hoped it would be the neighbour who helped him through his exile.

Jean-Bosco, 13, from the Katale camp west of Goma, lost touch with his father who is believed to be still hiding in the Zairean forest. His mother died during the war. There was no one in Bushoki to greet him, and questions brought tears to his eyes.

"We'll carry out searches in the region," the local official said. "If we can't find any relatives, he may have to come back to the orphanage."

Around 4,600 unaccompanied children -- orphaned or simply lost -- were registered after the Goma exodus, of whom 1,500 have already been reunited with parents, families or friends, ICRC spokesman Nina Winquist-Galbe said.

They form part of greater problems of Rwandan children scattered by the winds of war, of whom the ICRC has registered more than 95,000 throughout the Great Lakes region since August 1994. Of these, 40,000 are still searching for their parents.

Aid officials are particularly concerned at the fate of the unaccompanied children, possibly numbering several thousand, still languishing in Zaire.

"Many of these are probably being used as slave labour by the Hutu militiamen," the spokeswoman said. "If they're big enough to carry arms they're likely to be used as soldiers."

Meanwhile, despite their sober demeanor, the villagers of Bushoki were reliably said to be pleased to see the return of the children.

One woman, the aunt of a returnee, wore a tee-shirt carrying the advertising slogan for a brand of American cigarettes. It read: "You've come a long way, baby."


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


183 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Kenya;
Kisumu's Water Paradox A Boon To Illegal Dealers


BYLINE: Robert Otani, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

Kisumu - When he left his rural home in Migori District, in the south- western corner of Kenya, David Otieno was full of great expectations. And why not? He was armed with a Grade C Kenya Certificate of Secondary Education. Getting a well-paying job, replete with all the liberal perks that go with it, would not be much of a problem. So he set out for Kisumu, Kenya's third largest town after the capital Nairobi and tourist-attractive Mombasa on the Indian Ocean.

Kisumu is on the shores of Lake Victoria, the second largest fresh water lake in the world. It is four years hence, and Otieno's dream job is not forthcoming. His idea then was a sedentary job in an air-conditioned office. He could imagine himself in a chic suit and a silk tie to match as he signed vouchers for the day's little expenditures.

But this was not to be. Looking for this kind of job turned into an horizon- chasing affair. Then he began to look for "any" job. One day, he encountered an Asian prospective employer who sneered: "Taka kazi kabila gani (What kind of job are you looking for?)" To which Otieno answered: "Any". The elderly turbaned wholesale businessman suggested that Otieno start taking care of his toilets and gardens immediately. This offer so infuriated Otieno that he had a good mind of punching the man on the nose, but instead he walked away dejected and frustrated. 

The job hunt continued. But Otieno watched in disbelief as his elder brother, with whom he stayed, came home with wads of bank notes every evening. The notes were Nicholas Owino's earnings from the sale of water for domestic use.

Owino had not acquired the educational level of his younger brother. Thus, the 24-year-old Otieno decided that pushing the hand-cart loaded with 12 jerry-cans of water all over the residential estate was his big brother's just desserts.

"How can I join you in that God-forsaken work?" Otieno sneered when invited by his brother to join him in the water hawking business. "Why did I go to school at all--all 12 years of it? I could as well have stayed home to wait till I was old and strong enough for this."

That was before. But now Otieno had come face to face with reality. No more Alice-in-Wonderland ambitions. Water hawking was the only job left for him. He asked his brother and parents back home to help him buy a 12-jerry-can hand-cart like Owino's. They complied and soon Otieno was the proud owner of a Ksh 20,000 (US$400) cart replete with 12 jerry-cans, each costing Ksh 50.

Right now Otieno is well into his second year of water business and he cannot look back. "How I regret the two years I spent looking for an office job," he laments. "Within one short year, I have been able to put up a semi- permanent house at my rural home. I have also got myself a wife and paid the Ksh 5,000 ayie (symbolic fee paid by the groom to show his commitment to the envisaged union) and the 13 head of cattle without outside help.

"Besides, I manage my affairs pretty well. I hold an impressive account at Barclays Bank and will use those funds to buy a plot on which I wish to build another home in town."

Otieno is one of the 500-odd men, young and not so young, who sell water to the 500,000 thirsty Kisumu residents. In fact, the water business has become so lucrative and attractive that an unkept, sweat-drenched man pushing a ton- weight of water around the residential areas is a common sight indeed.

Most of Kisumu's water supply facilities were put up in the 1950's when the population was a meagre 80,000. The facilities, like other social service equipments in the town, continue to find it extremely hard to keep pace with an ever increasing population. According to the 1989 census, Kisumu is home for a quarter of a million people. But modest estimates put the current population at double this number.

The "Kisumu We Want" convention of December 1993 came up with startling data about the town's water situation. According to the convention report, the town's water demand of 50,000 cubic metres a day is a far cry from its hitherto capacity of 20,000 cubic metres.

The convention indicted a number of factors for this disparity. These included the municipal council's failure to adjust the water capacity to keep pace with the population growth, poor maintenance leading to leaks and the advent of water-quaffing industries like Kenya Breweries.

The problem with the Kisumu water is not only its scarcity. It is also poorly treated, making water-borne diseases such as typhoid fever, amoebic dysentery, common dysentery and diarrhoea the major medical complaints.

Ben Odera, a medical practitioner who operates a clinic at the sprawling Manyata Estate, says: "Although this is a malaria-prone area, over 80 per cent of my clients are typhoid, amoeba, dysentery or diarrhoea cases."

Municipal authorities maintain that the water is treated well enough, yet this does not seem to be the case as the incidence of these diseases does not abate. Recently a government chemist stirred a hornet's nest when he told a seminar in the town that the water was "unfit for human consumption".

Elijah Tonui, the Kisumu District chemist, meant well with the comment. But the municipal authorities, led by Mayor Lawrence Akinyi Oile, were up in arms. They accused the government official of exaggerating the situation and of inciting the residents against the council.

Other sources within the council are honest enough to admit that the water is either under or over-treated. Mostly the former. The proceeds from what is spared from the underdoing goes into individuals' pockets, quite in tune with the corruption greedily eating into the very fabric of the Kenyan society.

If the Kisumu water is impure and disease-laden, one is pretty lucky to have it flowing in the tap. Of course, the rich and mighty living in Kisumu's posh estates can afford to water their gardens and wash their cars with large hoses. But water taps in most of Kisumu are a vain decoration in the house.

A physics professor, who was recently transferred from Nairobi University to the nearby Maseno University College, was lucky enough to find a good house to rent. After two months in the house, but without a drop of water from the taps, he received a Kshs 4,500 bill from the council. But, being a clever man, he did not bother to complain and demand the correct bill. He called Town Hall and asked them to come and carry away the meter, arguing that he did not see the purpose it was serving.

Town hall complied. The meter was removed. My professor friend has not been billed again. He has not been showered either.

The water situation in Kisumu is assuming crisis proportions. In a town in which the circulation of money is despicably low due to endemic poverty in the area caused by its political neglect and marginalisation, this essential commodity is getting out of reach to most of the residents. And this, in an area bordering the second largest expanse of fresh water in the world!

A 20-litre jerry-can of water costs Ksh 10 in most of the residential estates. In the new middle-class estates like Migosi the rate can reach Ksh 20 during drought times. Thus, a family of 10 members who use 20 jerry-cans a day spend Ksh 200 a day on water, or Ksh 6,000 per month. This is the salary of a middle-class civil servant.

The inadequacy at the mains may be the major problem. But the situation is exacerbated by some unscrupulous residents, most of them council workers, who divert the supply to their private selling kiosks. These kiosks never run dry even during the driest of times.

Water traders get their supplies from wells sunk by individuals or from such kiosks for one shilling per jerry-can. Thus, a dealer makes a Ksh 108 profit from one trip of 12 jerry-cans.

A strong man can do 10 trips a day, pocketing a cool Ksh 1,080, or Ksh 32, 400 a month. How many university graduates earn this kind of money wherever they may be working?

What makes the water trade difficult to curb, let alone stop, is the fact that some council workers are involved and that it is such a big employer. The council's efforts at a more reliable and satisfactory supply will thus be frustrated by the kiosk owners and the hawkers. They will collude with the council's water and sewerage department staff to cause artificial shortages to make their trade indispensable. It seems the cycle may never end.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


184 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Kenya;
Kenyan Churchmen React Sharply To Proposed Religious Bill


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Nairobi - Kenyan church leaders have reacted sharply to a drafted " religious" Bill which the Kenya government intends to take to Parliament for enactment "soon".

The Bill, The Religious Bodies Registration Bill 1996, has been prepared by the Public Security and Public Order Laws Task Force, under the auspices of the Kenya Reform Commission in the Attorney General's Office.

It intends, among other things, to regulate, register and control religious organizations in this east African country.

The draft Bill, whose copy was made available to APS, seeks, among to establish a religious Affairs Advisory Committee, comprising 10 members and a chairman, who will be appointed by the Attorney- General for a period of three years. 

The Bill also envisages that the committee's chairman should be a retired judge or a retired priest. Nine committee members would be representatives of the various religious faiths in Kenya, while the 10th member would be a representative of the security services of the State.

The Bill also states that the selection of representatives of the various religious faiths "shall be in the discretion of the Attorney-General after consultation with their representatives".

In his reaction, Archbishop-elect of the Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) Dr. Rev. David Gitari, said "the Anglican Church in Kenya totally rejects the draft Bill."

"We are worried that the Government can draft such a Bill. We cannot accept it whatsoever", he said on November 30 at Saint Andrews Theological College, Kirinyaga, while addressing a religious congregation.

"The church will rise up and say NO to any move to table the Bill in Parliament for debate," he added.

The Anglican clergyman asked the country's education minister Joseph Kamotho, who was present, to convey their (church leaders') sentiments in this regard to the Government.

A spokesman for the Catholic Secretariat, the headquarters of the Catholic bishops' council, said the bishops would be meeting soon to deliberate on the issue. "The bishops are soon going to converge in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, to deliberate on this issue, among others", he told APS in a telephone interview.

The chairman of the National Council of Churches in Kenya (NCCK), Bishop Joseph Wesonga told APS in a telephone interview that "the national church organization was deeply concerned with the issue. It has a lot of implication on the day-to-day life of the Kenyan churches; hence we are currently making consultations with the government's legal authorities over the matter."

Retired Anglican Archbishop, Manasses Kuria, wondered what had prompted the Kenyan government to draft the "harsh" religious Bill. "Personally I see nothing beyond the Bill apart from being yet another legal attempt by government to interfere with the religious freedom that Kenyan Christians are currently enjoying," he said.

A spokesman for the Organization of African Instituted Churches of Africa (OAIC), said the organization was totally against the Bill, because "this will have more negative implications on some of the indigenous churches, which were yet to be registered in accordance with the laws of the country."

He was specifically alluding to Section 5 of the drafted Bill, which states that "no association of persons, body or organization shall engage in any religious activity as a religious body unless and until it is duly registered as a religious body in accordance with the provisions of this Act".

A group of religious men and women in Nairobi known as Prayer Maombi, in their reaction to the proposed Bill, described it as unconstitutional because it unjustifiably limits the enjoyment of the freedom of worship, which is enshrined in the constitution.

"It should not be encouraged especially at this time when many controls are being removed," they observed in their statement. "It gives excessive powers which if placed in wrong hands will be abused".

"By trying to put all the faiths together, the Bill ignores reality as far as religion is concerned and the special circumstances prevailing in Kenya," the religious group further stressed, pointing out that "it was drafted hurriedly, poorly and contains errors and inconsistencies and therefore it should be rejected".

Section 8 (3) of the Bill stipulates what could happen to any person who establishes a religious body contrary to the provisions of this Act.

"Any person who founds or establishes a religious body contrary to the provisions of this Act or who fails to comply with any of the conditions of registration imposed under subsection (3) of section 7 commits an offence and in addition to any criminal prosecution that may be instituted against such person, the minister may after consultation with and the advice of the registrar prohibit the operation of the body", the proposed Bill stipulates.

The Opposition Alliance, a local political alliance for opposition parties in the country, has also joined churches in opposing the enactment of the Bill.

Speaking at Athi River town, some few kilometres from the Kenyan capital, on December 1, the Alliance's leaders said the Bill was aimed at silencing " God's messengers from delivering the message they have been given for the world".

Its chairman, Mr. Mwai Kibaki, said it was a pity that some leaders contemplated blocking God's mouthpiece from pointing out evil. "The Government is drunk with power and now wants to usurp God's role as the head of the church", he stressed.

In a turn of events, the general secretary of the ruling political party, KANU (Kenya African National Union), Mr. Joseph Kamotho, denied on December 1 that the government had ever drafted any Bill to control regulation and registration of religious organizations.

According to Kamotho, the government had set up a committee to look into ways of checking the mushrooming religious cults. "The government has no intention of taking a contentious Bill to Parliament", he said, adding, "Even President Daniel arap Moi will not accept something which is not acceptable to the majority of Kenyans".

On November 29, the Acting chairman of the Law Reform Commission, Mr. J.F. H. Hamilton, while admitting that the proposed Bill had been drafted, said " it (the Bill) is far from being tabled in Parliament."


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


185 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Sudan;
Sudanese Women Stage Cultural Activities in Nairobi


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Nairobi - The Sudanese Women Association in Nairobi (SWAN) held a colourful cultural event at Kenyatta International Conference Centre (KICC) in Nairobi on November 30 in which over 50 women participated.

Dr. Pauline Riak, the chairperson of SWAN, told the crowd at KICC, "When social disintegration occurs in the society, women are expected to build relationships and the social fabric of human living through care and nurturing. The physical and psychological costs are high as women try to build stable lives amidst the massive internal and external population movements that are occurring," she explained. 

The Association is strengthening exiled and refugee women and has brought a strong sense of unity as well as a desire to work for their common good. SWAN was begun in February 1984 and has 494 members.

Another problem common to SWAN members is violence against women. "Domestic violence not only causes women and children physical and psychological suffering, but is also a major obstacle to individual growth and women's participation in development," Dr. Riak said.

SWAN is unique in that it was conceived, developed and managed by urban refugee without initial prompting or input from other individuals. Further, its members are heterogenous and are active participants in various warring factions inside Sudan.

Dr. Riak recognizes that Sudan is still at war. "Our questions have to do with dignified survival and the struggle for a just peace and national development," she explained.

The theme of the November 30 event was "SWAN IS A SYMBOL OF UNITY AND LOVE". Participants came from Nairobi, Kisumu (in Western Kenya) and seven African countries including Ethiopia, Uganda, Tanzania, Zimbabwe, and Sudan. Tribal dances were presented, locally made clothes, baskets and other items were on exhibition and traditional foods were also cooked.

SWAN has organized previous workshops on various topics such as stress control, HIV/AIDS and self reliance, how to make homes, and participation in nation building.

"Given the conflicts ranging among us in the south, the cultural activities are quite impressive," one member remarked.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 9, 1996


Zaire;
Fears Over Safety Of Catholic Bishop Seized By Tutsi Rebels


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Goma, Zaire - Religious authorities in eastern Zaire have expressed concern for the safety of a former Roman Catholic bishop who has not been seen since Zairean Tutsi rebel army personnel seized him on November 30.

Monsignor Phocas Nikwigize, 77, the former Hutu bishop of Ruhengeri in western Rwanda, was taken by a military official and three soldiers of the rebel authorities as he attempted to cross back into Rwanda, members of a missionary group in Goma reported.

The former bishop had accompanied tens of thousands of his parishioners into Zaire after they fled Ruhengeri in the closing stages of the 1994 civil war in which Hutu militias massacred more than a million Rwandese, mostly Tutsis. 

Nikwigize was prevented from crossing the Zairean border and driven away in his own car by a military official, a missionary with the White Fathers here said.

"No word of him has been received on either side of the border despite inquiries by aid workers in the region. It was clear by late Sunday that he had not entered Rwanda. We're afraid for his life," the missionary said.

Officials of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees and the International Committee of the Red Cross have made inquiries both in eastern Zaire and in Rwanda but without result, he explained.

An aide to the bishop of Goma, Monsignor Charles Maganya, is preparing a letter of protest to the rebel authorities who have controlled much of eastern Zaire since forcing out Zairean government forces in a rebellion six weeks ago.

The Vatican has been informed of Nikwigize's disappearance. Nikwigize, who resigned his bishopric in 1994, spent two years in Goma carrying out confirmations among the more than a million refugees living in camps in the region.

This follows the October 7 killing of four Spanish missionaries of the Marxist Order in Bukavu and the October 29 killing of the Roman Catholic archbishop of Bukavu, Monsignor Christopher Munzi Hirwa.

Zaire has 17.32 million Roman Catholics among its 43.8 million people, according to 1992 and 1994 figures. Christianity has existed in the vast African nation since Belgian colonial days, which ended with independence in June 1960.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


187 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Zambia;
Suspension Of Six Zambian Journalists Condemned


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Independent Media Association (ZIMA) and the Press Association of Zambia (PAZA) have condemned the suspension of six journalists from the state owned-media over allegation of receiving bribes from the Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT). The six were suspended on November 25 by the Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, Laura Harrison.

The six suspended are Zambia Information Service (ZIS) deputy director Nalishebo Mundia, Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation (ZNBC) commercial manager Abias Moyo, ZNBC sub-editor Gershom Musonda, Radio 2 manager Charles Banda, Kitwe-based ZNBC news editor Dominic Chimanyika and ZNBC-Television personality Chibamba Kanyama.

According to ZIMA, the suspensions follow allegations made on November 24, by former ZIMT vice-president, Alfred Zulu, to "project a positive image of the organization (ZIMT) and to promote the ideals of the opposition." Zimba alleged that the journalists had been appointed to the ZIMT board and were paid K200,000 (about US$170.00) a month to sit on it. But Zulu told ZIMA that only Gershom Musonda, Charles Banda and another ZNBC reporter, Rosemary Konkola, were members of his board. Zulu denied the other journalists were members of his board. None of the suspended journalists served as election monitors. 

ZIMT was among three independent monitors of the Zambia's November 18 presidential and parliamentary elections which declared the elections as 'not free and fair'. President Frederick Chiluba's Multiparty Movement Bright Mwape, ZIMA vice-chairman, stated "the suspension of government media journalists is harsh, premature and an affront to press freedom and democracy" . Mwape reportedly said that while ZIMA may not be in a position to comment on the merits of the case before concluding its own investigations, "it believed the rules of natural justice have been violated by the government's failure to lend the journalists initial opportunity to reply to the allegations made against them by a well-known discredited person - Isaac Zimba".

PAZA president, Ridgeway Liwena, The Post reports, charged in a press statement released in Lusaka on November 26 that "there was an element of injustice" in the manner Harrison handled the matter. "PAZA has learnt with surprise of the suspension of six journalists at Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation (ZNBC) and Zambia Information Services (ZIS) by the permanent secretary. We view the action as unfortunate in that it came from the highest authority. This denies the accused journalists an opportunity to appeal to the same ministry for arbitration," the statement asserted.

ZIMA further reports that Zambia's Electoral Commission chairman, Bobby Bwalya, threatened to order the arrest of a Post newspaper reporter for making inquiries about the November 18 election results. The Post reporter, Kunda Mwila, was threatened at the Electoral Commission's office on November 26. ZIMA says the reporter was inquiring on why election results from some polling stations had arrived a week late.

ZIMA reports that Bwaly, who had earlier refused to answer the reporter's questions in his office, "got emotional" when he later found reporter Mwila talking to the acting director of elections, Joel Sikazwe. Bwalya ordered Sikazwe not to entertain any questions from the reporter and "personally barred the reporter from entering Sikazwe's office, slammed the door in the reporter's face and warned that should he persist he would order police to have him arrested."

ZIMA chairperson, David Simpson, said that the report of Bwalya's threats against Mwila were "saddening". "It is saddening to see persons of the status of electoral commission chairperson, Judge Bobby Bwalya, not only refusing to answer legitimate press queries but also threatening to have the pressman arrested."

Reports of attacks on journalists in Zambia have earned international scorn as a letter from the Canadian Committee to Protect Journalists indicates. The letter, dated December 3 and addressed to Zambian president H.E. Fredrick Chiluba, views the ongoing legal cases as "contradictory to press freedom."

The letter further states, "We fear these actions mark the start of renewed clampdown on critics of the government in Zambia; therefore we urge you to encourage freedom of expression and the independence of the press, since they are essential to democracy."

Events of "persecution" against The Post newspaper throughout 1996,as well as a listing of the recent suspension and harassment of reporters, are detailed in the body of the letter.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


188 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Science and Health;
Aids Day Speeches Reveal Surge Of Cases In Africa


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Kampala - There is an alarming surge in HIV infection among teenage boys and girls in Kenya and Uganda, it was revealed as part of the activities to mark International AIDS Day.

Uganda's Deputy Prime Minister Brigadier Moses Ali told World AIDS Day participants (December 1) in the south-western Uganda town of Kabale that the rate of HIV infection is rising faster among adolescents than among adults. Fifty five per cent of the estimated 1.5 million people infected with HIV in Uganda are under age 19.

Brig. Ali told participants that as a consequence life expectancy in Uganda will by the year 2000 drop to 31-35 years due to the AIDS pandemic, down from 35-40 at present. Uganda's current life expectancy is already among the lowest in the world. 

Ali urged religious organizations in Uganda to subject individuals who claim "healing by faith" to scientific scrutiny to avoid exploitation by charlatans posing as faith healers. A number of controversial Ugandan preachers have claimed success in healing AIDS by the power of prayer.

Retired Anglican Bishop Misaeri Kauma, the Chairman of Uganda's AIDS Commission, pointed out that there were already 1.5 million AIDS orphans in Uganda. He wanted Uganda communities to sustain the traditional collective approach to help these children.

In neighbouring Kenya a disturbing study by two researchers indicates that adult AIDS victims believe that engaging in sex with minors confers healing to the affected individual, i.e. that it is a rejuvenating process. The study covered the worst HIV hit areas of Kenya.

The study conducted by Michael Mbito and Steven Thuku of the Centre for Adolescent Health (CAH), which focuses on creating awareness of health physical/mental issues among teenagers, revealed that many women with AIDS establish sexual affairs with minors in the belief that their condition would be alleviated. Males who are carrying AIDS, believing similarly, also establish relations with young girls.

CAH will hold a youth camp at St. Andrews Church, Nairobi, between 16-21 December at which youths will be enlightened on the impact of HIV/AIDS and its rapid spread in Kenya.

Meanwhile in South Africa retired Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu used the occasion of AIDS Day to urge South Africans to use the condom if they cannot stick to Christian teachings on sex. He appeared in an advertisement on state television as part of AIDS Day activities in South Africa.

"We in South Africa believe that sex should take place only in marriage." However, I want to urge all those who choose to have sex outside marriage to take the right precautions and practice safer sex. Please use a condom," said the retired prelate.

Archbishop Tutu's concern is motivated by recent South African statistics showing that nearly 4.5 per cent of the nation's population of 40 million is infected with HIV.

And in Liberia, the deadly disease is also on the increase. 150 cases and 43 deaths have been reported.

Speaking to journalists in Monrovia on a pro-World AIDS Day briefing November 28, the programme manager of the National AIDS and STD Central Programme (NACP) Dr. Isabella Simbeyo explained that this number does not represent the total number of persons infected throughout the country. He said the NACP has not been able to reach the entire country because of the civil war.

On plans to help control the spread of the disease, Dr. Simbeyo said "the NACP embarked upon a five-day community awareness campaign." The first area, he said, was in Clara Town on the Bushrad Island.

Dr. Simbeyo however lamented the government's inability to support the NACP. "The government is responsible to support this programme, but due to what is happening now in Liberia, where there is no money, the NACP is not fully supported," he said.

Dr. Simbeyo said there are plans for the NACP to go full blast as there are signs that the programme may receive some help from international Non- Governmental Organizations (NGOs).


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


189 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Sierra Leone;
Peace Dawns On Sierra Leone As Peace Accord Is Signed


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

Freetown - Sierra Leonean President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah and rebel leader Foday Sankoh signed a long-awaited peace accord here November 30, ending more than five years of civil war.

The deal paved the way for an immediate cessation of hostilities, the demobilisation and disarmament of Sankoh's Revolutionary United Front (RUF), and its integration into the national army.

Under the terms of the treaty, the RUF -- at war with successive Sierra Leonean governments since 1991 -- will also become a legitimate political party.

But both men and other parties in the peace process warned that the accord alone was not enough to end the crisis in Sierra Leone, one of the poorest countries in the world. 

"The challenge facing us now is how best to address ourselves to good leadership, governance and democracy," said Sankoh, whose Revolutionary United Front (RUF) has battled successive governments in Freetown since 1991. "If leadership fails, the people will take up arms again."

Sankoh and other senior members of the RUF had attempted to make last- minute changes to the deal in talks with Ivory Coast, whose government had been attempting to broker an end to the conflict since February.

However, RUF demands for the immediate withdrawal from Sierra Leone of foreign troops helping the army -- especially a South African mercenary unit - - were rejected, ministry sources said.

Instead, the document, which both Kabbah and Sankoh undertook to sign in a joint statement released earlier this month, would call for the departure of the mercenaries without specifying a withdrawal date.

Until February 1996, when an RUF delegation met representatives of Sierra Leone's defunct military junta in Abidjan, the rebels said they would not approach the negotiating table unless all foreign troops were expelled.

In May, by which time the junta had ceded power to Kabbah's elected regime, the question of foreign troops was one of two points in a detailed accord on which both parties failed to agree, and negotiations were suspended.

The second point was the RUF's insistence that a national budgetary and debt committee be set up to evaluate and deal with Sierra Leone's debt.

The accord will meet this demand in principle, but will not include specific undertakings, the Ivory Coast foreign ministry sources said.

Although the RUF maintains it is not a "spent force," observers believe the rebels no longer enjoy their former military strength and that their bargaining power has accordingly diminished.

A ceasefire has supposedly been in place since the early stages of the peace talks, but military authorities in Freetown have claimed considerable victories over the rebels in the last few months.

Many of these victories were achieved with the help of local militia groups, made up of traditional hunters known as Kamojor, the authorities said.

Earlier this month, Kabbah warned he would use the "military option" if the rebels failed to lay down their arms by December 1.

News of the peace accord, signed at 4:00 p.m. (1600 GMT) in the Ivorian capital, was greeted with widespread jubilation in Freetown itself, where people danced and cheered, cars and ships honked their horns and church bells rang.

"The war is over. We have peace at last," shouted revellers. The scene in Abidjan was more sober, though the two erstwhile enemies did embrace each other during the signing ceremony, and praised the accord as a new beginning for the impoverished west African nation.

"A tortuous period for the people of Sierra Leone has come to an end. In effect, the war has ended," said Kabbah of the pact.

The pact is "the dawn of a new era for Sierra Leone, an era of democracy, accountability and performance," said Sankoh.

Since the RUF took up arms against the government, more than 10,000 people in Sierra Leone have died and around one million have been displaced from their homes. An already poor economy has been ruined by damage to industry and agriculture.

Ivory Coast President Henri Konan Bedie, whose government hosted and mediated the peace process initiated in February, said the signing was "an historical event."

But he added the accord was a "framework which will not solve all problems. Its effective implementation requires much effort and patience."

A day before the ceremony, Sankoh had told journalists in his villa in Abidjan, where he has been staying since peace talks began in February, that it was imperative for both parties to sign, to come together.

"I am signing in the interests of the people of Sierra Leone," said Sankoh, barefoot and wearing loose blue robes and a light, greying beard. "The government is not forcing me to sign."

Sankoh returned on Wednesday from his jungle bases in Sierra Leone, where he had spent five days discussing the peace process with his fighters. The trip was "more or less successful. The boys' morale is high," he said.

Asked about the reported capture of RUF bases in the extreme east, near the Liberian border, Sankoh accused the army of violating a ceasefire agreed upon in the early stages of the peace process and reiterated in a joint communique signed a week ago by Kabbah and Sankoh.

"On their way to Kailahun 300 kilometers east of Freetown some fighters were attacked. They had to cross into Liberia instead of surrendering to the enemy. They would never surrender," said Sankoh.

The rebel leader accused government forces of staging attacks on RUF positions while he was in Sierra Leone.

"Kabbah has no control even of government forces," he said, adding, "but there is no need for us to complain."

"Is he ready for peace?" Sankoh asked, or just for "the donors and investment" that peace will bring?

Speaking of the rebellion he launched in 1991, since when more than 10,000 people have died, he said he took up arms "to show our concern for the people, because the system was using violence against the people."

Peaceful protests, such as strikes and demonstrations, failed to achieve democracy and "there was no alternative" to fighting, as "the armed struggle is a legitimate part of democracy."

As well as Bedie, ambassadors to Ivory Coast from the United States, Great Britain and France, representatives of the United Nations, the Organization of African Unity, the Commonwealth and several non- governmental organizations, the chairman of the African Development Bank, as well as a host of senior Ivory Coast military officers and ministers, attended the signing ceremony.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
