190 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Delegates Shed Tears At Historic Slave Trade Site


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Salvador, Brazil - The grey sea foamed against the dock at Solar do Unhao Saturday, just as it did for over 300 years during which 6 to 12 million African men and women arrived in Salvador, Bahia, Brazil, brought in ships to begin a life of slavery.

Solar do Unhao (Mansion of Unhao -- the name of the slave trader whose home still remains) was the site of morning worship (30 November) on the seventh day of the World Council of Churches' Conference held in Salvador, Brazil November 24 - December 3.

More than 400 members of the conference went to the historic slave dock in a convoy of buses, a mini-bus and six taxis. The delegates were clearly moved as they walked in a guided meditation from the dock where the slave ships landed, to a nearby white stucco shed where historians believe men and women were classified by age, size and relative health. 

In silence, men and women from around the globe made their way to a small church behind the dock where water was thrown on the slaves -- a collective " baptism" of human beings who were considered a cargo by their captors.

As the delegates gathered at the front of the dock, facing the surging Atlantic in the direction of the distant African coast, they sang "Deep River, " an African-American spiritual.

Then came a prayer of confession. "When others are cast down, and enslaved, made of no account for the menial labour they produce for the benefit of their masters, we watch from afar."

Dr. Aaron Tolen (Cameroon Presbyterian Church), one of eight presidents of the WCC, reminded the worshipers that there was abundant guilt in the years of the slave trade, which began before 1492 when Portuguese merchants and seafarers kidnapped Africans to be used as slaves in Portugal.

"Dear African brothers and sisters, we have heard words of repentance," Tolen said. "But those who brought us here were not alone in the making of this tragedy. We Africans share in the responsibility. We have degraded ourselves by selling our brothers and sisters as goods."

The Rev. Dr. Janice Nessibou of the Presbyterian Church of Ghana stood beside Elizabeth Sele Mulbah (Province of West Africa, Liberia) as she lifted a time-worn orange brick.

"This stone, that we have brought from Ghana, is a stone of tears," Nessibou explained. The brick was from the outer wall of a slave fort, Cape Coast Castle, in Ghana, where slaves were loaded for their long voyage to South America.

"During a project under the guise of restoration, the fort was destroyed," she said. "A local chief collected the stones and he called them 'stones of tears.'"

When the chief heard that the WCC was to hold a meeting in Salvador, "he sent this stone to be presented to the Afro-Brazilian community," Nessibou said. "Words cannot express what this stone means to our very souls."

The brick was accepted by Enilson Souza Rocha, general director of Ecumenical Coordination of Services (CESE) in Salvador. Rocha and the two women embraced one another with evident emotion.

Father Joseph A. Kwame Labi (Patriarchate of Alexandria) led the worshipers in an act of cleansing. Large bowls of water were placed at the front of the worship space and people lined up to dip their hands and wash their faces.

"You are invited to wash your hands in fresh water as a sign of healing, reconciliation and hope," Labi said.

As they came to the water bowls, delegates sang "Ewelina mandla," a Xhosa hymn from South Africa, and "O Healing River," an African- American spiritual.

After the words of absolution were said, the delegates received red, green and yellow ribbons which they tied around one another's wrists as a sign of " enduring friendship".

The young drummers of Olodum, a troupe of former Brazilian street children brought the service to a dramatic end.

Softly, the drum beat began.

"What sound is this?" asked Father Labi. The drums increased in volume as he answered, "This is the sound of a culture that refused to die. It is the resistance of those building a new community."

Delegates swayed and moved to the beat as the drums thundered in the courtyard. Others made their way to the edge of the dock and stood silently. As they gazed at the distant ocean horizon, their eyes brimmed with tears.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
World Conference Explores Christianity's Cultural Richness


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

Salvador, Brazil - Some 600 Christians from more than 80 nations gathered in Salvador, Bahia, Brazil on November 24 to December 3 to examine their cultural distinctions and learn more about how cultures have influenced a wide range of insights into the one gospel of Jesus Christ.

The Conference on World Mission and Evangelism, sponsored by the World Council of Churches (WCC), opened with worship Sunday night (24 November) in a canopied area overlooking the humid Atlantic shore.

Hundreds of delegates, whose clothing ranged from simple shirts and blouses to richly ornamented national garments, raised their voices lustily in order to be heard over a roaring thunderstorm as they sang the closing hymn, "Jesus Christ the Joy of the World."

The service was interrupted by a peaceful demonstration by Brazilian Methodists who displayed a banner decrying alleged sexism in their church. The protest took place in front of Methodist Bishop Paulo Ayres Mattos as he stood to deliver his sermon. Many of the delegates appeared not to know what was happening as a woman shouted denunciations of the bishop until her microphone was unplugged. 

Enilson Soza Silva, general secretary of the Ecumenical Commission of Service in Brazil, apologized to Mattos for the interruption. "This is truly a country of contrasts," he told the delegates.

Mattos declined to continue his sermon. "May God bless this conference," he said. "I hope that anything we do and anything we say has to do with the real capacity of the church to live in diversity and accept differences."

The conference is the 11th in a series of world mission encounters that began in 1910 in Edinburgh, Scotland. The last conference was held in San Antonio, Texas (USA) in 1989.

Under the conference theme, "Called to One Hope - the Gospel in Diverse Cultures," delegates will consider the results of an extensive worldwide five- year study examining the ways cultures and the gospel have influenced each other.

At a first press briefing, the Rev. Ana Langerak (Lutheran Church in Costa Rica), director of the WCC Unit that is organizing the conference, said the meeting site was carefully chosen.

The Brazilian state of Bahia has the second largest population of African blacks of any nation and Christians there live amid a vast array of cultures, she said. "Salvador is a microcosm of (the world's) diversity."

Bahia Christians include Roman Catholics, pentecostals, evangelicals, Protestants and Candomble, an indigenous Afro- Brazilian religion which some critics complain is a syncretistic combination of Christianity and spirit worship.

"Around the world we still experience the cultural alienation of Christians, " said the Rev. Christopher Duraisingh, (Church of South India) as he led the gospel and cultures study. Some falsely claimed, "in the name of the Gospel, apartheid could be defended. In the name of the Gospel, the (low) status of women could be defended."

"Xenophobia is rampant (and) the churches are no exception here," he added. But the main thrust of the conference, Duraisingh said, will be "the renewal of churches in mission and what that means for a local congregation."

"This is not a conference in which a few charismatic leaders speak and everyone takes notes and goes on," Duraisingh pointed out. "It's a conference that intentionally will want to listen to people on the ground."

True to this promise, the following two days were filled with nearly 30 " uncontros" (meetings) designed to expose delegates to the many ways in which cultures are reflecting the gospel of Jesus Christ around the world.

The alienated youth culture of Germany, competition with Muslim evangelists in Africa, the television culture of the United States and the increased visibility of the Sami people of the Nordic countries ...all these issues and more were raised in the encontros.

Exhibits showcasing the sites and colours of 28 national churches were also featured in a "Rainbow" festival of gospel and cultures running parallel to the conference.

The churches in Africa face a variety of challenges but most of them are open to leadership by young adults and women, according to Dr. Setri Nyomi of the All Africa Conference of Churches.

Nyomi said Christians are trying to avoid direct confrontations with Islamic evangelists who are increasingly active in Africa. "Our approach is to talk together and diminish the importance of competition," he said. "In talking together, we come to understand each other better and discover ways of working together."

Christians and Muslims are both winning converts among the indigenous religions of Africa, Nyomi said at the African encontro. In the meantime, Christianity continues to grow on the continent. Christians in Ethiopia are 40-million strong, reported Dimetros Woldu (Ethiopian Orthodox Church).

Encontros from Germany, UK, Cuba, Nordic countries and the US, among others, brought many issues of culture and religion to the attention of the delegates. Three specialized issue-centred encontros exposed delegates to cultural issues of indigenous peoples, youth and women.

Tables and booths in the Rainbow Festival displayed traditional clothing, vestments, artifacts and literature from churches around the globe.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


192 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 52 on Eastern Zaire (12/09)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Nairobi - WFP and UNHCR report that some 15,000 refugees have left the Kagenyi and Rubwere camps in the Karagwe region. According to some reports, they are said to be heading north and east. The exodus took place between Friday and Sunday night, and more people were reported to be on the road today although heavy rains appear to have temporarily stalled the refugee movement.

Some media accounts say aid workers have put forward the theory that Hutu hardliners may be organising mass departures in response to the repatriation preparations. 

Some 300 Rwandan refugees returned home from Tanzania on Sunday and many more were expected to follow on Tuesday, according to UNHCR, quoted by AFP. Earlier, UNHCR announced the return of about 1,118 refugees on Friday. It said a mass return was expected tomorrow after the food rations were distributed to refugees today. A UNHCR update, issued on Friday, said preparations for the return included setting up two way stations on the 30km road from the camps to the border and four water points, which would also be used as a collection point for children separated from their parents. WFP said it was distributing food to refugees in the greater Benaco and Ngara camps. The rations, consisting of cereals, pulses and vegetable oil, will be distributed to camps in the Karagwe region later in the week.

Rwandan radio said a planned operation to repatriate some 1,000 refugees from Tanzania on Saturday was scrapped. Rwandan military and civilian officials who went to the border to welcome the returnees were told the operation had been cancelled, but no reasons were given. The radio also reported that 163 Rwandan refugees arrived back in Kigali from Brazzaville, Congo, on Friday. It said 800 Rwandans had fled to the Congolese capital from Kinshasa last month after being "harassed and tortured" following events in eastern Zaire. More returnees were expected in the coming days.

Meanwhile, the refugee influx from Zaire and Burundi in Tanzania's Kigoma region has slowed down, UNHCR reported. In its Friday update, it said that over the last five days 5,200 refugees had arrived from Burundi and 550 had come by boat from Zaire. Some 100,000 refugees have arrived in Kigoma since last month.

Schools were due to reopen in the south Kivu area of eastern Zaire today after the regional authorities held a meeting last week to discuss the issue. Municipal and educational authorites would visit educational establishments in the course of the day to learn more about the situation, rebel Radio of the People announced.

Recent visitors to Zairean President Mobutu say his health is deteriorating and doubt whether he will ever return home, Associated Press reported yesterday. The news agency said it had been told privately by Mobutu's chief aide, Bosco Kassoubia, that the president "is very sick ... and he is very tired. He is incapable of having more than one visit a day." On Saturday, Kassoubia announced that all photo opportunities of the president would cease. Mobutu, who has not been in Zaire since August, is convalescing from cancer surgery at his villa in the south of France.

A report in the Washington Post said State Department officials believed Mobutu was negotiating with the South African Executive Outcomes security firm to supply mercenaries to put down the eastern Zaire rebellion. Rumours have been circulating of mercenary involvement on the side of the Zairean army. According to South African radio, French newspapers reported last week that 300 mercenaries were fighting alongside the Zaireans. However Executive Outcomes has denied the allegations. The radio reported the firm's owner as saying he had been approached to help in the Great Lakes region, but had declined.

French Foreign Minister Herve de Charette reiterated the call for an international conference on the Great Lakes region. In an interview with Radio France Internationale on Friday, he stated that Zaire's territorial integrity was a prerequisite for regional peace. He said a "latent civil war" was taking root in Zaire, with increasing political problems, and a conference should be convened as soon as possible, under UN and OAU auspices.

Leaders of Red Cross groups from the five Great Lakes countries were due to meet in Nairobi today to discuss the humanitarian crisis in the region. The two-day meeting, comprising representatives of the International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies from Burundi, Rwanda, Zaire, Tanzania and Uganda, will focus on strategic planning in the area, AFP said.

The Rwandan justice minister Faustin Nteziryayo met the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Jose Ayala Lasso, on Saturday to discuss the human rights situation in the country following the mass return of Rwandan refugees. A report on Rwandan radio said the minister briefed Ayala Lasso on measures taken by Rwanda to improve human rights conditions, especially in the country's prisons. Steps taken included the temporary release of minor offenders and setting up committees to examine the cases of detainees. He also explained that "advanced preparations" were underway regarding the trials of genocide suspects. Official Rwandan sources, quoted by AFP today, said the names of 1,900 genocide suspects had been published, listed by commune and prefecture. They are suspected of "first degree" involvement in the 1994 genocide, which renders them liable to the death penalty under a new law introduced in September.

Nairobi, 9 December 1995, 14:50 GMT (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


193 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 51 on Eastern Zaire (12/07-08)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Nairobi - Lt-Gen Maurice Baril, Canadian commander of the multi-national force has said the situation in eastern Zaire is improving. "Life is returning to normal, the markets are open and people are coming home," said Baril, who arrived in Goma on Sunday.

Any force sent to the region must have "a mission to accomplish", he added, hinting there may no longer be any need for sending foreign troops. While in Goma, Baril said he had not seen any movement of refugees during his visit, but acknowledged some were further west in the Zairean forest without aid. " The groups have broken up," he said. "It is difficult to know exactly where they are." He indicated that food-drops were now probably out of the question, describing them as "costly and dangerous". However, "if there were to be a catastrophe, we could do food-drops," he said. 

France insisted it was still committed to an international force, despite remarks at the weekend by Cooperation Minister Jacques Godfrain in which he said there was "no longer any question of going there (eastern Zaire)." The French foreign ministry later issued a commnique stating that "France's position on the implementation of United Nations resolutions on Zaire, notably on the deployment of a multi-national force, has not changed."

In an interview with Kenya's Sunday Standard newspaper, rebel commander Andre Ngandu Kissasse said his troops "had the weapons and the people's will to fight a war. We will reach Kinshasa very soon." He said some Zairean soldiers had joined the rebels, and others were so disillusioned without pay that they were no longer capable of fighting. Rebel leader Laurent Kabila meanwhile, who paid a short visit to Bukavu on Friday, told recruits in the area it was time to carry out the liberation struggle, rebel Radio of the People reported on Saturday. He defined their mission as "a disciplined army at the service of the people ... an elite body different from an outlawed armed gang."

UNHCR spokesman Filippo Grandi told AFP on Saturday that there have been 2, 754 corpses picked up and buried in the Goma region between November 2 and December 4. He said his figures were based on data from a local humanitarian agency working for UNHCR with responsibility for burying bodies. He added it was not known who killed them but that some had died of exhaustion or illness. Half of the bodies were thought to be refugees, and the rest Zaireans.

Ugandan security sources, quoted by AFP on Saturday, said at least 3,000 Zairean soldiers had joined up with Ugandan rebels based in Zaire. According to the sources, the soldiers - who had been driven out of Beni by Zairean rebels - believed the Ugandan army had helped the rebels take control of Beni, and they were now siding with the rebel Ugandan Allied Democratic Forces (ADF). Uganda has consistently denied any involvement in the Beni takeover.

Amnesty International has expressed concern that Rwandan refugees in Tanzania will be returned home without consideration for their rights to continue to seek asylum. In a statement dated 6 December, Amnesty "appeals for an immediate withdrawal of the decision by the Tanzanian government to expel all Rwandese refugees by 31 December 1996 and is urging the UNHCR to desist from taking any actions which would condone this decision". Saying that the refugees are "not just an anonymous mass", the human rights organization says many of them "would be at risk on return," due to continuing human rights problems within Rwanda.

A report from the UN Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda released on 7 December indicates that 162 returnees have so far been placed in detention from over 500,000 who returned from Zaire during November. The UNHRFOR says that 322,964 people had been registered in their home communes as of 1 December, and that "returnees were generally well-received". Some of those in detention are seeking protection from revenge attacks. In general, the report says local authorities have respected national directives so that arrests take place only after case files have been completed. 4,331 members of the former Rwandan Armed Forces (ex-FAR) have been registered, 12 of whom have been arrested. HRFOR have received reports of 26 returnees being ill-treated at the time of their arrest or during detention and are investigating.

Four returnees and two of their associates have been killed, according to HRFOR, but also four genocide survivors and two of their associates have been reported killed by returnees, apparently in an attempt to eliminate witnesses to crimes committed in 1994. HRFOR reports that property problems could be the largest impediment to rapid reintegration. The lack of housing - particularly in urban areas remains a "real and serious" problem.

In its report, the HRFOR reported on the reception of 75,000 Rwandan returnees who came from Burundi in July and August. Of those, about 2.65% are in detention presently.

Nairobi, 9 December 1996, 08:40 GMT (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


194 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Weekly Emergency Report No. 48


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3814 words


 

Rome - This report includes: A) Burundi, Rwanda, Zaire and Tanzania B) Liberia and Sierra Leone C) Angola. Issued 6 December 1996

PART I - HIGHLIGHTS (Details below in Part II)

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. Eastern Zaire a) WFP and other UN agencies maintain presence in the towns of Goma and Bukavu, but access to surrounding areas limited. b) Humanitarian agencies reach Uvira from Bukavu 3 December, marking first UN visit since evacuation of staff in October. Uvira markets reported functioning; commercial traffic on the escarpment road described as normal. c) UNHCR/WFP attempted mission to Sake and Minova area unsuccessful due to security problems near Sake. Distribution of WFP high-energy biscuits to returning refugees at way stations at Sake, Mugunga and Kulungu continues. d) No authorisation received for direct airlift from Entebbe to Kisangani. Situation in Kisangani unclear, but reported unstable. 

2. Burundi a) WFP continues attempts to increase food reserves in Burundi by exploring possibilities of moving food and fuel from Kigoma via the lake to augment present road transport. b) WFP mission to provinces of Gitega, Rutana and Ruyigi, origin of most Burundian refugees recently fleeing to Tanzania, reports continued tension; several communes described as almost completely empty. c) UN evaluation mission to Cibitoke confirms that large numbers of returnees continue to arrive from Zaire. d) Medical supplies for Action Contre la Faim brought to Bujumbura from Nairobi on Hercules flight organised by WFP.

3. Rwanda a) Another 28,000 returnees cross to Rwanda from Zaire during the week; more arrivals from Zaire expected. b) Since start of distributions of food assistance to returnees on 16 November, WFP and NGO partners have distributed 6,200 metric tons (as of 6 December), representing 380,000 monthly rations. c) Currently 2,210 metric tons of food are pre-positioned for the returnee programme; deliveries from WFP regional stocks are being stepped up. d) Measures taken to prepare for the arrival of returnees from Tanzania.

4. Tanzania a) Joint statement issued by UNHCR and the Government of Tanzania announces that all Rwandan refugees in Tanzania are to return to Rwanda by the end of the year; Government gives assurance that repatriation programme is to be carried out in an orderly and humane manner. Tanzania currently hosts 530,000 Rwandan refugees. b) Refugees continue to arrive in Kigoma region from Burundi. WFP dispatches additional blended food to increase supplementary feeding programmes in the region.

B. LIBERIA AND SIERRA LEONE

1. Liberia a) WFP food is given to disarmed soldiers as demobilisation process continues. b) Demobilisation begins in Voinjama, where hundreds of displaced persons and Liberian refugees from Guinea have returned following the deployment of ECOMOG troops. c) Support provided by WFP to Red Cross and UNICEF food-for- work projects to improve sanitary conditions in internally displaced shelters in Monrovia, and to NGO partner CCC in Tubmanburg for a similar project.

2. Sierra Leone a) Peace accord is signed by Sierra Leone President Ahmed Kabbah and RUF rebel leader Foday Sankoh. b) WFP will end general food distributions by 31 December, to focus on resettlement and rehabilitation programmes. c) Some 25,000 returnees in Pujehun district receive WFP return packages through World Vision and CCSL. d) Assembly points for disarmament and demobilisation of RUF combatants identified. USD 1.5 million received towards total Government demobilisation programme needs of USD 35 million.

C. ANGOLA

1. Update a) DHA Flash Appeal to donors issued in Angola on 21 November to cover UN requirements for demobilisation programmes. WFP requirements are 18, 700 metric tons of food commodities. b) UNAVEM to begin withdrawal by the end of the year. c) Security situation calm except for ambushes late November.

PART II - DETAILS

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. EASTERN ZAIRE - information as of 6 December

1.1 Although UN agencies, including WFP, now have a presence in the towns of Goma and Bukavu, access to the surrounding areas is limited. On 3 December, humanitarian staff were finally able to reach Uvira from Bukavu. This represents the first visit that UN agencies, including WFP, were able to carry out to the Uvira area since their evacuation in October.

1.2 The UN/NGO team that visited Uvira on 3 December met with the de facto authorities and were able to visit the town. While some WFP local staff were still in place, the WFP Office had been completely looted, as had the temporary warehouses. Access to the port was denied; however, the two cranes were reported to be more or less intact. Uvira town was reported to be very calm: markets had re-opened and were reasonably well supplied. Commercial traffic on the escarpment road was reported to be normal. No refugees were seen on the road.

1.3 Following reports of some 40-50,000 refugees moving from the Minova area (17 km south of Sake on the road between Goma and Bukavu) towards Goma, a UNHCR/WFP mission tried to visit the Sake/Minova area on 28 November, accompanied by Lieutenant General Baril, head of the multi-national force, but was forced to turn back to Goma when bursts of gunfire were heard on the road close to Sake. Agencies were denied access to Minova on 29 November. Distribution of WFP high-energy biscuits to returning refugees at other road- side way stations located at Sake, Mugunga, and Kulungu, which started on 29 November, continued throughout the week.

1.4 WFP has been waiting for authorisation from the Zairian authorities to conduct an airlift directly to Kisangani from Entebbe. So far, clearance has been given only to fly via Kinshasa, an unfeasible route given the vast distances involved. 95 metric tons of WFP food remain on standby at Entebbe airport.

1.5 WFP staff in Kisangani report that the security situation is unstable. A number of agencies have recently evacuated or reduced the number of their international staff.

2. BURUNDI

2.1 WFP food reserves in Burundi continue to be depleted as distributions outstrip imports. Meanwhile, WFP is pursuing all possible solutions to the problem of moving food and fuel to Bujumbura on Lake Tanganyika from Kigoma, Tanzania. Only by opening up this route will WFP be able to deliver the 2,500 metric tons authorised by the Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee, which is needed to feed the growing number of internally displaced persons and returnees.

2.2 Most Burundians who have fled to Tanzania since the beginning of November originated in the central and eastern provinces of Gitega, Rutana and Ruyigi. A WFP mission to that area during the week found continued tension, with several communes almost deserted. Burundian refugees in Tanzania now number some 190,000, larger than the Burundian population of the Uvira camps before the Eastern Zaire crisis.

2.3 During November, according to UNHCR figures cited in a DHA report, a total of 59,000 returnees crossed to Burundi from Eastern Zaire. This included 15,377 who passed through the Gatumba transit camp and approximately 44,000 who went directly to Citiboke province from Zaire. The WFP Burundi Country Director joined a UN evaluation mission to Cibitoke, and found that large numbers of returnees continue to arrive in Cibitoke and are camped along the main north-south road.

2.4 Insecurity continued to affect much of the country during the past week. In addition to the on-going insecurity in Rutana, Ruyigi and Cankuzo provinces, the WFP sub-office in Ngozi reported that problems continue in Kayanza and Muramvya provinces and in the north of Gitega province.

2.5 WFP Burundi caseload totalled 135,997 last week, of which 73,119 were beneficiaries of emergency relief distributions. A total of 24,765 people benefited from the WFP returnee package from 25 November to 1 December, 3,444 spontaneous returnees in Cibitoke province and 1,269 returnees at the Gatumba transit site (Bujumbura Rural province).

2.6 WFP organised a flight by a C-130 Hercules transport plane carrying 15 metric tons of medicines for Action Contre la Faim to Bujumbura from Nairobi. This quantity is in addition to the 52 metric tons of medicines carried by WFP trucks from Tanzania for various humanitarian agencies since the beginning of November.

3. RWANDA

3.1 The general security situation in Rwanda is calm and stable. However some incidents were reported at commune level.

3.2 More than 550,000 refugees are estimated to have returned to Rwanda from 15 to 30 November. Registration by local authorities currently in process to determine exact numbers.

3.3 Some 28,000 returnees came back to Rwanda from Zaire during the week of 27 November to 2 December, 24,000 via Gisenyi, 3,500 via Cyangugu and 500 via Kibungo. Further arrivals from Zaire are expected.

3.4 Distributions are currently on-going in all prefectures of Rwanda. They are generally implemented at the commune level, with the exception of Umutara, Kibungo, Butare, Gikongoro and Cyangugu where, due to low repatriation, the returnees receive assistance in transit centres at the prefecture level.

3.5 From 16 November, when distributions of food aid to returnees started, until 6 December, WFP and NGO partners distributed approximately 6,170 metric tons, which represents a total of 1,600,000 weekly rations or 380,000 monthly rations. In most communes monthly rations are provided.

3.6 The number of Zairian and Burundian refugees in Cyangugu prefecture has decreased due to repatriation. Currently, there are 400 Zairians (from Uvira) and 2,600 Burundians (from Cibitoke) in Cyangugu camps.

3.7 A total of 2,212 metric tons of food are pre-positioned for the returnee programme (equivalent to 571,071 weekly rations). The overall WFP stock position in the country stands at 7,805 metric tons (equivalent to 1, 570,000 weekly rations). Deliveries from WFP regional stocks to Rwanda are being stepped up to cover the increased distribution needs.

3.8 WFP is taking necessary measures to prepare for the arrival of returnees from Tanzania. Prefectures which are expected to receive the most returnees are Kibungo, Byumba and Butare. Food is being pre-positioned at commune level with the assistance of NGOs. WFP staffing is being strengthened and logistical capacity augmented in these prefectures.

3.9 Stocks of biscuits are also in place in areas expected to receive further returnees. Stock levels presently stand at 364 metric tons with 54 metric tons due to arrive shortly. The total is equivalent to 1,671,264 daily rations. Way-stations have been identified for distribution alongside the roads.

3.10 The WFP short-haul trucking fleet operating in Rwanda now numbers 39 trucks (7 x 7 metric tons capacity and 32 x 15 metric tons capacity). An additional 16 trucks (15 metric tons capacity) are expected to arrive in the coming days. WFP is currently looking into possibilities of increasing its short- haul fleet further due to the expected arrival of returnees from Tanzania. These trucks are used country-wide to assist in the food distributions at the commune level.

3.11 In order to facilitate the reintegration of returnees, the WFP Country Office is planning a massive expansion of food-for-work activities in Rwanda. Within a month an increase of up to 30 per cent is anticipated in some areas.

3.12 Food prices at local markets have risen in several areas of Rwanda. Some increases are due to crop failures and some to increased population because of massive repatriation. Further information on this issue will be available following the joint FAO/WFP crop and food supply assessment mission which started on 2 December.

4. TANZANIA

4.1 A joint statement has been released by UNHCR and the Government of Tanzania confirming that all Rwandan refugees in Tanzania are to return home by 31 December 1996. The message, addressed to all Rwandan refugees in the country, states that the United Republic of Tanzania has decided that all Rwandan refugees can now return to their country in safety. The Tanzanian Ministry of Home Affairs will coordinate the repatriation operations, assisted by the Tanzanian police force and, where necessary, the army. The Government of Tanzania has given its assurance that the repatriation process will be carried out in an orderly and humane manner. Tanzania hosts some 530, 000 Rwandan refugees.

4.2 Influxes continue on a large scale into Tanzania's Kigoma region. Kigoma has witnessed the arrival of approximately 102,000 new refugees since 1 November, bringing the overall population to 146,682 (approximately 116,000 Burundian refugees, 27,000 Zairians and 3,600 Rwandans). Influxes in the past few days have been predominantly from Burundi, where ethnic conflict is forcing increasing numbers to flee their homes. Burundian refugees arriving in Tanzania are in a poor nutritional state and WFP has despatched additional quantities of blended food to the region in order to increase supplementary feeding programmes.

B. LIBERIA AND SIERRA LEONE

1. LIBERIA

1.1 In the period 22 November-4 December, a total of 3,144 soldiers were demobilised. The total included 845 boys, two girls and 44 women. WFP has distributed over 75 mt food commodities to disarmed soldiers at the 8 operational demobilisation sites.

1.2 Demobilisation activities began on 1 December in Voinjama. Hundreds of displaced persons and Liberian refugees from Guinea have returned to Voinjama following the deployment of ECOMOG troops in the area at the end of November. Demobilisation has not yet started in Bo-Waterside or Greenville.

1.3 The UN Security Council has extended UNOMIL (United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia) until 31 March 1997. UNOMIL has been working closely with ECOMOG and the international humanitarian community during the demobilisation process.

1.4 The Greenville-Zwedru highway was opened last week by ECOMOG, enabling the safe travel of soldiers to Greenville for demobilisation. Demobilisation at Zwedru (Grand Gedah County) has been slow with only 79 fighters disarmed. Fighters have apparently requested a briefing on demobilisation by faction leader George Boley.

1.5 ECOMOG troops have been deployed to Tapeta, Nimba County. Troop presence is expected to create a buffer zone between National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and Liberian Peace Council (LPC) factions.

1.6 WFP November distribution to 244,079 displaced persons in 36 shelters throughout the country is scheduled to be complete on 6 December. As part of an effort to improve sanitary conditions of internally displaced person shelters in Monrovia, WFP is supporting Red Cross and UNICEF projects, including latrine construction, though food-for-work.

1.7 WFP, through implementing partner CCC, is also supporting a food-for- work environment clean-up project in Tubmanburg. The project, which will include women, ex-combatant and civilian participation, will create an employment-based safety net for vulnerable groups while improving sanitary conditions in the town through the removal of debris and litter.

2. SIERRA LEONE

2.1 President Ahmed Kabbah and Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebel leader Foday Sankoh signed a peace accord on 30 November in Abidjan. The agreement follows five years of civil war which have resulted in some 10,000 deaths. A commission for the consolidation of peace, made up of the Government of Sierra Leone and RUF members, is coordinating the details of the peace process in Abidjan.

2.2 Mechanisms are in place for the commencement of WFP resettlement and rehabilitation programmes throughout Sierra Leone by 1 January 1997. WFP will complete the last general food distributions by the end of December, which will then be replaced by targeted feeding programmes (resettlement and vulnerable group feeding). Surveys are on-going at each internally displaced persons site to identify food aid needs among vulnerable households. Resettlement assistance is being coordinated, and plans to expand NGO activity in rural areas in support of resettlement are being discussed.

2.3 WFP, through implementing partners World Vision and CCSL, has distributed return packages to more than 25,000 returnees in Pujehun district. Last week more than 8,000 former RUF captives were released in this district, on the orders of RUF leader Sankoh prior to the signing of the peace accord.

2.4 Kenema, Makeni, Bo and Mile 38 have been identified as assembly points for the disarmament and demobilisation of RUF combatants. The Government has signed accords with Africare (Kenema), ARD (Makeni), Evangelist Fellowship of Sierra Leone (Mile 38), and CRS (Bo) to assist in the reintegration of demobilised soldiers. A total of 2,000 soldiers are expected to be hosted in each of the camps, for a total caseload of 8,000. WFP is finalising its demobilisation plan in coordination with the Government's demobilisation programme, which was released at the end of November in Freetown. The cost of the Government demobilisation programme is estimated at USD 35 million. Funding received towards the project to date amounts to USD 1.5 million.

C. ANGOLA

1. UPDATE

1.1 Demobilisation of under-aged soldiers continues at a slow pace. Through 2 December, 629 under-aged soldiers from Vila Nova, N'Gove, Negage and Londuimbali Quartering Areas (QAs) were demobilised. Four additional QAs are expected to begin demobilisation on 10 December (Catala, Cahicuma, Andulo and Chitembo). It is hoped that demobilised soldiers from all eight QAs will be transported home before the end of the year.

1.2 A DHA Flash Appeal was issued in Angola on 21 November to cover the UN requirements for the demobilisation process until such time as all camps are emptied. WFP appeals to donors for 18,692 metric tons of food commodities to cover food requirements to Selection and Demobilisation Centres and QAs.

1.3 WFP has made a further appeal to donors for 96,033 metric tons of food commodities required for the period March 1997 - February 1998 to continue assistance to 700,000 displaced and war-affected persons.

1.4 A WFP-led mission to Likua and Jamba (Kuando Kubango) at the end of November found no immediate requirements for additional food aid.

1.5 Results of a MSF-Spain and CARE nutritional survey in Quilengues (Huila) and a MSF-Spain survey in Uige both showed improved nutritional conditions among vulnerable populations in these areas.

1.6 UN Secretary-General Boutros-Ghali on 19 November announced the withdrawal of four UNAVEM infantry and support units (600-700 persons) by the end of December 1996. UNAVEM is expected to withdraw all 7,000 troops from Angola by 8 February, when their mandate expires.

1.7 The overall security situation in Angola is reported as calm by the UNAVEM Huambo regional headquarters, however several ambushes throughout the country were reported at the end of November.

(End WFP Emergency Report No. 48 of 1996 - December 6, 1996)


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

195 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Business and Finance;
Money Transfer Woes in Liberia and Cameroon


BYLINE: Theo Nicol, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 960 words


 

Lagos - As they grapple with a seemingly endless civil war, Liberians still living at home are facing another onslaught; this time from smart money transfer agencies which have taken advantage of the collapse of the banking system, including the National Bank of Liberia, closed in April after a rebel attack on Monrovia.

That was before the transitional government of Ruth Perry came to power. Under the guise of helping Liberians to receive funds from relations abroad, some of the money changers whose outfits have mushroomed from just three to 12 immediately after the April attack, have resorted to fleecing their customers.

The process begins with the money merchants opening accounts in the United States and Europe into which customers pay the money they are sending to their relations. The receipts are then faxed to Liberia. For this, the money changers make sundry deductions for fax and telephone expenses, service charges and commissions before paying what is left to the beneficiaries. The deductions take as much as 30 per cent of the sum sent. Even so, payment is not made in the usual currency but in the anemic Liberian dollar and at the prevailing exchange rate. 

Few, if any, are lucky to collect what is left of the money in good time. Often, the beneficiary would make series of fruitless trips to the offices of the money changers, only to be fed on different excuses on each occasion to explain away their inability to pay promptly. As a result, frustrated Liberians caught in the web have nicknamed the financial houses "Go and come tomorrow."

In the absence of a judicial system which equally collapsed in the April attack on Monrovia, the victims have resigned their fate to God. "I've been waiting for my money for four months," laments one victim. "My husband sent if from the USA to let me pay my way to Ghana and take the children. Now I'm still waiting for it." Another victim explained that his family in the USA sent him 1,500 US dollars to help him relocate but that he ended up receiving only 900 dollars, half of it paid in Liberia dollars. "What can I do?" he asked in resignation. "At least it got me out of the war zone, only (for me) to go and start another financial war in Ivory Coast," he complained.

On the contrary, the finance companies see their activities as anything but a rip-off. To them, their business is patriotic and helpful to the people. " We are only here to help," says the managing director of one of the companies. "If we had not surfaced, our people wouldn't have been able to get money to pay their way to safety. As for the high charges you complain about, we cannot help it. We have to pay our staff and the telecommunications company for fax and telephone use. We also have to service our accounts abroad and most of all, since we are not a charity organisation, we have to make profit to stay afloat. We are only doing legitimate business which is of utmost service to our people."

He may have a point. At a worse level was the news that several people have died through suicide in Yaounde, Cameroun, following reports that the Banque Meridien BIAO Cameroun, BMBC had been shut down due to insolvency. An affiliate of a liquidated transnational bank, BMBC survived until three months ago because Camerounians, including the government, chose to continue doing business with it in the hope that the fortunes of the bank would change for the better. Even the minister of economy and finance, Justin Ndioro, felt that he could restructure the bank and avert its collapse. Ndioro and the government of Paul Biya only gave up after several vain efforts and withdrew the license of BMBC.

The government had earlier sought to convince the public of its ability to save the ailing bank by undertaking a strong media campaign to allay customers' fears that the bank could go bust. Now the disappointed customers are calling for the head of the government for misleading them. Apart from deceiving depositors, the government is also being blamed for contributing to the bank's collapse, having borrowed heavily from it and failing to pay back. In September last year, the ministry of finance had set up a commission to look into the state of affairs of BMBC, with an assurance that the bank would be given special attention through a package that was being worked out with the World Bank. And as late as July, the government released another statement, assuring customers that it was up to the task of saving the bank.

But all the plans failed when the government failed to pay its debt as agreed with the World Bank. In the event, the only option was liquidation of the bank. The morning after news of the liquidation was broadcast, depositors trooped to the bank to withdraw their money, only to meet all the doors shut. Their hopes of getting succour from government were dashed when the appointed liquidator, Emmanuel Etoundi Oyono, told them to forget about their money, as the process of liquidation is very long and cumbersome.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


196 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Business and Finance;
Nigeria: To Sell or Not to Sell


BYLINE: Ademola Adedoyin, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1307 words


 

Lagos - As the federal government begins preparation for the 1997 budget, the issue of privatisation has come to rivet the administration's attention.

Once again, they came calling two weeks ago. They are the egg-heads from the World Bank team on privatisation. In recent times, the World Bank has been rendering advisory services to Nigeria on how to revamp the economy after its cousin, the International Monetary Fund, shunned direct dealings with Nigeria. The IMF says the World Bank should put all the structures in place without which the IMF, and the Paris club would not give a clean bill of health for Nigeria to be considered for debt relief measures. 

It is not surprising, therefore, that Abuja has taken the World Banks recommendations seriously; the merger of the dual exchange rate, the removal of a cap on interest rates, a high level of fiscal discipline, as well as transparency and accountability. Though the administration is willing, it seems unsure whether the wholesale privatisation, particularly of the upstream sector of the oil industry and appropriate pricing of petroleum products, was the right thing to do.

Theweek learnt that when the World Bank team came two weeks ago, privatisation dominated discussions, with the proposals on the oil sector drawing some flak. Government sources say that while the administration has heartily endorsed the privatisation of the downstream sector, especially the refineries, government economic policy experts are divided over privatisation of the upstream sector.

A group led by Anthony Ani, the finance minister, is canvassing the view of the World Bank that the upstream sector should be privatised for a more efficient management to make more money available to the government for development of the economy. The argument is that the government's joint venture/partnership with six multinational oil companies is fraught with counter-claims on expenditures and then rancour over the administration's apparent inability to pay cash calls promptly. Indeed, it was to eliminate the problems of cash calls that the government came out with another option, that of production sharing contracts.

This option allows an oil company to carry all the risks of production without government investment. In turn, government receives only the petroleum profit tax and royalty. If the company fails to make an oil find, it bears all the losses. The Ani school of thought holds the view that there is no remarkable difference between profit sharing and privatisation. In privatisation, it argues that all the government need do is to monitor adequately the activities in that sector to ensure that the government is not short-changed in requisite payments.

As a senior partner with 60 per cent equity, the government has had to pay a colossal burden to keep the companies going. At the beginning of this year, the companies and the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, NNPC had agreed on an investment outlay of about $3 billion (N240 billion) plus N332 billion to sustain a minimum tempo of activities in the upstream sector.

The sum was later scaled down by 30 per cent with the government approving a capital contribution of $1.75 billion and N18 billion. The government's share is about $2.4 billion of the initial investment proposal because of its 60 per cent equity in the ventures.

Even then, the government went further to increase its investment last month by raising its spending level for Shell Petroleum Development Company from the initial $1.085 billion. This amount is however lower than the N1.35 billion which the company proposed to spend this year.

Chevron's investment was also raised to $846 million. The company had proposed $900million. by last month, the government had raised the working budgets of the six companies beyond the level at which they were pegged in July, that is when they were cut by 30 per cent.

Ordinarily, these huge sums would not have raised eyebrows since the government derives more than 90 per cent of its revenue from the sector. The snag, however, is the belief in officialdom that the joint venture partners short-change the government by padding up its expenditures. There is the suspicion that the government may unknowingly have been funding the ventures almost 100 per cent.

Dan Etete, the oil minister, said so boldly a few months ago when he announced that the oil companies were fleecing Nigeria and proceeded to set up a monitoring unit in the ministry to screen all cash call claims by the operators. To Ani and members of his group, all the brouhaha in the oil industry could be avoided by a stroke of privatisation.

Not so easy, counters Sam Aluko, chairman of the National Economic Intelligence Committee and Tam David-West, former petroleum resources minister who are leading the arguments against privatisation. They too have equally persuasive arguments. The first of these is the soul-stirring one of the national interest. They say that in the event of privatisation, few, if any Nigerian, would benefit from the upstream sector. As a highly capital intensive sector, very few Nigerians among those paraded as wealthy industrialists would be able to afford what it takes, thus leaving the field wide open to foreign domination. They call in evidence the experience of Iran during the Iran-Iraq war when the United States directed oil companies to leave that country.

More than a mere appeal to nationalist instincts, they have insisted that privatisation would not automatically stop Nigeria from being short-changed. They say that given the Nigerian environment, these companies may still be able to cook the books, thereby drastically reducing whatever tax and royalty should ordinarily accrue to the government.

Their recommendation is that rather than privatisation, the government should move to curb corruption in the oil industry, strengthen its monitoring unit and then encourage indigenous prospectors to build up their companies into viable ones like the multinationals.

As an example of what government initiative can achieve, they readily point to Norway, a fellow OPEC member-country, whose state oil company, Statoil, dominates crude oil exploration and production in that country. They believe the same could be done in Nigeria with the National Petroleum Development Company whose output for now is a paltry 10,000 barrels per day. It is not quite clear whose argument will sway Sani Abacha, the head of state. The World Bank team, Theweek learnt, has been told to call again sometime this month. In the meantime, Abacha has precious little time to make up his mind as the year races to a close and with it the 1997 budget that would spell out the administration's economic thrust, especially the bit on privatisation.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


197 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Nigeria;
Preparing For the Ritual


BYLINE: Akaninyene Esiere, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 960 words


 

Lagos - Amidst cries of biting poverty, government prepares to reflate the economy in next year's budget.

By the end of next year, the economy would be growing at the rate of 8 per cent, unemployment rate would be sliced by half, inflation rate will tumble single-digit figure just as effective demand is expected to receive a boom. Wishful thinking? No, says the government. To achieve this rather tall order, government is working round the clock to enshrine policies that will give vent to this dream in the 1997 fiscal budget. 

The series of meetings that precede each budget started last Monday in Abuja with the Joint Planning Board made up of directors-general, National Planning Commission. The five-step meetings will culminate in the December 12 NPC meeting to be chaired by Sani Abacha, the head of state, before the budget's final approval by the provisional ruling council.

Even before the take-off of the JPB meeting, officials from the presidency, the ministry of finance and the Central Bank have been meeting to envision the thrust of the budget. By mid last month, an official of the CBN in Lagos who wanted to speak with Paul Ogwuma, CBN governor, in Abuja could not do so as the governor had reportedly gone to Aso Rock for a discussion on the budget. Theweek learnt that the seemingly early preparation for the 1977 budget is to forestall the late announcement of budgets which has characterised the Abacha regime from inception. This year's budget was not announced until February 15, 46 clear days into the year. This, sources say, affected its implementation, especially the various aspects of reform and revenue generation. Government is said to be bent on announcing the next budget within the first two weeks of January.

Early preparations apart, next year's budget will pose little problem to government as there seems to be a level of consensus amongst various interest groups, including the government, on what the cardinal thrust of the next fiscal year should be. The organised private sector, represented by the Manufacturers Association of Nigeria, the National Association of Chambers of Commerce, Industry, Mines and Agriculture and the Nigeria Employers Consultative Association, is in unison that the economy needs to be reflated. In their various submissions to government; the three bodies have advocated the injection of more money into the economy. The consensus is that this year's economy has largely been characterised by lack of effective consumer demand.

Through the various bodies have praised government for its apparent success in managing the macro-economy as manifested in the declining rate of inflation, foreign exchange and interest rates stability, improved revenue generation and increased accountability, these have not translated to poverty alleviation and job creation which could have boosted consumer demand. In its first-half report, MAN lamented that the ware-houses of its members were brimming with unsold stock worth N6 billion. Sam Ohuabunwa, executive chairman, Pfizer Plc, made the point explicitly at a public lecture in Lagos week when he said that government's economic success has been at a great social cost to Nigerians. Analysts argue that since the budget is made for Nigerians, its success could only be measured in terms of the extent to which it has helped to solve their problems.

As if in deference to these demands, Anthony Ani, finance minister, hinted two weeks ago that next year's budget would aim to reflate the economy. He did not elaborate on how this would be achieved, but allayed fears that such monetary policies would lead to hyperinflation. To support his argument of non-inflationary growth, Ani said the fear expressed that injection of the Petroleum Trust Fund into the economy would be inflationary was misplaced, as the rate of inflation actually went down from 72.8 per cent a year ago to just 44.7 per cent by July. He said government would ensure that the expected reflation would not cause inflation.

Analysts are however skeptical. They say that the only way to achieve low inflation is to embark on capital projects that have the potential of generating employment rather than wage increases. Nze Ik Muo, a financial analyst, told Theweek that government can only reflate by embarking on investment in infrastructure that would reduce the cost of doing business. Such investments, he said, should focus on roads network, telecommunications, electricity and health care.

The suspicion is that the broad policy thrust of next year's budget will not be significantly different from the prevailing one. Having achieved some success in its "guided deregulation as government hopes to unify the dual exchange rates, privatize more of its parastatals, especially the telecommunications and energy subsectors, and carry through its tax and port reforms. But whether all this will translate to a happier, richer citizenry is another question.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


198 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Nigeria;
Claude Ake: The Spirit of The Dead


BYLINE: Wisdom Dike, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Lagos - A Letter written by social scientist and minority rights champion Claude Ake, the day he died in the recent crash, spells trouble for the Nigerian Liquefied Natural Gas Project.

Claude Ake, renowned professor of Social Science and Director of the Port Harcourt-based Centre for Advanced Social Science, was unusually calm that Thursday, November 7. After a four-day workshop of the centre, he summoned a meeting of the board of directors, discussed his vision and later met with officials of Ogba Solidarity, the umbrella organisation of his people. At 2. 30 p.m. Ake left for the Port Harcourt International Airport and boarded the ADC flight 086 that crashed near Lagos that evening killing all 143 person on board. 

Shortly before Ake's death, arrangements had been made by the management of the Liquefied Natural Gas company for an enlightenment forum for Ogba people. The forum was designed to educate the people on the gas transmission pipeline for the liquefied natural gas project. On November 14, exactly a week after the plane crash, representatives of Ogba people converged at the Civic Centre, Omoku, Rivers State, ostensibly for the schedule enlightenment forum. But instead of the forum, what took place was a showdown with officials of the LNG Limited.

The spoiler, Theweek learnt, was a letter which Ake had written to the LNG on the day of his death. The letter, written in conjunction with Ogba Solidarity group, contained a number of demands. With the demands yet to be met, J.J. Brian-West, community relations manager of Nigeria LNG Limited, laboured in vain November 14 to convince the community of the company's good mission in Ogba land.

Appeals by Okechukwu Ogbowu, chairman of Ogba/Egbema/Ndoni local government area, fell of deaf ears after Chinyere Nwokidu, spokesman of Ogba Solidarity, told the audience that Ake an indigene of Ogba land and a trustee of the organisation, had written to the company the day he died, announcing the postponement of the forum until proper discussions were held with the leaders of the clan. Nwokidu, a member of the National Economic Intelligence Committee and former commissioner for information and culture in Rivers State, alleged that the company had bribed some traditional rulers in the area with N4,000 and drinks in a bid to get the enlightenment forum to go ahead contrary to Ake's wish. This information immediately electrified the venue as it added to the anger of the crowd. To douse the fire, G.O. Obando, head of public affairs of LNG Limited, explained that the money in question was not a bribe but was meant to be used by the traditional rulers to mobilise people for the enlightenment forum. With Obando's explanation achieving no result, the forum had to hurriedly adjourn for security reasons.

Ogba people are demanding an economic stake and participation in the LNG project as well as an assurance of sustainable development with reference to the environmental impact assessment report of the LNG project. The people are said to be irked by claims of the company in various publications that "to obtain constructive input from the indigenous population, discussions were held by Nigeria LNG with the local Finima and Bonny communities and with those along the envisaged route of the gas transmission pipeline.

Ogba Solidarity has refuted the claims, saying that the company has never had any discussion with Ogba people. Ogba, the major producer of oil and gas in Rivers State, has two of the three gas plants for the gas project. They are located in Obite and Obrikom.

Ake, an unrepentant minority rights crusader, had sensitized his people early this year on the need to evolve strategies for participation in the oil and gas industry. He told the people in September to unite in the pursuit of their community rights. In keeping with his advice, the people of the area have been mobilized to resist attempts by oil companies to sidetrack the community in their oil/gas exploration and exploitation activities. They have vowed to stop the LNG pipeline should the company refuse to engage in dialogue.

Ogba people are not acting in isolation. The fight for justice by the oil producing areas recently received a boost when Dan Etete, the petroleum resources minister, directed oil companies to look into the genuine demands of their host communities to avoid a repeat of the Ogoni incident. The meaning: Enough lessons may have been learnt from the Ogoni tragedy.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


199 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
Film By Ethiopian Woman Premieres At Kennedy Center


BYLINE: Dimbulka Productions


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Washington, DC - Ms. Abrehet Abraha, one of the first women film producers of Ethiopia premiered her first film, "Bodiless Spirit," at the American Film Institute of the Kennedy Center, Washington, DC on December 5, 1996. There was a special reception following the screening in which the renowned Ethiopian Coffee Ceremony was featured accompanied by traditional music. " Bodiless Spirit" being released in the USA under a new title, "Broken Strings, " is a feature length video/film produced and distributed by Ms. Abraha through Dimbulka Production and marks the beginning of a new wave of quality products from Ethiopia. It is also the first of its genre to be subtitled for release to an American market. 

"Bodiless Spirit" or "Broken Strings" is a film that explores the powerful and uncontrollable feelings which erupt when fate causes a close interplay between love and jealousy. Set against the backdrop of the modern city of Addis Ababa, the film also provides a fresh look into life in contemporary urban Ethiopia.

Ms. Abrehet, an energetic young entrepeur, founded her company in 1986 in Addis Ababa where she successfully produced quality audio recordings of cultural music, compact discs of children's songs, and videos of cultural music. The film is her latest venture through which she is taking a bold step into the international arena. Ms. Abrehet displays a remarkable passion for the work she does in the field of commericial promotion of Ethiopian art. When asked why she devotes so much energy and time to her work, Ms. Abrehet replies: It is of my own experience as a modern Ethiopian woman who greatly values her traditions and ancestry that I developed a profound love of Ethiopian culture in all of its myriad forms. Perhaps because I lived through a tumultuous time in Ethiopia's history, I have this intense desire to penetrate Ethiopia's social fabric examining the heart and soul of my people as they live their daily lives today."

Dr. Ephraim Lsaav, noted Ethiopian scholar and Professor at Princeton University presented commentary, while opening remarks were made by independent filmmaker Abiyi Ford, Professor of Mass Communications at Howard University.

For more information, contact Dumbulka Productions at 202 955-5503.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


200 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Zambia;
Candidates, Monitors Discover Cheating


BYLINE: Masautso Phiri and Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Lusaka - A meeting to verify the election results in Mazabuka ended in an uproar on Tuesday last week when three candidates and their agents discovered that the results had been altered.

The losing candidates have now decided to petition the result in the High Court.

And Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) officials yesterday harassed the local Zambia Information Services (ZIS) reporter, Chasha Banda, for not reporting the story on verification. 

Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) board secretary, Gershom Musonda, who was in Mazabuka yesterday (Sunday) confirmed Banda's harassment by ZDC cadres.

"ZDC cadres were angered because Banda did not report anything about serious anomalies which were found during the verification exercise," Musonda said. "Haakantu himself was yesterday saying he will be the first to lynch Banda if he is found."

But ZIMT president, Alfred Zulu, condemned the action by ZDC cadres and advised all aggrieved parties to present their complaints to the Electoral Commission or petition the matter to the High Court.

"It's very regrettable for ZDC cadres to harass a reporter who has no say on the final selection of stories to be published," Zulu said in an interview yesterday.

And National Lima Party (NLP) candidate Evans Maambo, in an interview on Thursday, said they met on Monday and Tuesday to verify the results but could not make any headway.

"We found 47 alterations in the record of proceedings which had presidential results. No-one had signed for the changes," Maambo said. " We demanded for signed copies but they didn't have them."

And according to Maambo election officials voluntarily admitted that "they reopened the material and equipment after elections".

"The returning officer Mrs Hamusunse revealed that she did not do the alterations alone but with the responsible authorities and wondered why she was now being left alone to defend this," Maambo said.

Some changes which were made to Nega Nega polling station altered President Chiluba's result from 14 to 210 votes and Mung'omba's form 147 to 93. Others in Njomona 1 the ZDC president's results were reduced from 219 to 60 votes while Chiluba's were increased to 319 votes.

Maambo also revealed that two registers were used in the Mazabuka Constituency - the 1991 register and the Nikuv prepared one thereby making it difficult to know who was a registered voter and who wasn't.

The verification meeting was attended by Maambo, ZDC's Cypriano Haakantu, independent candidate Dowdy Chindindindi, election officials, ZIMT, the MMD, local police and polling agents.

And Guy Scott, the NLP co-chairman, will petition the Chongwe result where he claims a lot of anomalies and multiple voting has surfaced.

"We have evidence that some people voted on the strength of voter certificates issued inside Nkausu's house and others being brought from outside the constituency," Scott said. "We believe these individuals who have been given false addresses within Chongwe have been issued with a second card. "

In Malambo, NLP candidate, Daniel Mwale, whose name was wrongly entered as Daniel Mumba is also petitioning the results of the November 18 election.

All the NLP candidates cited deliberate barring of their agents from monitoring the election process, the NLP symbol being distorted and supporters being intimidated.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


201 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Business and Finance;
Fertilizer Shortage Blamed On Zambian Government


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - Government's involvement in the procurement and distribution of farming inputs has had a bearing on the current shortage of fertiliser in the country.

According to the latest issue of the Agricultural Market Bulletin, government's involvement in the agro sector, despite its claims of liberalisation, had resulted in the private sector's relaxed attitude to venture into fertiliser trading operations.

The agricultural weekly publication said private operators were very cautious to venture into the sector taking into account the relatively high risks involved because nearly all fertilizer had to be imported and also because of competition from the government. 

"Reportedly, this reluctance by the private sector is a direct result of the continued active involvement of the government in fertiliser marketing due to the fact that many farmers continue to heavily rely on government to meet their seasonal input needs," the bulletin read in part.

Despite some private institutions having the commodity, most farmers who have depended on credit purchasing, were having difficulties to access the fertiliser as it was being offered on a cash basis only.

Currently the country is experiencing a fertiliser shortage in most areas in the country which still have not received farming inputs despite the farming season having started two months ago.

The shortage, which is more pronounced in the peri-urban and remote areas of the country, however, confirms fears of a drop in maize production this farming season.

The shortage has further been worsened by the Peasant Farmers Union of Zambia's cancellation of a 100 metric tonne basal and top dressing fertiliser order for unexplained reason.

The union had in October secured a credit line with an American fertilizer manufacturer for the fertiliser consignment that was due to arrive in the country a fortnight ago , in a bid to supplement government's delayed efforts.

Meanwhile the bulletin has revealed that maize and mealie meal exports have continued with a total of 135,000 metric tonnes of maize and 20,000 tonnes of mealie meal expected to be exported this year from July 1996.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


202 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 9, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zambian Company Attributes Low Production To Smelter


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - Operational problems at the Nkana Smelter accounted for Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines' (ZCCM) low copper production figures in October and November, explained the company's public relations director, Francis Musonda, on Friday.

Musonda, in a statement to The Post on Friday, said the decline in production figures is as a result of operational problems at the Nkana Smelter during the month following the shutdown of the Nkana Oxygen plant for maintenance.

Production of finished copper fell 11, 805 tonnes short of the 52,217 tonnes target for the two months. 

In the ZCCM's September report released on December 3, a loss of K95 billion was reported for the second quarter.

The total sales revenue for the quarter was K290,125 million, a decrease of 27 per cent over the K397,364 million achieved in the September quarter of 1995.

The report attributed the decrease to the depreciation of the kwacha, lower copper prices, together with reduced copper sales volumes.

Musonda, however, said the conglomerate is relying on the rehabilitated Luanshya smelter to improve copper output.

The smelter, which is expected to be operational by the end of this month, was closed in 1994 due to under utilisation.

A decision was made to re-build the smelter and place it on standby when ZCCM accumulated 65,000 tonnes of concentrates which could have been treated had there been the capacity to do so.

The start-up of the smelter is also necessitated by the Mufulira Smelter operations which are currently at risk due to the non-availability of a stand- by 12 MVA electric furnace transformer.

Nevertheless, production figures for cobalt have maintained an upward trend since May, Musonda disclosed.

Cobalt Production, at 1155 tonnes for the second quarter, was 73 per cent higher than the 667 tonnes produced in the corresponding quarter of 1995.

The ZCCM report said this was due to the availability of high grade Nchanga cobalt concentrate. Sales of cobalt, at 1,146 tonnes were also 125 per cent higher than the 509 tonnes sold in the same period of 1995.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 9, 1996


Zambia;
Swearing-In Is A Formality In Zambia


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - It was interesting to see and hear our honourables taking oaths at State House, promising to do their best for the people of Zambia.

A colleague came to see me after the swearing-in ceremony and asked whether such ceremonies were necessary and important since very few of the appointees would live up to their pledges.

My colleague, who is very critical of the current regime, explained that what he had witnessed was a near circus and amounted to nothing in real of terms. 

He noted that in the past five years during which the MMD has been in power, ministers and other government leaders have done so much harm to this nation that one wonders what happened to their promises at the beginning of their term of office.

One example, he cited was that President Chiluba himself and his advisers have not been very honest in their dealings on national duties. The handling of the 1996 Constitution for example, left much to be desired and was below acceptable standards and a departure from democratic norms under which the MMD government pledged to rule.

Instead of all stakeholders reaching a consensus through a constituent assembly as suggested by most civic organisations and opposition parties, the MMD leaders, taking advantage of their majority in parliament, hijacked the occasion and ended up having a party constitution which only appeals to the MMD cadres, instead of the nation as a whole.

To date the current constitution remains the most condemned piece of document which has failed to attract any great brains both within and outside the country.

I told my friend that the swearing ceremony appears to be a mere formality in Zambia and there is very little commitment on the part of the appointed officers. To most of the leaders oaths taking starts and ends at State House and nobody cares to remember this important occasion thereafter.

I however, advised my colleague that as a citizen, he had a right to petition any leader whom he reasonably suspects to be living outside the expected norms of someone in a leadership position.

I further advised that it was the responsibility of every citizen to check the excesses and unacceptable conduct and behaviour of our leaders. Leaders should learn to live by example and when they conduct themselves dishonourably, they should be made accountable for their misdeeds.

Zambia;
Act For The Handicapped Coming


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - The government is in the process of introducing a new Act which will go a long way in addressing problems of the handicapped, disclosed Vice- President Godfrey Miyanda on Saturday.

And the Vice-President challenged the handicapped, who he said comprised 10 per cent of the Zambian population, to refrain from self pity and work towards integrating themselves into society. 

Vice-President Miyanda, officiating at a prize-giving ceremony after a wheel-chair race organised by Hands Ministries - a non-governmental organisation for the handicapped - at Lusaka's Pamodzi Hotel on Saturday.

Earlier handicapped persons presented a petition to Vice-President Miyanda in which they complained of poor facilities and utilities.

The petition included access to road crossing, buildings and ramps for the handicapped.

"I have received the petition but I won't comment much on it," Vice- President Miyanda said. " I agree there is need to facilitate these things to show that the government cares."

And community development minister Newstead Zimba disclosed that the government had already established a National Trust Fund for the handicapped and the Public Welfare system was under review.

"For these schemes to succeed there must be harmony and mutual trust amongst all players," Zimba said.

The race, flagged off from Kabwe round-about to Pamodzi Hotel, attracted one woman, Fatima.

The race was won by a finalist in the Atlanta Olympics, Lango Sinkamba, who beat 8 other participants.

Sinkamba was one of the two Zambians who competed in the wheel-chair 42- kilometre marathon in Atlanta where he was awarded a certificate of participation by the mayor of Atlanta.
