Zambia;
3 Arrested Over Ivory In Choma


BYLINE: Mabeni Sikalyabwanda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - Police in Livingstone have smashed a racket involving elephant tusks dealers after they discovered 56 fresh tusks and arrested three suspects in Choma.

The move has exposed the organised wanton killing of the jumbo, even after a world ban on ivory trade. 

Southern Province police chief, Ephraim Mateyo, said he was very much aware about the latest arrests but could not commit himself further.

Three suspects were arrested at a Zambia Railways house in Choma.

And two of them are from Lusaka's Lilanda township and Kanyama compound.

The suspects said the tusks were to be transported by rail to Lusaka.

And a wildlife official has said the killing meant that more elephants could have been injured because 28 elephants were gunned down.

Wild life officials warned the public to be wary of the possibly injured elephants, pointing out last week's incident involving an injured elephant which lead to the two killings of people in Zambia and Zimbabwe.

December 10, 1996


United States and Africa;
Former Zambian Foreign Minister Sues Newsweek Magazine


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's former foreign minister, Vernon Mwaanga, has sued Newsweek International for 50,000 U.S. dollars as compensation for libel and damages.

The magazine carried a story in 1994 in which it had implied that Mwaanga had recruited people at the ministry of foreign affairs to operate as drug agents and was using his position as minister to facilitate a drug syndicate. 

Mwaanga said in Lusaka Monday that the legal battle against the magazine was expected to take off on Jan. 17.

He said that he had decided to take legal action against the magazine so that it retracts the story and pays compensation for the damage it had caused to his reputation.

Correspondence between his lawyers and Newsweek indicate that Mwaanga is asking to be paid 50,000 dollars as compensation for damages, but the magazine has offered an out of court settlement of 10,000 dollars.

"For me really it is not the money that matters but for my name to be cleared of these allegations and in that regard I have asked Newsweek International to retract what they had printed about me," Mwaanga said.

Mwaanga, together with the former Zambian speaker of parliament, Sikota Wina, and his wife Nakatindi Wina, who was community development minister, were forced to step down in 1994, amid accusations of drug-dealing.

At that time, several international financial institutions had threatened to withhold their aid unless the Zambian president dealt with the problem of drug trafficking among highly-placed officials of his government.

Africa News


December 10, 1996


Central Africa;
OAU Welcomes Central African Republic's Truce


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) on Tuesday welcomed the truce between the government of the Central African Republic and rebel soldiers, which was negotiated in Bangui by a delegation of four African presidents.

The presidents of Burkina Faso, Chad, Gabon and Mali were dispatched by the Franco-African summit, which was held at Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso last week. 

The delegation secured the truce on Sunday after talks with President Ange- Felix Patasse and the rebels who had been calling for his resignation, among other demands.

In a press release, the OAU expressed ardent hope that the truce will lead in the shortest time possible to a durable agreement for the definitive resolution to the present crisis.

The organization reiterated its support for the on-going mediation efforts by the four African countries and said it was closely following up the situation as it unfolds.

The current army mutiny in Bangui was the third of its kind to be staged in 1996 against the democratically-elected government of Patasse, who was elected in 1993.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


208 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 10, 1996


Business and Finance;
Africa Told To Reduce Budget Deficits


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

SINGAPORE, Singapore (PANA) - The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, has urged African countries to continue implementing policies to reduce bloated budget deficits and encourage domestic savings.

He told ZIANA in Singapore that it had been proved the world over that high fiscal deficits retarded economic growth, and unless controlled, only prolonged the hardships of vulnerable groups already suffering under harsh market reforms being implemented in some countries.

He said his organisation would be willing to give expert advice to those African countries willing to listen and implement practical measures aimed at promoting growth. 

"We are working together with the World Bank trying to create conditions for growth for countries in Africa. This requires implementation of policies that have been successful in other countries in similar kinds of situations," Camdessus said.

"If we look at policies that have been successful, they are policies where governments are trying to reduce their deficits in order to open some opportunities to encourage savings."

Maintaining deficits exceeding 10 percent of gross domestic product, he said, would not make it possible to sustain, let alone promote, economic growth.

Zimbabwe, which embarked on wide-based market reforms in 1991, has disappointed major donors such as the IMF by its failure to reduce the budget deficit to a sustainable level of five percent of GDP.

The fiscal indiscipline, which saw the deficit in 1995 shoot up to 10 percent, led to the suspension of balance-of-payments credit from the IMF worth over 100 million U.S.dollars in September, 1995.

Since then, the government has made attempts to cut spending in non- essential services so as to win IMF support, seen as crucial to kick-start the reform effort.

Recent talks in Harare between the organisation and the government failed to yield positive results, beyond expressions of intent from the lending institution and promises of further negotiations early in January to assess progress made.

The government's dilemma is how to balance the books in the face of unplanned expenditure of more than 190 million dollars on salaries and bonuses for civil servants. This is at a time when other essential services such as health and education are competing for the government's scarce cash resources.

Projections are that the deficit in the year to June 1997 will exceed the original forecast of 8.5 percent, a figure unlikely to please experts at the IMF headquarters in Washington.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


209 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 10, 1996


Science and Health;
OAU For Poverty Alleviation Alongside Vaccination


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) has called for a multisectorial approach that would simultaneously meet the continent's quest for universal vaccination and deal with the ravages caused by poverty, famine and malnutrition.

Speaking in Dakar Tuesday, the organization's Assistant Secretary General, Pascal Gayama, also called for the uplifting of the the situation of women " since this directly affects the situation of the child."

He was presenting a paper titled "The commitment from national leaders for vaccination and immunization" at the 6th Consultative Group meeting of the Children's Vaccine Initiative, CVI, which entered its second and last day in the Senegalese capital on Tuesday. 

"There are many obstacles on the route that could lead to the the objective of keeping poliomyelitis out of Africa in the year 2000," Gayama said. "For polio as for most of other diseases, including the AIDS pandemic, nothing is worth than a multisectorial approach capable of containing, at the same time as we search for universal immunization, the ravages caused by poverty, famine and malnutrition."

The OAU official noted the high cost of treating epidemics but appealed to rich countries not to deprive Africa of the beneficial progress being made by developed countries in the field of medicine.

Gayama also encouraged researchers to explore the potential of traditional herbs and medicine, which could assist in improving the well-being of Africans.

He equally mentioned the Bamako Initiative, whose objective is to bring affordable medicine close to the people and communities.

He enumerated a series of activities which have been undertaken by African countries under the auspices of the OAU and with assistance from the World Health Organization to strengthen their vaccination activities.

Among these actions, Gayama said, was the recent launching of a major African anti-polio vaccination campaign in South Africa, under the chairmanship of President Nelson Mandela. The campaign was co-launched with Rotary Club International and the WHO.

He regretted, however, that the mushrooming of conflicts had aggravated the situation of African children, some of whom became refugees or displaced persons or faced with "the omnipresent danger of epidemics, including that of HIV/AIDS."

And yet, he said, slightly more than 28 African countries had doubled their rate of vaccinations.

Gayama expressed the OAU's readiness to cooperate with the CVI partners -- UNICEF, UNDP, World Bank, WHO and the Rockfeller Foundation.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 10, 1996


Science and Health;
Companies Donate Vaccine Doses To Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Africa's drive towards the eradication of poliomyelitis got a boost Monday evening in Dakar when four multinational vaccine companies announced the donation of 100 million doses of anti-polio vaccine.

Polio, according to Dr Ebrahim Samba, the World Health Organization regional Director for Africa, still cripples at least 12,000 children on the continent. 

The 100 million doses will be donated in the next three years by Chiron Vaccines, Pasteur Merieux-Connaught and SmithKline Beechamm. The doses are expected to meet the vaccination needs of between 25-30 million African children.

In addition, a grant of one million U.S. dollars will be provided by Wyeth- Lederic Vaccines and Pediatrics for strengthening of a laboratory network for the crippling disease's surveillance in Africa.

The donation was accepted by the WHO Director General, Dr Hiroshi Nakajima and Dr Denis Broun, Chief of health section at UNICEF.

It was part of the highlights during the first day of the 6th Consultative group meeting of the Children's Vaccine Initiative (CVI), which ends here Tuesday evening.

CVI was created during the 1990 World Children's summit to bring together diverse organizations and expertise to work towards the goal of providing better protection for the world's children against diseases through the development of new and improved vaccines.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


211 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 10, 1996


Business and Finance;
Privatisation Of Mozambican Glass Factory Completed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The Mozambican government on Thursday completed the privatisation of Vidreira, the only facotry in the country producing bottles and glassware.

About 55 percent of the company is now owned by the Portuguese firm Barbosa e Almeida, while the remaining 45 percent remains in the hands of the state. 

One peculiarity of this privatisation is that Vidreira has been split into two companies, Vidreira de Mocambique, and Cristalaria (crystalware) de Mocambique. The former is by far the larger company with initial capital of 5. 5 million U.S. dollars (three million from Barbosa e Almeida and 2.5 million from the Mozambican state).

The initial capital of the second company is 867,000 dollars, 400,000 held by the government and 467,000 by Barbosa e Almeida.

According to the head of the Vidreira Privatisation Commission, Mariamo Carimo, the debts amassed by Vidreira under state ownership will be paid off by the sale of the factory installations valued at 2.5 million dollars to the new companies.

Within three months, the two companies are to pay the state three million dollars, and this money will be used in the first instance to pay off Vidreira's debts.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


212 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 10, 1996


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia Says It Has Tantalum Deposits


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopia's state-owned Minerals Development Enterprise says the country has some 25 million tons of tantalum deposists, a rare mineral used in aeronautics and space-bound vehicles and instruments.

Tantalum, a hard gray metallic element that resists corrosion by most acids, is also used in dental and surgical instruments. 

Explorations in the past seven years in Kenticha, close to the Shakiso gold mining area of south-east Ethiopia, about 20km from Addis Ababa, have proved the availability of the rare mineral, local press Tuesday quoted Abdela Kedir, the head of the Tantalum Development Project, as saying.

He said tantalum explorations in nine areas of the Ado Shakiso district and trial production had yielded 20 to 30 tonnes of the mineral annualy during the last seven years.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 10, 1996


Ghana;
Rawlings Holds Out Olive Branch To Opponents


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - President Jerry John Rawlings Tuesday held an olive branch at his political opponents and said should his National Democratic Congress (NDC) win, the party's supporters would celebrate with the losers.

"We are members of one family. We will not be vindictive," he said. "There is much work ahead and we need to work together to build the country."

He was meeting officials from the International Foundation for Electoral Systems, one of several institutions which monitored Saturday's elections.

"Supporters of all the political parties which took part in the elections conducted themselves in a peaceful manner," said Rawlings. "I have always said a transformation has taken place in Ghana and I have been vindicated. Ghanaians are peace-loving."

With results from 138 constituencies, out of the 200, made public, Rawlings has 2,998,578 votes, representing 55.55 percent of the votes. John Agyekum Kufuor of the New Patriotic Party (NPP) has 2,231,524 votes (41.34 percent) while the third candidate, Dr Edward Mahama of the Peoples National Convention (PNC), has 167,153 votes (3.09 percent).

In the parliamentary race, NDC has 85 seats, NPP 50 and PNC has three.

Meanwhile, Kufuor Tuesday called on his supporters to remain calm and not to despair.

"Let us all show patience and tolerance while we wait (for the final result) ," he told a press conference at his party's head office of the in Accra.

"The calm and dignity they showed on Saturday, given the tremendous turn- out, does us all credit. I appeal to everyone to continue to show the same calm and dignity in waiting for the final results to be released. Let us all show patience and tolerance while we wait," Kufuor said.

214 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 10, 1996


Sudan;
Islamic Segregation: NIF Promulgates A New Law Against Women


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

London - Moslem women in Sudan have suffered from discrimination and degrading treatment ever since that dictator Nimeiri decreed the September laws in 1983. Nimeiri's Islamic laws were draconian enough and have remained on the statute book up until the present day. However, at the end of October the National Islamic Front(NIF) regime passed even more repressive legislation that set to plunge Sudanese women into the primitive world of seventh century Arabia when the Prophet Mohammed used harsh edicts to discipline, regulate and sober up society. 

Local Law with National Impact

The new laws have only been passed by the local council in Khartoum but are being viewed as a prototype for the rest of the country, the South included. Under the new laws women will be segregated from men in all areas of life. Public transport is to be segregated with a curtained off area at the front set aside for women. Women will not be allowed to sit in an empty seat next to a male bus driver. Women will no longer be allowed to mix with men in public places. Women can no longer enter any public facility where there are men. This applies especially to shops, meaning that shops will now be catering exclusively either to for men or women. Public occasions such as weddings will be segregated also. There will be no mixed dancing. Women will no longer be allowed into clubs or other social facilities. Women will not be allowed to drive cars. There will be a 5 o'clock curfew on women unless they are accompanied by a bona fide male relative who will have to provide documentation of his status to security officials upon demand. Women will have to observe a stringent form of Islamic dress when in public. In addition, the new law requires all shops and restaurants and food refreshment places to be closed on Fridays and no food will be served in public places during the month of Ramadan.

Taste Of Things To Come

As Khartoum is the national capital, it has to be expected that the new law will eventually be applied to the whole country. The new law proves the point made by Southerners of the need to secularize the national capital. Khartoum contains communities from all religions and cultures. The diversity mirrors that in the country at large. With the influx of large numbers of people from the South and other marginalised areas of Sudan, it is unlikely that there exists an Arab or Moslem majority in Khartoum. The regime often states that there are three million Southerners living in the North after fleeing from the South and most of them are residents in the national capital. The regime likes to say that these Southerners are opposed to the SPLA and support the NIF. Perhaps it is time to use the regime's statistics against it and point out that in addition to the three million Southerners, there are another three million ethnic Africans from the West and East. They are being ruled in Khartoum by a small minority of Arab Islamic zealots. This is a cast iron case of disenfranchisement and marginalisation. People who have run their own businesses, own considerable property and who have nurtured their own cultural lives whilst living in Khartoum, will now find themselves becoming non-citizens under the new law.

No Exemptions

The new law brings into sharp focus the often mentioned claim by the regime that non-Moslems are exempt from the application of Islamic laws. There are no exemptions whatsoever under the new law.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 10, 1996


Zambia;
Polls NGO To Continue


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - ELECTIONS Non-Governmental Organisation, Anti-Voter Apathy Project (AVAP) has quietly continued with its democracy enhancing programmes while many other NGOs are on break from the hectic campaigns of last month's presidential and parliamentary elections.

AVAP president, Bonny Tembo, said in Lusaka today that instead of resting on their laurels like everybody else was doing his organisation had decided to put into cruise gear their sensitization programmes.

With the help of USAID and the Southern University Democratic Governance Project, AVAP has held five co-existence workshops in Rufunsa constituency which brought together members of political parties - Movement for Multi- Party Democracy, United National Independence Party, National Party, Zambia Democratic Congress, National Lima Party and concerned citizens who included village headmen, teachers and Chief Unda-Unda. 

Later the workshops came out with resolutions which called on recently elected members of parliament to form constituency development committee which will embrace all political parties with a view to taking development to all.

MPs were also called upon to be much more accountable to the voters and strive to fulfill their pre-election promises. Furthermore they should learn to consult voters over key developmental issues including bills before parliament and those affecting ordinary people.

In another resolution participants called on government to improve on the dissemination of information to rural areas in order to empower the people. They also called on NGOs to spread their awareness campaigns to rural areas, where people are marginalised due to lack of information and communication facilities being enjoyed in both peri-urban and urban areas.

They also called on national leaders of political parties to try by all means to pursue peaceful means of settling their differences, because if war broke out in the country it will affect most the poor majority who have nowhere to run to.

They also called on the Church and NGOs to stop politicking and instead embark on the peace crusade in rural areas for the benefit of the rural population which has no access to both print and electronic media.

Participants also called on government to increase the number of police posts in rural areas in order to combat as well as to maintain law and order.

Since hunger has been identified as one of the obstacles to peace, government should facilitate an effective maize marketing system on behalf of peasant farmers who have no access to maize buyers.

Source: ZAMTODAY

Zambia;
Lip-Serving Women Prodded


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Kitwe - THE NON-GOVERNMENTAL Coordinating Committee has challenged women to stop the age-old female-folk occupation of gossip and bickering and instead concentrate on supporting each other if full realisation of their fight for recognition by government is to be achieved.

NGO-CC national chairperson, Evelyn Manda, said in Kitwe today that present attitudes of women in different NGOs affiliated to the committee will not help their advancement in social and economic circles because important issues are being sidelined. 

Ms Manda regretted that non of the NGOs affiliated to the NGO_CC has in the past year submitted their reports on activities held to articulate and put into practice the five priority areas of the Beijing platform of action which the Zambia government has picked as being crucial to the country.

She was speaking at the NGO_CC Copperbelt review workshop at Nkana hotel. At this gathering also will be discussed contributions to be included in the government policy frame work on NGOs and it will also elect new office bearers for the region.

On recent national elections Ms Manda observed that Zambians should be praised for having voted peacefully in the November 18 elections and that the election of 11 women to the national assembly was an indication that women have the confidence of the electorate.

The NGO-CC will in the next five years articulate the Beijing platform of action, set up provincial focal points to ensure that women at grassroots are reached and inform women on issues concerning their welfare.

Sports - Soccer;
Zambia Refuses To Play Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - THE Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) has spurned an invitation to play the Zimbabwe "Warriors" national team whose soccer association had requested the match to be played on December 21.

But the Zimbabwe Football Association, (ZIFA), which has been publicizing the match with great zeal, is still confident that the match against Africa's top-rated team will go ahead even next month. 

"We got the Zimbabwe invitation but because of the fact that our team will be away to East Africa for some time, we decided that we play them (Zimbabwe) some other time and not December 21 as earlier suggested by ZIFA. We thank them for the offer and we will soon announce new dates for the match," said FAZ acting general secretary, Julio Chiluba in an interview yesterday.

But former national team coach, Jones Chilengi, in an interview recently advised FAZ to arrange a match against Zimbabwe which he observed would give Zambia a tough match since they play a similar pattern as the South Africans.

"FAZ must arrange a match or two against Zimbabweans because I feel Zimbabwe and South Africa play almost the same type of football," said Chilengi in a telephone interview from his Zimbabwe base.

And in an interview yesterday ZIFA boss, Leo Mugabe, expressed confidence that his team would play Zambia even if it meant next month.

"We just got the news that your team (Zambia) is going to East Africa but still, we hope to play them when they come back because we also want to use the match to prepare for our World Cup matches next month," said Mugabe.

ZIFA is said to have proposed January 4 as the possible date for the match, which has been widely publicized in the Zimbabwean media.

Sports - Soccer;
Weah's Victim Finally Complains


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY

Lusaka - DEFENDER for Porto football club, Jorge Costa, who was hurt by World football of the year, George Weah has finally lodged a formal compliant against the AC Milan striker, who butted him and broke his nose after a European Cup match last month.

The compliant, which could end in a trial, has been handed to the judicial police in Porto.

The Liberian striker, Weah, has admitted the charge the assault, in the players tunnel at the end of a bad-tempered game in Porto in November, but maintains that Costa provoked him with a series of dangerous fouls during the game and by making racist insults.

Africa News


December 10, 1996


Business and Finance;
Kwacha Faces Further Depreciation In Zambia


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - The latest Bank of Zambia fortnightly statistics have revealed a further depreciation of the kwacha.

The statistics, as at November 29, showed commercial banks' weighted retail buying and selling exchange rates depreciating by 0.3 per cent to K1,263.70 and K1,294.61 per US dollar respectively. 

As the last six months come to a close this December, the commercial banks' lending rates have maintained a steady high, averaging around 69 per cent.

The banking system net claims on Government, however, fell by K18.6 billion to K117 billion.

Money supply increased by 2.4 per cent in October to K554.6 billion in October compared to K541.7 billion in September.

For the month of November 1996, gross international reserves increased by 1 per cent to US$206.6 million.

The price of copper, Zambia's main export, at the London Metal Exchange (LME) averaged US$1.01 per pound in November compared with 89.64 US Cents per pound in October. This is a significant increase in view of the past four months in which the price averaged at 89 Cents per Pound.

221 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 10, 1996


Ghana;
Ghana Again Inspires Africa (Editorial)


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Lusaka - Ghana, Africa's first independent state, appears to have taken the lead once more.

Last Saturday's general election appears to have been the most credible so far this year on the continent.

The elections were keenly contested in a way that no other has been.

They were the kind of multi-party elections that Africa needs. 

There was no telling who the winner was until the last count. Even the incumbent was not certain of victory until the final result was declared.

This is in sharp contrast to the sort of "multi-party" elections the continent has begun to witness once more. They lack the excitement of an election and the results are predictable, not least, because of the open manipulation of the electoral process by incumbent administrations.

In the end the election is reduced to a mere ritual in which voters have no real choice.

Zambia had one such election last month.

Despite the large amount of money spent on the exercise, it had little meaning. Choice was limited by a controversial constitution that was bulldozed through the legislative process.

The results when they came were no different from those recorded during the one party era and they are still the subject of dispute by the opposition and election monitors.

Nobody is certain what they mean anyway, since some of the major contenders were not on the ballot and others were barred.

Zambia simply wasted money on an election that is unlikely to change things for the better. The election merely tarnished the country's international image and that of its leaders.

That is precisely what President Jerry Rawlings, a former military man, has avoided for his country.

President Rawlings has clearly shamed the people who once were considered Africa's pioneering democrats at their own game.

The Ghanaian election attracted international attention because it was genuine. There were over 100 international observers from many parts of the world who watched over the polling .The Ghanaian authorities had nothing to hide.

There cannot be the slightest doubt that those elections will work in Ghana's favor internationally as well as being a source of pride for the Ghanaians.

This cannot be said of the increasing charades Africa is beginning to witness once more from those who pay lip service to democracy.

Genuine democracy is the world trend today and those who delude themselves that they can define democracy in a shallow self-serving way are bound to be isolated.

The danger is not, as is commonly perceived, from the international community only. Increasingly citizens of many countries will want to belong to countries that are truly democratic. Those tyrants who will still hope to disguise their true colours by shouting democracy at every forum without practicing it will be exposed one by one - and already some have been.

It is really time for serious and well meaning leaders in Africa. Tyranny has ensured the continent's backwardness amidst valuable resources. It is unlikely that the people will continue to accept this state of affairs. They will want honest and serious leaders and that will happen soon .

The bells may be tolling for Africa's tyrants who should seriously learn something from what has happened in Ghana. It shows clearly that with devotion and honesty, democracy can work in even in Africa.

It is fitting that Ghana, the continent's first independent state, should lead the way in this regard. Perhaps, just as Kwame Nkrumah proved the inspiration for Africa's liberation, President Rawlings will also be the pioneer of real and sustainable democracy in Africa.

Certainly, President Rawlings has set high standards which should put to shame those who preach democracy from rooftops but are unwilling, or too afraid, to practice it. Such leaders merely waste their peoples' time and can only ensure the rapid impoverishment of their countries.

Nobody can have faith in them when they do not practice what they preach and therefore they have no credibility even when they are overwhelmingly retained in fraudulent "democratic elections".


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


222 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 10, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
COMESA Establishes Court Of Justice


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - THE Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) has established a court of justice to deal with legal matters involving member states.

Officially opening the first meeting of the COMESA committee of legal experts at Lusaka's Mulungushi International Conference Center yesterday, acting secretary general, Anastase Munyabatenzi, said the framework for the court had already been provided for by ministers of justice and attorneys general in the treaty.

"The court of justice is already charged with ensuring the adherence to law in the interpretation of the treaty," Munyabatenzi said. 

And legal affairs minister Vincent Malambo, in an official statement read on his behalf by solicitor general Sam Chisulo, urged COMESA to seek a more consolidated economic integration for all African countries.

The two day conference will mainly consider activities leading to the creation of the court of justice such as the establishment of a temporary registry at COMESA secretariat, the appointment of the registrar of the court, the process of nominating the judges, the appointment of judges to be effected by the authority of heads of states and government and the determination of the seat of the court after the judges have been appointed.

But Malambo observed that in the context of the globalisation of world trade and the formation of large economic blocs, Africa might become increasingly marginalised.

"It is now an accepted fact that the world is fast becoming divided into powerful regional blocs increasingly becoming larger in size and you will all agree that in the context of the globalisation of world trade and the formation of large economic blocs, Africa may become increasingly marginalised" Malambo noted. "It therefore becomes imperative that while we have already made great progress in economic integration such as under COMESA this should be consolidated in order to face the rapid changes taking place globally."

The meeting has been poorly attended, with only representatives from Zambia, Zimbabwe, Angola, Kenya, Swaziland, Sudan and Kenya.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 10, 1996


Zambia;
A Number Of Voter Cards Uncollected, Observes OAU


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - Even though the errors contained in the Nikuv Computers prepared register were purported to have been corrected, a number of voters' cards were left uncollected at the polling stations, observed the OAU delegation that came to monitor last month's elections.

The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) group also noted that in some polling stations, a small number of registered voters could not find their names at the polling stations where they had registered and consequently could not vote.

The OAU team further observed that even though elections on polling day took place in a calm, serene and peaceful atmosphere, many parties pointed out that the controversy over certain clauses of the constitution, the voters' registration exercise and unequal access to the media had caused uneasiness in certain sections of the population. 

"Certain parties thought that the Electoral Commission was independent and discharged its responsibilities in an objective manner while others did not think so," the OAU report read in part. "In this connection, it is important that the Commission should not only be independent but it must be perceived by all concerned to be so."

The OAU also expressed concern over disagreements in "the manner in which the registration exercise was carried out" as a "reflection of the deep mistrust that exists between some political parties and the Electoral Commission."

The report also notes that the members of the independent Electoral Commission were appointed "too late" to effectively stamp their authority on the conduct of the elections.

The OAU delegation, which was headed by Mozambique, also observed that the political tension created by the controversy over the constitutional clauses heightened by the retroactive application of the two-term clause and the unacceptability of the voters register to all the parties because of what some parties considered as flawed registration exercise.

The OAU election observer team which monitored the elections in Lusaka, Copperbelt, Eastern and Southern provinces advised that there was need to have consensus on issues such as the Constitution, an independent Electoral Commission and the process of voters registration.

"These would enhance sustainable peace and stability not only in Zambia but also in the region and in the continent as a whole," concludes the OAU report.

The report exposes distortions in the state owned and government controlled Zambia Daily Mail of December 4 that the OAU had declared the Zambian elections free and fair.
