Africa News


December 10, 1996


United States and Africa;
Former Zambian Foreign Minister Sues Newsweek Magazine


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 897 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's former foreign minister, Vernon Mwaanga, has sued Newsweek International for 50,000 U.S. dollars as compensation for libel and damages.

The magazine carried a story in 1994 in which it had implied that Mwaanga had recruited people at the ministry of foreign affairs to operate as drug agents and was using his position as minister to facilitate a drug syndicate. 

Mwaanga said in Lusaka Monday that the legal battle against the magazine was expected to take off on Jan. 17.

He said that he had decided to take legal action against the magazine so that it retracts the story and pays compensation for the damage it had caused to his reputation.

Correspondence between his lawyers and Newsweek indicate that Mwaanga is asking to be paid 50,000 dollars as compensation for damages, but the magazine has offered an out of court settlement of 10,000 dollars.

"For me really it is not the money that matters but for my name to be cleared of these allegations and in that regard I have asked Newsweek International to retract what they had printed about me," Mwaanga said.

Mwaanga, together with the former Zambian speaker of parliament, Sikota Wina, and his wife Nakatindi Wina, who was community development minister, were forced to step down in 1994, amid accusations of drug-dealing.

At that time, several international financial institutions had threatened to withhold their aid unless the Zambian president dealt with the problem of drug trafficking among highly-placed officials of his government.

Africa News


December 10, 1996


Central Africa;
OAU Welcomes Central African Republic's Truce


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) on Tuesday welcomed the truce between the government of the Central African Republic and rebel soldiers, which was negotiated in Bangui by a delegation of four African presidents.

The presidents of Burkina Faso, Chad, Gabon and Mali were dispatched by the Franco-African summit, which was held at Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso last week. 

The delegation secured the truce on Sunday after talks with President Ange- Felix Patasse and the rebels who had been calling for his resignation, among other demands.

In a press release, the OAU expressed ardent hope that the truce will lead in the shortest time possible to a durable agreement for the definitive resolution to the present crisis.

The organization reiterated its support for the on-going mediation efforts by the four African countries and said it was closely following up the situation as it unfolds.

The current army mutiny in Bangui was the third of its kind to be staged in 1996 against the democratically-elected government of Patasse, who was elected in 1993.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


235 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 10, 1996


Business and Finance;
Africa Told To Reduce Budget Deficits


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

SINGAPORE, Singapore (PANA) - The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, has urged African countries to continue implementing policies to reduce bloated budget deficits and encourage domestic savings.

He told ZIANA in Singapore that it had been proved the world over that high fiscal deficits retarded economic growth, and unless controlled, only prolonged the hardships of vulnerable groups already suffering under harsh market reforms being implemented in some countries.

He said his organisation would be willing to give expert advice to those African countries willing to listen and implement practical measures aimed at promoting growth. 

"We are working together with the World Bank trying to create conditions for growth for countries in Africa. This requires implementation of policies that have been successful in other countries in similar kinds of situations," Camdessus said.

"If we look at policies that have been successful, they are policies where governments are trying to reduce their deficits in order to open some opportunities to encourage savings."

Maintaining deficits exceeding 10 percent of gross domestic product, he said, would not make it possible to sustain, let alone promote, economic growth.

Zimbabwe, which embarked on wide-based market reforms in 1991, has disappointed major donors such as the IMF by its failure to reduce the budget deficit to a sustainable level of five percent of GDP.

The fiscal indiscipline, which saw the deficit in 1995 shoot up to 10 percent, led to the suspension of balance-of-payments credit from the IMF worth over 100 million U.S.dollars in September, 1995.

Since then, the government has made attempts to cut spending in non- essential services so as to win IMF support, seen as crucial to kick-start the reform effort.

Recent talks in Harare between the organisation and the government failed to yield positive results, beyond expressions of intent from the lending institution and promises of further negotiations early in January to assess progress made.

The government's dilemma is how to balance the books in the face of unplanned expenditure of more than 190 million dollars on salaries and bonuses for civil servants. This is at a time when other essential services such as health and education are competing for the government's scarce cash resources.

Projections are that the deficit in the year to June 1997 will exceed the original forecast of 8.5 percent, a figure unlikely to please experts at the IMF headquarters in Washington.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


236 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 10, 1996


Science and Health;
OAU For Poverty-Alleviation Alongside Vaccination


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) has called for a multisectorial approach that would simultaneously meet the continent's quest for universal vaccination and deal with the ravages caused by poverty, famine and malnutrition.

Speaking in Dakar Tuesday, the organization's Assistant Secretary General, Pascal Gayama, also called for the uplifting of the the situation of women " since this directly affects the situation of the child."

He was presenting a paper titled "The commitment from national leaders for vaccination and immunization" at the 6th Consultative Group meeting of the Children's Vaccine Initiative, CVI, which entered its second and last day in the Senegalese capital on Tuesday. 

"There are many obstacles on the route that could lead to the the objective of keeping poliomyelitis out of Africa in the year 2000," Gayama said. "For polio as for most of other diseases, including the AIDS pandemic, nothing is worth than a multisectorial approach capable of containing, at the same time as we search for universal immunization, the ravages caused by poverty, famine and malnutrition."

The OAU official noted the high cost of treating epidemics but appealed to rich countries not to deprive Africa of the beneficial progress being made by developed countries in the field of medicine.

Gayama also encouraged researchers to explore the potential of traditional herbs and medicine, which could assist in improving the well-being of Africans.

He equally mentioned the Bamako Initiative, whose objective is to bring affordable medicine close to the people and communities.

He enumerated a series of activities which have been undertaken by African countries under the auspices of the OAU and with assistance from the World Health Organization to strengthen their vaccination activities.

Among these actions, Gayama said, was the recent launching of a major African anti-polio vaccination campaign in South Africa, under the chairmanship of President Nelson Mandela. The campaign was co-launched with Rotary Club International and the WHO.

He regretted, however, that the mushrooming of conflicts had aggravated the situation of African children, some of whom became refugees or displaced persons or faced with "the omnipresent danger of epidemics, including that of HIV/AIDS."

And yet, he said, slightly more than 28 African countries had doubled their rate of vaccinations.

Gayama expressed the OAU's readiness to cooperate with the CVI partners -- UNICEF, UNDP, World Bank, WHO and the Rockfeller Foundation.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December 10, 1996


Science and Health;
Companies Donate Vaccine Doses To Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Africa's drive towards the eradication of poliomyelitis got a boost Monday evening in Dakar when four multinational vaccine companies announced the donation of 100 million doses of anti-polio vaccine.

Polio, according to Dr Ebrahim Samba, the World Health Organization regional Director for Africa, still cripples at least 12,000 children on the continent. 

The 100 million doses will be donated in the next three years by Chiron Vaccines, Pasteur Merieux-Connaught and SmithKline Beechamm. The doses are expected to meet the vaccination needs of between 25-30 million African children.

In addition, a grant of one million U.S. dollars will be provided by Wyeth- Lederic Vaccines and Pediatrics for strengthening of a laboratory network for the crippling disease's surveillance in Africa.

The donation was accepted by the WHO Director General, Dr Hiroshi Nakajima and Dr Denis Broun, Chief of health section at UNICEF.

It was part of the highlights during the first day of the 6th Consultative group meeting of the Children's Vaccine Initiative (CVI), which ends here Tuesday evening.

CVI was created during the 1990 World Children's summit to bring together diverse organizations and expertise to work towards the goal of providing better protection for the world's children against diseases through the development of new and improved vaccines.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 10, 1996


Business and Finance;
Privatisation Of Mozambican Glass Factory Completed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The Mozambican government on Thursday completed the privatisation of Vidreira, the only facotry in the country producing bottles and glassware.

About 55 percent of the company is now owned by the Portuguese firm Barbosa e Almeida, while the remaining 45 percent remains in the hands of the state. 

One peculiarity of this privatisation is that Vidreira has been split into two companies, Vidreira de Mocambique, and Cristalaria (crystalware) de Mocambique. The former is by far the larger company with initial capital of 5. 5 million U.S. dollars (three million from Barbosa e Almeida and 2.5 million from the Mozambican state).

The initial capital of the second company is 867,000 dollars, 400,000 held by the government and 467,000 by Barbosa e Almeida.

According to the head of the Vidreira Privatisation Commission, Mariamo Carimo, the debts amassed by Vidreira under state ownership will be paid off by the sale of the factory installations valued at 2.5 million dollars to the new companies.

Within three months, the two companies are to pay the state three million dollars, and this money will be used in the first instance to pay off Vidreira's debts.

Africa News


December 10, 1996


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia Says It Has Tantalum Deposits


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopia's state-owned Minerals Development Enterprise says the country has some 25 million tons of tantalum deposists, a rare mineral used in aeronautics and space-bound vehicles and instruments.

Tantalum, a hard gray metallic element that resists corrosion by most acids, is also used in dental and surgical instruments. 

Explorations in the past seven years in Kenticha, close to the Shakiso gold mining area of south-east Ethiopia, about 20km from Addis Ababa, have proved the availability of the rare mineral, local press Tuesday quoted Abdela Kedir, the head of the Tantalum Development Project, as saying.

He said tantalum explorations in nine areas of the Ado Shakiso district and trial production had yielded 20 to 30 tonnes of the mineral annualy during the last seven years.

Africa News


December 10, 1996


Ghana;
Rawlings Holds Out Olive Branch To Opponents


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - President Jerry John Rawlings Tuesday held an olive branch at his political opponents and said should his National Democratic Congress (NDC) win, the party's supporters would celebrate with the losers.

"We are members of one family. We will not be vindictive," he said. "There is much work ahead and we need to work together to build the country."

He was meeting officials from the International Foundation for Electoral Systems, one of several institutions which monitored Saturday's elections.

"Supporters of all the political parties which took part in the elections conducted themselves in a peaceful manner," said Rawlings. "I have always said a transformation has taken place in Ghana and I have been vindicated. Ghanaians are peace-loving."

With results from 138 constituencies, out of the 200, made public, Rawlings has 2,998,578 votes, representing 55.55 percent of the votes. John Agyekum Kufuor of the New Patriotic Party (NPP) has 2,231,524 votes (41.34 percent) while the third candidate, Dr Edward Mahama of the Peoples National Convention (PNC), has 167,153 votes (3.09 percent).

In the parliamentary race, NDC has 85 seats, NPP 50 and PNC has three.

Meanwhile, Kufuor Tuesday called on his supporters to remain calm and not to despair.

"Let us all show patience and tolerance while we wait (for the final result) ," he told a press conference at his party's head office of the in Accra.

"The calm and dignity they showed on Saturday, given the tremendous turn- out, does us all credit. I appeal to everyone to continue to show the same calm and dignity in waiting for the final results to be released. Let us all show patience and tolerance while we wait," Kufuor said.

241 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 11, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Recovering Nigerian Star Seeks Inspiration From His Past


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Cleveland, United States (PANA) - As the captain of the Nigerian under-23 soccer team at the Atlanta Games, Nwankwo Kanu's two spectacular goals in the competition's semi-finals helped Nigeria clinch the soccer gold, the country's first.

Now, as a recovering heart patient at the 75-year-old Cleveland Clinic in the American state of Ohio, Kanu has turned to those same goals to uplift his spirit and help in his recovery process.

With less than a minute to go in that semi-final match between Nigeria and Brazil, Kanu collected the ball in the opponents' 18-yard box and flipped it past hapless defenders even as he had to turn almost 180 degrees for tactical reasons.

The goal drew Nigeria level at 3-3. Then, Kanu went ahead to score the " golden goal" that gave Nigeria the match. 

Sitting in a room in the 11,000-worker hospital complex a thin smile creased his face as he watched a video tape of that match. That changed to a broad smile as the images of him celebrating his first goal flashed across the screen of a 19-inch television set.

"I thank God for seeing me through the surgery, and I hope to go back to the sport soon," he said.

Kanu has been discharged from the hospital where he underwent four hours of surgery to repair a heart valve which doctors say was defective from birth.

The defect, diagnosed by Kanu's Italian club doctors at Inter Milan as a valvular insufficiency of the aorta, threatened his life.

However the doctors who performed the surgery have pronounced it a success. The prognosis is good for a speedy return to the pitch for the 20-year-old star.

"My doctors have said that I will recover fully and could return to the sport...by February if I follow my rehab well," he told a visiting Nigerian delegation recently.

First, he needs to settle his 100,000-dollar hospital bill and begin his graduated rehabilitation.

The Nigerian government has already approved about 50,000 dollars for the bills and is expected to consider the player's appeal for further assistance since his rehabilitation bills will also run into several thousands of dollars.

Kanu, tall with long, almost oversized limbs, has already started the first stage of rehabilitation. This includes daily workouts on a treadmill at the hospital's Rehabilitation Center.

Everyday he trades his navy blue bathrobe for a track-suit and a blue cap inscribed with the letter "K", as the takes the elevator from his 14th-floor room to the rehabilitation center on the first floor.

Yet for the full rehabilitation, which will involve swimming and jogging, he has been scheduled to travel to a sports-oriented facility in California, thousands of miles away from Cleveland.

The Cleveland facility is a non-profit academic medical center which has treated 75,000 patients from at least 100 countries.

Doctors at the clinic and his managers are not saying much in terms of when Kanu will return to sport, seemingly concentrating on restoring his health first.

"We are taking it step by step," his manager, Franklin Sedoc, said. "That's how we handled it when Kanu first learned about his heart condition and that's how we will approach his rehabilitation."

Cleveland Clinic cardiologist John Kramer said that Kanu's surgeon, Dr. Bruce Lytle, decided to repair the defective valve rather than replace it. This is designed to improve Kanu's chances of returning to soccer.

However, sources close to the hospital are more emphatic, saying that while the doctors are being cautious, they believe that the Nigerian international will go back to the sport in which he has recorded an impressive achievement even at 20 years of age.

Recently named African Footballer of the Year for 1996, Kanu's past soccer glories include helping Nigeria's under-17 team to victory in Japan in 1993 and Dutch club Ajax Amsterdam to several titles, including the European Champions Cup.

Whether he will come back to win more laurels remains to be seen but Kanu is not giving up.

"I am not finished," he said when the news of his heart problems broke. "No one knows what the future holds but you have to fight for what you believe in. I just want to get back to the pitch."


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


242 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 11, 1996


Science and Health;
Gambia Achieves 100% Coverage In Hepatitis Vaccination


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Within a decade, Gambia has managed to vaccinate all its children against hepatitis B, a doctor from that nation has said.

At the just-ended sixth working group meeting of the Children's Vaccine Initiative (CVI), Gambia was mentioned, together with Botswana, South Africa and Swaziland, as countries which had succeeded in "sustaining hep B immunization within the EPI", or the Expanded Programme on Immunization.

The hepatitis B vaccine was originally developed to respond to the very high incidence of primary liver cancer in developing countries, as a result of chronic infection with the hepatitis B virus. 

Dr Abdoulie Jack of Gambia's Medical Research Council Laboratories, Banjul, said the smallness of the country's population was a factor in its 100- percent vaccination coverage.

"However, if we managed to do it, other countries can do it as well provided there is stringent management of the resources available, including cold chain systems, doses, vehicles and logistics," he told PANA in Dakar.

He said that all African countries had the potential as Gambia to attain the same degree of cover against hepatitis B so long as the task was made part of their primary health care systems.

Gambian surgeon Ebrihim Samba said poor management of resources for the vaccination programmes, in African countries, was regrettable.

"In some countries, it is not surprising to find EPI vehicles being used to ferry fish," said Samba, the World Health Organization Regional Director for Africa.

He said that massive international funding for vaccination programmes in Africa had not been matched by results.

Lack of money and the reluctance of funding agencies to pump more of it into hepatitis B programmes were cited as reasons for the low levels of vaccination in some countries, although 74 nations have included hepatitis B vaccine within their EPI.

Dr Peter Ndumbe, of the Faculty of Medicine and Biomedical Studies at Yaounde University, Cameroon, said funding agencies opted to give priority to poor countries which showed sustainable immunization programmes against other diseases.

He said that besides inadequate money for hepatitis B, there had been problems in mobilizing resources for eradicating yellow fever, whose resurgence has been observed over the last five years in sub-Sahara Africa.

In a paper on the "New Approaches To Vaccine Introduction," he said that 31 West, Central and Eastern African states were "at risk of the urban and jungle cycles of epidemic and endemic yellow fever."

Yellow fever outbreaks, he said, were reported in Sierra Leone and Benin in 1996. In Benin, he added, 60 percent of the children who died "had been fully immunized with the six routine EPI vaccines."

To deal with the problem of inadequate funding for EPI, another document presented at the Dakar meeting urged governments to establish separate budgets for vaccination programmes.

It called, also, on donors to direct their resources toward the vaccine independence initiative, so as to reduce dependency on external funds.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


243 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 11, 1996


Sudan;
Sudan Confirms Al Mahdi Has Left The Country


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan's Ministry of the Interior confirmed Wednesday that former Prime Minister Sadiq Al Mahdi had left the country.

State radio and the government-run Sudan News Agency quoted the ministry as saying that "Mr Sadiq Al Mahdi has disappeared from his home since Monday and later on it became clear that he is now outside the country." 

The ministry was reacting to a news reports Wednesday that Mahdi was now in Asmara, Eritrea.

It said that Mahdi, who has opposed President Omar El Bashir's plan to impose Islam's Sharia laws on the nation, had not been forced to leave the country.

"It is common knowledge that Mr.Sadiq El Mahdi has been enjoying the freedom of movement and used to attend all occasions without any restrictions, " said the ministry.

Mahdi, an Oxford educated politician who was prime minister from 1986-1989, remained in Sudan despite his ouster in a bloodless coup in 1989 by Gen. Omar El Bashir. Mahdi refused to join the Sudanese opposition exile communities in Cairo, London or Asmara. He has said, often, he preferred a "civil struggle" to an armed confrontation in removing Bashir's government.

However, opposition parties in exile including Mahdi's UMMA (freedom) Party joined recently with the anti-government Sudan People's Liberation Army of John Garang. They formed an allied army to fight the Bashir government.

Recent government reports from Khartoum said the opposition forces, based in neighbouring Eritrea, had on many occasions attacked border army posts and planted mines which have killed or wounded many people.

Sadiq El Mahdi is the great great grandson of Muhammad ibn el- Sayyid Abdullah who in 1883 defeated major Egyptian and British forces who tried to impose Egyptian rule over Sudan.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 11, 1996


Ghana;
Rawlings Increases Lead In Presidential Race


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ghana's incumbent president, Jerry Rawlings, has stretched his lead in Saturday's presidential polls, the Electoral Commission said Wednesday in certified results it released.

Kwadwo Afari-Gyan, chairman of the commission, told a news conference that with results from 179 constituencies confirmed, Rawlings had won 3,593,221 votes or 56 percent. 

John Kufuor of the New Patriotic Party has 2,628,628 votes or 41.0 percent, while Edward Mahama of the People's National Convention (PNC) trails with 189, 037 or 2.9 percent.

Afari-Gyan said the National Democratic Congress (NDC), Rawlings' party, had so far won 117 parliamentary seats, the NPP 57, the PCP four, and the PNC, one.

He said total results from five regions have been collated. They are the Ashanti, Greater Accra, Eastern, Upper West and Northern regions.

The commission has yet to certify results from seven constituencies in the Volta Region, five in the Western region, three each in the Central and Brong Ahafo regions and two in the Upper-East region.

Africa News


December 11, 1996(


Business and Finance;
Zambian Mining Company Prospects Brighten


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - The discovery of more copper ore and the enforcement of the rehabilitation programme has brightened the future of Nchanga Division, making it more attractive to potential investors.

Copper, according to information released by Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) yesterday, is being found at a faster rate making operations more viable. 

Nchanga Divisional general manager, Robert Russell, in a press statement yesterday, said drilling of existing sources and exploration of future reserves had been very successful.

"The division depleted three million tones of ore last financial year but generated three times as much to the tune of nine million tones," he said.

Russell said steps had been taken to boost production to higher levels and this had included replacement and rehabilitation of existing equipment.

Chief geologist Dave Armstrong said the future of any mine depended on continued exploration of minerals.

He said for the three million tones depleted in the open pit last year nine million tones has been generated this year.

He said his department was doing a major re-evaluation of the mining potential of the entire Nchanga area and was confident that additional ore would be proved.

The overall objective is to safeguard the mining future at Nchanga following the completion of operations in the main open pit within the next 10 years.

LANGUAGE: English

246 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 11, 1996


Zaire;
A Zairean Analysis of the Conflict in Eastern Zaire


BYLINE: Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja, Africa Policy Information Center (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2800 words


 

Harare - The restoration of the Mobutu regime, with the installation of the Kengo government in July 1994, came in the wake of the genocide in Rwanda and at the time of France's intervention there to erase the traces of its own role as an accessory to crime.

Having supported the Habyarimana regime and trained its genocidal machine, including the extremist Hutu Interahamwe militia, the French were relieved to have in Kinshasa a regime that would let them permit the Rwandan killers, both soldiers and militiamen, to cross into Zaire with all their weapons. The fact that these killers were now free to use Zairean territory to launch raids into Rwanda, and to slaughter Tutsi citizens and residents of Zaire, is the immediate cause of the current fighting in eastern Zaire. 

The roots of this violent conflict lie deep in the history of the Great Lakes region as well as in the political alignments of the Mobutu regime nationally, regionally and internationally. There is, in the first place, the question of whether or not people of Rwandan origin, or Banyarwanda (Hutu, Tutsi and Twa), can claim Zairean citizenship on basis of being native to Zaire as of August 1885, when this country came into existence as the Congo Free State. If so, they would, as other indigenous people all over Africa, lay claim to ancestral lands in eastern Zaire. In the second place, the conflict has to do with the consequences for Zaire of the Hutu-Tutsi conflict in both Rwanda and Burundi. In either case, the actions and decisions of the Mobutu regime since 1972 have helped to exacerbate tensions and to bring about the present crisis.

Rwanda and Burundi are two of the major precolonial kingdoms to have survived Western conquest and occupation as more or less viable political entities, with the monarchies being destroyed between 1959 and 1961 in Rwanda and between 1965 and 1968 in Burundi. The population of both countries is made up of three social groups traditionally distinguished on the basis of occupation: the Hutu (roughly 85%), the Tutsi (14%) and the Twa (1%). The Twa are a pygmoid people, who also have important settlements west of the great lakes in the equatorial forest of Central Africa, including the nearby Zaire's Ituri Forest. Contrary to colonially created myths, the Tutsi-Hutu conflict is not a centuries old struggle between "Hamitic" pastoralists (Tutsi) and Bantu agriculturists (Hutu). For the Tutsi are not "Hamites." They are a Bantu people who share a common Bantu culture with the Hutu, with whom they speak a common Bantu language, Rinyarwanda or Rirundi, depending on the country.

Immigration and settlement in eastern Zaire by the Banyarwanda occurred at different moments, and for a variety of reasons. As in other parts of the world, the entire Great Lakes region did constitute a commercial frontier for relatively powerful states like ancient Rwanda. And there is historical evidence that Rwandan agricultural colonies were established in the islands of Lake Kivu, now part of Zaire, in the 18th century. In addition to this, a group of ethnic Tutsi claims to have settled during the 17th century in the hills they have named "Mulenge" between Lakes Kivu and Tanganyika, or between Bukavu and Uvira in the South Kivu province of Zaire. Accordingly, they call themselves Banyamulenge.

This oral tradition is hotly contested by other indigenous Zairean groups. One of these, the Bafulero, actually contests the right of these ethnic Tutsi to call themselves "Banyamulenge" on the ground that "Mulenge" is the title of a Bafulero chief whose land is located some 200 kilometres south of the area occupied by these Tutsi.

However true this dismissal of the Banyamulenge's oral history might be, it would be difficult to deny that some Rwandan settlements may have found themselves west of the colonial boundary as drawn in 1885. Moreover, the Banyarwanda who lived on Idjwi Island, the largest of Lake Kivu islands, became Belgian subjects in 1910, as did other Kinyarwanda speaking colonies in North Kivu, when Germany ceded the lands they occupied to Belgium, in a boundary adjustment between the two imperial powers.

The legal distinction between them and other Congolese became academic after Belgium took over Rwanda and Burundi in 1920 as League of Nations mandatory power and, in 1945, as United Nations trusteeship authority. For all practical purposes, Belgium governed Zaire, Rwanda and Burundi as a single colonial entity known as "Le Congo Belge et le Ruanda-Urundi", with a single army, the Force Publique, a single governor general in Kinshasa and two lieutenant governors general in Lubumbashi and Bujumbura, respectively. As a teenager growing up in the Belgian Congo in the 1950s, it never occurred to me that these three territories were destined to become three separate nation-states.

Belgium moved thousands of Banyarwanda peasants to the eastern Zaire districts of Masisi, Rutshuru and Walikale m North Kivu between 1937 and 1955, for purposes of easing the demographic pressure in heavily populated Rwanda, and recruited thousands more for work in mining, transport and agricultural enterprises in Shaba, Maniema and South Kivu provinces throughout the colonial period. Most of these Banyarwanda voted in the first municipal elections of 1957-58, and in the general or independence elections of 1960. Representatives of their communities, albeit few ones, were also elected to public office in Zaire. In spite of a new influx of Banyarwanda in 1959-61, mostly Tutsi political refugees fleeing their homeland as a result of the Rwandan Revolution, Zaire continued to welcome them with open arms.

Problems began to appear when the numbers of Banyarwanda grew progressively due to both natural increase and clandestine immigration in the postcolonial period. In January 1972, under the influence of his Tutsi chief of staff Bisengimana Rwema, Mobutu signed a decree giving Zairean citizenship to all natives of Rwanda and Burundi who had settled in Zaire before 1950. In addition to their success in professional and business activities, the Banyarwanda in general and the Tutsi in particular were now in a stronger political position to use their proximity to Mobutu for greater economic and social gains. This they did with gusto, using their financial means and their newly found political power to acquire more land in heavily populated North and South Kivu provinces. Needless to say, they could always find indigenous chiefs who were willing and even eager to privatize ancestral lands in exchange for money and/or political favours. All this increased the resentment that other Zaireans had towards them, which was partly based on the latter's distaste for the Banyarwanda's apparent social exclusiveness.

The 1972 decree was so unpopular that Mobutu himself accepted to sign a law passed by his one-party parliament in June 1981 invalidating the decree and defining Zairean nationality or citizenship on basis of membership in an ethnic group known to exist within the borders of Zaire as defined in August 1885. By this token, only those Banyarwanda who had actually solicited and obtained naturalization in Zaire could be declared citizens. All those who were citizens by virtue of being descendants of pre-1885 settlements, of the 1910 boundary change, and of the pre-1950 migratory movements were automatically deprived of their Zairean citizenship. The question that this action raises with respect to international law and fundamental human rights, and the one that the Banyarwanda raised at the national conference in 1992, is whether it is legally and morally acceptable for a state to deprive a section or stratum of its inhabitants of their citizenship rights.

Stripped of their citizenship, Banyarwanda peasants are also denied land rights, as the land they occupy and use is being claimed as ancestral land by the indigenous groups among whom they live. The land question is at the heart of the conflict between them and other Zaireans in both North and South Kivu. Before the genocide in Rwanda, thousands of people died in interethnic violence in 1992-93 in North Kivu. Instead of finding ways of resolving the conflict in a responsible manner, Zairean authorities added fuel to fire with xenophobia appeals, while soldiers and military officers became implicated in arms trafficking on both sides.

An example of this state-sponsored terrorism is the xenophobia campaign waged by the provincial authorities of North and South Kivu before and during the current war in eastern Zaire. In September 1996, South Kivu Deputy Governor Lwasi Ngabo Lwabanji stated in a radio broadcast that if the Tutsi Banyamulenge did not leave Zaire within a week, they would be interned in camps and exterminated. The Banyamulenge's reply was succinctly put by a young fighter who told Chris McGreal of the Mail and Guardian that "we don't come from Rwanda and they cannot force us to go because we know how to fight and the army does not" (M&G, 25-31 Oct. 1996). Being basically a praetorian guard, Mobutu's army was decisively routed in a very short time, as the Tutsi and their allies took control of Uvira, Bukavu and Goma, the major cities of the Kivu region.

At the present time, the plight of the Banyarwanda is inextricably linked to the Hutu-Tutsi conflict in Rwanda and Burundi. The 1990 invasion of Rwanda by the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) from Uganda; the assassination of the first democratically elected President of Burundi, the Front Democratique Burundais (FRODEBU) leader Melchior Ndadaye; and the genocide in Rwanda are part of the political background to the current conflict in eastern Zaire.

Like Tutsi communities all over the world and in the Great Lakes region in particular, the Tutsi of Zaire did raise funds for the RPF cause and send some of their young people to take part in the struggle as fighters. This participation in the RPF war effort, at a time when the Zairean government was supporting the Habyarimana regime, did raise questions as to the loyalty of Zaire's Tutsi in particular and that of the Banyarwanda in general. To many patriots in Zaire, this type of behaviour meant that the Banyarwanda were using their Zairean citizenship in an expedient manner-for purely political ends or pecuniary advantage-while their real heart and loyalty were elsewhere. However understandable such feelings are, they do not justify officially led or sanctioned xenophobia campaigns against all Tutsi. Statements broadcast by South Kivu Governor Kyembwa wa Lumuna and his deputy Lwasi were, according to McGreal, "remarkably similar to the extremist Hutu messages broadcast during the Rwandan genocide" (Mail and Guardian, Nov. 1-7, 1996).

The Mobutu regime bears a major blame for the current situation, for having allowed the French through their Operation Turquoise, to assist Habyarimana's army and the Interahamwe to regroup in Zaire for purposes of reconquering Rwanda. These killers then used the Zairean refugee camps to raid Rwanda on a regular basis and to organize the slaughter of Zaire's Tutsi. For two years and a half, Zaire and the international community watched and did nothing to stop this, while the UN and the major powers continued to be more preoccupied with feeding refugees, including the killers, rather than searching for a solution to the whole crisis. Like any other responsible government would, Rwandan authorities have given military support to the Tutsi of Zaire as a way of putting an end to the Hutu extremists' raids into Rwanda.

Now that the rebel alliance is doing the job that the international community failed to do, the only justification for humanitarian intervention in the Great Lakes region is to pursue and arrest all the remaining killers to bring them to justice for genocide, and to prepare an enabling environment for the resettlement of the returnees in Rwanda. There is no need for foreign military intervention in Zaire. The UN-mandated intervention does not inspire confidence, because it was initiated by the French, whose motives are suspect. Jean-Francois Medard, a world renowned professor of African affairs at the Institute of Political Studies at the University of Bordeaux in France told Newsweek magazine in 1994 that "French policy in Africa is erratic and criminal," as his country's "government operates not on principle, but on cynicism" (Newsweek, November 21, 1994, p. 30).

Finally, a word about the so-called rebel alliance. The Tutsi are not fighting alone. They have been joined by several non-Tutsi groups of rebels who have waged for years a low intensity and at times sporadic campaign of armed struggle against the Mobutu regime. The best known of these groups is the Parti de la Revolution Populaire (PRP), a remnant of the 1964 eastern front of the "second independence" movement, which is led by Laurent Kabila. For over 30 years, the PRP has maintained a maquis in the mountains of the Fizi-Baraka area near Uvira, and has not succeeded in playing its once expected role as a spearhead of the second phase of the national liberation struggle in Zaire.

The alliance's administrative control over Goma, Bukavu and Uvira is the latest but much larger version of the state-within-a-state that the PRP has maintained for years over its Fizi-Baraka enclave. Mr. Kabila, the PRP chief, had for all practical purposes become a typical African warlord rather than a revolutionary guerrilla leader. If he and his allies are to be congratulated for once again showing to the whole world the bankruptcy of the Mobutu regime and, above all, for ending the Rwandan refugee problem in Zaire, they are far from being the liberators they hope to be. For a strategy of genuine national liberation requires the kind of political work that the PRP has not done, nor has the capacity to undertake.

Only a legitimate and democratically elected government can resolve the land and citizenship issues involving the Banyarwanda of Zaire. The PRP-led alliance is part of the popular struggle for democracy in Zaire, and needs to be brought into the ongoing process of peaceful change initiated by the democracy movement since 1980. As for the Great Lakes region as a whole, there will be no durable peace and security without democracy and social progress in Zaire, on the one hand, and until a just and lasting solution is found to the problem of coexistence between Hutu and Tutsi in Rwanda and Burundi, on the other.

Harare, Zimbabwe, November 19, 1996

Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja is former vice president of the National Electoral Commission of Zaire, president of the African Association of Political Science, and professor African Studies at Howard University.

Distributed by the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC), 110 Maryland Ave. NE, No. 509, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546- 1545. E-mail: apic@igc.apc.org.

247 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 11, 1996


Zaire;
WFP Eastern Zaire Situation Report No. 34


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Rome - EASTERN ZAIRE: A UN team, consisting of WFP, UNHCR and UNICEF representatives, visited the Uvira area over the weekend and returned to Bukavu 9 December. Access to the port was denied as was access to Fizi for security reasons.

TANZANIA: Up to 25,000 refugees, mainly from Kagenyi and Rubwera camps in the Karagwe area, are reported to have dispersed. While most have moved south towards Chabalisa, some 5,500 moved northwards towards the Ugandan border. Unconfirmed reports of insecurity in area south of Murungo. It has been reported that refugees are preparing to return to Rwanda. 

WFP has offered its empty food bags to assist in the packing and transport of personal effects. There should be enough bags to provide one bag to every two refugees. Weekly food distributions commenced yesterday in Tanzania camps and should be completed by tomorrow morning. This should ensure a food supply to those returnees heading to Rwanda during repatriation.

RWANDA: On 9 December, WFP and NGO partners (CARE, CRS, LWF, World Vision, Concern, CRR, IFRC, Trocaire, Caritas, ADRA, MEC, GAA, AHA, World Relief, AEF, EEF, IRC, MSF, ASS, Salvation Army, Ingabo) distributed approximately 746 metric tons of food. This represents 44,670 people assisted with a monthly ration. All returnees (from the large inflow during November) have received their initial 7-day ration at the commune level with most now receiving monthly rations. The ration is made up of 400 g of cereals, 120 g of pulses, 20 g of oil and 5 g of salt per person and per day. WFP, UN agencies and NGOs have put together a detailed contingency plan in Kibungo prefecture for the return of refugees from Tanzania.

Seven way stations will be set up along the road from the border to Curazo (36.5 km from Rusumo). These way stations will provide water, medical care and biscuits. The average distance between way stations will be 11 km. WFP continues to supply food to prefectures, focusing on areas expecting returnees from Tanzania. 1,200 metric tons of mixed commodities were transported within the country over the weekend of 7-8 December. In Kibungo, WFP and partner agencies have thus far prepositioned 463 mt of food in nine of the Kibungo communes, representing 122,600 weekly rations already in place.

The prepositioning of food in Kibungo prefecture continues in preparation for a possible 340,000 returnees to this prefecture. WFP and NGO partners hold regular weekly meetings to discuss issues and problems faced during food distributions and preparations for the possible influx of refugees from Tanzania. All NGOs have agreed to involve women's groups in their ongoing distributions and longer term objectives such as an expansion of WFP's food- for-work activities in the communes.

WFP and partners are keen to ensure that women make an active contribution to the planning and monitoring of new projects, as well as benefit directly from any new initiatives. One of the most serious problems being encountered at commune level is the lack of storage space. The use of "Cocoons" (small storage facilities of 20 to 100 mt capacity provided by CARE) and the increased number of WFP storage tents of 500 ton capacity in the country (two erected with six more under way) should help alleviate this problem. Following reports of irregular rainfalls in Butare and Gikongoro prefectures, the FAO/WFP crop assessment mission in the country will visit these areas to assess the situation.

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION, PLEASE CONTACT WFP EASTERN ZAIRE CRISIS SUPPORT FACILITY (CSF): International Fax Line: 39 6 5228-2828 International Telephone Line: 39 6 5228-2535 Electronic Mail Address: ezaire@wfp.org WFP HAS AN EASTERN ZAIRE EMERGENCY SITE ON THE INTERNET WITH LATEST REPORTS AND MAPS. THE ADDRESS OF WFP IS: http://www.wfp.org


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


248 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 11, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 54 on Eastern Zaire (12/11)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

Nairobi - Rwandan refugees in Tanzania appear to be on the verge of leaving the camps in large numbers. A report from the office of the Humanitarian Coordinator in Kigali said 13,000 Muslims throughout the camps had asked to be repatriated this weekend. They will probably walk to the Rusumo border crossing, with some transport assistance for vulnerable groups. UNHCR, in its daily report, said the atmosphere in the Ngara camps was relaxed and refugees seemed to be preparing to go back. Some were selling their belongings or harvesting their beans. Further north, in Karagwe, the situation was less clear with reports of some 23,000 refugees fleeing away from the border following a campaign of intimidation by Hutu extremists in the camps. According to WFP, many of these refugees had moved south towards Chabalisa, but around 5,000 were heading northwards to the Ugandan border. UNHCR said the local authorities in the Karagwe region were enforcing measures promulgated a year ago, to restrict the movement of refugees outside four kms of the camps and to stop all commercial activities. UNHCR added it was sending 270 trucks to Tanzania from Rwanda to be used in the repatriation process.

Radio Tanzania today said arrangements to repatriate 130,000 refugees in Karagwe had been finalised. It quoted the district commissioner as saying the plans had been drawn up with UNHCR collaboration. 

About 559 refugees from Karagwe arrived at a refugee camp in southwest Uganda yesterday and Monday, and it was expected that more would arrive today, WFP said. Oruchinga camp in Mbarara shelters 6,500 refugees, 5,000 of whom are Rwandan Hutu moderates who left the country in 1992-94. The refugees coming from Tanzania are crossing the Kagera river which straddles the border by private canoe, and then walking the remaining 2kms to the camp.

A WFP programme for supplying food to Rwandan prefectures expecting an influx of returnees from Tanzania is underway. WFP said 1,200 MT of mixed commodities were transported within Rwanda over the weekend. A detailed contingency plan has been elaborated by WFP, UN agencies and NGOs for Kibungo prefecture, which may have to cope with as many as 340,000 returnees.

Representatives of the Tanzanian and Rwandan governments and UNHCR are due to hold a meeting at the Tanzania-Rwanda border crossing tomorrow. The meeting is likely to be continued in the Ngara camps the next day and is expected to kick-start the repatriation process which is planned to begin at Ngara. All returnees will be required to register at commune level, DHA Kigali said. During the repatriation from eastern Zaire, there was some confusion as some refugees registered at commune level and others at sectoral level.

Aid workers, quoted by Reuters, said they believed Tanzanian troop reinforcements were heading for the northwestern camps to enforce the government's repatriation deadline of December 31 and that anyone escaping from the camps would face arrest.

Tanzanian Prime Minister Frederick Sumaye yesterday warned refugees against taking part in politics or military training and told them to respect the laws of the land. Addressing Burundian refugees at a camp in Kibondo district, he said they should continue living peacefully until they were ready to go home, Tanzanian radio reported. Any refugees who left the camps would be arrested, jailed and repatriated despite the fact that their countries were in turmoil. The minister said the warning came after the arrest of some refugees who had been involved in murder, theft and poaching.

The exiled Rwandan Hutu organisation, Rally for the Return of Refugees and Democracy in Rwanda (RDR), has alleged, in a statement issued on Monday, that the repatriation of Rwandan refugees from Tanzania may just be the start of a new cycle of instability and a "return to square one."

The UN inter-agency mission which flew over the Shabunda area on Sunday and Monday confirmed the presence of some 50,000 mostly Rwandan refugees in the region of Katshunga. The team - made up of UNHCR, DHA, UNDP, UNICEF, WHO plus MSF and advisers of the Zairean interior and defence ministries - found that the Zairean army had cut off the road beteen Shabunda and Kindu at Matukamo/Magenbe and were preventing refugees from walking towards Kindu. The plane managed to land at Shabunda and after some time on foot, the team located two refugee camps near Nialubwe, one consisting of 300-400 people, the other of about 2,000. These camps cannot be seen from the air. The mission also established that many refugees, some 20,000, were walking towards Walikale and then onwards to Kisangani.

UNHCR said 1,400 refugees from the Virunga National Park in the Goma region returned to Rwanda via Cyangugu yesterday. It said about 35,000 refugees, who had emerged from the forests, had been repatriated since November 19.

Kisangani has been calm over the past few days and newly-arrived Special Presidential Division troops are reported to be in control of the situation, according to the UN in Kinshasa. Only sporadic gunfire has been heard. Local authorities and missionary sources indicate a general price increase and overall food shortages, especially in Kisangani, Lubutu and Kindu. The local authorities warn that if the food situation does not improve by next week, the overall health of the population and general security are quickly expected to deteriorate. The Belgian embassy in Kinshasa announced that it had provided about 110 MT of food aid to affected people and soldiers in Kisangani over a week ago.

Unconfirmed reports said pockets of ex-FAR and Interahamwe troops have engaged Zairean rebels in a series of clashes, west of Goma. According to an AFP report, local eyewitnesses claimed the fighting, some 50kms away from Goma, had been underway for several days. Zairean Justice Minister Joseph Nsinga Udjuu meanwhile has urged the international community not to abandon his country. He called on countries "to resume their place at the side of the Zairean people and help it (Zaire) to again find political, social and economic stability without which human rights are at risk." The UN High Commission for Human Rights announced the deployment of the first two observers to Kinshasa yesterday, following allegations of human rights abuses in Zaire.

The USA and its European allies yesterday stressed the need to deploy a multi-national force (MNF) to the Great Lakes region to help with the humanitarian crisis, according to a spokesman for Belgian Foreign Minister Erik Derycke. He was speaking after a meeting in Brussels on the sidelines of a NATO ministerial gathering which included US, French, British and Dutch delegates. "No-one at the meeting questioned it (MNF)," the spokesman said. He added that an ambassadorial level meeting on Friday at UN headquarters in New York should confirm yesterday's talks.

Nairobi, December 11 1996, 15:15 GMT (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


249 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 11, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Great Lakes Situation Report No. 11


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3494 words


 

Washington DC - U.S. Agency For International Development, Bureau for Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) . GREAT LAKES - Complex Emergency Situation Report No. 11 Fiscal Year (FY) 1997, December 10, 1996. Note: The last situation report was dated December 5, 1996. 

Overview

The Banyamulenge and the Banyarwanda people, who are Tutsi of Rwandan origin, settled in the Mulenge hills of South Kivu, Zaire, and the Masisi region of North Kivu, Zaire, more than 200 years ago. Sporadic ethnic violence in the Masisi region has occurred since 1959, but it again escalated in the fall of 1995 as the former Rwandan army (the ex-FAR) and the Rwandan Hutu militia (the Interahamwe) targeted Banyarwanda Tutsi in an apparent attempt to create an area of Hutu control. In September 1996, the situation in the Uvira region of South Kivu began to resemble that of the Masisi region, as government-sanctioned harassment of Banyamulenge Tutsis intensified. On October 8, 1996, the South Kivu Deputy Governor declared that Banyamulenge residents should leave the area within seven days or risk treatment as rebels. On October 14, fighting broke out between the Banyamulenge rebels and the Zairian Army (FAZ) near Runingo refugee camp, in South Kivu, forcing the roughly 220,000 refugees to flee. The Banyamulenge joined forces with other Zairian rebels to form the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL), and the fighting spread, moving up the eastern border of Zaire from Uvira to Bukavu, as well as south from Rutshuru (North Kivu) to Goma. As a result of shelling from Rwanda on October 26 and November 1, hundreds of thousands of refugees from Kibumba, Katale, and Kahindo camps near Goma, fled to Mugunga camp. Both the ex-FAR and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)-financed Zairian Camp Security Contingent (CZSC), became involved in the fighting. After suffering defeat, the FAZ and CZSC retreated to the west, looting villages and displacing Zairians from Goma town and surrounding areas. Following Hutu attacks from Mugunga camp on Goma town, the ADFL counter-attacked on November 14, forcing the ex-FAR and Interahamwe to retreat to the west and compelling hundreds of thousands of refugees to flee.

Numbers Affected

Rwandan refugees: An estimated 600,000 Rwandan refugees have returned from the Goma area camps to Rwanda. Zambia hosts 1,000 Rwandan refugees, and Tanzania hosts 1,200.

Burundian refugees: Of the 143,000 Burundian refugees originally in the Uvira area, some 62,000 refugees have returned to Burundi and about 13,500 have arrived in Tanzania.

Newly Displaced: Fleeing continued fighting in Burundi, a new caseload of about 100,000 Burundian refugees has entered Tanzania. Approximately 35,000 Zairians have fled to Tanzania. About 475 Rwandan and Zairian Tutsis were airlifted from Brazzaville, Congo, to Kigali, Rwanda. Some 800 remain in the Congo and 11,500 Zairians are reported in Uganda. The U.S. Embassy in Zaire estimates that 170,000 Zairians have been displaced by the conflict in eastern Zaire, including 20,000 from Uvira, 60,000 from Bukavu, 40,000 from Goma, and 50,000 from rural areas.

Unknown Populations: The U.S. military estimates there are 225,000 to 285, 000 people on the move within Zaire. UNHCR believes that there still may be as many as 400,000. It is uncertain whether these are displaced Zairians, Rwandan or Burundian refugees or former Rwandan militia.

Current Situation The United Nations (U.N.) World Food Program (WFP) reports that some 28,000 returnees came back to Rwanda from Zaire during the week of November 27 to December 2, 24,000 via Gisenyi, 3,500 via Cyangugu, and 500 via Kibungo.

On December 5, the Government of Tanzania (GOT) announced a decision to close the Rwandan refugee camps by December 31. Relief agencies are preparing for the return of an estimated 410,000 refugees.

Political/Military Situation Clashes continue in eastern Zaire, between ADFL and FAZ forces. The ADFL claims to have captured towns at the northern and southern ends of a 250 mile front. Reports that the ADFL captured Kindu and Kisangani do not appear accurate. The U.N. Department of Humanitarian Affairs (UNDHA) reports that the situation in Kisangani has become increasingly volatile. Some 400 Zairian soldiers remain in Kisangani after fleeing the rebel advance in north Kivu and shooting and looting are common occurrences. Uvira, Bukavu, and Goma remain calm and under ADFL control.

In response to U.N. Security Council Resolution 1080, the U.S. Government (USG) plans to participate in a multinational effort, led by Canada, to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian assistance and the repatriation of refugees. The mission of the multinational force is still under discussion.

The USG has helped to locate groups of refugees and displaced persons in eastern Zaire using aerial surveys and other means to gain accurate and complete information. The USG and others are working with the Canadians to plan for airdrops of emergency food to stranded refugees if necessary. Relief agencies have expressed reservations about airdrops, executed in the absence of a team on the ground to clear the drop zone and ensure distribution to malnourished refugees and/or internally displaced persons (IDPs).

Relief Efforts

Donors and humanitarian agencies are providing relief and rehabilitation assistance to returnees in accordance with the Government of Rwanda (GOR) plan, agreed upon at a conference hosted by the Canadian International Development Agency in Geneva on November 23. Participants agreed to support the GOR in promoting reconciliation and dialogue and in meeting reintegration and development needs, including housing, justice, security, and human resources development. Participants also called on all parties involved in the conflict to allow full humanitarian access to refugees and displaced persons in eastern Zaire.

On November 18, the U.N. announced a $259.5 million Flash Appeal for U.N. programs in Rwanda and eastern Zaire. UNHCR issued an appeal on November 19 for $66.9 million to support its emergency operations for refugees and IDPs in eastern Zaire and the immediate integration of more than 500,000 returnees in Rwanda.

On November 15, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) launched an appeal for $38.5 million to support its eastern Zaire operation for three months. ICRC has Government of Zaire (GOZ) permission to operate throughout Zaire and has the capacity to provide non-food relief for 525,000 people and food for 250,000 people per month. The GOR has sanctioned U.N. agencies and ten non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to provide cross- border assistance to refugees in eastern Zaire. Approved NGOs include Concern International, Medicins Sans Frontieres/Holland (MSF/Holland), American Refugee Committee (ARC), Trocaire, Oxfam, Save the Children Fund/UK (SCF/UK), African Humanitarian Action, Merlin, International Rescue Committee (IRC), and Lutheran World Federation.

Uvira: On December 3, a U.N./NGO team gained access to Uvira for the first time since expatriate relief workers evacuated on October 22. The team saw no refugees on the road from Bukavu to Uvira. They found that the WFP and UNHCR offices and warehouses had been looted. Access to the port was denied but the two cranes were reportedly intact. Uvira town is calm and markets have re- opened and are well-stocked. The nearby refugee camps are deserted.

Bukavu: Since mid-October, about 8,000 refugees have returned through the Bukavu-Cyangugu corridor. UNHCR is planning for the possible return of 30,000 Rwandan refugees from the Bukavu area and for some 25,000 Zairian IDPs who are making their way to Bukavu. In preparation, NGOs have established four way stations to provide water and medical assistance. NGOs currently working in Bukavu include Concern International, MSF/International, IRC, SCF/UK, Christian Aid, Oxfam, and Caritas. U.N agencies and ICRC are also working in Bukavu.

Goma: On November 27, a convoy of relief agencies found some 40,000 Rwandan refugees in fairly good health in Minova, located about 35 km southwest of Goma. On November 28, some of these refugees began moving towards Goma. Relief agencies set up way stations between Minova and Goma to distribute high protein biscuits and to provide water, sanitation, and health care. Relief agencies have been denied access to Minova since November 29 due to fighting in the area, but distribution of biscuits continues at way stations in Sake, Mugunga, and Kulungu. Fighting has reportedly pushed those remaining in the Minova area westward further into Zaire. The following relief organizations are currently operating in Goma: ARC, Merlin, Trocaire, SCF/UK, Concern International, Catholic Relief Services (CRS)/Caritas, Oxfam, MSF/I, ICRC, UNHCR, and WFP.

Kisangani: Access to the internally displaced populations in this area is now hindered by insecurity. Aviation Sans Frontieres pulled out of the area after its aircraft came under fire on December 2 and ICRC has withdrawn staff from both Kisangani and Kindu.

Rwanda: Of the 600,000 estimated returnees, nearly 323,000 have registered in their home communes as of December 1, according to the U.N. Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda UNHCR reports that the returnees are in good condition in general and in some of the communes are placed temporarily in a transit center until they are registered. After registration, they collect a seven-day food ration and will eventually receive monthly rations. UNICEF provides 100 grams of blended food supplement to all children under five years of age. Food distribution is ongoing in all prefectures of Rwanda. Distributions are implemented at the commune level with the exception of Mutara, Kibungo, Butare, Gikongoro, and Cyangugu where returnees receive assistance in transit centers at the prefecture level. From November 16 to December 6, WFP and NGO partners distributed approximately 6,170 metric tons (MT), which represents a total of 1,600,000 weekly rations.

WFP plans food-for-work activities for the seasonal lean periods of December and March-April, for returnees as well as the local population. Emphasis will be placed on assisting women-headed families.

The GOR Ministry of Rehabilitation and Social Integration reported on November 25 that there were 135,000 families without shelter in rural areas and 65,000 families in urban areas, of which about 20% are in Kigali. Some returnees find their homes occupied by squatters when they return. The GOR has given squatters two weeks to vacate dwellings belonging to returnees and has set up temporary transit centers to house returnees and displaced residents.

Burundi: WFP food reserves in Burundi are being depleted rapidly. WFP is attempting to move food and fuel across Lake Tanganyika from Kigoma , Tanzania, to import the 2,500 MT of food per month approved by the Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee.

UNHCR reports that of the 62,000 Burundian refugees who have returned to Burundi from Zaire, about 45,000 spontaneously repatriated to Cibitoke province and 15,000 arrived through the Gatumba transit center outside Bujumbura. WFP is distributing returnee packages to both populations.

The U.N. Human Rights Field Operation in Burundi (HRFOB), UNHCR, and NGOs are closely monitoring returns to areas where fighting is taking place. UNHCR reports that about 38,000 of the returnees to Cibitoke have settled in 10 government sites. HRFOB currently has five human rights observers and two officers providing technical assistance in Burundi.

Tanzania: Tanzanian refugee camps are burgeoning, as a result of influxes from Burundi and from eastern Zaire. WFP reports that new arrivals from Burundi are in poor nutritional state, with a 19% malnutrition rate for children under five years of age recorded in Mtendeli camp. WFP is sending additional quantities of corn-soy blend to the Kigoma region for supplementary feeding programs.

A joint statement issued by UNHCR and the GOT stated that conditions in Rwanda now allow for safe repatriation of Rwanda refugees. The GOR has given its commitment to receive all the Rwandan refugees and assumes responsibility for the repatriation. UNHCR has asked that all vulnerable persons wishing to return to Rwanda, including the elderly, the disabled, unaccompanied minors, and pregnant women, register with UNHCR by December 9 so that arrangement could be made for their transport. Some refugees have stated that they will require confirmation that their land is unoccupied prior to returning.

On December 4, the humanitarian community met in Kibungo, Rwanda, to coordinate relief efforts for refugees returning from Tanzania. The GOR wants relief assistance along the Ngara-Kibungo corridor provided in a staggered manner so as to encourage refugees to keep moving rather than encamping at way stations. The GOR has suggested establishment of water points every 5 km, way stations every 10 km, health posts every 10-15 km, and biscuit distribution points every 20 km.

MSF/I and Swiss Disaster Relief will be responsible for epidemic control and ARC will operate two mobile health units from Rusumo, Rwanda, at the border, to Kibungo. IRC and Oxfam will be responsible for water and sanitation needs from Rusumo to Kayonza, 92 km inside the border. From Kayonza a separate route splits off toward Kagitumba, 100 km to the north. ARC will handle all major relief efforts along this route. SCF, ICRC, and Food for the Hungry (FHI) will be working on unaccompanied children issues.

NGOs divided responsibilities for coordination of all NGO relief activities along the corridor that returnees will take. From Rusumo to Rwanteru, 18 km from the border, MSF/I will coordinate activities. World Vision Relief and Development (WVRD) will coordinate activities from Kirehe, 25 km inside the border, to Remera, 68 km from the border. ARC will be responsible for the piece stretching from Kabarondo, 76 km inside the border, to Rwamagana, 107 km from the border. USAID's Disaster Assistance Response Team (USAID/DART) will be providing funds to NGOs assisting returnees.

WFP is pre-positioning food commodities in Kibungo, Byumba, and Butare prefectures. Food is being pre-positioned at the commune level with the assistance of NGOs. Repatriation packages consisting of food and non-food items will be distributed at the commune level. UNHCR reports that 274 Rwandan refugees returned from Tanzania on December 5.

USG Assistance

On October 26, BHR/OFDA deployed a USAID/DART to Kigali, Rwanda, to conduct assessments, supply information updates, and provide funding to NGOs, U.N. agencies, and international organizations for programs to assist with repatriation efforts. On November 7, 1996, U.S. Ambassador to Rwanda, Robert Gribbin, declared a disaster, noting that the refugee crisis in eastern Zaire poses a humanitarian emergency for Rwanda. On November 12, 1996, U.S. Ambassador Daniel Simpson declared a disaster in Zaire, as a result of the violent break-up of refugee camps in eastern Zaire.

BHR/OFDA provided 675 rolls of plastic sheeting (sufficient to shelter 12, 000 families) and 13,300 blankets to UNHCR/Kigali. BHR/OFDA has also shipped 20 World Health Organization (WHO) emergency health kits which contain enough medical supplies to assist 200,000 people for three months to the Ministry of Health for distribution to health clinics in high impact communes. On November 18, the USG pledged $140 million in humanitarian and development assistance to address needs in the Great Lakes region.

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has seconded staff to UNHCR/Rwanda, UNHCR/Tanzania, and to WHO in Kigali to provide epidemiologic and public health assistance to refugees and others displaced by the conflict in eastern Zaire. CDC staff also participate in short term assessments health performed by IRC and the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) in Rwanda.

RWANDA: USG FY 1997 Humanitarian Assistance (to date):

BHR/OFDA, through the USAID/DART, is currently processing grants to 18 NGOs to provide shelter assistance, distribute relief commodities, support water and sanitation needs, provide health care, meet seeds and tools needs, and assist unaccompanied children inside Rwanda. In addition, BHR/OFDA is procuring communications equipment for the GOR and assisting UNDHA to collect and disseminate information. USAID/DART has authorized several NGOs to begin implementation of urgent relief programs and expenditures of over $20 million will be finalized by mid-December.

BHR/OFDA Assistance

Grants in process. $20,000,000

Grant to ICRC for assistance to Rwandan refugees and displaced persons in eastern Zaire .$5,000,000

Plastic sheeting, blankets, emergency health kits .698,688

Airlift of relief supplies to Rwanda for UNICEF . $90,000

BHR/OTI Assistance

BHR's Office of Transition Initiatives (BHR/OTI) has provided a total of $375,000 to the Women in Transition project and to fund visits by local reporters to the Tribunal in Arusha. BHR/OTI also funded experts to travel to Rwanda to conduct an evaluation on the genocide trials.

BHR/OTI Assistance . $408,000

GREAT LAKES REGION: USG FY 1997 Regional Humanitarian Assistance (to date):

BHR/FFP Assistance

In FY 1997, BHR's Office of Food for Peace (BHR/FFP) has committed 96,000 MT of P.L. 480 emergency Title II commodities for WFP. These commodities, valued at $72,500,000, will assist refugees and displaced persons in Rwanda, Zaire, Burundi, and Tanzania.

BHR/FFP Assistance .$72,500,00


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
