December 12, 1996


Ghana;
President Rawlings Re-Elected For Second-Term


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ghana's incumbent president, Jerry Rawlings, has won a second-term of office following his National Democratic Congress (NDC) victory in Saturday's elections.

With results from 197 constituencies, out of 200, so far declared, Rawlings has won 4,024,253 votes or 57.2 per cent, while John Agyekum Kufuor of the New Patriotic Party (NPP) has 2,805,498 votes or 39.9 per cent. 

Dr Edward Mahama of the Peoples National Convention has 210,026 votes or 3. 0 per cent.

In the parliamentary race, results from 195 constituencies have been confirmed. NDC has 130 seats, NPP 59 seats and PNC one seat. Voter turn out was 76.8 percent.

Speaking at a news conference Wednesday, Dr Kwadwo Afari-Gyan, the electoral commissioner, said results from three constituencies - North Dayi, South Dayi in the Volta Region and Ajumako-Enyan-Essiam in the Central region - are yet to be certified.

Meanwhile, the British prime minister, John Major, has sent a message to Rawlings congratulating him on his re-election. Major said the United Kingdom looks forward to expanding relations with Ghana.

The message, delivered by the British high commissioner, Ian Mackley, said the peaceful and transparent conduct of the elections "is tribute to the commitment which the people of Ghana have shown to the development of democracy."

"Britain greatly values its long, warm relations with Ghana and we warmly welcome Ghana's progress under democratic rule," Major said.

Africa News


December 12, 1996


Southern Africa;
Zaire, Zambia, Zimbabwe Sign Power Contract


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zimbabwe is to import a total of 250 megawatts of electricity from Zaire and Zambia under a tripartite power export contract signed in Lusaka on Wednesday.

Under the contract, the Zambia Electrity Supply Corporation (ZESCO) is expected to earn about 1.3 million U.S dollars each month. 

The power trading agreement was signed by senior officials from the Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA), Zaire's Societe National d'Electricite (SNELl) and the hosts, ZESCO.

In a statement, ZESCO's Chief Executive Robinson Mwansa, who signed for Zambia, said the agreement was made under Southern African Development Community Power Pool (SAPP).

Under short-term contracts, ZESCO would export 100 megawatts of electricity to Zimbabwe while SNELl would channel 150 megawatts to Harare using the Zambian network.

"The three utilities bring to SAPP their electrity trading experience and have taken a lead in implementing the SAPP agreements thereby bringing enormous savings to the customers in the region," Mwansa was quoted in the statement as saying.

He said the power export agreement would last until Zimbabwe is able to obtain power from Cahora Bassa hydro-electric dam in neighbouring Mozambique.

The agreement was signed by the ZESA executive, Simbalashe Mangwengwende while Vika Dipanzu did so for SNEL.

LANGUAGE: English

262 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 12, 1996


Sierra Leone;
DOCUMENT) Amnesty Says Sierra Leone Violence Persists Despite Peace Pact


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

London - Less than a week after a peace agreement was signed by the Government of Sierra Leone and the armed opposition Revolutionary United Front (RUF) to end a bloody internal conflict, more than 150 civilians have been brutally mutilated and killed in the north of the country, Amnesty International said today.

"There should be an immediate monitoring of human rights in Sierra Leone as only then there may be some hope of bringing such atrocities to an end," the organization said.

Amnesty International is calling for a human rights verification commission, with the support and participation of the international community, to be immediately established. It should include international human rights observers with the expertise and credibility necessary to monitor human rights effectively while the peace agreement is being implemented. 

Failure to do this could seriously undermine the efforts which have been made during 1996 to bring peace and an end to human rights violations in Sierra Leone and which resulted in the signing of a peace accord on 30 November.

Days after the peace accord was signed, the villages of Kubehuna and Magbenka, in Tonkolili District, Northern Province, were attacked by armed men. The villagers, forced to flee their villages because of the conflict, had begun to return to their homes. According to eye-witnesses, the attackers entered the villages and began firing at civilians or attacking them with machetes. Some villagers -- mostly women and children -- died after being forced to enter a house which was then set alight. Other victims had arms and legs cut off. As in previous similar killings, the identity of the perpetrators of the atrocities in Kubehuna and Magbenka was unclear: survivors were unable to say whether it was government soldiers or rebel forces who attacked them.

This latest atrocity is consistent with the torture, ill-treatment and killings of unarmed civilians which have characterized the conflict in Sierra Leone since it began in 1991, but particularly since 1994 when it developed into a campaign of violence directed against civilians. The identity and motives of those carrying out attacks on civilians became increasingly difficult to establish.

On 30 November the Sierra Leone Government and the RUF signed a peace agreement in Cote d'Ivoire. The agreement called for the immediate cessation of hostilities, the demobilization and disarmament of the RUF and its integration into the national army. A neutral monitoring group, with the participation of the international community, is to be established to monitor breaches of the cease-fire provided by the peace agreement.

The latest atrocity in Tonkolili District emphasizes the urgent need for monitoring of the cease-fire to be accompanied by a human rights verification commission to monitor adherence to the human rights standards referred to in the peace agreement, including those guaranteeing right to life and the right not to be tortured and ill-treated.

In September 1996 Amnesty International published a report, Sierra Leone: Towards a future founded on human rights, which made concrete recommendations to the Government of Sierra Leone, to the RUF and to the international community to build on commitments to respect human rights. As well as effective monitoring of human rights, it called for effective control to be exerted over both government soldiers and RUF forces.

Amnesty International also stressed the importance of clarifying the truth about human rights abuses -- by both government soldiers and rebel forces -- during the conflict. True reconciliation cannot be achieved if the right of victims and their families to truth and justice are ignored.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


263 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 12, 1996


Zaire;
Archbishop Issues SOS for Kisangani


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Kisangani - In my capacity of Archbishop of Kisangani, Zaire I desperately launch an appeal to the powers of this world and to political decision makers to assist the population of Kisangani, Upper Zaire, and of Maniema, as well as the hundreds of thousands of refugees and displaced people wandering in North and South Kivu.

For over a month, the great powers and political decision makers, on whom the fate of all humanity depends, have been unable to make up their minds. With the reinforcement of the media, the United Nations adopted a resolution to send to Eastern Zaire a multinational military force, with a humanitarian mission to include providing security for aid corridors and organizations charged with the distribution of food and medicine. Only a portion of the refugees have returned to Rwanda; however, to believe public opinion (and contrary to the simplest calculations) the 

mission decided upon by the UN has become useless!

This evasion and hesitation have led to the inevitable flux of refugees, displaced people, and panic-stricken populations towards Kisangani or deeper within the forest, which will only create further insecurity in the region. To our great surprise, no one speaks of these refugees and displaced people anymore. However, think of the misery and distress, the desolation and death among these people, among whom only the strongest can continue their journey! Beyond any doubt, these hesitations constitute an imminent danger for the several million inhabitants of Kisangani and neighboring dioceses, whose numbers will soon be increased by the arrival of those displaced.

Furthermore, with the fall of Butembo-Beni and the sacking of Bunia, both sources of food for Kisangani, and with the sharp reduction in river traffic towards Upper Zaire, this city is in danger of a famine of unimaginable magnitude.

Thus, acting as the voice of the voiceless, I appeal to the decision makers of the world and in Zaire to resolve to bring aid to Kisangani and all victimized regions of Zaire, by urgently sending food an medicine, whose transport and distribution should be secured in an efficient manner. Persuade that you are affected by the same sentiments, I ask you to accept this expression of my distinguished consideration.

-- L. Monsengwo Pasinya, Archbishop of Kisangani, 9 December 1996

Translated from French by African Faith and Justice Network. AFJN asks that you write, fax, phone or e-mail President Clinton and relay this message of Archbishop Monsengwo. President Bill Clinton, The White House, Washington DC 20500. Tel. 202 456 1111 Fax 202 456 2461 email: president@whitehouse.gov


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


264 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 12, 1996


Zaire;
WFP Eastern Zaire Situation Report No. 35


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Rome - EASTERN ZAIRE: A joint UN/NGO/Government of Zaire mission visited the Shabunda/Kindu area, some 175 km west of Bukavu, and flew at low altitude around the Lubutu/Walikale/Bukavu area. The mission found approximately 10, 000 Rwandan and Burundian refugees in the town of Shabunda and up to 40,000 in two camps around Shabunda. An additional 20,000 to 30,000 refugees were reported in Walikale and 10,000 to 15,000 refugees in Lubutu. WFP is presently studying the possibility of putting a team together to assess the needs of the population around Shabunda and attempt to distribute needed food commodities. Access to this area is very insecure and may require assistance.

The northern axis from Goma continues to be closed to all international humanitarian workers. Access to the western and southern routes as far as Kalungu (some 50 km west of Goma) is permitted. Assessment missions as far as Kitchungu, half-way between Sake and Masisi, have been undertaken by the UN, however the terrain and pockets of resistance are unknown and thus deemed unsafe for further travel. 

Since 26 November, WFP has distributed approximately 27 metric tons of mostly high-protein biscuits, as well as some pulses and maize, to over 25, 000 returnees on their way back to Rwanda, as well as to Zaireans requiring assistance near or in Goma town. WFP is currently distributing biscuits at way stations on the western and northern axis. Field assistants, driving in the area to assess needs, also carry small quantities of biscuits that can be distributed to vulnerable groups as needed. The ration distributed is 500 grams of high-protein biscuits, representing 2,290 kcal/person.

The food supply situation in Goma is limited with a reduction in the number of trucks arriving to the town leading to a price increase of 66 per cent for imported goods. Vegetables and fruits have also witnessed a sharp rise in price by some 150 per cent. This is mainly caused by food production areas in the high lands being inaccessible due to insecurity. The ongoing fighting forced most of the population to flee to other areas leaving their farms, which for the most part were destroyed and looted during their retreat. Also with the repatriation of refugees, the cost of labour has escalated. WFP is studying the food requirement situation in the region with particular emphasis on food security and the means to reestablish the previous supply network.

TANZANIA: It has been reported that 10,000 to 13,000 refugees, who wish to return to Rwanda as a group from the Ngara camps, have asked UNHCR for transportation for children and other vulnerable groups. This group plans to return in the next few days.

Some 1,900 and 800 refugees repatriated from Ngara respectively on 10 and 9 of December. These refugees were provided with transportation for their return.

Reports continue to be received that refugees in Tanzania are preparing to leave. Markets in and around the camps have seen a dramatic drop in the price of clothing, as people sell their belongings. It has also been noted that food prices have remained stable, implying that returnees may be planning to bring their food stocks, from the recent distribution, with them to Rwanda.

Consultations between the Governments of Tanzania and Rwanda, and UNHCR are being planned in Ngara on 12 December, concerning the repatriation of refugees to Rwanda from Tanzania. Other UN agencies, including WFP, and NGOs will also likely take part in the consultations.

RWANDA: Since 15 November, WFP and NGO partners (CARE, CRS, LWF, World Vision, Concern, CRR, IFRC, Trocaire, Caritas, ADRA, MEC, GAA, AHA, World Relief, AEF, EEF, IRC, MSF, ASS, Salvation Army, Ingabo) have distributed approximately 9,457 mt of food commodities (cereals, pulses and oil), representing 566,287 persons assisted with a monthly ration. In addition, 1, 256,600 daily high-protein biscuit rations have been distributed.

WFP stocks in Rwanda for the returnee programme are currently at 3,964 mt (2,886 mt cereals, 735 mt pulses, 209 mt vegetable oil and 134 mt of salt). In Kibungo prefecture, where stocks are currently being built up in preparation for a possible inflow of returnees from Tanzania, stocks stand at 259 mt in the warehouse and 552 mt prepositioned in the communes. The process is ongoing and within one to two days WFP will have prepositioned enough food in that prefecture for the possible return of 340,000 persons.

UN agencies and NGOs met with the Prefet of Kibungo to finalise preparations for the possible return of refugees from Tanzania. In the event of a mass return, way stations will be used. Three NGOs, IFRC, RRC (Rwandan Red Cross) and World Vision, will be responsible for the way stations.

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION, PLEASE CONTACT WFP EASTERN ZAIRE CRISIS SUPPORT FACILITY (CSF): International Fax Line: 39 6 5228-2828 International Telephone Line: 39 6 5228-2535 Electronic Mail Address: ezaire@wfp.org

WFP HAS A GREAT LAKES EMERGENCY SITE ON THE INTERNET WITH LATEST REPORTS AND MAPS. THE ADDRESS OF WFP IS: http://www.wfp.org


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


265 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 12, 1996


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 55 on the Great Lakes (12/12)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Nairobi - Some 35,000 refugees in Tanzania's Ngara region have left Kitali camp, but instead of returning to Rwanda as expected, they went further into Tanzania, WFP said. At a crossroads, where they could have headed for Rwanda, they turned instead towards Isaka in north-central Tanzania.

Further north in Karagwe, 7,000-8,000 refugees are reported to have left the camps to establish unofficial settlements. WFP said they had been told they would not receive aid as long as they were outside the system, but they replied that they did not care. The refugees have said they will not return to the camps, nor to Rwanda. Yesterday, UNHCR said some 23,000 refugees had fled the Karagwe camps away from the Rwandan border following a campaign of intimidation by Hutu extremists. Some are reported to have returned to the camps.

Requests for repatriation to Rwanda by refugees in Tanzania's camps have dropped off substantially, according to a report yesterday from the DHA Information Centre in Kigali. The only request of importance came from up to 13,000 Muslims in the Ngara camps who want to return on Saturday. In Lumasi camp, 445 refugees who had registered to return, reportedly changed their minds and rumours are said to be circulating throughout the camps that the repatriation has been called off. 

Relief agencies have launched aid airlifts to help stranded refugees in eastern Zaire, ICRC announced. AFP reported that an ICRC C-130 Hercules plane flew from Nairobi yesterday with aid for the Shabunda region, where groups of some 100,000 refugees have been spotted, and another flight left today, ICRC said. An ICRC spokesman, quoted by AFP, said shipments - comprising mostly high energy biscuits, medical supplies, plastic sheeting and blankets - were flown to Kindu, and will be tranported on to Shabunda using smaller planes.

The Archbishop of Kisangani, Monsengwo Pasinya, has appealed to world leaders not to forget the plight of hundreds of thousands of displaced people and refugees wandering around in eastern Zaire, and warned that Kisangani was consequently facing "imminent danger". He pointed out that only a portion of the refugees had returned to Rwanda, and the "evasion and hesitation" shown by the world community had resulted in a flow of "panic-stricken" people towards Kisangani or deeper into the forests. "No-one speaks of these refugees and displaced people anymore," he said. "Beyond any doubt, these hesitations constitute an imminent danger for the several million inhabitants of Kisangani and neighbouring dioceses, whose numbers will soon be increased by the arrival of those displaced. Furthermore with the fall of Butembo-Beni, and the sacking of Bunia, both sources of food for Kisangani, and with the sharp reduction in river traffic towards Upper Zaire, this city is in danger of a famine of unimaginable magnitude." Acting as the "voice of the voiceless" , he appealed for urgent aid to the city.

Bunia still appeared to be in government hands yesterday, after local Radio Candip which broadcasts from the town, transmitted new stories in line with the authorities' stand. The radio, monitored by the BBC, broadcast news of Mobutu's imminent return and remarks by the justice minister on improving the human rights situation in the country.

Zaire said yesterday it was not aware of any negotiations to bring in mercenaries to fight alongside its army, but it did not rule out seeking military help from allies to regain rebel-captured territory. "If we are obliged to work with even the devil himself we will do so in order to win back Zaire's territorial integrity," Information Minister Boguo Makele told Reuters. He added however that the time for such military help had not yet arrived.

Heavy fighting again broke out on the Uganda-Zaire border yesterday, the Ugandan 'New Vision' newspaper reported today. It said some 1,000 Ugandan soldiers battled about 500 rebels from the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) in the Ruwenzori mountains which straddle the border. At least 16 rebels were reported killed in the operation which was aimed at dislodging them from their mountain hideout.

In Burundi, two main Tutsi parties have rejected mediation in the country's ethnic conflict by former Tanzanian president Julius Nyerere and both refused to take part in peace talks, due to open in Arusha today. The main opposition party, Uprona, accused Nyerere of bias and slammed the continued regional economic embargo against Burundi. "Given the situation created by the measure, as illegal as it is unjust, of imposing a total blockade against Burundi... and the biased attitude (of Nyerere) regarding terrorist and genocidal organisations...it is no longer open to us to accept his invitations," said a letter from Uprona president Charles Mukasi. The leader of the Tutsi- dominated Rally for Democracy and and Economic and Social Development (RADDES) , Joseph Nzeyimana, also turned down the invitation. To date, it was not known exactly who would attend the talks. A spokesman for Burundian leader Pierre Buyoya, speaking on BBC radio, said the government would participate in the talks but would not negotiate with "killers" or those espousing a " genocidal philosophy". These groups must first renounce killings, and then the government would talk to them, he said.

More than 1,000 people were massacred in Burundi in one month between late October and late November, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Jose Ayala Lasso said yesterday. According to Ayalo Lasso, most of the victims were killed by soldiers. "The human rights situation in November can be described as alarming with its wave of massacres, arbitrary arrests, looting and destruction of property," he said in a monthly report, quoted by AFP. The report said killings were mostly carried out by the army but Hutu rebels were also responsible. The return of tens of thousands of Hutu refugees from Zaire was partly to blame for the increase in tension, the report stated. Particularly volatile areas were said to be the provinces of Kayanza, Bururi, Cibitoke, Gitega, Ruyigi and Bujumbura-Rurale. A government spokesman said on the BBC that the authorities were investigating reports of massacres but had found nothing to substantiate the accusations.

The judicial system in Rwanda remains heavily overloaded, with only 20 defence lawyers for some seven million inhabitants and increasingly overcrowded prisons, a report by the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights said yesterday. UN observers recorded 82,200 prisoners in the country's 192 detention centres, with 23,200 new detainees in the period January-November. Among them are 3,000 women and over 2,000 adolescents.

Meanwhile, a senior Rwandan army officer appeared before a military court in Kigali yesterday accused of allowing the massacre of displaced people at Kibeho camp in southwest Rwanda in April 1995. Rwandan radio said the trial of Lt.Col Fred Ibingira was adjourned until next Thursday after the defendant and his lawyer rqeuested more time to prepare his defence. An AFP report said Ibingira is accused of not taking the necessary decisions to stop the killings and save the displaced people under his protection. The massacre occurred after RPA troops moved into the camp to close it down.

Nairobi, December 12 1996, 11:25 gmt (ENDS)

Africa News


December 12, 1996


East Africa;
WFP Eastern Zaire Situation Report No. 36


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Rome - TANZANIA: With the assistance of the multi-national force led by Canada, WFP plans to airlift some 100 metric tons of corn-soya blend for camps in the Kibondo district of Kigoma region starting tomorrow. This airlift is to target a highly nutritious food commodity to mostly newly arrived Burundian refugees who are in poor condition.

646 refugees repatriated to Rwanda on 11 December, which is approximately one-third of the total repatriated on 10 December. Reports of negative propaganda are reported to be hindering the process of repatriation. 

RWANDA: On 11 December WFP and NGO partners (CARE, CRS, LWF, World Vision, Concern, CRR, IFRC, Trocaire, Caritas, ADRA, MEC, GAA, AHA, World Relief, AEF, EEF, IRC, MSF, ASS, Salvation Army, Ingabo) distributed approximately 287 mt of food (cereals, pulses and oil), representing 17,185 people assisted with a monthly ration. The cumulative total distributed now stands at 9,743 mt, representing 583,413 persons assisted with a monthly ration.

WFP stocks in Rwanda for the returnee programme are currently at 3,937 mt (2,734 mt cereals, 845 mt pulses, 178 mt vegetable oil and 180 mt salt). In Kibungo prefecture, where stocks are currently being built up in preparation for a possible inflow of returnees from Tanzania, stocks stand at 219 mt in the warehouse and 616 mt prepositioned in the communes. WFP continues to preposition enough food in communes of Kibungo for the possible return of 340, 000 persons.

To increase needed storage space in Rwanda, a storage tent of 500 mt capacity is being transferred from Goma to Kigali. WFP continues to expand the storage capacity at the commune level.

Over the next week WFP Byumba sub-office staff will visit all communes to meet with NGOs, local leaders, beneficiaries and women's groups to identify food-for-work projects. The projects will target returnees as well as local vulnerable populations.

EASTERN ZAIRE: WFP Goma was interviewed on the Voice of America this morning. The broadcast was translated into Kyniarwanda and French. WFP reported that more than 600,000 refugees had already returned to Rwanda and encouraged those refugees remaining in Eastern Zaire to return. WFP also announced that it had sufficient food commodities available for their return.

On the 10 and 11 of December, a total of approximately 2,500 refugees crossed the border from Goma to Gisenyi. The returnees came partly through the Virunga forest and partly from the Minova/Numbi direction. Some 400 refugees were reported to have returned through the Bukavu/Cyangugu border point yesterday.

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION, PLEASE CONTACT WFP EASTERN ZAIRE CRISIS SUPPORT FACILITY (CSF): International Fax Line: 39 6 5228-2828 International Telephone Line: 39 6 5228-2535 Electronic Mail Address: ezaire@wfp.org

WFP HAS A GREAT LAKES EMERGENCY SITE ON THE INTERNET WITH LATEST REPORTS AND MAPS. THE ADDRESS OF WFP IS: http://www.wfp.org

Africa News


December 12, 1996


Zambia;
Northern Zambia Road Washed Away


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - THE Old Mkushi-Masansa feeder road is said to have been washed away by the recent heavy rains which hit Zambia since the middle of last month.

Kamimbya Ward Councillor, Everest Mutolwa, confirmed the washing away of the road adding that about 60 kilometres of the road has become impassable as the road is full of water where previously there were potholes. 

The washing away of the road has stopped vehicles from reaching Chief Kanyeshya's area.

Councillor Mutolwa said an appeal for help has already been sent to government and he was hopeful that the National Roads Board will soon have the road rehabilitated.

He said people of the area were hoping that a bridge will be built on Lunsenfwa river at a place where a pontoon is now operating in order to lighten communication between Old Mkushi and Kabwe through Kampumba road.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

268 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 12, 1996


Business and Finance;
Retail Chain Goes South


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Livingstone - SHOPRITE CHECKERS, the South African retail chain, today opened their seventh shop in Livingstone and it was quickly filled with christmas shoppers out to get a bargain early.

Most of the shoppers talked to, as they jostled around the shop, said it was the nicest thing that had happened in their city over a long, long time adding that they had expected the new shop to have opened its doors to the shopping public earlier than today. 

Many were just happy to mill around looking at the shelves neatly packed with reasonably priced consumer goods from Zambia and other parts of the world.

"The prices appear to be reasonable and the shop is quite well stocked and neatly stacked on the shelves," an old man visiting the shop in the company of his son remarked.

Company General Manager, Mauritz Alberts in an interview said the shop had opened with an initial capital of R1.8 million (about K509,400,000) and it took four weeks to prepare well for the opening sales.

The new shop has employed 76 Zambians including the branch manager, George Mweemba.

Mr Alberts said Shoprite Checkers aims to keep reasonable prices and good stocks backed up by an efficient service adding that the retail chain has already offered contracts to Zambian farmers and other suppliers for food stuffs and general merchandise.

This is the seventh Shoprite Checkers shop in Zambia after the ones opened in Lusaka, Kabwe, Kitwe, Ndola, Mufulira and Chingola.

Some Livingstone residents, however, complained that most of the 76 workers had come from the Copperbelt instead of from among the local people.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


269 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 12, 1996


Business and Finance;
Treasury Bills Order Justified In Zambia


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - The Bankers Association chairman, Bill Erwin, yesterday assured non-bank investors in treasury bills that the new Bank of Zambia regulations do not affect them in any way and they would continue to be catered for under the commercial banks.

Bank of Zambia on December 5, announced that with effect from Tuesday, December 3, it would transfer the retail trading in treasury bills and bonds to the commercial banks.

"Therefore, only commercial banks will participate in the primary dealings with Bank of Zambia and in turn the banks will deal with the public and other institutions at the secondary level. The off-tender treasury bill window will cease to operate and the rediscount facility offered to non-banks will be discontinued. The commercial banks will, however, offer these facilities to the non-bank investors," read the Bank of Zambia statement in part. 

Erwin said the change in regulations had nothing to do with commercial banks' own participation in the treasury bill auction.

"Up until now companies and individuals could deal directly with Bank of Zambia if they wished to purchase treasury bills. This is unusual as most central banks do not deal with the public. Under the new rules these have to deal with a commercial bank who will consolidate orders on behalf of their clients," he said.

And in a report presented on Tuesday, the Zambia Coalition on Debt and Development (ZCDD) held commercial banks partly responsible for the near stagnation of the Zambian economy.

"The heavy involvement of commercial banks in treasury bills has reduced their traditional role of financial intermediates. They have opted to maximise their profit earnings by holding government debt. The high interest rates and the free risk nature of this type of debt makes it extremely attractive. Commercial banks would therefore be unwilling to lend to businesses which comparatively are more risky than the treasury bills. The effect is a slow down in the growth of the economy," said the report.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

December 12, 1996


Business and Finance;
Japanese Donate To Zambian Aquaculture Station


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia received US$4.7 million (about K5.9 billion) project aid from the government of Japan yesterday for the upgrading of Mwekera Aquaculture station.

The Japanese government, in a press statement released by its embassy in Lusaka yesterday, said the Mwekera Aquaculture station's drainage network, water supply system, and other facilities had deteriorated and proved to be a handicap to the institution. 

Mwekera station, established in the 1930s, is the core institution among the country's aqua culture stations (Fish farming institutions).

Its main activities are seed production of tilapia fish, common carp and the distribution of some other species as well as sale of seeds to other aqua- culture stations and fish farmers.

"The objective of this project is to repair and improve the station's facilities in order to enable the Mwekera Aquaculture station to fulfill its desired functions," stated the press release.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


271 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 12, 1996


Business and Finance;
Government Urged To Be Transparent With Zambia's Debt


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Coalition on Debt and Development (ZCDD) has called for transparency in Zambia's debt situation.

Presenting a report on Zambia's debt situation at an Economics Association of Zambia (EAZ) meeting on Tuesday, David Musona, Suya Chidumayo and Gertrude Ngenda who had been working with the African Forum and Network on Debt and Development (AFRODAD), said that the country's debt problem has been chronic for many years now and requires a solution both in the short and long term.

Their report reveals that Zambia's total external debt stock in 1970, at US$654 million, had increased to US$6,543 million, by December 1994. 

This represented 240 per cent of Gross National Product(GNP) and the scheduled debt service was 51 per cent of foreign exchange earnings.

The report stated that Zambia's foreign exchange earnings have remained at an average of $1,200 million per year since 1970.

"Another important feature of Zambia's debt problem is that more than 95 per cent of the loans are held by government. This has raised the fiscal burden of debt, that is, the pressure of debt repayment on the government budget," said the report.

Recommending possible solutions to the debt burden, the report urged that Zambia and other African countries in the same predicament should take a common approach in negotiations with multilateral lending institutions instead of their current individual stances which had only served to weaken their positions further.

The report also advised that Parliament should begin to play a more active role in approving loans and monitoring Zambia's debt situation.

"It is our belief that loan resources should be properly apportioned to the service and productive sectors. Borrowing for the social sector in the absence of a growing productive sector is irresponsible," said the report. " We recommend that the Zambian Government be more transparent regarding negotiations on Debt relief by providing information beyond the published annual reports."


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


272 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 12, 1996


Burundi;
Burundi Team Leaves For Talks in Tanzania


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - A Burundi government delegation left Bujumbura Thursday for Arusha, Tanzania, accompanied by representatives of three minor parties that backed the coalition of Hutu President Sylivestre Ntibantunganya, overthrown in the July 25 military putsch.

Informed sources at Bujumbura airport said the government team consisted of Foreign and Cooperation Minister Luc Lukingama, Planning Minister Minani Evariste, Minister of State for Cooperation Havyarimana Leonidas, as well as advisers from the president's and prime minister's offices.

The delegation will take part in a session aimed at ending the ethnic crisis that has bedevilled Burundi since October 1993. 

Airport sources said, however, that representatives of the Hutu-dominated majority party, the Burundi Democratic Front (FRODEBU) were prevented from boarding the plane that would have flown them to Arusha.

Contacted by telephone, the FRODEBU spokesman, Bavuginyumvira Frederic, told PANA in Bujumbura that the border police had prevented him and the party's secretary general, Nzojibwami Augustin as well as the speaker of the national assembly from taking the flight to Arusha " on orders from the attorney general."

Bavuginyumvira said he was not aware of the motive behind the police action "which deprives a big portion of the population the opportunity of being represented at the Arusha negotiations upon which they had placed a lot of hope."

FRODEBU backs the embargo that has been imposed by neighbouring eastern and central African states to force Burindi's military regime to return the country to constitutional rule.

The two FRODEBU leaders prevented from going to Arusha forthrightly back the sanctions, which have already cost Burundi some 200 million US dollars, according to latest government figures.

The Tutsi-dominated opposition parties have also not sent any representatives to the Arusha intra-Burundi talks. These had said in advance that they did not believe the mediator, former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere, was neutral. They have demanded the appointment of a new "arbitrator. "

Speaking before his departure for Arusha, Rukingama told journalists that " we shall not start negotiations because our pre-condition is the lifting of economic sanctions."

Burundi is confronted with an armed rebellion by guerillas from the majority Hutu ethnic group, which is fighting the Tutsi military government that took power last July.

A total of 150,000 people have been killed in the conflict between the two ethnic groups since the first democratically-elected President Melchior Ndadaye was assassinated by Tutsi soldiers on Oct. 21, 1993.

Latest figures issued by humanitarian organisations indicated that more than 1000 people were assassinated in November.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December 12, 1996


Rwanda;
Rwandan Army Officer To Reappear Before Court Marshall


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

KIGALI, Rwanda (PANA) - A Rwandan army officer, accused of failing to prevent the massacre of Hutu refugees at Kibeho, south-western Rwanda, in April 1995, will re-appear before a court marshall next week.

Lt. Col. Fred Bingira, who appeared before the court Wednesday, has been charged for not preventing the killing of 300 people in the said camp, which his battalion had been sent to cordon off. 

The court said the officer did nothing to protect the victims and authorised the use of weapons by his troops against them.

Under the guidance of his lawyer, Sgt. Kayijuka Gabo, the accused requested for more time to prepare his defence because the summon to appear before the court had reached him late. He was given eight days to prepare his defence.

The court, chaired by Lt. Col. Munyakazi, includes five majors and a second lieutenant. It reconvenes Dec. 19.

Africa News


December 12, 1996


Sudan;
Sudan Belittles Impact Of Mahdi's Escape


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan's President Omar Bashir has belittled the recent escape of former Prime Minister Sadik el-Mahdi to neighbouring Eritrea, saying it will not threaten his government nor affect its islamic orientation.

Mahdi's escape and his joining the opposition "will not scare us nor will it obstruct the advance of our Islamic cultural orientation," the Sudan News Agency (SUNA) quoted Bashir as saying. 

He was addressing a graduation ceremony Wednesday for 7,500 university students who have completed military training at the popular defence forces camps in Khartoum.

Mahdi, who was ousted by Gen. Bashir in a bloodless coup in 1989, escaped to Eritrea where an armed Sudanese opposition group has recently been active. He has reportedly joined hands with John Garang's Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) to fight for the downfall of the Bashir regime.

The Sudanese ministry of the interior on Wednesday confirmed that Mahdi had disappeared from his home since Monday.

Prime minister from 1986-1989, he had decided to stay in Sudan since the coup and did not join the opposition in exile in Cairo, London or Asmara. He has often shrugged off violent means as a way of removing the government, saying he preferred "civil struggle."


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December 12, 1996


Ghana;
President Rawlings Re-Elected For Second-Term


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ghana's incumbent president, Jerry Rawlings, has won a second-term of office following his National Democratic Congress (NDC) victory in Saturday's elections.

With results from 197 constituencies, out of 200, so far declared, Rawlings has won 4,024,253 votes or 57.2 per cent, while John Agyekum Kufuor of the New Patriotic Party (NPP) has 2,805,498 votes or 39.9 per cent. 

Dr Edward Mahama of the Peoples National Convention has 210,026 votes or 3. 0 per cent.

In the parliamentary race, results from 195 constituencies have been confirmed. NDC has 130 seats, NPP 59 seats and PNC one seat. Voter turn out was 76.8 percent.

Speaking at a news conference Wednesday, Dr Kwadwo Afari-Gyan, the electoral commissioner, said results from three constituencies - North Dayi, South Dayi in the Volta Region and Ajumako-Enyan-Essiam in the Central region - are yet to be certified.

Meanwhile, the British prime minister, John Major, has sent a message to Rawlings congratulating him on his re-election. Major said the United Kingdom looks forward to expanding relations with Ghana.

The message, delivered by the British high commissioner, Ian Mackley, said the peaceful and transparent conduct of the elections "is tribute to the commitment which the people of Ghana have shown to the development of democracy."

"Britain greatly values its long, warm relations with Ghana and we warmly welcome Ghana's progress under democratic rule," Major said.

Africa News


December 12, 1996


Southern Africa;
Zaire, Zambia, Zimbabwe Sign Power Contract


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zimbabwe is to import a total of 250 megawatts of electricity from Zaire and Zambia under a tripartite power export contract signed in Lusaka on Wednesday.

Under the contract, the Zambia Electrity Supply Corporation (ZESCO) is expected to earn about 1.3 million U.S dollars each month. 

The power trading agreement was signed by senior officials from the Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA), Zaire's Societe National d'Electricite (SNELl) and the hosts, ZESCO.

In a statement, ZESCO's Chief Executive Robinson Mwansa, who signed for Zambia, said the agreement was made under Southern African Development Community Power Pool (SAPP).

Under short-term contracts, ZESCO would export 100 megawatts of electricity to Zimbabwe while SNELl would channel 150 megawatts to Harare using the Zambian network.

"The three utilities bring to SAPP their electrity trading experience and have taken a lead in implementing the SAPP agreements thereby bringing enormous savings to the customers in the region," Mwansa was quoted in the statement as saying.

He said the power export agreement would last until Zimbabwe is able to obtain power from Cahora Bassa hydro-electric dam in neighbouring Mozambique.

The agreement was signed by the ZESA executive, Simbalashe Mangwengwende while Vika Dipanzu did so for SNEL.

LANGUAGE: English

December 13, 1996


Business and Finance;
Shares At Ghana Stock Remain Low


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Total volume of shares traded at the stock market remained low Wednesday despite a slight improvement in the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) All-Share Index.

The GSE All-Share Index went up moderately by 0.28 points to end at 357.23 points. 

Overall offers were 1,248,126 shares as against bids of 162,840 shares at a total volume of 18,260 shares.

On the broader market, the breweries made significant strides being the two gainers as against one decliner.

Kumasi Brewery Limited (KBL) gained 25 cedis to close mid-week trading at 655 cedis while Accra Brewery Limited gained 10 cedis to close at 560 cedis.

Fan Milk Limited was the only loser with two cedis ending at 402 cedis.

Market capitalisation climbed slightly to 2,656.35 billion cedis from Monday's 2,655.94 billion cedis (1,720 cedis= one U.S. dollar).

Following were the last prices of listed equities quoted in cedis: (ST) ABL 560 ' 10 AGC 23,200 ALW 1,415 CFAO 20 EIC 420 FML 402 - 2 GCB 701 GGL 244 HFC 130 KBL 655 ' 25 MGL 140 MLC 50 MOGL 6,000 PAF 170 PTC 130 PZ 370 SCB 4, 900 SPPC 112 SSB 1,050 UNIL 780 UTC-E 50 (ET)


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


278 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


Tanzania;
Corruption Report Handed Over To Mkapa


BYLINE: Yasin Kachechele, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - The trend of corruption in Tanzania partly stems from low wages and inadequate fringe benefits which fail to satisfy workers needs, according to a recent report issued here.

The over 500-page report, handed over to President Benjamin Mkapa, also blames unscrupulous businessmen who have corrupted top officials to win government tenders and favours, especially tax evasion.

Although Mkapa said the report "only gives scientific ways on how to deal with and eradicate corruption," the public and the media have gone further and suggested that measures should be taken against top officials cited in the report as being corrupt. 

According to the report, the majority of Tanzanian public servants are forced to demand bribes in order to make ends meet. This could be corrected by better incomes and wages.

However, it accuses high ranking officials with access to many facilities of resorting to corruption because "they want to accumulate wealth." High ranking officials under the previous government of President Ali Hassan Mwinyi have been named as corrupt.

However, the country's finance minister, Prof.Simon Mbilinyi, was recently forced to resign following an uproar in parliament over reports that he had been bribed to give tax exemptions to local businessmen.

The report, compiled by a team of nine commissioners, headed by former Prime Minister Joseph Sinde Warioba, states that the colonial era laws on corruption, which was adopted in 1958, was full of loopholes. The commission was set up in January 1996 to also review the law, regulations, procedures and the mode of operations in the government and parastatal organisations.

In addition, the report, whose compilation took 11 months, notes that the public institutions set to wipe out corruption, including the judiciary, were corrupt.

"The public, because they need services, are forced to give out bribes but they don't like it," says part of the report, quoted by the Tanzanian News Agency (SHIHATA).

Ministries and departments singled out in the report as being corrupt include those of education, health, home affairs, treasury, judiciary, attorney general's chambers, trade and industry, lands, natural resources, tourism and public works.

The report has not spare the media either, which should, in principle, help in exposing corruption. In two lines, it affirms that the Tanzanian media have been infested with "cheque-book journalists."

"To clamp out corruption, the president has to summon reports of all top officials tarnished by corruption and all top government official should declare their property," the report suggests.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


279 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


Zambia;
Court Acquits Former Zambian Vice-President


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A former Zambian vice-president in Kenneth Kaunda's government, Maiza Chona, on charges of "falsely alarming the public", was acquitted Friday by a Lusaka magistrate because he had "no case to answer".

He was charged after issuing a statement in the supreme court on Nov. 14 that "a bomb had been planted at former President Kaunda's residence in Lusaka." 

Chona had made the statement before a full supreme court bench which was then hearing a petition filed by opposition parties challenging President Frederick Chiluba's citizenship.

The former vice-president, who is a lawyer, claimed that two of the witnesses they intended to call to challenge Chiluba's citizenship had received parcel bombs.

He was summoned to court Tuesday to answer the charges. His lawyers, however, argued that there was no way Chona should be summoned to court when he had not been formally arrested and charged with the offence.

Principal Resident Magistrate Francis Nsokolo said in his ruling that the reasons for issuing the summons to Chona were wrong as well as the procedure that was used by the state in order to secure his attendance of the court.

"I dismiss the charge against the accussed person," he said.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


280 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


Business and Finance;
Poor Nations Poor States Hold Their Own In Trade Talks


BYLINE: Sure Chimbga, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

SINGAPORE, (PANA) - The just-ended World Trade Organisation (WTO) conference in Singapore has delivered a win-win outcome for developing countries which in the past five days resisted Western attempts to link labour standards with trade privileges.

Led by the United States, industrialised member countries of the WTO had demanded that core labour standards be put on the WTO agenda, which would have for the first time put the WTO in direct confrontation with the International Labour Organisation (ILO).

But over 120 speakers who presented speeches at the conference were unanimous that labour issues were not in the realm of the WTO and should instead be discussed within the ILO. 

Zimbabwe and other member countries of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) also took a strong stance against the issue, saying it could cause unnecessary confrontation among member states and cloud the vision of the WTO in its quest to liberalise global trade.

The US and the European Union countries found themselves fighting a losing battle, with developing member countries of the WTO accusing the West of trying to impose their rules on weaker nations.

Speaking at the closing ceremony WTO ministerial conference chairman, Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Yoo Cheow Tong, emphasised that labour issues were best dealt with by the Geneva-based ILO.

He said the ministerial declaration recognised that the ILO was the competent body to set and deal with labour standards.

It rejected the use of labour for protectionist purposes which he said was very important for safeguarding the multilateral trading system, particularly for developing countries.

He said ministers had also agreed that the comparative advantage of low- wage countries "must in no way be put into question (and) does not inscribe the relationship between trade and core labour standards on the WTO agenda."

Cheow emphasised the WTO would not undertake further work on the relationship between trade and labour standards, implying the subject was unlikely to be raised at future WTO meetings.

Meanwhile, the meeting, the first to be held since ministers signed the WTO agreement in Marrakech, Morocco in April 1994, has been hailed by delegates as an important milestone in laying the foundation for future co-operation between the rich and poor countries in removing tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade and investment.

"The conference has provided a strong political message underlining opportunities in the new global economy, while ignoring the challenges that our economies face," the Singapore trade minister said.

"The message this conference has sent is one of confidence in the multilateral trading system as it approaches its 50th anniversary in 1998 and in its ability to promote growth and guarantee stability," he said.

Also expected to benefit from the outcome of the conference would be the so- called least developed countries, which many delegates said were in the danger of being permanently left behind as the rest of the world moved towards global economic integration.

In their declaration, the ministers pledged to provide more technical assistance to ensure that the countries, ranging from Afghanistan to Zambia, successfully implemented Uruguay Round commitments.

Richer countries would explore ways of granting preferential duty-free access for the exports of least developed countries, particularly for clothing and textiles.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


281 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


Business and Finance;
Low Gold Production For Ashanti


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Gold production by the Ashanti Goldfields Company (AGC) at the Obuasi mine fell slightly in the last 12 months ending Sept. 30, 1996, as compared to the same period in 1995, the company said.

In 1995 gold production stood at 932,323 ounces, while that for 1996 dropped to 883,853 ounces. The company had earlier projected that production will hit the one million ounces mark. 

According to Sam E. Jonah, chief executive of AGC, the low gold production reflected the drop in production from the surface mines as well as the treatment of larger tonnages of ore.

"The shift in emphasis from the surface to higher grade underground ore has been initiated and continues to be the focus of the new management," he said in Accra Thursday in an interim report.

He, however, said "1996 has been a milestone year for the company, a year in which it has been transformed from a gold producer with a single mine in Ghana to a group with several operating mines."

The company now has "major development projects and an exploration portfolio that includes land positions on each of the most promising gold mineralisation belts of sub-Saharan Africa," Jonah added.

It moved rapidly in the last six months to add value to the former Cluff properties that were acquired in January, increased exploration and development at Freda-Rebbecca in Zimbabwe leading to a 17 percent increase in reserves and eight percent increase in gold production.

On the company's earnings in 1996, the report shows it earned 70.9 million U.S. dollars representing 33 percent lower than the previous year.

"Earnings were depressed, particularly in the last six months by the high operation costs of the Obuasi mine which is focusing on surface mining operations," it adds.

The next five years will see the company seeking to transform the underground mine into a bulk tonnage and mechanised mining operation that will double ore production to 3.5 million tonnes a year, the report notes.

The company made a profit of 71.4 million dollars as against 105.8 million dollars for 1995.

Ashanti's shares are currently listed on the Australian Stock Exchange which adds up to its existing listings in Accra, Harare, London, New York and Toronto.

Africa News


December 13, 1996


Zambia;
Zambian Parties Asked To Pay 49,000 Dollars For Petition


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian opposition parties have been told that their petition against President Frederick Chiluba's victory in last month's elections can only be heard if they pay the equivalent of 49,000 US dollars.

The pre-condition has been spelled out to the four political parties that lodged their petition in the Zambian Supreme Court on Nov.29, challenging Chiluba's eligibility to stand for the presidency.

The payment demand has been made by the country's solicitor general, Sam Chisulo, as a condition for the petition's hearing. 

The opposition parties want the Supreme Court to probe chiluba's nationality, in accordance with the new constitution, which requires that only citizens whose parents were also born in country qualify to run for the office of president.

The opposition parties charged that Chiluba lied about his nationality when he filed electoral nomination papers last November.

The petitioning parties are the United National Independence Party (UNIP) of former President Kenneth Kaunda, the Liberal Progressive Front, the National Congress and Agenda for Zambia.

State senior counsel, Mainza Chona, who is one of the lawyers for the petitioners confirmed to PANA Friday that he had received a letter from Chisulo informing him about the costs being asked before the hearing takes place.

"The solicitor general is demanding 49 million kwacha from us. I think the fee is wild and exorbitant," Chona said.

The solicitor general's demand has been described as "wild and outrageous" by some political parties.

Liberal Progressive Front chairman, Rodger Chongwe, said that the fee was exorbitant for an appearance in court. He claimed that the objective was to frustrate Zambians so that Chiluba's nomination was not challenged.

"Chisulo should not kill these proceedings by demanding an outrageous sum of money. It is a cheap ploy to kill the petition that no government employee should engage in," Zambia Democratic Congress deputy secretary Azwell Banda charged, adding that the demands were political and unprofessional.

A week before the Nov. 18 polls, the four parties filed a petition asking the court to order postponement of the elections until the question of Chiluba's nationality was resolved.

That petition was dismissed after the court ruled that it was premature and contrary to the provisions of the electoral law, which requires that a petition be filed within 14 days after the new president has been sworn-in.

The four parties then filed a fresh petition after the elections on Nov.29.

Africa-at-Large;
OAU Blames Inaction In Zaire On International Community


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) Friday said Africa was unable to act in the crisis in eastern Zaire due to the failure of the international community to provide it with effective means.

"Africa has had to stand by and watch the unfolding of yet another crisis which at one time threatened to have a possible humanitarian catastrophe," the organisation's secretary general, Salim Ahmed Salim, said. 

He attributed this to "a combination of developments in eastern Zaire itself and the inability of the international community to take speedy and timely action to help stabilize the situation" despite the commitment made by the leaders of the Greater Lakes region.

Salim was opening a seminar on peace-making and peace-keeping for the OAU staff, organized by the New York-based International Peace Academy.

The nine-day seminar, which will provide advance training for senior OAU staff involved in conflict prevention, management and resolution, is co- sponsored by the OAU with the support of the government of Denmark, whose minister for development cooperation is also participating.

Other participants include African and other diplomats and NGOs based in Addis Ababa, and resource persons from various United nations agencies, the International Court of Justice and the Commonwealth.
