Africa News


December 13, 1996


South Africa;
Political Conflict Flares At Thokoza


BYLINE: Stuart Hess, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Johannesburg - EVICTIONS in the East Rand township of Thokoza are being hampered as people evicted earlier this week are returning to the houses.

No action has yet been taken against them, but there is a discernible tension in the township. The police and army are patrolling the area in strength.

Some journalists were stoned on Wednesday but no one was hurt. Inkatha Freedom Party provincial leader Themba Khoza sent out messages on pagers falsely claiming that the police had killed residents and that bodies were lying in the streets. 

Ten of the 16 residents evicted by the police on Wednesday moved back to the houses the next morning. Meanwhile, the Alberton town council is continuing with further evictions in other areas of the township.

IFP leader in Thokoza, Sipho Sithole, demanded that the council immediately stop evicting residents.

The tension in Thokoza is being exacerbated by former African National Congress-aligned Self-Defence Unit (SDU) members who are assisting the town council with the evictions, said an officer from the local police station who refused to be named.

"Some of the men who are evicting people are reservists who belonged to the SDUs," he said.

He said the IFP was unhappy about the reservists evicting residents because "they favoured the ANC". Prior to the general elections in 1994, the SDUs were known to be aligned to the ANC, while the IFP was supported by the Self- Protection Units (SPUs).

IFP members - supported by former SPU members -clashed with police amid the continuing evictions in the township this week. Three people, including IFP youth league leader Thabani Dlamini, were arrested and charged with assault after a group of nearly 200 IFP supporters tried to stop the evictions.

The Alberton Town Council began on November 28 to evict residents staying illegally in houses. According to the council, more than 500 families are to be evicted. "Those people forced the real owners out of their homes and have lived there since 1993," said council representative Themba Maluleka.

"They attacked the legal residents and forced them out of their homes, they should go back to where they came from," he added.

Maluleka said the former residents were presently staying in squatter camps outside the township and plans were in place to return them to their homes.

"About 100 families have already been evicted. We would love to complete the evictions by Christmas, but the current problems we are experiencing means that will probably have to change," said Maluleka.

Negotiations regarding the illegal occupation of homes had been taking place for almost two years, he said. Evictions would definitely continue regardless of the negotiations with the IFP, which were still continuing up to early this week.

People evicted this week said they had no idea why the council was removing them from "their homes". One said: "This is basically a war against the IFP."

"We have stayed here a long time and everything was peaceful, the police are only making people angry and more violence will occur," said Simons Shongwe, who was evicted this week.

He was one of six residents at Dube Street told to vacate their houses. He said he did not know what to do with his belongings which were left in the front garden.

Shongwe said he moved into the house because nobody was living in it at the time: "The house was empty, my family needed a place to stay. Nobody gave us any trouble until the police came here today."

Shongwe wants the government to provide him with another house. He said he would stay with neighbours or possibly build his own shack.

The IFP this week threatened to destabilise the province of Gauteng. "The ANC are using the police to get their revenge on us," said Sithole. "The ANC accused the IFP of working with the police in 1992 and 1993, now they are using the police to enforce their authority".

"They (the ANC) could not get rid of the Zulus in 1993 but now that they are in power they want to assassinate IFP leaders," Sithole said.

The IFP had never denied that people occupied houses illegally, but believed the government's current action was "outrageous".


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


296 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


South Africa;
Clarence Makwetu Won't Go Quietly


BYLINE: Rehana Rossouw, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Johannesburg - ATTEMPTS by Pan Africanist Congress members to ease the departure of its president, Clarence Makwetu, have been stymied by his insistence on contesting his position at the organisation's congress this weekend.

While Makwetu has not been blamed entirely for weaknesses in the PAC, senior members believe his deficient leadership has contributed to the weaknesses of the organisation.

Many had hoped rumours that he would be offered an ambassadorial position by President Nelson Mandela would bear fruit, and that he would leave the organisation in a "dignified manner". 

"But like many African leaders, he probably believes he is a life president and he is refusing to back down gracefully," said a senior PAC member.

At a PAC convention in September, called as a crisis measure to chart a way forward for the organisation, eight criteria were drafted for the election of a new leadership. These include "be dynamic", "be vigilant", "work harmoniously in a collective environment" and "inspire confidence within the PAC constituency". Many PAC members believe Makwetu falls short.

Bishop Stanley Mogoba should be a shoo-in for the position, and the Methodist Church has already appointed the Rev Mvume Dandala as his successor as presiding bishop. Mogoba has retired from the church. Other contenders are PAC deputy president Motsoko Pheko and retired United Nations official Phillip Kgosana.

Mogoba was appointed by the PAC convention in September to initiate a " healing process" to reconcile party members.

Although the convention was not a constituted gathering, its recommendations will be put to the PAC congress this weekend. Among them is a call to retain the ideology of Pan-Africanism by promoting African languages, and entrenching African values in the education system and through black economic empowerment.

The convention resolved that the PAC remain a liberation movement but have departments which reflect Cabinet portfolios. Political education among members should be stepped up and party schools established to train both rank- and-file and senior leaders about PAC policy.

* This weekend's congress is being held at the University of Venda in Thohoyandou.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


297 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


South Africa;
'Courts Bail Out On Violence'


BYLINE: Ann Eveleth, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Johannesburg - INKATHA Freedom Party leader Biva Nkwenyana appeared in court last month in connection with three separate murder cases - including one allegedly committed after his first court appearance - but he is still out on bail.

Nkwenyana's alleged accomplice in one of the murders, Vusi Zwane, was also released on bail but was re-arrested last week after injuring himself during an alleged armed robbery attempt.

Nkwenyana and Zwane are two of dozens of violence suspects released on bail in KwaZulu-Natal every year. Their cases, however, demonstrate the gaps in the province's criminal justice system which allow political violence to continue. 

Nkwenyana received bail for the first time early last month after a KwaMsane magistrate recused himself from the case and it was referred to Empangeni.

Nkwenyana is the IFP representative on the KwaMsane Community Policing Forum and crowds of his supporters arrived at court for his bail hearing, Natal Violence Monitor Mary de Haas said this week.

He was released on R3 000 bail in his first case, only to be rearrested at the court in connection with a separate case, for which the same magistrate immediately granted bail. A week later Nkwenyana was granted bail for a murder allegedly committed while he was out on bail for the first two cases.

Nkwenyana's lawyer announced in court that police members would be called to give evidence in support of his bail application. This allegedly included the KwaMsane police station commander Captain Dlamini, whose name appeared in the Transitional Executive Council report on hit squads in 1994, De Haas said.

These releases were authorised despite investigating officers and witnesses having testified about Nkwen-yana's danger to the community. "The lives of witnesses, their families and properties have been placed in great danger," said De Haas.

"All of this happened despite strong arguments against bail by (North Coast investigator Captain Mandlenkosi) Vilikazi.

"The magistrate says the case against them is not very strong, but at this stage if you are pursuing charges against them and they are a potential threat to the community, there is certainly enough reason to hold them."

De Haas said she had recently received information that potential witnesses in the cases could be targeted, and Nkwenyana has allegedly organised a march against a local trader believed to have played a role in his arrest.

De Haas recounted the case in response to queries about rising tensions in the province in the run-up to the Christmas holidays. "There is no sense sending out extra people once a year if you are not going to put the perpetrators behind bars and keep them there," she said.

"The entire bail and justice system needs serious attention. Generally speaking, the police don't argue strongly enough against bail. But in this case, a policeman who argued against it met a magistrate who ignored the legislation about tighter bail conditions. The Department of Justice is a danger to people's safety if it lets murder suspects out on bail."

Network of Independent Monitors (NIM) South Coast representative Selvan Chetty said the failure of the courts to deny bail to suspects arrested in connection with last year's Shobashobane massacre was one of the main reasons for the resurgence of tensions in the area since June.

"Out of 128 political violence suspects arrested by Bushy Englebrecht's (special investigation) unit early this year, only five are still behind bars. If people facing multiple murder charges are out on bail, the community won't want to talk about giving evidence," he said.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


298 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


South Africa;
Mandela 'To Open Amnesty Flood Gate'


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1894 words


 

Johannesburg - Applications for amnesty from the the PAC and ANC are pouring in to the truth commission, and with a likely extension of the cut- off date right-wingers will also be able to apply, writes Eddie Koch

PRESIDENT Nelson Mandela is expected to cap a week of dramatic developments around the truth commission by announcing on Friday that people who took part in election bombings and other acts of violence during the run-up to his 1994 inauguration will now be able to apply for amnesty.

The meeting comes after announcements that former law and order minister Adriaan Vlok has finalised his amnesty application and that guerrillas from the African National Congress and Pan Africanist Congress's military wings are streaming in to ask for amnesty before the deadline on Saturday. It was also the week in which the first security force officer responsible for a serious massacre - Brian Mitchell - received amnesty.

The outcome of the summit at Mandela's office in the Union Buildings - due to be attended by Freedom Front leader Constand Viljoen, truth commission deputy chairman Alex Boraine and Justice Minister Dullah Omar - will provide the pivot around which the commission will now begin to take more shape as an active agent for reconciliation. 

The truth body, in operation since January, has so far functioned mainly as a forum for victims to express the pain they have suffered as a result of human rights abuse in the apartheid period. The organisation has, until now, had only limited success in terms of its other major function: to flush out the truth from perpetrators in exchange for giving them amnesty.

Members of the commission believe they will have time and opportunity to accomplish a more effective mood of reconciliation than the organisation has achieved so far if there is agreement to amend the truth laws so that more right-wingers can apply for amnesty.

Sources inside the commission say the president will probably announce plans at a midday press conference that will enable right-wing terrorists who disrupted the country's first non-racial election with a violent car-bomb campaign to apply for amnesty.

That move - along with the dramatic announcement this week that former minister Adriaan Vlok has applied for amnesty, and the decision this week to grant mass killer Brian Mitchell amnesty, is bound to bring the right-wing more into line with the principles of the country's new Constitution and its stress on the need for national reconciliation.

Vlok was reported to have almost completed his amnesty application while a group of police generals and senior officers under the leadership of former commissioner, General Johan van der Merwe, will submit about 50 applications.

On top of that, the PAC announced this week that the entire high command of its guerrilla wing, the Azanian People's Liberation Army (Apla), would apply for amnesty. An additional 600 applications from rank-and-file Apla cadres will be made before the deadline at midnight on Saturday.

Amendments to the truth laws, especially an extension of the period for which people involved in political violence can qualify for amnesty, will also benefit Apla guerrillas who carried out terror campaigns in the early part of 1994.

The ANC has also already handed in about 300 applications and is busy processing many more. The organisation has promised to make the names of each applicant public this week, but it is known the list will include Defence Minister Joe Modise, his deputy Ronnie Kasrils, and Rashid Abu Baker, former commander of the Umkhonto weSizwe's special operations unit, who is now a general in the SANDF.

These late but dramatic moves will effectively shift the truth body firmly away from being a forum for public venting of anger and grief about past atrocities into becoming a more effective instrument for extracting the truth about these events - and then promoting forgiveness on the basis of the disclosures. A staffer told the M&G there was a "polling-booth" atmosphere at the organisation's head office in Adderley Street, Cape Town as boxes filled with applications streamed in to meet the Saturday deadline.

Mandela is expected to tell journalists on Friday that his Cabinet will recommend to Parliament early next year that it amend its truth commission legislation in order to change the cut-off date for offences that qualify for amnesty from the end of 1993 to May 10 1994, the date of the presidential inauguration.

The deadline for amnesty applications to be handed in by midnight on Saturday December 14 is also likely to be shifted ahead by a few months to enable those who committed human rights abuse in the early months of 1994 to prepare their submissions.

In exchange for this concession, Mandela will probably ask Viljoen to encourage more support from his supporters to back the Constitution and the government of national unity.

The M&G has been informed that there is still considerable debate within the ANC about how the president should handle requests from a range of quarters to amend the amnesty rules. But the fact that Viljoen has been asked to attend the Friday summit indicates Mandela is likely to use the occasion to make one of those statesman-like gestures he has mastered. The timing would also bolster the mood of confidence that has been created by the passing of the new Constitution and would also accord with the spirit of the Christmas season.

And the decision to grant amnesty to Mitchell, a police captain sentenced to 30 years in prison for his role in the massacre of 11 people at Trust Feeds in KwaZulu Natal, has already prompted a flood of new applications for amnesty from perpetrators.

Officials in the commission's investigative unit said more than 3 500 applications had been submitted late this week and the total was expected to reach 4 000 by the Saturday deadline.

By far the biggest proportion of security force applicants were from the police with relatively few coming from the military. However a small group of former Military Intelligence agents were expected to apply and also a large group from 32 Battalion - the mercenary unit that fought in Angola and is reputed to have carried out train violence during the pre-election period.

ANC spokesman Ronnie Mamoepa said staff were preparing to release a list naming all the organisation's members asking for amnesty.

The amnesty committee's decision about Mitchell was the first dealing with a security force officer guilty of a serious offence and, as such, has provided perpetrators and their legal teams with some clear guidelines about what kind of treatment they can expect from the panel of judges on the committee.

During a conference in Stellenbosch last week on legal aspects of the truth commission, lawyers acting for former policemen and military officers expressed outrage that the amnesty committee had not provided clear guidelines for people who were thinking of applying but were still undecided.

The Mitchell judgment does not refer specifically to the way it interpreted the principal of proportionality -that the crime committed should have been commensurate with the political motives of the perpetrator - but the fact that the police captain was indemnified and set free indicates the committee is willing to take a fairly liberal interpretation of the principle.

Commission chair Desmond Tutu said he had been surprised by the decision. At the time the decision was announced he was preparing a reply to an Afrikaner group that had told him they did not believe former security force members would qualify for amnesty. "This was a wonderful coincidence. It pulled the rug from under their feet," he said.

The ruling provides other guidelines: it notes Mitchell was under the command of the Joint Management Committee System that co- ordinated the National Party government's counter-offensive against the ANC in the 1980s; he considered it his duty to carry out the strategy; he had no personal motive in planning the massacre; and some of the constables who actually carried out the attack had already received indemnity under earlier legislation.

"I think this ruling was deliberately done to assist requests by legal representatives who were desperately needing more guidelines for the clients to consider while applying for amnesty," said Antjie Krog, a poet and journalist who specialises in the truth commission. "I think the ruling has helped people who want to talk about the past by giving them some guidance through this slow process of amnesty."

The NP this week also bolstered amnesty procedures by issuing a statement urging its supporters who have committed crimes and violations of human rights to approach the commission.

The gradual alignment of right-wing parties, including the NP and the Freedom Front, with the objectives of the truth commission is likely to marginalise military figures like former defence minister Magnus Malan who have urged their supporters to risk being prosecuted in court rather than cooperate with the truth body.

There are, however, still some dissenting voices. "This whole TRC has become a circus. The ruling about Brian Mitchell was a scheme in order to get people to come and apply for forgiveness," said Cyril Ramolo, an attorney acting for families of political activists who were murdered by agents of the state's death squads in the 1980s. "But if people really want forgiveness they would go voluntarily. These people (perpetrators) are not willing. They are being pushed and manipulated into going."


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


299 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


South Africa;
No Place On Island For Ex-Prisoners


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Johannesburg - Former Robben Island prisoners are bitter at not being consulted about its development, reports Rehana Rossouw

FORMER Robben Island prisoners have slammed their leadership for excluding them from plans to transform the island into a monument celebrating the struggle against apartheid. They claim promises that they would benefit from the island's development have not been kept, and that senior positions on the project have been earmarked for white professionals.

The island is to be developed as a world heritage site, national monument and museum, with the section where political prisoners were held to be converted into a Museum of the Freedom Struggle in South Africa.

The plans, approved by the Cabinet in September, include incorporating the University of the Western Cape's Mayibuye Centre into the project. 

The Department of Correctional Services will hand over authority of the island on Wednesday to the Department of Arts, Culture, Science and Technology. The plans follow work spearheaded by presidential advisor Ahmed Kathrada, who was instructed by the Cabinet in August 1995 to establish the Future of Robben Island Committee.

His final proposal, drawn up after he had invited public submissions, says the "special history of Robben Island will be taken into account during the planning and development process ... via the inclusion of ex-political prisoners ... through arrangements which can contribute to the socio-economic upliftment of ex-prisoners".

But former prisoners say they have been excluded from the process. None have been offered any of the 177 new jobs created by the redevelopment, which will include a chief director earning R26000 a month.

Western Cape co-ordinator of the Ex- Political Prisoners Committee, Zolile Ndindwa, said many former prisoners felt bitter and marginalised. The committee was formed in April 1995 to look after ex- prisoners' welfare and is chaired by Kathrada. Other committee members include Tokyo Sexwale, Terror Lekota and Jeff Radebe.

"We were never involved in a representative capacity on the Future of Robben Island Committee. Now its proposals are being presented to us as a fait accompli," he said.

"Prisoners did not make submissions to them, because many did not have the capacity to do so, and expected their organisation to call them together, hear their views and represent them."

Ndindwa said he was contacted by Mayibuye Centre director Andre Odendaal last week to help find former prisoners to fill the new positions on Robben Island. He did not contact any, as he has not seen the final proposal for the island, and does not know what positions are available.

"Odendaal seems to be in a hurry, there seems to be a deadline. I don't know when it is. I haven't seen any advertisements for positions. All I know is ex-prisoners complain to me constantly, and I feel their pain.

"Some are starving and very bitter, and their bitterness rubs off on me as well. They feel abandoned by their leaders."

Former Robben Island inmate Zanile Mazantsan said he did not think there had been any meetings in the past year for ex-political prisoners to discuss the island's development.

"I'm very hurt, even though I am employed and better off than most ex- political prisoners. Even unskilled ex-prisoners could have been involved in some small way," he said.

Mazantsana said he had hoped to get involved marketing Robben Island memorabilia, and had brought together a group of ex-political prisoners to form a company. He is also involved in a consortium which is bidding for two radio licences for ex-political prisoners.

"But then I heard a business owned by whites has a contract to market memorabilia. Why were skilled ex-prisoners not given an opportunity to tender? Who agreed they should do it? There is absolutely no communication with ex-prisoners who toiled on Robben Island.

"Why are only white professionals being earmarked for positions in the Robben Island project? I know of at least three ex- prisoners who have MBAs and are fully capable of getting involved in some way or another.

"Eventually ex-prisoners will not tolerate people who do not have their welfare at heart. It will be very interesting to find out who is involved finally in Robben Island, who is going to benefit financially. We will force them to step down."

Kathrada said "hurried decisions" had to be taken to ensure continuity because the Department of Correctional Services was quitting the island by the end of the year. The positions were being filled as a temporary measure until permanent posts were advertised next year. "In all fairness to ex- prisoners, I want to confess that I have not been in touch with them. But we have a list of their names now and steps are being taken to hold provincial meetings and report on our plans for the future."

Future of Robben Island Committee member and former Robben Island inmate Eddie Daniels said the committee had not met for some time as Kathrada was overseas, but he was confident it had the welfare of ex-prisoners at heart. " There are a lot of people who believe Robben Island belongs to them. It doesn't, it belongs to the struggle. The people on Robben Island were only the black men who were caught," he said.

"What about the white men and women, the black women, the people in exile and those who weren't caught? Doesn't Robben Island belong to them as well?" Daniels said.

He said the Ex-Prisoners Committee was supposed to deal with pensions, rather than representing ex-prisoners on the Robben Island Committee. "Most of the people on the committee are premiers and cabinet members. How are they supposed to meet regularly?"


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


300 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


BYLINE: Eddie Koch, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Johannesburg - PRESIDENT Nelson Mandela, probably the only leader of an industrialised nation who does not have access to potable water in his own home, has been brought in line with his presidential colleagues from other parts of the world.

A R250 000 pipeline was this week being run into Mandela's traditional home at Qunu in the Eastern Cape so the president can spend Christmas there without having to use drinking water from drums that have to be bussed into the house from Umtata.

And, just in case political opponents use this elementary service to claim that Mandela has hopped aboard the gravy train, the pipeline has been installed at no cost to the state. The Liberty Life Foundation provided the funds so that water from a current scheme to bring potable water to Qunu could be rushed along into Madiba's home. 

When the president visits Qunu he has to wash and drink from 25 litre drums trucked about 100km from Umtata into the village.

This extraordinary situation highlights the fact that the lack of potable water is one of the biggest problems faced by rural people in most parts of the country. Qunu villagers apparently face major health hazards because they are forced to drink from polluted springs and ground water supplies that often dry up in the winter months.

Although the Department of Water Affairs and Forestry is not paying for the presidential pipeline, it does form part of a larger scheme to remedy the dire water situation in this part of the Eastern Cape.

Minister of Water and Forestry Affairs Kader Asmal had already approved a major project to supply the entire village and 42 000 people living in the surrounding administrative area with water that is expected to be complete by August 1998. Some "R1,5-million will be spent in the current year to bring the water scheme on stream -and the Liberty donation allowed the president to tap into this supply in advance.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


301 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


South Africa;
Medical Fund Near Collapse


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Johannesburg - Pro Sano, the third-largest medical aid scheme in the country, has run up R90- million losses and now faces serious charges of bribery and corruption. Marion Edmunds and Mungo Soggot report

A TOP medical aid scheme for public servants is on the verge of collapse, racked by financial mismanagement and corruption allegedly involving leading insurance and consulting groups.

Papers filed in the Cape Town Supreme Court this week by the Department of Health claim Pro Sano Medical Aid has been allowed to run up losses of nearly R90-million while its ruling council took bribes from companies eager for its business.

The scheme, the country's third largest, provides medical cover to 70 000 members, most of them teachers, postal and municipal workers and staff at Telkom and Eskom. 

The members contribute nearly R44-million a month into the scheme.

But the health department's registrar of medical schemes claims the council has been operating an ambitious kickback network, involving high-profile groups including Metropolitan Life.

Department registrar Danibl Kolver says the Pro Sano council cannot be trusted to save the scheme amid "wholesale and continuing irregularities which are seriously prejudicial to members".

Kolver says the court must move quickly to put the scheme into judicial management, as compromising evidence could disappear.

He says prolonged uncertainty could herald the scheme's collapse, depriving its members of medical cover.

The application is due to be heard in court on Friday, and Kolver is also calling for a commission of inquiry. Kolver sprang into action after presenting on November 15 a forensic report to the Council of Medical Aid Schemes. The chairman of the council is Justice David Melamet.

The papers detail a string of allegations against the Pro Sano council, but Kolver says he does not want to vilify anybody by naming names. The council's current chairman Shuayb Patel, who took office in November, said his predecessor was Bernard Wentzel who resigned last month. In the previous year Lionel Kearns was chairman. The organisation's principal officer until last month was Dr Louis Kathan, whose predecessor was Solly Fourie. The current principal officer is Sidney Stadler.

The papers say that in 1990 the council quietly set up its own company, Bon Sano, which has been used to ferry under-the-table payments to council members.

Bon Sano's illicit funtions included sponsoring council members' overseas travel and paying salaries to several key current and past employees of Pro Sano.

Bon Sano took on Pro-Sano's funeral policy for which it received R1,069- million a year. However, Kolver said: "it is not apparent what services, if any, Bon Sano, is to perform in consideration of which it receives this very substantial income)"

Kolver's list of irregular payments received by Pro Sano's council include:

lR638 631 from consultant Willmore Spies, which company received commission and administration fees from one of Pro Sano's policies, the Admed insurance policy.

The department's papers claim that Wentzel had demanded "commission" from Willmore Spies for the commission that Willmore Spies got from Pro Sano.

Willmore Spies, which received commissions totalling R4,4-million between 1991 and 1995, was sub-broker to consultant Alexander Forbes, which earned R4, 2-million. Willmore Spies also received unauthorised administraion fees worth R1,4-million, while Alexander Forbes bagged undisclosed administration fees worth R2,3-million.

l R10 000 from Metropolitan Life, which was used to fly two members of the management council to a conference in Boston in the United States this year.

Within months of the payment, Pro Sano struck an in-principle agreement with Metropolitan Life that one of its subsidiaries would take over Pro Sano's administration from Medscheme.

* R6 000 from Quality Health Holdings for part of the expenses of the wives of the chairman and the principal officer to attend the same Boston conference.

* A portion of the cost of university education for the son of the chairman of the management council was paid by Medscheme and Quality Health Holdings.

Kolver questions the relationship between Pro Sano and two Old Mutual employees who set up an investment company, Sterling Investments.

The two employees earned commissions on investments they made for Pro Sano.

Kolver also questions Medscheme's administration and scolds top accountant Ernst & Young for failing to blow the whistle on Pro Sano's doctored accounts for the year to December 1995.

"It is necessary to establish why Ernst & Young issued an unqualified audit report when it had earlier formed the view that the respondent was conducting business in insolvent circumstances and had reported it to the Public Accountants' and Auditors Board."

He said that the auditors' statement that Pro Sano was "trading itself out of a deficit situation was at the very least misplaced optimism."

Patel told the Mail &Guardian the council intended to fight the application. He said the registrar had failed to note that there had been major changes in policy this year, adding that the scheme was on track for a surplus in 1996. "There is lots of politics in all this."

Kolver points out that Pro Sano proceded to lose another R22-million from December 1995 until mid year.

The bad news for the members of the scheme is that, like all medical aid policy holders in South Africa, their premiums are expected to increase - possibly as much as 25% in a looming industry shake-up.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


302 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


Eritrea;
President Describes Investment Opportunities


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3254 words


 

Washington - The text of remarks, as prepared for delivery by President Isaias Afwerki of Eritrea, to the Conference on Commercial and Investment Opportunities in Eritrea on December 10.

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Let me begin by expressing my gratitude for the honor of addressing you today and express my thanks to those who worked hard to make this event possible. Thank you, Mr. Kassum and Mr. Allison, for welcoming us with your kind introduction. I would also like to thank the Corporate Council on Africa for organizing this conference, the International Finance Corporation for sponsoring it, the U.S. Agency for International Development for financing our private sector representatives to participate in this event, and all the participants for taking the time to attend. Thank you all for your efforts.

THE ECONOMY AND GROWTH STRATEGY

In the next 25 minutes or so, let me share with you my own views about the evolving business environment in Eritrea, and the investment opportunities emerging for the private sector and long-term foreign investors in our economy. 

Initial Condition: As you all may be aware, Eritrea is a young nation emerging from the ruins of decades of war and economic suppression. The liberation struggle left the country's infrastructure almost completely destroyed, its people scattered and its government and economic institutions very run down.

Growth Strategy Adopted: In spite of its poor initial conditions at liberation, Eritrea has emerged as a politically stable and economically promising nation in sub-Saharan Africa. Its economic and investment policies are moving in the direction of strong support for private domestic and foreign entrepreneurs and investors. Progress has been made in establishing a slim, forward-looking and corruption-free state bureaucracy. Efforts towards the establishment of a comprehensive legal framework and judiciary system are well under way. We in the government are very keen to establish a close partnership with private investors to find solutions to any remaining constraints to private sector development, foreign investment and economic recovery and growth.

Eritrea has established cooperative relations with Ethiopia, and joined a number of regional and international trade and investment promoting agencies. We have established diplomatic and commercial relations with many leading countries, including the United States and Canada. Eritrea has also signed agreements to promote stronger trade and investment partnerships with both bilateral and multilateral agencies. These initiatives will facilitate market expansion for Eritrean goods and services, and enhance Eritrea's attractiveness as a platform for producing goods and services for export to readily accessible foreign markets of more than 300 million people.

To encourage the private sector to become the primary engine of economic growth and employment generation, we have adopted (i) a rational, simplified and competitive tax system; (ii) an open and liberal trade and investment regime; (iii) realistic market-based interest and exchange rates; (iv) an encouraging investment policy and efficient licensing procedure; and (v) sound and flexible labor regulations. Eritrea is also a crime-free and pleasant place to conduct business, and reasonably well connected to regional and international business centers through fast improving communications and transport facilities.

Economic Achievement: Eritrea is blessed with good natural resources and a strategic location for establishing business operations which offer attractive investment opportunities for accelerated private sector development. More importantly, and complementing its natural advantages, Eritrea has a disciplined, motivated and hard-working people who are eager to be trained. Our economic reconstruction efforts have been successful in generating small- and medium-scale investments, and in improving the quality of the country's infrastructure. The overall reliability of the supply of power, transport and communications services has been restored and improved substantially in most parts of the economy. The management of public enterprises has improved drastically, resulting in full commercialization and an average capacity utilization that has increased to around 70 percent, compared to the low of 20-30 percent before liberation. Reversing the secular negative growth of the 1980s, Eritrea, during 1992-96, achieved an average GDP growth rate of over 5 percent per annum. The rate would have been higher had it not been for inadequate or erratic rainfall patterns which resulted in a poor harvest in three of the last four years. The average inflation rate during this period has been consistently below 10 percent.

With the expected positive impact of investments under way to improve water resources management, Eritrea can move toward even faster growth. To make this happen, we will continue encouraging private sector participation and foreign investment in all sectors of our economy, including private provision of infrastructure.

ADVANTAGES OF INVESTING IN ERITREA

The Foreign Investment Policy Regime: Eritrea's investment rules are among the most liberal in Africa. There are no exchange controls for repatriating dividends and capital gains, and foreign investors are treated equally with local investors in securing access to land, utilities and other production inputs. While foreign investors are encouraged to train Eritreans, securing work permits for employing foreign workers with skills that cannot be readily available in the Eritrean labor market is not a problem. The overall tax rate structure is relatively competitive. Duties on imports of capital and intermediate goods, spare parts and raw materials are a low 2 percent; but an additional sales tax of 3 percent is also levied on imports of raw and intermediate materials. All imports for re-export are duty-free, and exports are exempted from sales and export taxes. Eritrea's investment policy provides guarantees against nationalization or confiscation.

Political Stability and Governance: During the last five years, we have laid the foundation for good governance and long-term political stability, free from corruption and bureaucratic malaise. A Constitutional Commission, composed of legal experts and representatives of the general public, completed a draft constitution for the state of Eritrea. Based on this draft, preparation of new commercial, civil and penal codes, and the procedures and court institutions needed to implement them is under way, with the objective of establishing an efficient and competent civil service accompanied by an independent and swift judiciary system.

Entrepreneurial Drive: Entrepreneurial creativity, inventive genius, manual skills and sense of duty are important requirements for succeeding in economic development, and all these attributes are very much in evidence in the Eritrean population. Eritrea has a long tradition of craftsmanship and entrepreneurship, which was stimulated by the new technologies in agriculture and industry introduced from Europe and elsewhere. These left a positive legacy in terms of inventiveness and creativity, which was put to good use during the armed struggle for liberation. This inventive genius and drive of the people can be used again in the peacetime reconstruction and development of our economy.

Disciplined and Hard-Working Labor Force: We strongly believe that Eritrea's real asset is its people. In our development strategy, we gave top priority to accelerated human resource development. For well understood reasons, most Eritreans have little or no formal education, but they do learn new tasks quickly and have the dexterity to work with their hands. Finding competent and disciplined workers, therefore, is not a problem. The current labor law establishes regulations regarding minimum working conditions; employer and worker associations; procedures for collective bargaining and resolution of disputes; and powers and duties of the state in resolving labor disputes. Setting the minimum wage is left to market forces and employer- employee negotiations. Work permits for foreign workers are granted when a qualified Eritrean cannot be found.

MAJOR INVESTMENT SECTORS

The major sources of growth in the Eritrean economy consist of investments and productivity improvements in agriculture, fisheries, general manufacturing, and in services like finance, communication, transport and tourism. In addition, we have good long-term prospects for developing high- value mineral deposits (such as gold, silver and copper), hydrocarbons (oil and natural gas) and geothermal resources. The main sectors in which foreign investors can find long-term business opportunities are commercial agriculture, fisheries and fish processing, general manufacturing industries - - including privatization, energy and mining, and provision of construction, tourism, financial and a wide range of infrastructure services.

Agriculture: This sector is the mainstay of the Eritrean economy (as a means of livelihood for the large majority of the population), but operates at very low levels of technology and productivity. The scope for increasing output with the application of relatively simple inputs and improved farming and water management practices is correspondingly large. Eritrea has significant water resources (seasonal rivers, underground water, etc.) that could be developed to establish irrigated agricultural estates for the production of high-value agricultural products; these resources are yet to be developed. Foreign investment can be especially promising in the production of fruits, vegetables, flowers and greenhouse plants, industrial crops, and livestock production, including dairy and meat (beef, mutton, pork and poultry).

Fisheries: Eritrea's coastal waters are among the potentially most productive fishing grounds in the Red Sea. Thus, fishing offers attractive investment opportunities for the private sector, both local and foreign. According to recent estimates, there is a potential for catching about 60,000 tons of demersal and 20,000 tons of pelagic fish per annum. The present fish catch of 6,000 tons could be increased 15 times without any risk to long-term fisheries sustainability. The most promising areas of investment for foreign investors in the sector are in canning tuna, sardines and anchovies; fish processing (salting, drying, smoking, filleting, etc.) and packing; fish meal manufacturing; establishment of cold storage and transport facilities; and fishing boat construction and maintenance.

Manufacturing: Our country offers many opportunities for light manufacturing both for the domestic market and for regional exports. The context is continuously improving as we enhance our human capital and physical infrastructure. In addition, 39 of the 42 public manufacturing enterprises inherited from the previous regime are slated for privatization. This divestiture program offers opportunities to acquire established enterprises which, with further investment in modernization and capacity expansion, could become competitive producers both in the regional market and for export to Europe and the Middle East. The privatization program is driven by our own strong conviction that commercial production of goods and services should be the domain of the private sector, and is expected to be completed by the end of 1997. There are no special conditions attached to buying any of the enterprises in the list, but expansion plans and export programs will be favorably considered in evaluating bids.

Mining Sector: We welcome foreign investment in the mining sector. A number of foreign and local investors are already investing in prospecting and exploration for precious minerals, with some seven exploration and six prospecting licenses having been issued. Among the most significant foreign companies involved are Western Mining Corporation of Australia and Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana. Other companies entering the sector are from the United States, Canada, South Africa and France. A mining license grants an exclusive right to the licensee to mine for specified minerals within the licensed area. It can be transferred, assigned or encumbered, and inherited with the prior approval of the Licensing Authority. Mining companies have the right to freely dispose of their production either locally or in the international market. There is no restriction on the repatriation of profits.

Oil and Gas: Geological studies and preliminary exploration suggest good prospects for discovering significant hydrocarbon resources. We are actively encouraging private investment in the development of petroleum oil and natural gas resources. This sector is open to private participation, and foreign investors are invited to invest on the basis of internationally competitive production sharing contracts. The first exploration contract was signed with Anadarko Petroleum Corporation (USA) in 1995. To encourage private investors to invest, the state is prepared to enter into joint ventures with the private sector and to invest up to 20 percent of the equity capital in strategic oil and gas projects. Investment contracts offered in the sector are consistent with established industry norms, including production contracts running for up to 25 years with up to 10 years extension.

Hotels and Tourism: A principal attraction of Eritrea is its ancient and fascinating heritage as part of the historic Axumite Kingdom. Eritrea's offshore islands in the Red Sea and parts of the mainland along the coast have beautiful beaches. A glimpse at life under the waters of the Red Sea off the Eritrean coast opens up a veritable treasure chest of colorful corals. Eritrean shores, positioned between two oceans and two distinct seas range from tropical to temperate and provide a fascinating spectacle of marine life and a treasure trove for scuba divers. Mainland Eritrea boasts spectacular mountain scenery dotted with interesting traditional villages. These features beckon the establishment of appropriate tourism facilities for an effective presentation to visitors and business travelers. They can form a solid basis for attractive business operations in special-interest tourism, ecotourism and safari tourism.

Banking and Finance: Private companies depend on an efficient financial sector for long-term loan and equity capital and for short-term working capital. Presently, with one commercial bank (which has 14 branches), one housing bank and one insurance company, Eritrea is underbanked. To alleviate the shortages of financial services, we are about to enact a "Financial Institutions Act" permitting the licensing of private financial institutions, including foreign banks. Eritrea also has good long-term prospects for establishing off-shore banking services and for becoming a competitive financial center in the region, given its proximity to the Arab Gulf, Africa and the Middle East.

Private Provision of Infrastructure: In addition to power, there are two critical infrastructure services that could benefit from increased private investment: transport and telecommunications. Existing trucking and bus services are mainly privately owned and further private investments in these subsectors are welcomed and encouraged. Port and airport facilities, as well as postal and telecommunications systems are state-owned but the government is investigating ways to involve the private sector in their operation. Private and foreign investment is especially welcomed and encouraged for increasing the coverage and modernization of the country's telecommunications network. Our government accords priority to private and foreign investment in this sector.

Power Generation: Eritrea is an energy-deficient country. About 82 percent of its total energy demand is met from fuel-wood and biomass resources. Electricity, which is generated from imported diesel, meets only slightly over 1 percent of total demand. Installed power generation capacity in 1992 was under 50MW. Public investments now under implementation will bring power generation to 150MW by the end of 1997. Even with this increased capacity, however, a shortage of power is expected to continue though tariff rates are based on full cost recovery. To alleviate this problem, and to diversify the sources of supply, the government is encouraging private investment in geothermal and solar power, and foreign direct investment in these subsectors is welcomed and encouraged.

CONCLUSION

In conclusion, our country may not be perfect but we are striving to make it a dynamic port of call for the international investor. I want to wish each of you here a productive day and I hope to welcome you as partners and investors in Eritrea. I would again like to express my gratitude to the many people and organizations who have made it possible for us to meet here today. Thank you for your attention.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


303 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


United States and Africa;
Moose Outlines U.S. Ties with Eritrea


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2614 words


 

Washington - Following is the text of remarks as prepared for delivery by Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs George Moose at a December 10 commercial and investment conference on Eritrea.

President Isaias, ministers, distinguished guests. I am pleased to have been invited to participate in today's event. I am doubly pleased at the level of interest shown by the many businesses represented here. Your presence attests to the success of the efforts made by the government and people of Eritrea to build Eritrea's reputation as a privileged partner for commerce and investment.

I would like to take this opportunity to outline U.S. policy toward the Greater Horn of Africa, describe U.S. efforts to contribute to the stability and growth of the area, and explain why we regard Eritrea as an important key to the region's future. 

THE TROUBLED HISTORY OF THE HORN

The Horn of Africa is struggling to free itself from the legacy of colonialism, Cold War conflict, and misrule. Some areas are well on the way to recovery, but others regrettably are still suffering. Much of the poverty and suffering that the region has known in recent decades can be attributed to the vagaries of an inhospitable climate, a fragile ecology, and recurring cycles of drought. But these natural calamities were greatly exacerbated by the incompetence and irresponsibility of repressive dictatorships, failed economic policies, and personal political ambitions that produced fratricidal warfare.

Yet, if that were the whole story, I dare say none of us would be here today. For the demise of old, discredited regimes has given rise to the emergence of new ideas, and hope for a new generation. What is happening today in Eritrea illustrates what can be accomplished by the determined application of this new thinking. Moreover, the emergence of committed new leadership in the region has given the United States new and viable partners with whom to work in addressing the full range of shared regional and international concerns.

The differing consequences of the last two major droughts to hit the Horn are instructive. The drought of 1984-85 caused almost unimaginable suffering. Hundreds of thousands of lives were lost -- and television images broadcast around the world captured the enormity of the tragedy. The 1994 drought had the potential for being equally serious and devastating. Yet the feared disaster never came to pass, and the event went virtually unnoticed by the international press. Certainly, the international relief agencies played a part in the successful effort to avert a catastrophe. But far more important than any outside assistance was the existence of governmental leadership that took seriously its responsibilities for the welfare of their citizens. In stark contrast to the inept and oppressive authorities in place in 1984, this new generation of responsible and concerned leaders was able to mobilize the active support of their populations in order to make the most effective use of outside assistance, and to rely on a functioning market system that could compensate for scarcity and distribution problems.

U.S. POLICY IN THE GREATER HORN

This evident connection between stability and success and the presence of responsible and performing governments is central to U.S. policy, in the Greater Horn and throughout the African continent. The complex transformations under way in the Greater Horn present us with both opportunities and challenges, which the United States is seeking to address in four interrelated dimensions of our policy toward the region.

-- First, we support African efforts to establish democratic institutions and governments, to protect fundamental freedoms, and to institute the rule of law. Experience has demonstrated that these are also the essential requirements for genuine stability and national cohesiveness, as well as for sustainable economic growth and prosperity. Absent these basic conditions, ideas will not flourish, investors will not support promising economic sectors, and entrepreneurs will not take the risks necessary to create a dynamic, growing economy. That is why in 1996 alone, the U.S. provided $100 million to support democratization, human rights, and rule of law programs in Africa.

-- Second, the administration has made a commitment to assisting African leaders deal with root causes of crises and conflict.

We know that it is far less costly, in both human and monetary terms, to intervene early to prevent crises than it is to react to them. The large- scale instability that plagued the region of the Greater Horn over the past three decades prompted the international community to provide massive resources for humanitarian relief operations, resources which might have been more productively devoted to long-term development. Food aid to this region amounted to over $4,000 million between 1985 and 1992.

Crisis and conflict prevention are primary goals of the Greater Horn of Africa Initiative (GHAI), which was launched in 1994 with President Clinton's full backing. It also explains our continuing support for the development of the conflict prevention and resolution mechanisms of the Organization of African Unity, based in Addis Ababa. President Isaias has been a leader in the region in focusing on the need for regional solutions to problems of food security and conflict, issues of great importance to Eritrea.

-- Third, and very closely related to the foregoing, we are convinced of the centrality of environmental issues. Environmental degradation, including soil erosion and deforestation, contributes to both poverty and political instability. And like other "transnational" issues -- international crime, narcotics trafficking, infectious diseases -- environmental issues do not respect national borders. They can only be addressed in partnership with other concerned and responsible governments.

As an indication of our concern, Secretary Christopher has mandated the establishment of a worldwide network of "environmental hubs" in key regions around the world. I am pleased to say that the first environmental hub on the African continent will be established next summer in the U.S. Embassy in Addis Ababa, with responsibility for the entire region of the Greater Horn.

-- Finally, we understand that it is free trade, free markets, and opportunities for the private sector that will build the economies of the region. The World Bank estimates that about 350 million new jobs will be needed in sub-Saharan Africa within a generation. Only the private sector -- free to allocate resources and respond to market signals -- can create jobs and income on this scale. Moreover, it is the private sector that can best provide Africa with much-needed access to investment, know-how, and technology.

The United States is working to promote private investment in Africa through a variety of institutions, including the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, the Trade and Development Agency, the U.S. Export-Import Bank, and the Africa Growth Fund. We are looking to take full advantage of innovative new technologies to facilitate the dissemination of business information. An example is the Leland Initiative, which will help provide a number of African countries with high-speed access to the Internet. We are currently working to conclude such an agreement with the Eritrean government. The administration also intends to take advantage of the renewed interest evidenced by the Congress in a more comprehensive and aggressive approach to promoting trade and investment in Africa, by putting forward new proposals designed to give special focus to those countries actively engaged in market reform.

VIABLE PARTNERS

These are the policies that have guided the administration's approach to the Greater Horn over the past four years. We believe they provide a firm foundation on which to build over the next four years. But we also understand well that the best policies, however well conceived and vigorously pursued, will be foiled in the absence of viable and serious partners with whom we can work in pursuing common goals.

Happily, Eritrea is such a partner. It has also become a vital and integral part of a wider subregion that is undergoing a fundamental political transformation. Eritrea itself has emerged from its long struggle for independence to embark on an exciting program of political and economic rebirth. While that 30-year struggle left the country physically impoverished, it also forged a keen sense of national identity, unity, and purpose.

Neighboring Ethiopia is also in full transition from a failed and disastrous military dictatorship to a modern democratic and open-market state. Kenya, Uganda, and Tanzania are seeking to consolidate their own political and economic gains and are in the process of recreating a framework for East African cooperation.

But even as they look with justifiable satisfaction on the significant progress that has been made, regional leaders recognize that the status quo is not sufficient to ensure lasting stability and progress for the region. President Isaias was one of the first leaders in the region, along with Prime Minister Meles of Ethiopia, to recognize that national stability and prosperity can only be secured through regional peace and economic cooperation. To that end, they took the lead in revitalizing IGAD, the Intergovernmental Authority on Development. Through their commitment to IGAD, the states of the Greater Horn have created a forum where, despite their evident differences, they can continue to pursue a broad agenda of regional issues. The United States has welcomed and strongly supported this effort to develop regional solutions to shared political, economic, and environmental problems.

Regional leaders like President Isaias also know that sustained progress also requires an ongoing commitment to economic and political institution- building at home. Eritrea has embarked on an impressive effort to draft a constitution which will incorporate protections for fundamental human freedoms. The consolidation of the rule of law will help earn Eritrea a prominent place in the world community and will assure investors and business executives that they will be treated fairly. These protections will also give full scope to the enormous creative energies of the Eritrean people. We recognize the difficulty of pursuing comprehensive reforms so quickly. But we have high expectations for Eritrea, and few doubts about the country's ability to accomplish whatever it sets out to do.

Eritrea's effort to draft a constitution through a process of dialogue with its people is matched by its effort to rebuild and reform its economy. It has launched an ambitious program to restore and improve the country's basic physical infrastructure -- roads, ports, railroads, power generation, and telecommunications -- much of which did not survive the struggle for independence. Equally important, it has embarked on a concerted effort to create a legal and regulatory framework -- including an attractive new investment code -- that is already beginning to empower the private sector to buoy the national economy.

We are already seeing these efforts pay off. U.S. businesses have invested or committed $300 million in Eritrea, in various business sectors. This influx of capital, and the ties to the world trading economy it has brought with it, is a key factor in Eritrea's impressive growth over the last several years.

Our embassy in Asmara has noted the country's commitment to developing its marine resources, including oil exploration led by Anadarko Petroleum; shipping and port facilities; tourism and recreation; and seafood processing and packaging. The government has also identified promising investment opportunities in salt, glass making, leather, and textiles. The road from the capital Asmara to the port city of Massawa is an impressive achievement of engineering, as is the ongoing work on a rail link between the two cities. Both are indications of the high goals to which Eritrea aspires.

Anyone who has traveled to Eritrea has experienced the country's dynamism firsthand. USAID Chief of Staff Dick McCall went there in March of this year to inaugurate the new USAID mission in Asmara. His visits to the countryside and extensive discussions with Eritrean officials confirmed his assessment of Eritrea's extraordinary potential for accelerated economic growth and development. The factor that most impressed him was the evident drive and dedication of its people and the vision of its leadership, which are surely the most important resources any country could hope for. That same impression was shared by the participants in the highly successful trade mission that the Corporate Council sponsored in May.

In sum, Eritrea is undergoing impressive change. It is doing so by espousing the same principles that guide entrepreneurs and investors all around the world -- individual initiative and self-reliance. A quote from an article in the Financial Times earlier this year offers one of the best descriptions of what Eritrea represents: "Eritrea is proud and principled, and virtually without peer in Africa as it pursues its own model of development and vision of democracy." We in the U.S. government offer to Eritrea and to those who seek to do business there our best efforts. And we extend to both our best wishes.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

December 13, 1996


United States and Africa;
Clinton Meets with Eritrea's President


BYLINE: White House


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Washington - Following is the text of the announcement issued by the Office of the Press Secretary on President Clinton's meeting with Eritrean President Isaias Afwerki to discuss the crisis in Central Africa and the situation in the Sudan. 

President Isaias Afwerki of Eritrea met today with National Security Adviser Anthony Lake at the White House for over an hour. President Clinton and Vice President Gore joined the meeting briefly. The leaders discussed the crisis in Central Africa, options for bringing increased stability to the region, particularly Zaire, and the situation in Sudan.

President Clinton congratulated President Isaias for the exceptional progress Eritrea has made in reforming its economy and attracting foreign investment.
