Africa News


December 13, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
Zambian Disco Group In Festive Extravaganza


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Lusaka - ZAMBIA'S first disco giant, CLOUDS or the Cool Lovable Outrageous Disco Sounds in full, will over the festive period celebrate it's 20th anniversary in show-biz at Lusaka's Hotel Intercontinental pool side, the outfit's spokesman, Martin Simwaka, disclosed yesterday.

"The jam extravaganza will put together all sounds from CLOUDS mobile disco, through our stint at Q-Stique, Room at the Top, Hilites to the days of Valentino's and the Oasis night clubs," said Simwaka, adding: "Of course, we will not forget the double jam fusion at the Chinese Great Wall and the now simple but breath- taking dine and dance shindigs at Pete's Steak House."

According to Simwaka, the gate outlay will be announced later while plans are underway to feature all dee Jays that once spun records for CLOUDS. 

"We are trying to get all the Dee Jays that we have worked with over the twenty years to feature during the celebration," he disclosed. "We want it to be a memorable show."

CLOUDS was established in 1976 by former Zambia Airways aircraft engineer, Hanif Adams and his erstwhile pal, Yunous Essa.

Using speakers hired from Lewis Kunda, owner of the one time 70's sensation, Lord Lewis disco, the outfit was a roving ministrel, jamming wherever a good venue could be found.

But as the decade wore on, the outfit found a permanent base at the Q- Stique in Lusaka's Emmasdale residential area where it proved to be a real crowd puller.

At the turn of the last decade, Hanif teamed up with the late "Dirty" Dick Curtis and established the Room at the Top, or RATT in short on the 19th floor of Society House. The latter pulled out and the joint was re-named Hilites.

But a mysterious fire gutted Hilites and for sometime Hanif was in limbo. He, however, linked up with Lusaka businessman, Humphrey Mapoma, and turned his restuarant the Breezing lounge into what became known as Valentino's or Valies.

As Valentino's continued to pull crowds, Hanif decided to open another night club at the former Oasis restaurant, called Pepe's.

But just as business was picking up, the owners decided to turn the restaurant into some Arabic eatary and Hanif was forced out. About the same time too, the owners of the building in which Valentino's was housed decided to up rent to unreasonable levels, prompting Hanif to pack up.

Disillussioned but not beaten, Hanif decided to move into the Chinese Great Wall restaurant where he put up double jams, catering for rhumba and disco freaks.

But misunderstandings with the owners forced Hanif to shift to Pete's Steak House, where CLOUDS is presently housed.

The feast, therefore, is a welcome diversion which should appeal to those who were there.

Hanif, who recently returned from the United States with a sack full of musical surprises promised: "If you were there, be there!" Need I say more?


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


353 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


Business and Finance;
Black Market Rules Zambian Emerald Industry


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Lusaka - Lack of security and qualified marketing agents have robbed the Zambian emerald industry of its potential as a major forex earner for the country.

Emeralds in Zambia are mainly mined by small scale miners and there are about 200 operators in the Copperbelt Province alone, according to statistics from the mining ministry.

"The problem with emerald mining in Zambia is that we manage to get a lot more material on the black market than through formalised channels. There is no security for the miners as well in the areas where emeralds are mined. Fifty per cent of a mine owner's production is lost to his workers while the rest is at risk from robbers during transportation," said Oliver Makungu, one of Zambia's few marketing agents in precious minerals. 

Makungu is an agent for a number of offshore clients he refused to name and also owns a lapidary in Lusaka.

New mines minister Christon Tembo has instructed the police to step up security in the mining areas on the Copperbelt due to the high spate of mineral thefts in the area.

Even the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) confirmed in a statement last Friday that it had stopped movement of copper by trucks to the South African port of Durban and would concentrate on the Northern rail routes because of the high risk of theft.

According to Makungu, the Zambian emerald is more prevalent on the black market than the formal market.

"This is very frustrating considering that people prefer the Zambian emerald to the Columbian emerald," he said.

One of the directors of Pilala Mine on the Copperbelt, who declined to be named, said some South and West African businessmen were making a killing on Zambian emeralds.

"Since most of us do not have the capital to invest in equipment, they offer to provide equipment in exchange for half our production. Unfortunately, the exchange is done before the stones are even valued as that is another expensive process. These people are probably given more than what they put in, " he said.

He explained that the efforts by individual mine owners to market their stones usually resulted in great losses.

"What these people don't understand is that there are cartels on the European and American markets. It is better to use international agents when selling to these markets otherwise material worth US$3,000 is given away at $500 simply because people tried to do their own selling" Makungu revealed.

Makungu advised that it was time the gemstone trade in Zambia was opened up to investors.

"After all we have liberalised the economy, there is nothing wrong with setting up something similar to a stock exchange where we can find out who is selling and where gemstones can be bought," he said.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

December 13, 1996


Business and Finance;
Shares At Ghana Stock Remain Low


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Total volume of shares traded at the stock market remained low Wednesday despite a slight improvement in the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) All-Share Index.

The GSE All-Share Index went up moderately by 0.28 points to end at 357.23 points. 

Overall offers were 1,248,126 shares as against bids of 162,840 shares at a total volume of 18,260 shares.

On the broader market, the breweries made significant strides being the two gainers as against one decliner.

Kumasi Brewery Limited (KBL) gained 25 cedis to close mid-week trading at 655 cedis while Accra Brewery Limited gained 10 cedis to close at 560 cedis.

Fan Milk Limited was the only loser with two cedis ending at 402 cedis.

Market capitalisation climbed slightly to 2,656.35 billion cedis from Monday's 2,655.94 billion cedis (1,720 cedis= one U.S. dollar).

Following were the last prices of listed equities quoted in cedis: (ST) ABL 560 ' 10 AGC 23,200 ALW 1,415 CFAO 20 EIC 420 FML 402 - 2 GCB 701 GGL 244 HFC 130 KBL 655 ' 25 MGL 140 MLC 50 MOGL 6,000 PAF 170 PTC 130 PZ 370 SCB 4, 900 SPPC 112 SSB 1,050 UNIL 780 UTC-E 50 (ET)

355 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


Tanzania;
Corruption Report Handed Over To Mkapa


BYLINE: Yasin Kachechele, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - The trend of corruption in Tanzania partly stems from low wages and inadequate fringe benefits which fail to satisfy workers needs, according to a recent report issued here.

The over 500-page report, handed over to President Benjamin Mkapa, also blames unscrupulous businessmen who have corrupted top officials to win government tenders and favours, especially tax evasion.

Although Mkapa said the report "only gives scientific ways on how to deal with and eradicate corruption," the public and the media have gone further and suggested that measures should be taken against top officials cited in the report as being corrupt. 

According to the report, the majority of Tanzanian public servants are forced to demand bribes in order to make ends meet. This could be corrected by better incomes and wages.

However, it accuses high ranking officials with access to many facilities of resorting to corruption because "they want to accumulate wealth." High ranking officials under the previous government of President Ali Hassan Mwinyi have been named as corrupt.

However, the country's finance minister, Prof.Simon Mbilinyi, was recently forced to resign following an uproar in parliament over reports that he had been bribed to give tax exemptions to local businessmen.

The report, compiled by a team of nine commissioners, headed by former Prime Minister Joseph Sinde Warioba, states that the colonial era laws on corruption, which was adopted in 1958, was full of loopholes. The commission was set up in January 1996 to also review the law, regulations, procedures and the mode of operations in the government and parastatal organisations.

In addition, the report, whose compilation took 11 months, notes that the public institutions set to wipe out corruption, including the judiciary, were corrupt.

"The public, because they need services, are forced to give out bribes but they don't like it," says part of the report, quoted by the Tanzanian News Agency (SHIHATA).

Ministries and departments singled out in the report as being corrupt include those of education, health, home affairs, treasury, judiciary, attorney general's chambers, trade and industry, lands, natural resources, tourism and public works.

The report has not spare the media either, which should, in principle, help in exposing corruption. In two lines, it affirms that the Tanzanian media have been infested with "cheque-book journalists."

"To clamp out corruption, the president has to summon reports of all top officials tarnished by corruption and all top government official should declare their property," the report suggests.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


356 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


Zambia;
Court Acquits Former Zambian Vice-President


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A former Zambian vice-president in Kenneth Kaunda's government, Maiza Chona, on charges of "falsely alarming the public", was acquitted Friday by a Lusaka magistrate because he had "no case to answer".

He was charged after issuing a statement in the supreme court on Nov. 14 that "a bomb had been planted at former President Kaunda's residence in Lusaka." 

Chona had made the statement before a full supreme court bench which was then hearing a petition filed by opposition parties challenging President Frederick Chiluba's citizenship.

The former vice-president, who is a lawyer, claimed that two of the witnesses they intended to call to challenge Chiluba's citizenship had received parcel bombs.

He was summoned to court Tuesday to answer the charges. His lawyers, however, argued that there was no way Chona should be summoned to court when he had not been formally arrested and charged with the offence.

Principal Resident Magistrate Francis Nsokolo said in his ruling that the reasons for issuing the summons to Chona were wrong as well as the procedure that was used by the state in order to secure his attendance of the court.

"I dismiss the charge against the accussed person," he said.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


357 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


Business and Finance;
Poor Nations Poor States Hold Their Own In Trade Talks


BYLINE: Sure Chimbga, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

SINGAPORE, (PANA) - The just-ended World Trade Organisation (WTO) conference in Singapore has delivered a win-win outcome for developing countries which in the past five days resisted Western attempts to link labour standards with trade privileges.

Led by the United States, industrialised member countries of the WTO had demanded that core labour standards be put on the WTO agenda, which would have for the first time put the WTO in direct confrontation with the International Labour Organisation (ILO).

But over 120 speakers who presented speeches at the conference were unanimous that labour issues were not in the realm of the WTO and should instead be discussed within the ILO. 

Zimbabwe and other member countries of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) also took a strong stance against the issue, saying it could cause unnecessary confrontation among member states and cloud the vision of the WTO in its quest to liberalise global trade.

The US and the European Union countries found themselves fighting a losing battle, with developing member countries of the WTO accusing the West of trying to impose their rules on weaker nations.

Speaking at the closing ceremony WTO ministerial conference chairman, Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Yoo Cheow Tong, emphasised that labour issues were best dealt with by the Geneva-based ILO.

He said the ministerial declaration recognised that the ILO was the competent body to set and deal with labour standards.

It rejected the use of labour for protectionist purposes which he said was very important for safeguarding the multilateral trading system, particularly for developing countries.

He said ministers had also agreed that the comparative advantage of low- wage countries "must in no way be put into question (and) does not inscribe the relationship between trade and core labour standards on the WTO agenda."

Cheow emphasised the WTO would not undertake further work on the relationship between trade and labour standards, implying the subject was unlikely to be raised at future WTO meetings.

Meanwhile, the meeting, the first to be held since ministers signed the WTO agreement in Marrakech, Morocco in April 1994, has been hailed by delegates as an important milestone in laying the foundation for future co-operation between the rich and poor countries in removing tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade and investment.

"The conference has provided a strong political message underlining opportunities in the new global economy, while ignoring the challenges that our economies face," the Singapore trade minister said.

"The message this conference has sent is one of confidence in the multilateral trading system as it approaches its 50th anniversary in 1998 and in its ability to promote growth and guarantee stability," he said.

Also expected to benefit from the outcome of the conference would be the so- called least developed countries, which many delegates said were in the danger of being permanently left behind as the rest of the world moved towards global economic integration.

In their declaration, the ministers pledged to provide more technical assistance to ensure that the countries, ranging from Afghanistan to Zambia, successfully implemented Uruguay Round commitments.

Richer countries would explore ways of granting preferential duty-free access for the exports of least developed countries, particularly for clothing and textiles.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


358 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


Business and Finance;
Low Gold Production For Ashanti


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Gold production by the Ashanti Goldfields Company (AGC) at the Obuasi mine fell slightly in the last 12 months ending Sept. 30, 1996, as compared to the same period in 1995, the company said.

In 1995 gold production stood at 932,323 ounces, while that for 1996 dropped to 883,853 ounces. The company had earlier projected that production will hit the one million ounces mark. 

According to Sam E. Jonah, chief executive of AGC, the low gold production reflected the drop in production from the surface mines as well as the treatment of larger tonnages of ore.

"The shift in emphasis from the surface to higher grade underground ore has been initiated and continues to be the focus of the new management," he said in Accra Thursday in an interim report.

He, however, said "1996 has been a milestone year for the company, a year in which it has been transformed from a gold producer with a single mine in Ghana to a group with several operating mines."

The company now has "major development projects and an exploration portfolio that includes land positions on each of the most promising gold mineralisation belts of sub-Saharan Africa," Jonah added.

It moved rapidly in the last six months to add value to the former Cluff properties that were acquired in January, increased exploration and development at Freda-Rebbecca in Zimbabwe leading to a 17 percent increase in reserves and eight percent increase in gold production.

On the company's earnings in 1996, the report shows it earned 70.9 million U.S. dollars representing 33 percent lower than the previous year.

"Earnings were depressed, particularly in the last six months by the high operation costs of the Obuasi mine which is focusing on surface mining operations," it adds.

The next five years will see the company seeking to transform the underground mine into a bulk tonnage and mechanised mining operation that will double ore production to 3.5 million tonnes a year, the report notes.

The company made a profit of 71.4 million dollars as against 105.8 million dollars for 1995.

Ashanti's shares are currently listed on the Australian Stock Exchange which adds up to its existing listings in Accra, Harare, London, New York and Toronto.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


359 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 13, 1996


Zambia;
Zambian Parties Asked To Pay 49,000 Dollars For Petition


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian opposition parties have been told that their petition against President Frederick Chiluba's victory in last month's elections can only be heard if they pay the equivalent of 49,000 US dollars.

The pre-condition has been spelled out to the four political parties that lodged their petition in the Zambian Supreme Court on Nov.29, challenging Chiluba's eligibility to stand for the presidency.

The payment demand has been made by the country's solicitor general, Sam Chisulo, as a condition for the petition's hearing. 

The opposition parties want the Supreme Court to probe chiluba's nationality, in accordance with the new constitution, which requires that only citizens whose parents were also born in country qualify to run for the office of president.

The opposition parties charged that Chiluba lied about his nationality when he filed electoral nomination papers last November.

The petitioning parties are the United National Independence Party (UNIP) of former President Kenneth Kaunda, the Liberal Progressive Front, the National Congress and Agenda for Zambia.

State senior counsel, Mainza Chona, who is one of the lawyers for the petitioners confirmed to PANA Friday that he had received a letter from Chisulo informing him about the costs being asked before the hearing takes place.

"The solicitor general is demanding 49 million kwacha from us. I think the fee is wild and exorbitant," Chona said.

The solicitor general's demand has been described as "wild and outrageous" by some political parties.

Liberal Progressive Front chairman, Rodger Chongwe, said that the fee was exorbitant for an appearance in court. He claimed that the objective was to frustrate Zambians so that Chiluba's nomination was not challenged.

"Chisulo should not kill these proceedings by demanding an outrageous sum of money. It is a cheap ploy to kill the petition that no government employee should engage in," Zambia Democratic Congress deputy secretary Azwell Banda charged, adding that the demands were political and unprofessional.

A week before the Nov. 18 polls, the four parties filed a petition asking the court to order postponement of the elections until the question of Chiluba's nationality was resolved.

That petition was dismissed after the court ruled that it was premature and contrary to the provisions of the electoral law, which requires that a petition be filed within 14 days after the new president has been sworn-in.

The four parties then filed a fresh petition after the elections on Nov.29.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 13, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
OAU Blames Africa's Inaction In Zaire On International Community


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) Friday said Africa was unable to act in the crisis in eastern Zaire due to the failure of the international community to provide it with effective means.

"Africa has had to stand by and watch the unfolding of yet another crisis which at one time threatened to have a possible humanitarian catastrophe," the organisation's secretary general, Salim Ahmed Salim, said. 

He attrbitued this to "a combination of developments in eastern Zaire itself and the inability of the international community to take speedy and timely action to help stabilize the situation" despite the commitment made by the leaders of the Greater Lakes region.

Salim was opening a seminar on peace-making and peace-keeping for the OAU staff, organized by the New York-based International Peace Academy.

The nine-day seminar, which will provide advance training for senior OAU staff involved in conflict prevention, management and resolution, is co- sponsored by the OAU with the support of the government of Denmark, whose minister for development cooperation is also participating.

Other participants include African and other diplomats and NGOs based in Addis Ababa, and resource persons from various United nations agencies, the International Court of Justice and the Commonwealth.

Africa News


December 14, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Boutros-Ghali Congratulates Successor


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - The outgoing United Nations Secretary- General Boutros Boutros-Ghali on Friday congratulated his successor, Kofi Annan of Ghana, who is billed to take over as head of the organization on Jan. 1, 1997.

Botros-Ghali's spokeswoman, Sylvana Foa, said "the Secretary-General has worked closely with Mr. Annan through these past five years and wishes him every success." 

She said that Boutros-Ghali was pleased that the decision to appoint annan was unanimous "and is especially gratified that Africa has been able to maintain the office of Secretary-General for a second five-year term."

Foa said that getting an African to serve a second term had been the objective of the secretary-general "throughout these recent months".

The spokeswoman also expressed the secretary-general-general's "deepest thanks" for the support and encouragement given to him during his tenure by the member states and peoples of the UN.

In what is generally regarded as a mere formality, the 185-member UN General Assembly is expected to elect Annan on Tuesday.

The US, saying that Boutros-Ghali has not carried out enough reform at the UN, vetoed a second term for the Egyptian on Nov. 19, although he received the support of all the other members of the 15 members of the council.

On Dec. 4, the 74-years-old Egyptian diplomat "suspended" his candidature, paving the way for four African candidates --Annan, Amara Essy of Cote d'Ivoire, Hamid Algabid of Niger and Ahmedou Ould Abdallah of Mauritania -- to enter the race.

The council members agreed to give priority to African candidates to give the continent a chance at a second mandate, in accordance with an informal tradition.

Boutros-Ghali, the first African to head the UN, will serve out his current term on Dec. 31.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


362 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 14, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Brain Drain Cited As Cause of Africa's Backwardness


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

MUTARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Brain drain has been cited as one of the major contributors to Africa's low economic growth.

This was said here Saturday by the Vice-Chancellor of the Zimbabwe-based Africa University, Bishop Emilio De Carvalho, when he addressed hundreds of people gathered to witness the institution's second graduation ceremony since its establishment in 1992. 

Bishop Carvalho appealed to African governments and private institutions to ensure university graduates from the continent found decent jobs so they could contribute to the development of their countries.

He said ignorance, under-development, poverty, illiteracy and paucity of skills and resources were still the major constraints affecting the enjoyment of prosperity for the majority of African people.

"The greatest problem with our continent is not so much the lack of qualified educated citizens, it is indeed the lack of profiting from the thousands of national graduands who leave schools and universities each year.

"Africa stands at the crossroads, either we stand firm and decide to raise our own people from the ashes of ignorance and poverty or we are going to continue to deviate our attention and action, making us to develop peoples and nations other than our own," said Carvalho.

He stressed the need for African governments to empower students in their respective countries with relevant values and skills that would ensure self- dependency through provision of educational opportunities to all.

The bishop was speaking at a colourful graduation ceremony for 21 students from Angola, Tanzania and Zimbabwe, who received degrees in agriculture and natural resources and divinity.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


363 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 14, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Annan Pledges To Redefine UN Objectives


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - The United Nations Secretary-General- elect, Kofi Annan of Ghana, says his priority will be to redefine the organization's objectives in the post cold-war era.

In a statement Friday after the security council voted unanimously to recommend him to the UN General Assembly as the seventh UN Secretary-General, Annan said: "it is time to agree on what the UN can and must do, and what it cannot do. 

"Those choices will require consensus and cooperation amongst all member states," said Annan, whose appointment is expected to be ratified by the 185- member assembly next Tuesday.

He noted that the collective will and combined resources of the member states, "their vision of what we will strive to achieve together", would determine the effectiveness of the UN in the years ahead.

Annan called for "a time of healing" to restore confidence between governments and the UN to help replenish its financial strength and its political and moral authority, rebuild its sense of common purpose and maintain its trust and cooperation among the peoples of the world.

He pledged to sustain the morale, motivation and performance of the UN staff members, whom he called the organisation's greatest assets.

"I accept with humility, and also with determination, my nomination by the security council," the 58-year-old Ghanaian said.

"If the General Assembly acts favourably on the recommendation of the Security Council, I shall dedicate myself to pursuing these objectives, to which I have devoted most of my life, with vigour and full commitment," he added.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


364 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 14, 1996


Mozambique;
EU Funds For Mozambican Consumers Project


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The European Union is to provide 150,000 US dollars to finance a consumer education project in Mozambique.

The project, to be carried out by Proconsumer, the country's recently founded consumers' defence association, will be advised by the Portuguese National Consumer Defence Institute (INDC). 

INDC's deputy chairman, Joaquim Carapico, who has been in Mozambique since Monday at the invitation of Proconsumers told a press conference Saturday that it was up to Mozambicans to set up their own model of consumer protection, in accordance with the specific realities of the country.

He stressed the need for civil society to educate ordinary citizens on their rights as consumers. Such education should start early, he said, "when consumers are still children, in school, and in everything concerning their life".

Carapico said that the passing of a legislation defending consumers would be a significant step in helping citizens understand their rights and duties in this area.

According to the chairman of Proconsumer, Francisco Lichuca, the consumer education project seeks to make citizens aware of their rights and persuade businesses to comply with their obligations.

Next Tuesday, the mozambican parliament's chairman, Eduardo Mulembue will grant an audience to the leaders of Proconsumer and of other Southern African consumers' defence associations, who are attending a conference in Maputo.

Among the matters to be discussed during the audience include propspects for law on consumer protection and the recent importation of 13,000 tonnes of wheat flour, contaminated with the banned additive potassium bromate.

The flour was imported from Belgium by the Mozambique international trading company.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

December 14, 1996


Science and Health;
Cholera In Zaire and Rwanda


BYLINE: World Health Organization (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 106 words


 

Geneva - Cholera in Zaire: A total of 1133 cases and 23 deaths have occurred in Goma Hospital since 16 November and the local WHO epidemiologist reports that the number of cases has now stabilized.

Cholera in Rwanda: A total of 106 cases and 10 deaths have been reported since 16 November in Runda transit camp, 20 kms from Kigali. WHO is supporting the Ministry of Health in follow up and close monitoring of diarrhoeal diseases at commune level, particularly among recent returnees.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


366 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 14, 1996


United States and Africa;
Rwandan Refugees in Tanzania on the Move


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Washington - Bureau For Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA), Great Lakes Update, Fact Sheet No. 4 -- December 13, 1996.

Tanzania: The situation in the Tanzania refugee camps is evolving rapidly and confirmed information is sketchy. The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reported that on December 12, Rwandan refugees began to pour out of the Ngara refugee camps in Western Tanzania and most camps are now partially or completely emptied. This includes Benaco camp, which previously held 150, 000 and Lumasi camp, which previously held 113,000. Most refugees started to move east, but some were blocked by Tanzanian military troops. Those intercepted by Tanzanian forces turned around and headed back towards the camps, and possibly towards the border with Rwanda. UNHCR has stated that the Ngara camps will not be reconstituted. Oxfam and the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies have established water stations every five kms along the main route from Ngara to the Rwandan border. It is unclear how many refugees passed the Tanzanian blockade and are still headed east. 

All refugees have a two week supply of food and are in good condition, as there was low malnutrition in the camps, most refugees have been vaccinated and they are carrying shelter materials with them. The availability of water and health services east of Ngara is unknown.

Also from the Ngara region, UNHCR reports that about 35,000 from Kitali, Lukole, Keza and Mushuhuru camps are reportedly heading south, possibly towards Zambia and/or Malawi. If indeed they are heading that way, the refugees will first reach the Kibondo, Kasulu and Kigoma camps where UNHCR is currently assisting an estimated 230,000 Burundian and 36,000 Zairian refugees, along with about 1,200 Rwandan refugees.

UNHCR also reported that on December 7-8, about 23,000 Rwandan refugees from the Kagenya and Rubwero camps in the Karagwe area of Tanzania, north of Ngara, dispersed to avoid repatriation. UNHCR located several groups of these refugees and persuaded about 4,000 to return to the camps for later repatriation to Rwanda. There are some reports of additional movements out of the Karagwe region camps, but no numbers have been provided. Food distributions were scheduled to occur in the Karagwe camps today, which may trigger refugee movements.

There are a total of 530,000 Rwandan refugees in Tanzania and an additional 5,000 have returned to Rwanda since September. The Government of Tanzania has called for the repatriation of all Rwandan refugees by December 31 but has declared that no forced repatriation would occur.

Rwanda: The main route from the Ngara area camps to Rwanda is north west, via the Rusumo crossing into Kibungo Prefecture in Rwanda. A USAID Disaster Assistance Response Team (DART) representative and a Food for Peace officer watched an estimated 1,800 Rwandan refugees cross into Rwanda on December 13 aboard 11 Tanzanian Red Crescent trucks, via the Rusumo crossing. UNHCR and NGOs have been focusing their preparedness efforts on the Rusumo-Rwamagana corridor and are accelerating their efforts to prepare for a mass return, which, given current population movements, could begin as early as tomorrow. Following a December 4, meeting in Kibungo involving Government of Rwanda (GOR), UNHCR, NGO and DART representatives, NGOs began to establish water points, health posts and biscuit distributions along the route from the Rusumo border crossing to Rwanteru, 18 kms inside the border; from Kirehe (located 25 kms inside the border) to Remera (located 68 kms inside the border); and from Kabarondo (located 76 kms inside the border) to Rwamagana (located 107 kms inside the border.) An NGO has been designated the lead agency along each corridor. USAID/DART reports that, as of December 13, sufficient water, health and biscuit distributions points were in place. A USAID/DART representative will deploy to Kibungo tomorrow.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


367 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 14, 1996


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 57 on the Great Lakes (12/14)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Nairobi - Tanzanian troops are surrounding groups of the more than 300,000 Rwandan refugees who left their camps in the Ngara area on Thursday and seeking to prevent them from dispersing, according to media reports. Aid agencies and journalists are not being allowed access to these areas, fuelling speculation that the troops will make a concerted effort to encourage refugees to return to Rwanda. To date there have been no reports of the use of force by Tanzanian soldiers, but the authorities have reiterated that the 31 December deadline remains in place.

Today, WFP reports that a group of over 100,000 refugees in the Kitale-Keza area to the south of Ngara, are moving in an easterly direction into the interior of Tanzania. The group is reported to have formed a column 20 kms long. It is unclear whether there are troops present in the area and whether the movement of refugees to the east will be blocked. 

Yesterday, Tanzanian troops allowed refugees, who had left Benaco, Lumasi and Musuhura camps on Thursday afternoon, but who had begun to make their way back to the camps, to rest. Later, the troops issued orders that the refugees had to continue on to the Rwandan border. It appears, however, that the army's attempts to prevent refugees from returning to their camps were largely unsuccessful. Yesterday UNHCR was expecting tens of thousands of refugees to be at the Rwandan border by nightfall, but reporters at the border this afternoon say there are no signs of large numbers of refugees.

About 2,500 refugees joined UNHCR's repatriation convoys back to Rwanda yesterday, the largest in a single day so far. Since the beginning of December, 5,261 refugees have returned to Rwanda voluntarily; this compares to a total number of 3,279 voluntary returnees between 1 January and 30 November this year. At the same time, 7,000 of the 23,000 refugees who had fled their camps in the Karagwe area were reported to have gone back to their camps, while about 500 arrived in Uganda.

The nearest crossing point into Rwanda is about 20 kms north west of Ngara at Rusumo. The ICRC, IFRC and Oxfam have established health, meeting and water points every five kms along this main route to the border, while aid agencies are also scaling up their activities within Rwanda. They are reported to have established water points, health posts and biscuit distributions along a 100 km route from the Rusumo border crossing to Rwanteru, Kirehe, Remera, Kabarondo and Rwamagana in Rwanda.

Zaire's Interior Minister, Kamanda wa Kamanda, said yesterday that Zaire does not recognize a ceasefire called by rebels of the Alliance of Democratic Forces in eastern Zaire. Speaking to Reuters, Mr Kamanda said, 'We do not recognise this ceasefire. In this war we believe that the other side is the Government of Rwanda and those who are supporting Rwanda so we shall do everything in our means to recover lost territory.'

On Monday, heads of state and government from Great Lakes countries will meet in Nairobi to discuss the situation in eastern Zaire. The Secretary General of the OAU, Salim Ahmed Salim, will attend, as will Julius Nyerere, founding president of Tanzania and currently mediator for the peace talks on Burundi.

Nairobi, 14 November 1996, 13:30 GMT (ENDS)

Africa News


December 14, 1996


South Africa;
ANC Welcomes Extension of Amnesty Date


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Johannesburg - The extension of the amnesty cut-off date and deadline for applications by President Nelson Mandela today Friday 13 December, underlines the deep seated commitment of the ANC to the process of reconciliation and nation building.

The ANC believes the decision by the President would not have been taken lightly but in the best interests of the country and its people. In this regard, the ANC gives its support to the decision and calls on all other political parties to do likewise.

The ANC calls on all those implicated in heinous deeds of the past, gross violations of human rights and indeed those who committed crimes against humanity, to reciprocate the goodwill of the government and President Nelson Mandela, to co-operate to the fullest extent of the law with the Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

Issued by Department of Information and Publicity P.O. Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107, 13 December 1996

Africa-at-Large;
Boutros-Ghali Congratulates Successor

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - The Outgoing United Nations Secretary- General Boutros Boutros-Ghali on Friday congratulated his successor, Kofi Annan of Ghana, who is billed to take over as head of the organization on Jan. 1, 1997.

Botros-Ghali's spokeswoman, Sylvana Foa, said "the Secretary-General has worked closely with Mr. Annan through these past five years and wishes him every success."

370 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 14, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Brain Drain Cited As Cause of Africa's Backwardness


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

MUTARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Brain drain has been cited as one of the major contributors to Africa's low economic growth.

This was said here Saturday by the Vice-Chancellor of the Zimbabwe-based Africa University, Bishop Emilio De Carvalho, when he addressed hundreds of people gathered to witness the institution's second graduation ceremony since its establishment in 1992. 

Bishop Carvalho appealed to African governments and private institutions to ensure university graduates from the continent found decent jobs so they could contribute to the development of their countries.

He said ignorance, under-development, poverty, illiteracy and paucity of skills and resources were still the major constraints affecting the enjoyment of prosperity for the majority of African people.

"The greatest problem with our continent is not so much the lack of qualified educated citizens, it is indeed the lack of profiting from the thousands of national graduands who leave schools and universities each year.

"Africa stands at the crossroads, either we stand firm and decide to raise our own people from the ashes of ignorance and poverty or we are going to continue to deviate our attention and action, making us to develop peoples and nations other than our own," said Carvalho.

He stressed the need for African governments to empower students in their respective countries with relevant values and skills that would ensure self- dependency through provision of educational opportunities to all.

The bishop was speaking at a colourful graduation ceremony for 21 students from Angola, Tanzania and Zimbabwe, who received degrees in agriculture and natural resources and divinity.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


371 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 14, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Annan Pledges To Redefine UN Objectives


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - The United Nations Secretary-General- elect, Kofi Annan of Ghana, says his priority will be to redefine the organization's objectives in the post cold-war era.

In a statement Friday after the security council voted unanimously to recommend him to the UN General Assembly as the seventh UN Secretary-General, Annan said: "it is time to agree on what the UN can and must do, and what it cannot do. 

"Those choices will require consensus and cooperation amongst all member states," said Annan, whose appointment is expected to be ratified by the 185- member assembly next Tuesday.

He noted that the collective will and combined resources of the member states, "their vision of what we will strive to achieve together", would determine the effectiveness of the UN in the years ahead.

Annan called for "a time of healing" to restore confidence between governments and the UN to help replenish its financial strength and its political and moral authority, rebuild its sense of common purpose and maintain its trust and cooperation among the peoples of the world.

He pledged to sustain the morale, motivation and performance of the UN staff members, whom he called the organisation's greatest assets.

"I accept with humility, and also with determination, my nomination by the security council," the 58-year-old Ghanaian said.

"If the General Assembly acts favourably on the recommendation of the Security Council, I shall dedicate myself to pursuing these objectives, to which I have devoted most of my life, with vigour and full commitment," he added.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


372 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 14, 1996


Mozambique;
EU Funds For Mozambican Consumers Project


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The European Union is to provide 150,000 US dollars to finance a consumer education project in Mozambique.

The project, to be carried out by Proconsumer, the country's recently founded consumers' defence association, will be advised by the Portuguese National Consumer Defence Institute (INDC). 

INDC's deputy chairman, Joaquim Carapico, who has been in Mozambique since Monday at the invitation of Proconsumers told a press conference Saturday that it was up to Mozambicans to set up their own model of consumer protection, in accordance with the specific realities of the country.

He stressed the need for civil society to educate ordinary citizens on their rights as consumers. Such education should start early, he said, "when consumers are still children, in school, and in everything concerning their life".

Carapico said that the passing of a legislation defending consumers would be a significant step in helping citizens understand their rights and duties in this area.

According to the chairman of Proconsumer, Francisco Lichuca, the consumer education project seeks to make citizens aware of their rights and persuade businesses to comply with their obligations.

Next Tuesday, the mozambican parliament's chairman, Eduardo Mulembue will grant an audience to the leaders of Proconsumer and of other Southern African consumers' defence associations, who are attending a conference in Maputo.

Among the matters to be discussed during the audience include propspects for law on consumer protection and the recent importation of 13,000 tonnes of wheat flour, contaminated with the banned additive potassium bromate.

The flour was imported from Belgium by the Mozambique international trading company.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


373 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 15, 1996


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (12/09 - 12/015)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Geneva - News for Week 50 from 09 - 15.12.1996

17.10.96 Germany: Parliamentary debate

A parliamentary motion of the German deputy E.Brecht (SPD), who directed the German parliamentary mission in W.S. in April 1996, asks to the government to intensify its initiatives, particularly inside the European Union and the Euro-Mediterranean dialogue, in order to move on the implementation of the peace plan in W.S.. In his answer the Minister of Foreign Affairs declares that the government shares the concerns expressed by the motion. The German Government has sustained the efforts of the UN in order to restart the peace process. In its mind the UN have still to play a central role for the solution of this conflict. It will work in the Security Council in favour of the maintain of the MINURSO. A total withdrawal would be dangerous. War could start again. The German government will work for the continuing and intensifying of the efforts of the UN. It will maintain its strict neutrality, its contacts with both parties and favor the direct dialogue. In its mind the problem of the POWs must be resolved urgently for humanitarian reasons, in the frame of the UN peace plan. ( 66 POWs have been released meanwhile) 

Answering to a question the German government declaredthat the humanitarian support of Germany for the years 1988 to 1996, mainly food for the refugee camps near Tindouf, amounts more than 6 millions $.

05.12.96 Autonomy or independance ?

Ahmad Alaoui, councelor of King Hassan II declares that the King offers the regional autonomy of the territory of Western Sahara to the Polisario Front, in condition of its renouncement of total independence. This proposal was already discussed in occasion of the contacts between Moroco and the Polisario Front last September and is connected with the Moroccan project of regionalization which divides the kingdom in 16 provinces with economical, social and cultural autonomy. A Polisario representative in Madrid rejects the Moroccan offer, saying his organisation is fighting for independence and a referendum has to take place. (El Pais)

10.12.96 Eastern Timor - Western Sahara

In occasion of the attribution of the Nobel Peace Prize to him and to bishop X. Belo, Mr. Ramos-Horta, spokesman of the Resistance in Eastern Timor, said: "In the process of decolonization of non-autonomous territories, self- determination allowed nearly always the independence of those territories. But it is not the case in the majority of the conflicts remaining today. The case of Western Sahara and Eastern Timor are two examples. In the case of W.S. the UN make themselves accomplice of a minor regional power."

10.12.96 Human Rights in Morocco

According to OMDH ( Organisation Marocaine des Droits de l'Homme) the human rights situation has worried in 1996 after 3 years of improvement. In a declaration of 32 pages a lot of violations of human rights are listened. The Moroccan H.R. organisation announces a 3 month campaign against torture used by the security forces. An other Moroccan H.R. organisation, AMDH (Association Marocaine des Droits de l'Homme), numbered 9 individuals died in 1996 after torture and illtreatment in the police stations, 57 "disappeared" and 70 persons still jailed as political prisoners.

10.12.96 Fishing agreement

Morocco will not renew its fishing agreement with the European Union (concluded in december 1995 for 4 years) for ecological but nor political reasons. The Moroccan government just signed a cooperation agreement with the United States in which it commits itself to protect marine wealth in return of support for the renewal of its fishing fleet.
