LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


374 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


East Africa;
WFP Great Lakes Situation Report No. 39


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1452 words


 

Rome - RWANDA: Some 105,000 Rwandan refugees returned from Tanzania on 16 December. The cumulative number from 14 to 16 December is estimated at 143, 500. The majority of those returning in the past few days is coming from the Ngara camps however some 20 trucks loaded with returnees from the Karagwe camps arrived at the Rusumo border point yesterday. These returnees subsequently repatriated to Rwanda. The refugee inflow is continuing today at the same rate as yesterday.

All returnees are entering Rwanda at Rusumo (Kibungo) with most walking the first 20 km to Rwenteru. Some vulnerable refugees are receiving transportation from the border point from IFRC/RRC, which was the only organisation yesterday allowed to enter the area 20 km from the border. From Rwenteru, those returnees who originate from Byumba prefecture are being transported to their prefecture while the majority, who originate from Kibungo prefecture, continue to walk to their home communes. 

WFP distributed high-energy biscuits to 40,000 returnees (12 mt) yesterday from two distribution points between Nyakarambi and Curazo on the way to Kibungo town. Today, WFP is distributing high-energy biscuits from Kibehe located 4 km from Nyakarambi towards Kibungo.

The WFP Umutara sub-office has provided 3 mt (10,000 daily rations) of high- energy biscuits to the NGO, ARC, for distribution to returnees walking along the road between Kayonza and Murambi. An additional 198 mt of mixed commodities is being sent to the communes in Umutara today.

WFP is planning on commencing weekly food distributions to repatriates in the Rusumo commune of Kibungo, from where some 100,000 returnees originate from the 105,000 who have repatriated thus far. These distributions are expected to begin as soon as today.

While monitoring the nutritional situation, WFP plans to cut food rations by 70 per cent after the first month of assistance. WFP aims to prevent dependency on external food assistance and encourage the returnees to become self-sufficient. WFP will assist with reintegration through food-for-work programmes.

From 13 to 16 December, WFP and NGO partners (ADRA, AEF, AHA, ASS, CARE, Caritas, Concern, CRR, CRS, EER, GAA, IFRC, Ingabo, IRC, LWF, MEC, MSF, Red Barnet, Salvation Army, Trocaire, World Vision and World Relief) distributed approximately 150 mt of food commodities to the communes (cereals, pulses and oil). This represents 8,952 persons assisted with a monthly ration. The cumulative total since 16 November now stands at 10,759 mt (644,251 monthly rations).

ZAIRE: A UN mission, including WFP, to the Lobutu area came back to Kisangani yesterday and estimated that there were approximately 120,000 refugees and internally-displaced persons (IDPs) in the Lobutu area. Refugees originate from camps in the Bukavu and Goma regions. More refugees are still on the road with reports that the number could increase to 150,000 by the end of this week. The adults appear to be in satisfactory condition however the children seem affected by the first signs of malnutrition and present the symptoms of severe dehydration.

WFP is planning on airlifting into Kisangani 120 mt of food items (including 20 mt of biscuits) using a Zairian transporter (Boeing 707). The transportation of food onwards to Lubutu/Tingi Tingi, to assist the estimated 120,000 refugees and IDPs, will be carried out in collaboration with La Procure (the logistics service branch of the Catholic Church) with vehicles and/or using available small aircraft.

A Coordination Committee has been established in Kisangani to coordinate relief assistance to the affected population. Today the first meeting is planned.

A DHA/WFP/UNICEF mission to Kisangani, Lubutu and Shabunda out of Kinshasa is scheduled for tomorrow, 18 December.

UGANDA: 2,400 Rwandan refugees, coming from the Karagwe region in Tanzania, have been registered in Orutshinga, Uganda. WFP carried out an assessment mission to the affected area on 16 December.

200 Zairian refugees arrived in Nebbi, in northwest Uganda. More could be expected to arrive in the event of a further advance north of the Banyamulenge/Alliance rebels in Eastern Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


375 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Nigeria;
A Deadly Ritual: Farmers And Pastoralists Clash in Sokoto


BYLINE: Fatai Salami, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Lagos - If anyone had any misgivings about the decision of the Sokoto State administrator to set up a State Intelligence Committee, such misgivings must have been vanquished by the tragedy that befell the people of Gwadabawa local government area of the state two weeks ago.

The local government area has been thrown into mourning by a clash between farmers and cattle rearers which left seven people dead and over 10 others injured.

The clash, according to investigations, was triggered by a major misunderstanding between farmers and Tuaga Zaki village and some pastoralists over the clearance of remnants of animal feed in a farmland by the latter. A passerby attracted by the exchange of words intervened in an attempt to amicably resolve the issue. The peacemaker was yet to achieve result when the tale bearers rushed to town with incorrect versions of what was happening. While some claimed that some farmers had descended on innocent Fulani cattle rearers, others said that it was the troublesome cattle rearers who were attempting to strangle the farmers. With relations between both parties already strained by past misunderstandings arising from inadequate grazing land and the absence of clearly demarcated cattle routes, the result was a free-for-all fight in which dangerous weapons were freely used. 

Last week, the state government made spirited efforts to reassure the injured farmers, who were complaining bitterly that they taken to the hospital only to be abandoned there, and that the Fulani cattle rearers have been allowed to go scot-free, instead of being punished to prevent future occurrence of such tragic clashes.

Dismissing the allegations, Rasheed Raji, the state military administrator, told newsmen that the fight between the farmers and the cattle rearers took place at night and that by the time the news reached the police the next day, the pastoralists had vanished. He explained that although he was away in Abuja when the clash took place, the secretary to the state government, in the company of some other top government officials, visited the village with the police and the state security service when government house got information about the unfortunate incident. Raji said that the injured persons "were taken to the hospital and materials were given to them as assistance from the state government," adding: "For anybody to come and tell you that we have abandoned them is very wrong and very, very unfair."

The state administrator stressed the need for dialogue in settling problems between farmers and cattle rearers, adding that the solution does not lie in taking up arms at the least provocation. "All we need to do, " he said, "is to dialogue with them (the pastoralist). If we keep on fighting, we continue to lose people, but we can dialogue. When they come, show them their routes. If we can dialogue, since we know it's an annual event, I think the problem will be reduced if not eliminated.

Raji recalled that it was his administration's desire to find a lasting solution to the problem that informed its decision to establish the State Intelligence Committee. The committee, inaugurated November 21, is headed by the secretary to the state government, with the directors-general for agriculture, establishments, local government affairs, health and education as members. Other members are representatives of the army, police, SSS, Customs, Prisons, Immigration, National Drug Law Enforcement Agency and Federal Road Safety Commission . The committee is among other things, to look into farmers/pastoralist relations, land disputes with a view to advising the State Security Council on the best way to tackle such problems.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


376 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Sierra Leone;
After Five years of Strife, Truce at Last


BYLINE: Festus Owete, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Lagos - It was an elated Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, Sierra Leonean president, who declared some days ago that the real enemy of his country is now hunger and poverty. The president's pronouncement stemmed from the peace accord signed November 30 in Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire, between his government and the rebel group, the United Revolutionary Front, hopefully closing a chapter that opened when Foday Sankoh, a former army corporal, led a group of armed men in March 1991 to launch an attack on the hitherto placid West African Country.

Since then an estimated 10,000 civilians have been killed while half of the population have fled the country. Last two weeks peace talks which signified an end to one of Africa's most brutal civil wars were hosted by Henri Konan Bedie, the Ivorien president, who had earlier in the year over similar talks. Sources close to the talks indicated that the "perseverance" of Bedie was the catalyst for reaching a compromise, as the conference was almost marred by differences over the wording of the peace agreement. 

With the signing of the pact, the Kabbah administration has achieved a feat which eluded his three immediate predecessors in office. Joseph Momoh, whose ouster was sought by the rebel group, handled the situation with kid's glove. His successor, Valentine Strasser, inherited the conflict, with all his efforts to contain it proving futile. It was a frustrated Strasser who openly criticised leaders of ECOWAS member nations at the organisation's summit in 1993 for leaving Sierra Leone in the cold while doing a lot for the neighboring Liberia. Following Strasser's removal from power in January this year, Julius Maada Bio, the new leader, brokered peace talks with the rebels in February at the height of preparations for the multi-party elections held next month. The talks attended by international observers including representatives of the UN, OAU and Commonwealth of Nations, were marked by smiles, handshakes and a communal prayer. This two factions found one common ground: the discontinuation of the electoral process as a way of laying a better foundation for the future of democracy in the country, founded by British humanitarians in 1787. The agreement was, however, of no effect, as local and international pressure sustained the transition to civil rule programme which subsequently brought Kabbah to power.

On assumption of power in March, the administration of Kabbah initiated new peace talks, expressing optimism that the rebels would lay down their arms before the end of the year. Although one of such talks was suspended in May by Kabbah on the basis of minor disagreements, his government remained committed to restoring peace to the troubled country. Amidst feelings of disappointment occasioned by the suspension of the talks, Nath Wellington, economic and development minister, told the newsmen that "differences have been narrowed to the extent that we are poised for the signature of a formal peace agreement anytime from now."

In spite of sporadic violence in the last few months, the government was encouraged to end the war by certain positive developments, notably the release of captives and the surrendering of some of the rebels. In response to Kabbah's ultimatum to the rebels to lay down arms by December 1 or "face the military option," no fewer than 750 members of the United Revolutionary Front in various parts of the country gave themselves up at the Sierra Leonean embassy in Monrovia, the Liberian capital, last month. Earlier, about 600 hostages held since the outbreak of the war five years ago were freed, while another 200 civilians, including women and children, regained their freedom after being held captive for two years.

As if showing signs of exhaustion, Sankoh in October urged the OAU to once again intervene in the crisis, a development which may have given rise to the generous offer to the rebel who, last month, was allowed to return to his jungle base in Sierra Leone to consult his guerrillas on the stalled peace process.

Analysts, however, caution that the time has not come for the real celebration. Their reason: It may yet be a pyrrhic victory for the Kabbah administration, which is sure to face an upsurge in crime, an unfortunate development usually associated with postwar periods.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


377 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Nigeria;
Shaping Up For the Next Millennium


BYLINE: Akaninyene Esiere, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1694 words


 

Lagos - As the 21st century inches closer, the various sectors of the Nigerian economy are undergoing a great overhaul to meet the demands of what is expected to be a more sophisticated market place. Old and boring ways of doing business are fast being discarded. New business cultures tailored to meet the taste of the no-nonsense and impatient foreign investors that increasingly trooping to "virgin" Nigeria, have become the in-thing. Bureaucratic bottlenecks are being hacked to the barest minimum in an economy notorious for redtapism. New technologies - by Nigerian standards - are making speedy service delivery a pleasant surprise.

Nowhere else are these "alien" ways of conducting business as pronounced as in the banking industry. The spectre of distress notwithstanding, banks are increasing reforms in the economy, internationalising the system is only a question of time and that for banks to play their pivotal roles as investment catalysts, they too must learn the ways of their better-run international cousins. Besides, fierce but healthy competition is expected to be the cutting edge in Nigeria's banking environment in the 21st century. 

It was these considerations that moved the egg heads at the six-year-old Liberty Merchant Bank, arguably one of Nigeria's three most profitable merchant banks, to assemble at the Training and Conference Centre, Ogere, Ogun State, in October to brainstorm over the bank's future. The "Ogere Retreat" was to give birth to the bank's Three-Year Medium-Term Visioning Process running through April 1997 to the dawn of the year 2000. Liberty's managers hope that by March 2000 when the process might have run its course, the bank would have attracted happy, loyal customers who would see the bank as their natural choice, thus enabling it to achieve a balance sheet would be 2.5 times its prevailing N3.8 billion ; a pre-tax profit N1.5 billion; a five- branched bank, (two more than the current three); ;as well as a highly contented and skilled workforce.

To achieve these, says Paul Kokoricha, the bank's assistant general manager, management information systems, Liberty intends to invest in relevant technologies "that will support our staff, make us respond to customers faster and not make us suffer competition disadvantage." In the first year of its "rolling plan," the bank intends to give its customers remote access to their systems, thus ensuring that customers gain access to their accounts from their offices or homes. Electronic mail is to be introduced in the second year, while fully automated electronic banking would come on stream by 2000, making it possible for a linkage of all its branches via satellite. This will, of course, not come cheap; Liberty hopes to invest between N20 million and n26 million on new technologies in the first year alone.

Perhaps the most ambitious bank in the area of new technologies is the United Bank for Africa. The bank is going the whole hog of floating a subsidiary banking technology company, a satellite telecommunication system that will ensure that the bank's services are rendered on-line in all its 202 branches nationwide. Ogie Eboigbe,UBA's corporate affairs manager, told that Sani Abacha, the head of state, has already granted a license for the subsidiary and that the bank intends to make the services available to other banks that are willing to pay to be "hooked." The acquisition of the license further enhances UBA's profile in the area of new technologies, as it is about the only Nigerian member of the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication. Though Eboighe would not say how much it costs, UBA already operates a dial-up modem and its 1995 Information Technology Plan is expected to transform the bank's branch network into what is called one- stop centres.

Union Bank with the largest network of branches in the country is equally investing in new information technologies. Though Kabir Dangogo, its public relations manager, shied away from elaborating for fear of "our competitors," he confirmed that two-thirds of the bank's 260 branches have been computerised, with full computerisation expected to be completed soon. Though he would not dabble into specifics, Dangogo told that Union Bank is embarking on a new concept that "will revolutionise our service." Liberty, UBA and Union Bank are, however, not alone, as virtually all other networth banks are also embarking on the upgrading of their information systems.

The banks are equally embarking on increased training of their staff. Here, Union Bank seems to take the lead. Though there are no comparable statistics, Dangogo said that as the largest employer of labour in the industry, they are the biggest trainer of manpower, "as it is our top priority." Liberty, according to Kokoricha, is voting between three and five per cent of its pre- tax profit for manpower development alone. Going by its 1996 performance, that would amount to roughly N15 million this year, a big investment on what Kokoricha described as "strategic intent to improve the quality of our people, step up recruiting hurdles and build a learning culture within the bank." To demonstrate the imperatives of human resource development, banks which can afford it are sending their top management staff abroad for courses. One of the latest beneficiaries is Fola Adeola, managing director of Guaranty Trust Bank, debatably the second most profitable new generation bank, who vacated his cosy office for a six-month training programme at America's Harvard Business School, possibly the world's topmost business school.

Even banks which cannot afford the prohibitive cost of overseas courses are sending their staff for various forms of training, here at home, especially at the elitist Lagos Business School.

The banks are, however, holding close to their chest, specific innovative strategies they are embarking on to satisfy their customers apart from the accuracy and speed guaranteed by the investment in new technologies. Either for fear of having their innovations snatched by competitors or because the new financial products are still awaiting Central Bank approval, bankers are unveiling very little. Among the innovations that have already seen the light of day is First Bank's Western Union Money Transfer, where money from any part of the world could be conveniently sent to anyone resident in Nigeria without the person necessarily banking with the bank. Union Bank has equally introduced its Easycash automated teller machine in some parts of Lagos to enable account holders cash their "cheque" with ease and without congesting the counter. On its part, Liberty Merchant Bank is diversifying into "fairly new areas of business" such as specific Investment Banking and Trust Company, it last week embarked on the most ambitious unit trust scheme in the country and with a lot of foreign input, requiring a stake-holder to cough out a minimum of N20,000. Apart from its Easycash, Union Bank is packaging a "new concept" to meet the yearning of its customers. And with its London and South African offices, the bank hopes to handle the bulk of foreign investment transactions that are expected to come into the Nigerian economy. The bank's optimism was reflected by Dangogo when he boasted: "I don't see how they (foreign investors) will come into Nigeria without going through Union Bank.

To further polish their ambition of cornering plum businesses, many banks are moving to high-profile headquarters. The imposing UBA House on Marina, Lagos, is an example. The Afribank building on Broad Street in Lagos is nearing completion. GTB has already moved to its more spacious Victoria Island head office and Liberty is awaiting CBN approval to relocated. But perhaps the most ambitious structure is the Union Bank House on Marina. The 32-storey building which may be ready for occupation by the first quarter of next year, prides itself as the tallest structure in West Africa and has a helicopter landing facility for cash movement and in case of fire.

Added to these, bankers are becoming more, courteous and customer-friendly, constantly plastering their lips with smiles. Some of the banks, such as Societe Generale and Union, have full fledged customer relations officers with whom customers who receive unsatisfactory services can lodge their complaints. Union Bank has even gone further by opening a hot line for customers to phone managers and complain if they were not satisfactorily attended to.

The truth is, these banks that are copying the "ways of the West" don't have a choice. They are aware that to stay in business and be profitable they have got to move with the times. They equally know how fully well that a free market that is beckoning on Nigeria will bring in an unprecedented volume of business and that only highly sophisticated banks can cope. In addition, by next month, the CBN is going to divest itself of its retail banking role, thereby further putting pressure on the banks. But above all else, the era of megabucks for the banks that adequately reform themselves is just by the door- step.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


378 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Nigeria;
Visions for The Giant


BYLINE: Peter Akpona, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Lagos - Amidst support from the World Bank and the IMF, the Vision 2010 Committee reconvenes to map out strategies for tackling the task before it.

Two weeks after its inauguration, the Vision 2010 Committee reconvenes in Abuja, the country's to weave the plot for the effective tackling of its assignment. Unlike the inauguration and plenary sessions which were mainly ceremonial, the 173 member committee will this time meet for two days (Tuesday and Wednesday), for a seminar to acquaint members with the nitty- gritty of their work.

The committee will then break into sub-committees to handle sub-themes of the vision. Ernest Shonekan, committee chairman, has identified 12 such sub- themes, among them norms and standards, good and stable governance, elimination of corruption and accelerated economic growth. His committee has, accordingly, been slated to be split into 12 sub-committees, each to be made up of people with similar interests. 

At the inauguration November 27, the head of state had given the Vision 2010 Committee a terms of reference including defining for Nigeria its correct bearing and sense of economic, political, social and cultural direction; setting appropriate goals, target and time-frame for achieving set economic, political, social and cultural objectives; as well as suggesting comprehensive practical solutions for redeeming Nigeria's external image, and protecting the nation's environment and ecology. In addition, the committee is expected to design a master plan for launching Nigeria as a leading sporting nation in the world. It is also charged with prescribing specific roles for the public and private sectors in economic and social activities, as well as devising means for ensuring proper and credible performance in the roles so assigned to each sector for the attainment of an effective, comprehensive and qualitative health care delivery system and an accelerated agricultural production.

Abacha had in his National Day address in which he hinted on the setting up of the committee, told the nation that in order to obliterate the economic and other sectoral calamities which have bedeviled the nation since the oil boom era. "an articulate formula is needed to bring the nation back to course. " He identified profligacy in government, poor programme implementation and non-planning which made the nation to depend solely on oil, as some of the ills which the committee would seek solutions to. The head of state lamented that previous attempts at planning were done by civil servants "with limited vision, "which informed the choice of technocrats (including traditional rulers and successful traders) to dream for the nation under Vision 2010.

Perhaps most significant is the plan by Vision 2010 to identify and redefine the nation's values. Such values, according to committee chairman Shonekan, include social discipline, respect for elders and constituted authorities, hard work, honesty and incorruptibility. As Shonekan put it, "We must now go back to our roots, rediscover the best of African tradition and re-inculcate these virtues in our citizenry."

Even before it begins work, Vision 2010 seems to have become the darling of corporate bodies within the country as well as to the international community. The World Bank has applauded the setting up of the committee and has even concluded plans to send its poverty alleviation team to the country early next year to liaise with the appropriate sub-committee of Vision 2010 that will fashion out the strategies that would lead to the eradication of poverty in Nigeria by 2010.

The interest of the World Bank in project is said to be informed by the similarity of purpose it shares with the Vision 2010 especially in the area of poverty alleviation. Even the fastidious International Monetary Fund has signified interest in the work of the committee. Shonekan disclosed last week that the IMF has pledged to assist Nigeria in the formulation and actualization of the vision. On their part, some corporate bodies within the country have organised seminars aimed at generating ideas which they hope to give as inputs to the work of the committee.

Encouraged by the enthusiasm of these organisations, and the need to involve all Nigerians in the vision, the committee has called for memoranda from interested persons, groups and institutions. With the interest the vision now generates locally and internationally, the nation can hardly wait for September 1997, when government expects to receive the official report of the visioners.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


379 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Kenya;
Amnesty Calls Kenya to Release More Political Prisoners


BYLINE: Human Rights Watch (New York)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

New York - Human Rights Watch/Africa today welcomed the release on bail of Kenya's prominent opposition figure Koigi wa Wamwere on December 13, 1996, and called on the Kenyan government to grant bail to Koigi's two co- defendants Charles Kuria Wamwere and Godfrey Ngengi Njuguna who remain in prison.

Mr. Wamwere's application was granted on medical grounds and bail was set at Kshs. 200,000 (approximately U.S. $3,500). "Releasing Koigi on bail is a welcome and long-overdue step which will hopefully be followed by bail to his co-accused," noted Executive Director Peter Takirambudde. "But the real question is: when will the Kenyan government end its political manipulation of the judicial system?" 

Koigi wa Wamwere, a former member of parliament and founder of a human rights organization, is a long-time critic of the government of President Daniel arap Moi and has been continually harassed by the government. Mr. Wamwere is a former political prisoner, adopted by Amnesty International as a prisoner of conscience while detained on treason charges between October 1990 and January 1993. The charges were eventually dropped, but Mr. Wamwere was held without bail during that time and complained of mistreatment at the hands of security officials. In September 1993, Mr. Wamwere was arrested along with others and charged with possessingseditious publications which included leaflets published by his human rights organization on the issue of ethnic violence. He was held for one month before being released on bail.

Mr. Wamwere was arrested again on November 5, 1993, along with fourteen others and accused by the government of attempting to raid a police station in Nakuru and to rob two police constables of their rifles on November 2, 1993. The initial press conference announcing the raid described the perpetrators without reference to Mr. Wamwere or the others arrested. The government eventually released or dropped charges against twelve of those initially arrested with Mr. Wamwere.

The government has continued to pursue charges of armed robbery against Mr. Wamwere, Charles Kuria Wamwere (his brother) and Godfrey Ngengi Njuguna. The three defendants were convicted in the lower court proceeding, which resulted in a sentence of four years and six strokes of the cane in October 1995. The trial was criticized by local and international human rights groups and bar organizations for not meeting international standards. The trial is continuing on appeal. Until his release on bail on November 13, 1996, Mr. Wamwere was held in Nakuru prison, where there is severe overcrowding, diet is poor and prisoners have frequently been denied adequate medical treatment. Charles Kuria Wamwere and Godfrey Ngengi Njuguna remain in Nakuru prison to date.

The political nature of the trial is underscored by the fact that the week before Mr. Wamwere's release on bail, the Chief Justice in Nairobi asked for the files to be sent to him in Nairobi. Under Kenyan law, the Chief Justice need not see a file in order for a bail application to be approved. Human Rights Watch/Africa shares the belief of other human rights organizations that the arrest of Mr. Wamwere and his co-accused is part of a pattern of harassment of human rights activists, political opposition figures and government critics.

Human Rights Watch/Africa called on the Kenyan government to restore judicial independence and end its practice of using criminal charges to harass government critics. Human Rights Watch/Africa also called on the government to release on bail Mr. Wamwere's two co-defendants currently being held under the same charges.

Human Rights Watch 485 Fifth Avenue New York, NY 10017-6104 TEL: 212/972- 8400 FAX: 212/972-0905 E-mail: hrwnyc@hrw.org. 1522 K Street, N.W. Washington D.C. 20005 TEL: 202/371-6592 FAX: 202/371-0124 E-mail: hrwdc@hrw.org


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


380 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Angola;
Angola Loses Wildlife In Armed Conflict


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Angola might have lost 90 percent of its larger mammals, in addition to other wildlife, killed during the civil war between the government in Luanda and anti-government Angolan forces called UNITA, a study by environmentalists shows.

The study, by the Southern African Research and Documentation Center in Harare -- in collaboration with the International Conservation Union -- is on the impact of armed conflict in the Southern Africa.

Contained in the 1994 report on the "State of the Environment in Southern Africa", researchers say that similar destruction of wildlife occurred in Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Namibia and Zambia following fighting in those countries. 

Southern Africa had been engaged in wars for independence lasting decades. In addition, Angola and Mozambique have experienced civil wars between nationalistic forces and those opposed to socialist rule in their country.

After years of fighting Portuguese colonialists, Angola's civil war started after independence in 1975 and ended formally 20 years later. There is now a United Nations-sponsored cease-fire in the country.

Environmentalists say that armed conflict has resulted in the multiplicity of environmental hazards in the region which have, in parts, hampered sustainable environmental management and caused economic and social instability.

Among these problems they say are localized deforestation caused by large concentrations of displaced people. These people were normally crammed on the periphery of urban areas and largely depended on fuel wood for energy.

Pollution has also been cited as another fall-out of wars, following the breakdown of infrastructure and management of wastes. This has been the case in South Africa where the manufacture and testing of military equipment has led to pollution of local water bodies.

In Angola, people have been making brisk business from scrap metal and disabled military material strewn around the country.

Angola produces about 10,000 tones of scrap metal each year added to the country's junk resulting from two decades of war.

Environmentalists estimate that the country accumulated 500,000 tons of scrap metal by 1990, most of it in the "vehicle graveyards".

Junk metal earned the Angolan treasury some six million dollars in 1990 in exports to South African scrap metal dealers.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


381 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


South Africa;
Taiwanese Ambassador To South Africa Leaves


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The Ambassador of the Republic of China (Taiwan) to South Africa left Johannesburg Sunday for Taipei, following Pretoria's recent announcement that diplomatic relations between the two countries would end on Dec. 31, 1997.

Before his departure, Ambassador I-Cheng Loh said his government was extremely disillusioned by South Africa's decision to switch diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing from 1998. 

He described his recall as a way for the Taiwan government to tell South Africa that it would be forced to renew its relation.

"We believe we have supported South Africa to the best of our ability," Loh said, "and our support was substantially larger than that of many countries."

He said the question of his return to South Africa in the future would depend on the development of bilateral negotiations on a new framework for future relations between the two countries.

"I see myself returning next year to take part in the negotiations," he said.

Loh's departure follows a statement by the Foreign Ministry of the Republic of China, saying it had withdrawn its ambassador for an indefinite period, as South Africa's unfriendly announcement had: "seriously damaged Taiwan's dignity and interests, as well as bilateral relations."

Taiwan has also suspended 15 aid and cooperation programmes with South Africa, as well as most of the 36 existing agreements between the two countries.

It is generally accepted that South Africa was the most important of the 30 countries -- many of them African -- which until now recognized Taiwan as opposed to Mainland China.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 16, 1996


Algeria;
New Impetus To Algerian, Canadian Cooperation In Offing


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Stagnant for the past eight years, economic ties between Algiers and Ottawa are set for a revival, beginning with the construction of a new Canadian embassy in the Algerian capital, an official said.

The official, Dan Bourdria, is Canada's minister for international cooperation. 

Reporting this Monday, an Algerian newspaper, Presse Algiers, quoted Bourdria as saying that Algeria was good for business, despite the running war with Moslem militants.

Boudia was accompanied by a strong business delegation during his two-day visit. He signed five cooperation agreements related to the creation of a joint fishery company and to financial aid to Algeria.

Canada has loaned 75 million U.S. dollars to the Algerian Development Bank. In October, Canada loaned 55 million dollars to the Algerian hydrocarbon company, SONATRACH.

Boudria said that Algeria was expected to receive the larger share of 60 million dollars granted to all the Maghreb countries under the Canadian aid programme.

A year ago, Algeria bought Canadian wheat worth 400 million dollars. Canada imported 300 million dollars worth of Algerian oil.

December 16, 1996


Zambia;
Kaunda's Injunction Against TV Documentary Adjourned


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A Lusaka High Court adjourned on Monday hearing of an interim injunction granted to former President Kenneth Kaunda seeking to stop the airing of a documentary on him by the Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation.

Kaunda's lawyer, Mwangala Zaloumis, told reporters Monday that the court had refused her application to review the anti-Kaunda documentary, "A Trail of Deceit", before hearing of the injunction resumes Dec 23. 

The corporation was restrained last week from televising the show after Kaunda won an injunction to stay the broadcast.

The corporation had earlier run excerpts of the film to show that Kaunda had, in conjunction with the independent daily "Post" newspaper, waged a smear campaign among the donor community against the Movement for Multiparty Democracy government of President Frederick Chiluba.

Africa News


December 16, 1996


Nigeria;
Lagos Military Administrator Escapes Bomb Blast


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Lagos state administrator, Col. Muhammed Marwa, escaped unhurt when a suspected time bomb exploded Monday on a busy Lagos road, wounding two people in his convoy.

Police have arrested six suspects in connection with the incident, which occurred near the Sheraton Hotel, in the Ikeja district of Lagos. Part of the hotel's window was shattered by the blast.

Lagos State Commissioner of Police Abubakar Tsva confirmed that "the administrator was not injured."

He told journalists that the explosion, suspected to be a time-bomb, had been planted under a stone beside the road.

The device exploded at about 7.20 a.m. (0620 GMT), as Marwa past that section of the road on his way to the office at the Lagos State Government Secretariat.

Tsva said the last vehicle in the convoy, a peugeot, was damaged and two of its occupants seriously wounded. Police and army bomb experts are investigating the blast.

Police Deputy Superintendent Goni Gogo said there was a striking similarity between the device and the Nov 14. explosion near the Murtala Muhammed International Airport which killed three people, among them the airport's chief security officer.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


385 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


East Africa;
Crucial Great Lakes Summit Opens


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

NAIROBI, Nairobi (PANA) - The second summit of heads of state and government on the volatile Great Lakes Region began Monday in Nairobi without two key players, Burundi and Zaire.

Opening the two-day meeting attended by nine heads of state and government, Kenyan President Daniel Arap Moi described the non-participation of Zaire as regrettable because he had done everything possible to ensure that Zaire, torn by civil strife, was represented.

Burundian military leader Pierre Buyoya, who seized power July 25, was not invited because his government is not recognized. Moreover, regional countries have enforced an economic blockade against Bujumbura. 

Describing the situation in Zaire as sensitive, Moi said he was in contact with Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko up to Monday and that he had promised to send his prime minister, "I have not received any positive response".

Moi added: "It would have been useful and helpful if Zaire had accepted my invitation in order to explain to this summit their perception of the problem they face and how they expect to be assisted."

Moi probably set the tone of the summit when he said the "Zairean problem is a sensitive and internal matter to that country", emphasizing the need for respect for territorial integrity and calling for the withdrawal of any foreign forces inside Zaire.

The Kinshasa government has accused Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda of supporting Tutsi-led rebels who have conquered much of eastern Zaire. Meanwhile, the Zairean parliament has passed a law barring the country's participation in meetings such as the current regional summit as long as Zairean territory is occupied by "foreign troops".

Moi said since the last regional summit in Nairobi on November 5, there had been further incursions into Zaire. Such actions, he said, would only serve to prolong the problem.

"This calls for a change to our approach to the crisis and our emphasis should, therefore, shift to helping Zaire," Moi said, in an appeal to the international community and humanitarian organizations.

Although Moi said "virtually all" the estimated half a million Rwandan refugees who were in Zaire were now back home, relief agencies say there are another 500,000 people on the move in eastern Zaire, running away from an offensive by rebels determined to topple the government in Kinshasa.

The presidents of South Africa and Zimbabwe, Nelson Mandela and Robert Mugabe are attending the summit for the first time in their capacities as chairmen of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and of the SADC organ in Politics, Defence and Security, respectively.

Other heads of state and government attending are Presidents Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania, Frederick Chiluba of Zambia, Isaias Afeworki of Eritrea as well as Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi. The Organization of African Unity (O.A.U.) secretary-general, Salim Ahmed Salim, and former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere who is acting as mediator on Burundi are also attending.

Cameroon, which chairs the O.A.U., was represented by a senior government official.

Given the floor at the opening ceremony as he had to return home the same day, Mandela described the Zairean situation as sensitive and that he would rather reserve his comments for a meeting of heads of state.

However, he said that Mugabe, as head of the SADC organ on Politics, Defence and Security, would be able to articulate the region's position on the crisis in the Great Lakes.

Sources close to the summit said the leaders were expected to adopt a communique which would call on Zaire to recognize the inalienable right to citizenship and nationality of all people within its boundaries. This is a direct reference to the mainly Tutsi population that moved to eastern Zaire some 200 years ago and are now being forced to return to the original homes of their ancestors in Rwanda.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 16, 1996


Science and Health;
WHO Monitors Cholera Outbreak?


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - WORLD Health Organisation officials in Lusaka are keeping a close eye on the fast appearing cases of cholera in Zambia which so far have mostly been confined to the sprawling shanty townships of the major cities and towns.

World Health Organisation representative, Dr Wilfred Boayue, says his organisation has started working closely with the Zambian government through the Ministry of Health on how to control the situation. 

In addition WHO has attached one of its officers to the Ministry of Health, specifically on the committee working out modalities on how to prevent cholera through a sustained campaign.

"The WHO is ready to co-operate more with the Ministry of Health in order to fight the cholera outbreak much more effectively," he said.

So far cases of the disease have been breaking out sporadically in most major centres of the country including the capital - Lusaka. But even then these cases have been confined to the sprawling shanty towns where standards of hygiene are virtually none-existent.

To date there have been no deaths recorded in Lusaka over the upsurge of cholera.

Source: ZAMTODAY

Africa News


December 16, 1996


Zambia;
French React To Zambia's Shattered Image


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - CONCERNED with the ruthless image bashing which Zambia has continued to receive from local publications and power hungry politicians, the French come up with a corrective book which is already receiving overwhelming attention abroad.

Serge Bosc, the in-charge of technical and cultural co-operation at the French Embassy in Lusaka disclosed today that the book is already circulating in Europe and many people are eager to read it. 

The book is entitled "La Zambie Contemporaine" and it was prepared with the knowledge of the Zambian government and it aims to correct the bad publicity which Zambia has unjustly suffered by portraying a correct and true political and cultural situation in Zambia.

The book also includes issues related to women and gender as well as the environment and business.

Mr Bosc said relations between Zambia and France is warm and his government intends to keep things that way adding that friendship ought to be kept alive and warm at both government and community levels and in this regard the French were happy.

He observed that Zambia has similar cultural identities with the French and that was why both nations were in tune.

Mr Bosc was speaking at a one week workshop for the ZambiaCounselling Council which is an umbrella body that will serve to cordinate and control all counselling activities in the country.

The group is receiving some financial support from the French government and interim chairman Chimutulanje Lwenje was hopeful that the support will continue until the organisation was well founded.

Source: ZAMTODAY

Africa News


December 16, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia beats Kenya


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - JUNIOR international, Edward "Bubble Brown" Kangwa, yesterday went on rampage scoring a brace to give the Zambia national soccer team a deserved 2-0 win over their Kenyan counterparts, the Harambee Stars, in an international friendly played in Mombasa.

Kangwa, a last minute inclusion in the team currently in Kenya for a series of friendlies, drew first blood in the first half after rounding up a couple of Kenyan shirts before unleashing a cannon that left the Kenyan keeper sprawled. 

In the second half, Kangwa continued to terrorise the Kenyan defence with subtle moves aided by a well oiled midfield marshalled by Aggrey Chiyangi.

A defensive blunder by the Kenyans provided the chink that the ZANACO point man needed to slot in the second and final goal.

After the game, Chiyangi enthused: "We played better than the last game. At least the pitch was better than the one we used in Nairobi when we lost 1-0."

According to Chiyangi, the team will return home on Tuesday, dispelling reports that they would proceed to Uganda for two more friendlies.

"The information we have is that we will return home on Tuesday. We don't know anything about going to Uganda," Chiyangi said.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


389 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Zambia;
Voters' Register Had Too Many Errors


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Lusaka - The voters' register had too many mistakes, observed Zambia Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ZACCI) chairman, George Chabwera, on Friday.

Chabwera, speaking at an Alliance forum at Lusaka's Intercontinental Hotel on Friday, revealed that he failed to vote due to errors on the register.

"In my case I could not vote because there was a mix up regarding my name," Chabwera said. " I had to be omitted from the register." 

But despite pointing out mistakes in the Nikuv register, Chabwera condemned the Opposition Alliance's decision to boycott the November 18 elections.

"I did not vote myself because of too many mistakes in the register but ladies and gentlemen, you have to be aware of the activities of the old regime, their interest is their survival," Chabwera said. "Liberation politics and civil disobedience cannot work at the moment. For us in ZACCI we are very disappointed with the Alliance of the opposition for boycotting the elections. You denied your members the right to decide the leaders they wanted and you denied us an opportunity too because you robbed the people of a chance to choose their rightful leaders."

And reacting to Chabwera's remarks, Opposition Alliance and Liberal Progressive Front chairman, Rodger Chongwe, said they had opted to boycott the elections because the electoral process was fraudulent and the results were predetermined. He claimed that the results were planned that UNIP would get 45 seats, MMD 96 and the rest 15.

"The basis of the boycott was because we did not want to take part in the elections whose electoral process was fraudulent. The election results were predetermined," Chongwe told the ZACCI team which included executive secretary Gideon Phiri, board member Theo Bull, and national trustee Yvonne Goma. "As businessmen you may support the government in power but if the government is unable to govern the country properly there will be no conducive environment for you to do business in."

Chongwe warned that the issues at hand were serious and affected the nation as a whole and not just political parties hence the need for the business community and associations to get involved.

And other leaders of the Alliance - UNIP secretary general Sebastian Zulu, Labour Party president Chibeza Mfuni and his vice Paul Kapongo, National Democratic Party president Tenthani Mwanza, Salvation Party president David Kasuba - all urged the business community to face reality and get involved in solving the current political crisis.

Zulu warned that Zambia was sitting on a volcano.

"We have information that the army will take over," Zulu said. "We are not threatening you."

Mfuni said the business community had a crucial role to play in any situation involving the politicians since it had the necessary finances and infrastructure.

But Bull, who walked out of the talks shortly after presenting his views, told opposition parties not to put blame on the government alone.

"We have lost aid because of the high interest rates and because of MMD. I don't think it is good to blame the government anyhow," Bull said and dramatically walked out of the forum.

Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) president Alfred Zulu yesterday said in an interview that the business world should come out from its shell and take an impartial and pragmatic view on what is happening in the nation.

"The corporate world led by ZACCI is so naive to issues of good governance and I think businessmen ought to come out from their shell and identify themselves with entire society and the system," Zulu said.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


390 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Zambia;
Kapembwa Calls For Commission Autonomy


BYLINE: Milimo Moyo and Sheikh Chifuwe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - Only an independent and autonomous Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) can exercise absolute impartiality, said ACC commissioner justice Robert Kapembwa on Friday.

Justice Kapembwa said "autonomy is important because, in fighting corruption, there is need to be absolutely impartial".

And justice Kapembwa assured that the ACC Bill, which is now awaiting presidential assent, will enable the Commission increase its capacity to fight corruption. 

commissioner, Robert Kapembwa said the new bill had certain positive features which would enable the commission "cast its net wider".

he added, "only an independent and autonomous body can exercise absolute impartiality."

Justice Kapembwa said the Bill would stop accusations of double standards when dealing with top government officials who are suspected of corruption.

"The so-called 'small fish-big fish' syndrome will come to an end with the enactment of the Bill,"he assured.

The ACC Bill was widely opposed by ruling MMD back benchers at the close of the 7th Session of Parliament. The back benchers charged that the Bill was manufactured during finance minister Ronald Penza's last trip to Washington where the International Monetary Fund (IMF) cited good governance as a pre- requisite to donor aid.

They called for lengthy amendments to the Bill which were conceded to by cabinet.

He emphasised that even under the current law the Commission did not need presidential consent to prosecute top government officials.

"When it comes to prosecutions we do not have to get consent from the President," justice Kapembwa said. " The reports we submit to him are merely to inform the President."

And British High Commissioner to Zambia, Patrick Nixon, officially opening the re-furbished training centre for ACC investigators and prosecutors, said corruption was a worldwide syndrome which needed concerted efforts to eradicate.

"No country is immune to corruption. It is like cancer cutting away the heart of a country and we should therefore, stand up to stamp it out," Nixon said.

The occasion marked the completion of a K980 million three-year programme of assistance by the British government.

Justice Kapembwa said the centre would assist in the training of competent " and honest" personnel.

LANGUAGE: English

391 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Emergency Report No. 49 (12/13)


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2707 words


 

Rome - This report includes: A) Burundi, Rwanda, Zaire and Tanzania B) Angola

PART I - HIGHLIGHTS (Details below in Part II)

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. Tanzania - information as of 13 December. a) Approximately 400,000 refugees from the Ngara camps of Kitali Hills, Lumasi, Benaco, Keza and Mushuhura leave the camps on 12 and 13 December. Refugees first move south- east from Ngara, apparently to avoid repatriation to Rwanda. Later on 13 December unknown numbers of the refugees change direction and head towards the border of Rwanda at Rusumo. Some refugees return to the abandoned camps. b) Burundian refugees in two camps in Ngara remain in place. c) Previously, approximately 23,000 refugees fled the camps of Kagenyi and Rubwera in Karagwe district, on 10 December. Many returned to the camps, but 10,000 are thought to be still in surrounding area. 

2. Rwanda a) In preparation for return of refugees from Tanzania, WFP has stocks of high-protein biscuits in position at seven way-stations along road between Rusumo and Curazo in Kibungo prefecture. Stocks of general rations have been built up in the prefecture (285,000 weekly rations as at 12 December). Additional stocks available in Kigali. b) Returnees from Zaire have received at least a two-week ration, most a one-month ration. From 16 November to 12 December, WFP and NGO partners distributed over 10,020 metric tons of food aid in the form of full rations (cereals, pulses and oil) and an additional 1,250,000 daily rations in the form of high-protein biscuits. c) Rwanda Government launches an appeal for USD 739.4 million to resettle returnees. Governments of Canada and Rwanda to co-chair meeting in Kigali on 13 and 14 December on coordination and implementation of assistance to returnees.

3. East Zaire a) Joint UN/NGO/Government of Zaire mission visits Shabunda/Kindu area, 175 km west of Bukavu. Mission estimates that some 10, 000 Rwandan and Burundian refugees are in the town of Shabunda and up to 40, 000 in two camps nearby. Additional 20,000 to 30,000 refugees reported in Walikale and 10,000 to 15,000 refugees in Lubutu. Area difficult to access. b) UN team visits Uvira area 7-9 December. c) Northern axis from Goma still closed to international humanitarian personnel. Access possible to west and south as far as Kalungu. UN assessment on-going where possible. d) Approximately 3,900 refugees cross the border from Goma to Gisenyi between 10 and 12 December. Some 400 refugees return through the Bukavu/Cyangugu border point on 11 December.

4. Burundi a) All groups involved in the conflict invited by Nyerere to negotiations in Arusha. b) Insecurity reported in many parts of the country, with situation deteriorating in Bubanza province and serious conflict in Kayanza province (500 people reported killed). c) MSF-Belgium reports nutritional situation remains alarming in Karuzi province; up to 50,000 displaced persons affected. WFP attempting to evaluate areas of Kayanza where up to 30,000 displaced persons reported to be in need of assistance. Despatch of WFP food commodities to CRS in Gitega started, to cover 20,000 beneficiaries for 14 days.

B. ANGOLA

1. Update a) WFP base manager murdered by unknown attackers in Kwanza North on 12 December.

PART II - DETAILS

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. TANZANIA - information as of mid-day, 13 December.

1.1 Approximately 400,000 refugees from the Ngara camps of Kitali Hills, Lumasi, Benaco, Keza and Mushuhura have left the camps and were reported on 12 and 13 December to be moving south-east from Ngara in what seemed to be an effort to avoid repatriation to Rwanda. The majority of these refugees had received a two-week WFP food ration before they dispersed and were said to be carrying possessions with them. However, on the afternoon of 13 December, it was reported that many refugees (numbers unknown) were heading towards the border of Rwanda at Rusumo, about 20 kms north-west of Ngara. Many also reported to have returned to the abandoned camps.

1.2 Some 80,000 Burundian refugees remain in two camps in Ngara and are not on the move.

1.3 Prior to the Ngara movement, approximately 23,000 refugees had fled the Tanzanian camps on 10 December, mainly from Kagenyi and Rubwera camps in Karagwe district. While most have now returned to the camps, UNHCR reports that approximately 10,000 are still in the surrounding area.

1.4 Some 800 and 1,928 refugees repatriated from Ngara on 9 and 10 December respectively. On the morning of 11 December, 644 refugees repatriated, bringing the total number of returnees from Tanzania from 1 to 11 December to 4,179.

1.5 In order to meet increased supplementary feeding needs of the more recently arrived refugees in the Kibondo district of Kigoma region, WFP is airlifting some 45 metric tons of corn-soya blend with the assistance of the multi-national force led by Canada. A further 300 metric tons has been despatched by road. Influxes to the Kigoma region of Tanzania continue from both Zaire and Burundi.

2. RWANDA - information as of 12 December

2.1 WFP Rwanda is ready for the returnees from Tanzania with stocks of high- protein biscuits and food commodities in place for distribution. Seven way- stations have been set up and 200,000 biscuit rations are pre-positioned alongside 37 km of road between Rusumo and Curazo (Kibungo prefecture). The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, the Rwandan Red Cross and World Vision are responsible for the way stations. WFP also has staff ready to receive the returnees throughout Kibungo.

2.2 General food stocks in Kibungo prefecture have been built up over the last week in preparation for the return of several hundred thousand returnees to this prefecture. WFP food stocks in this prefecture, as at 12 December, stood at 285,000 weekly rations, with 167,000 weekly rations pre-positioned in the communes where refugees are expected to return. A total of 1,200 metric tons of mixed food commodities are available in Kibungo and an additional 4,000 metric tons are available in Kigali, only two hours from Kibungo. 70 metric tons of high-protein biscuits are also in stock in Kibungo.

2.3 In addition, pre-positioning of food stocks is taking place in the communes of Byumba and Umutara prefectures, both of which are also expected to receive a significant number of returnees from Tanzania.

2.4 As of 11 December, total WFP food stocks in-country designated for the returnee programme as a whole are 3,937 metric tons, equivalent to approximately 230,000 monthly rations or 980,000 weekly rations. The total stock of high-protein biscuits in Rwanda is at 372 metric tons, equivalent to 1,860,000 daily rations. The overall WFP food stock level in Rwanda stands at 8,000 metric tons, for all programmes. WFP also has significant quantities of food within the region: 12,603 metric tons in Kampala and Isaka and 17,992 metric tons in Dar es Salaam and Mombassa.

2.5 From 16 November to 12 December, WFP and NGO partners (CARE, CRS, LWF, World Vision, Concern, CRR, IFRC, Trocaire, Caritas, ADRA, MEC, GAA, AHA, World Relief, AEF, EEF, IRC, MSF, ASS, Salvation Army, Ingabo) distributed approximately 10,020 metric tons of food commodities (cereals, pulses and oil) , representing 600,000 persons assisted with a monthly ration. In addition, more than 1,250,000 daily high-protein biscuit rations have been distributed. All returnees are believed to have received at least a two-week ration with the majority having received a one-month ration. Registration of returnees in the communes continues, with around 70 per cent of the returnees counted so far.

2.6 From 3 to 9 December, 5,077 Rwandan refugees came back from Zaire (3, 165 via Gisenyi and 1,912 via Cyangugu), 1,536 from Tanzania and 288 from Uganda.

2.7 The Rwanda Government launched an appeal for USD 739.4 million to resettle returnees (including the Tanzania caseload). The Governments of Canada and Rwanda are co-chairing a meeting in Kigali on 13 and 14 December which will focus on the coordination and implementation of assistance to returnees. Major donors, UN Agencies and non-governmental organizations will attend the meeting.

3. EASTERN ZAIRE - information as of 12 December

3.1 From 7 to 9 December, a joint UN/NGO/Government of Zaire mission visited the Shabunda/Kindu area, some 175 km west of Bukavu, and flew at low altitude around the Lubutu/Walikale/ Bukavu area. The mission found approximately 10,000 Rwandan and Burundian refugees in the town of Shabunda and up to 40,000 in two camps near the town. An additional 20,000 to 30,000 refugees were reported in Walikale and 10,000 to 15,000 refugees in Lubutu. WFP is presently studying the possibility of assessing the needs of the population around Shabunda and of distributing needed food commodities. Access to this area is very difficult due to insecurity.

3.2 A UN team, of WFP, UNHCR and UNICEF representatives, visited the Uvira area from 7 to 9 December. Access to the port was denied as was access to Fizi, for security reasons.

3.3 Goma area

a) The northern axis from Goma continues to be closed to all international humanitarian personnel. Access to the western and southern routes as far as Kalungu (some 50 km west of Goma) is permitted. Assessment missions as far as Kitchungu, half-way between Sake and Masisi, have been undertaken by the UN, however the terrain and the location of pockets of resistance are unknown and thus the area is deemed unsafe for further travel.

b) From 26 November to 8 December, WFP distributed approximately 27 metric tons of food assistance, mostly high-protein biscuits, to over 25,000 returnees on their way back to Rwanda, as well as to Zairians requiring assistance near or in Goma town.

c) The food supply situation in Goma is limited, as a reduction in the number of trucks arriving to the town has led to a price increase of 66 percent for imported goods. Vegetables and fruits have increased in price by some 150 percent. This is caused mainly by the fact that food production areas in the highlands are inaccessible due to insecurity. Fighting forced most of the population to flee to other areas, leaving their farms, which for the most part were destroyed and looted when they left. In addition, with the repatriation of refugees, the cost of labour has escalated. WFP is studying food requirements in the area, with particular emphasis on food security and the means to reestablish the previous supply network.

d) From 10 to 12 December, approximately 3,900 refugees crossed the border from Goma to Gisenyi. The returnees came partly through the Virunga forest and partly from the direction of Minova and Numbi. Some 400 refugees returned through the Bukavu/Cyangugu border point on 11 December.

4. BURUNDI

4.1 Former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere has invited "all groups" involved in the conflict in Burundi to negotiations in Arusha, Tanzania. Negotiation between the Burundian government and opposition and rebel groups is the last remaining condition for regional sanctions to be lifted.

4.2 FAO issued a statement this past week predicting that a decrease in agricultural production and the effects of the regional sanctions will adversely affect the nutritional status of the Burundian population in general and internally displaced persons in particular.

4.3 Insecurity continued in Kayanza and Bujumbura Rural provinces, and deteriorated in Bubanza province. Information is not available on the security situation in much of the country, but it is clear that many parts of Bururi, Muramvya, Gitega and Karuzi provinces continue to be unsafe. Conflict was particularly serious in Kayanza province with reports that up to 500 people may have been killed, thousands of houses destroyed and large numbers of people forced to moved.

4.4 The WFP Burundi caseload totaled 148,957 from 2 to 8 December. Emergency relief rations were provided to 10,401 displaced persons at the Johnson Centre in Bujumbura. WFP delivered commodities to the NGO VISPE for distribution to 15,000 displaced persons in Karuzi province. MSF-Belgium has reported that the nutritional situation in Karuzi remains alarming, affecting up to 50,000 displaced persons. WFP is trying to send needs evaluation teams to different areas of Kayanza where it is reported that up to 30,000 displaced persons are in need of assistance. WFP has started to despatch food commodities to CRS in Gitega, sufficient for 20,000 beneficiaries, for 14-day emergency relief distributions.

4.5 Some 27,600 persons benefited from WFP returnee packages. Benficiaries included 2,105 spontaneous returnees to Cibitoke province. Distributions in this province continue to be carried out in very difficult conditions, as military-escorted convoys in armoured vehicles are necessary for access to the area. Returnee package rations are deemed sufficient for three months consumption, providing about 1,215 kcal/person/day.

B. ANGOLA

1. UPDATE 1.1 On 12 December, a WFP official was murdered in the northern province of Kwanza North. Mr. Jorge Leitao, an Angolan, was the WFP base manager for the area. He was shot dead by unknown attackers on the road linking the towns of Ndalatando and Ngonguembo. Mr Leitao was on a mission at the time to coordinate information on the tracing of families of child soldiers who are in the process of being demobilised, part of WFP's current rehabilitation work in Angola.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

392 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 58 on the Great Lakes (12/15-16)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Nairobi - Rwandan refugees began pouring back into Rwanda from Ngara camps in Tanzania over the weekend. DHA in Kigali reported that by yesterday, some 24,000 refugees had crossed the border into Rwanda and the flow was increasing towards the end of the day with some 5,000 refugees crossing every hour.

Most of the returnees who arrived at the Birenga transit centre in Kibungo prefecture had already been trucked onto their home communes by yesterday. DHA reported a 10km long column of refugees inside Rwanda. However information is quite hard to come by, as access along the 60km stretch of road from Kibungo town to the Tanzanian border is restricted and most NGOs have not yet been allowed to operate. Assistance is currently being provided by the International Federation of the Red Cross and the Rwandan Red Cross. UNHCR has also been allowed to cross the border. The biggest of the Ngara camps - Benaco - is now empty as 200,000 refugees are said to be heading for the border. 

As of this morning, a steady stream of refugees continued to cross into Rwanda. Returning refugees report that the Tanzanian authorities have been using tear gas and firing into the air to prompt an exodus from the camps. UN staff in Ngara yesterday reported some NGOs as saying large numbers of people were still in the bush and two fairly large of concentrations of 5,000 and 10, 000 were said to be moving south and east. The team also reported that significant portions of the population in the Karagwe camps appeared to be " at large" outside the control of both UNHCR and the authorities. Two large groups of people are said to be heading for Kenya. UNHCR is hoping to truck the inhabitants of Karagwe down to Ngara from where they could walk across the border, UN staff said.

IOM, according to a DHA report from Kigali, has positioned 76 trucks at a BP station 22 kms from the border with a further 70 trucks in Kibungo. IOM also indicated that the Rwandan government has said it will closely monitor the repatriation process and will use the army to intervene if necessary. By 1830 last night, a significant army presence was in evidence along the road to the Nyakarambi transit camp, near Gatore. Rwandan President Pasteur Bizimungu was on hand to welcome the returnees at the Rusumo border point yesterday, but warned that members of the Interahamwe and ex-FAR would be " dealt with".

Regional leaders are meeting in Nairobi today to discuss the crisis in the Great Lakes, although Zaire and Burundi are not taking part. South African President Nelson Mandela and President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe are attending for the first time according to the Kenya News Agency. Burundi mediator, former Tanzanian president Julius Nyerere will be at the meeting along with OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim.

A 14-nation steering committee which met in New York on Friday decided to wind up the mission of the Canadian-led multi-national force by the end of this month. After the announcement was made in New York, Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien issued a statement in Ottawa saying the force had served as a "catalyst" for the return of hundreds of thousands of refugees to Rwanda. Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy also claimed the mission had led to the refugees' return. "The fact that the movement of peoples took place exactly at the time when the announcement of the international force was made is not a coincidence," he said.

Nairobi, 16 December 1996, 10:55 gmt (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)
