393 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


East Africa;
WFP Great Lakes Situation Report No. 38


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Rome - TANZANIA: As of mid-morning on 16 December, a total of 45,000 Rwandan refugees returned to Rwanda from Ngara camps in Tanzania. This includes some 30,000 who repatriated on 15 December and some 7,500 who returned on 14 December. It appears that the repatriation is organised by camp, with Lumasi camp already emptied and Benaco camp almost empty. Both camps are in the Ngara region. The Tanzanian authorities, who are assisting with the return of the Rwandan refugees, appear to be concentrating on the Ngara camps prior to the Karagwe camps. 

RWANDA:

All refugees are entering Rwanda at Rusumo (Kibungo). On the Rwandan side of the border the majority of refugees are walking the first 20 km towards Kibungo. Some vulnerable refugees are however receiving transportation from the border point.

The returnees appear to be in a good nutritional state. WFP food aid distributions in Ngara camps were completed only three days ago when all returnees received two-week rations.

WFP is distributing high-energy biscuits to returnees at Rwenteru way- station (20 km from the border) and at two other way stations on the way to Kibungo town. Provision of biscuits closer to the border had to be halted when local authorities declared they would allow only the National Red Cross to operate in the area between the border and Rwenteru.

In Kibungo prefecture, from where 65 per cent of the Rwandan refugees in Tanzania originate (340,000 persons), WFP food stocks consist of 150 mt of high-energy biscuits (750,000 daily rations), 828 mt of cereals, pulses and oil already pre-positioned in the Kibungo communes (219,000 weekly rations), as well as 636 mt of mixed commodities at the extended delivery point and transit centres (168,000 weekly rations). WFP also has large quantities of stocks in Kigali, which is a two-hour drive from Kibungo.

Seven WFP storage tents are operational in Kibungo prefecture (3,100 mt capacity in total). Two are in Nyakarambi transit centre, two in Kibungo town and one each in Kigarama, Kayonza and Murambi.

Pre-positioning of food stocks is also taking place in communes of Byumba and Umutara prefectures, both of which are also expected to receive a significant number of returnees from Tanzania.

WFP's food distributions in other prefectures of Rwanda (to returnees from Zaire and within the Rwanda Rehabilitation Programme) continue uninterrupted despite the emergency in Kibungo. They are implemented with the assistance of 22 NGOs.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


394 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 59 on the Great Lakes (12/16)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

Nairobi - As of 14:00 today, 60,000 Rwandan refugees had crossed into their homeland from Tanzania's Ngara camps, bringing the total number of returnees since Saturday to 90,000, according to UNHCR figures. The refugees were said to be crossing at the rate of up to 15,000 an hour.

A BBC correspondent said the flow was intensifying every hour, although mid- afternoon, the rate slowed because of heavy rain. However a number of refugees were reluctant to return and the BBC said Hutu militias were seen jogging in formation away from the border. 

Refugees from the Rubwera and Kagere camps in northwest Tanzania, who do not want to return to Rwanda, continued to arrive at Orukinga camp in Uganda's Mbarara area at the rate of about 500 a day, reports the IFRC. The initial response of the Ugandan border authorities has been to send some of the refugees back to Tanzania, but refugees have been crossing the Kagera river on the border under cover of night. A total of 2,000 refugees have arrived and according to some reports, 30,000 may be on their way.

Rwanda is to receive $500 million in international aid to help with the repatriation of returnees, Canadian International Cooperation Minister Don Boudria said on Saturday. His announcement followed a meeting of donor countries and aid organisations in Kigali on Friday which was a follow-up to the Great Lakes humanitarian aid conference held in Geneva last month. During that meeting, Rwanda appealed for $740 million to help resettle the returnees. Boudria said the priority was housing, but aid would also be channelled towards boosting Rwanda's judicial and social service systems, as well as agriculture.

Fuel prices and public transport fares have increased considerably in Kinshasa, raising fears of a backlash by residents unable to afford the price hikes. Zairean radio, monitored by BBC, on Friday announced that fuel prices had risen from 68,000 to 71,000 new zaires, and the price per litre of gasoline now stood at 78,000 new zaires. Bus fares had risen from 30,000 to 35,000 new zaires, and taxis from 35,000 to 40,000 new zaires. The Zairean government also submitted budget proposals to parliament on Friday which called for reserving 35 percent of overall public spending in the coming financial year for defence, Reuters reported. It said that in recent weeks, the government had imposed extra taxes on local and international businesses as contributions to the war effort.

Zairean President Mobutu is due back in the country tomorrow after an absence of over three months, Zairean television announced. He underwent cancer surgery in Switzerland in August, and has since been convalescing in the south of France. Mobutu is expected to stay at the Tshatshi military camp in Kinshasa and will make a broadcast to the nation. Observers point out that Zairean public opinion expects Mobutu to take personal charge of military counter-offensive aimed at re-establishing control in the rebel-held east of the country.

IFRC has delivered a consignment of 10 MT of relief supplies for tens of thousands of refugees and displaced people in Kisangani. A Hercules C-130 flew into the town yesterday in what IFRC described as the first of a series of regular flights between Kisangani and Nairobi. Kisangani itself was reported to be calm, and food supplies had already been flown into the town by France and Belgium. Aid organisations were expected to airlift more supplies this week. NCA/ACT have begun airlifting food and medicines to Kisangani, for distribution there, and onward delivery to Lubutu by land and Katshungu by air. AFP quoted relief agencies as saying some 500,000 people were on the move in eastern Zaire heading westwards in the regions of Kindu, Lobutu, Walikale and Shabunda ahead of the rebel offensive.

Various reports said the original population of Lobutu have vacated the town and some 90,000 refugees and displaced people had moved in, probably including Interahamwe and ex-FAR. Aid organisations on the ground corroborated the information, saying these people were staying put in Lobutu and not moving on to Kisangani. According to IFRC, 300,000 displaced people were stuck between Walikale and Lobutu without food and assistance, and were in a poor state. UN sources said Zairean military authorities were blocking the refugee advance some 200km east of Kisangani near Lubutu, and some 200 km east of Kindu near Shabunda.

It was probable that this would lead to the natural creation of camps as the refugee population in Shabunda and Lobutu continued to swell. An ex-FAR camp near Kingulube, some 180km east of Shabunda, has - according to Zairean security officials in Kinshasa - reportedly been dismantled but it is not known where the former Rwandan soldiers have moved to.

Burundi on Saturday expressed surprise over a UN human rights report which said over 1,000 people had been killed in just one month in the country, mostly by government forces. Interior Minister Epitace Bayaganakandi said he did not know the sources used by UN observers, nor how they had worked out the number of people killed during fighting in Burundi. Bayaganakandi added that it had "become a habit among some agencies to ignore the crimes of terrorist organisations and to blame systematically the Burundi army for killings with inflated casualty figures for propaganda purposes." Also on Saturday, Burundi's Foreign Minister Luc Rukingama again appealed for the lifting of economic sanctions imposed on his country by regional countries following the July coup. Speaking in connection with Burundi peace talks in the Tanzanian town of Arusha, he said his government had drawn up several recommendations for peace in Burundi which would be presented to mediator Julius Nyerere. Tanzanian radio said five parties from Burundi, including the Hutu-dominated Frodebu party and the exiled extremist Hutu organisation CNDD, were represented in Arusha. Few details of the meeting have been released. Meanwhile, the UN in Tanzania announced that three barges loaded with fertilisers and medicines, exempt from the regional sanctions, left the port of Kigoma for Bujumbura on Thursday.

Uganda has said it will grant an amnesty to rebel leader Joseph Kony if leaders in the north - where he is waging his rebellion - and next of kin of people killed by his fighters, agree to pardon him. According to newspaper reports, special presidential adviser Salim Saleh told a seminar in the northern town of Gulu on Saturday that Kony - who leads the Lord's Resistance Army - could then return to Gulu and resume his career as a Roman Catholic catechist. AFP said that until now, President Museveni had refused to grant an amnesty to Kony, saying he must stand trial.

Nairobi, 16 December 1996, 15:30 gmt (ENDS)

UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

395 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Angola;
Angola Loses Wildlife In Armed Conflict


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1089 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Angola might have lost 90 percent of its larger mammals, in addition to other wildlife, killed during the civil war between the government in Luanda and anti-government Angolan forces called UNITA, a study by environmentalists shows.

The study, by the Southern African Research and Documentation Center in Harare -- in collaboration with the International Conservation Union -- is on the impact of armed conflict in the Southern Africa.

Contained in the 1994 report on the "State of the Environment in Southern Africa", researchers say that similar destruction of wildlife occurred in Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Namibia and Zambia following fighting in those countries. 

Southern Africa had been engaged in wars for independence lasting decades. In addition, Angola and Mozambique have experienced civil wars between nationalistic forces and those opposed to socialist rule in their country.

After years of fighting Portuguese colonialists, Angola's civil war started after independence in 1975 and ended formally 20 years later. There is now a United Nations-sponsored cease-fire in the country.

Environmentalists say that armed conflict has resulted in the multiplicity of environmental hazards in the region which have, in parts, hampered sustainable environmental management and caused economic and social instability.

Among these problems they say are localized deforestation caused by large concentrations of displaced people. These people were normally crammed on the periphery of urban areas and largely depended on fuel wood for energy.

Pollution has also been cited as another fall-out of wars, following the breakdown of infrastructure and management of wastes. This has been the case in South Africa where the manufacture and testing of military equipment has led to pollution of local water bodies.

In Angola, people have been making brisk business from scrap metal and disabled military material strewn around the country.

Angola produces about 10,000 tones of scrap metal each year added to the country's junk resulting from two decades of war.

Environmentalists estimate that the country accumulated 500,000 tons of scrap metal by 1990, most of it in the "vehicle graveyards".

Junk metal earned the Angolan treasury some six million dollars in 1990 in exports to South African scrap metal dealers.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


396 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


South Africa;
Taiwanese Ambassador To South Africa Leaves


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The Ambassador of the Republic of China (Taiwan) to South Africa left Johannesburg Sunday for Taipei, following Pretoria's recent announcement that diplomatic relations between the two countries would end on Dec. 31, 1997.

Before his departure, Ambassador I-Cheng Loh said his government was extremely disillusioned by South Africa's decision to switch diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing from 1998. 

He described his recall as a way for the Taiwan government to tell South Africa that it would be forced to renew its relation.

"We believe we have supported South Africa to the best of our ability," Loh said, "and our support was substantially larger than that of many countries."

He said the question of his return to South Africa in the future would depend on the development of bilateral negotiations on a new framework for future relations between the two countries.

"I see myself returning next year to take part in the negotiations," he said.

Loh's departure follows a statement by the Foreign Ministry of the Republic of China, saying it had withdrawn its ambassador for an indefinite period, as South Africa's unfriendly announcement had: "seriously damaged Taiwan's dignity and interests, as well as bilateral relations."

Taiwan has also suspended 15 aid and cooperation programmes with South Africa, as well as most of the 36 existing agreements between the two countries.

It is generally accepted that South Africa was the most important of the 30 countries -- many of them African -- which until now recognized Taiwan as opposed to Mainland China.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


397 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Algeria;
New Impetus To Algerian, Canadian Cooperation In Offing


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Stagnant for the past eight years, economic ties between Algiers and Ottawa are set for a revival, beginning with the construction of a new Canadian embassy in the Algerian capital, an official said.

The official, Dan Bourdria, is Canada's minister for international cooperation. 

Reporting this Monday, an Algerian newspaper, Presse Algiers, quoted Bourdria as saying that Algeria was good for business, despite the running war with Moslem militants.

Boudia was accompanied by a strong business delegation during his two-day visit. He signed five cooperation agreements related to the creation of a joint fishery company and to financial aid to Algeria.

Canada has loaned 75 million U.S. dollars to the Algerian Development Bank. In October, Canada loaned 55 million dollars to the Algerian hydrocarbon company, SONATRACH.

Boudria said that Algeria was expected to receive the larger share of 60 million dollars granted to all the Maghreb countries under the Canadian aid programme.

A year ago, Algeria bought Canadian wheat worth 400 million dollars. Canada imported 300 million dollars worth of Algerian oil.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


398 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Zambia;
Kaunda's Injunction Against TV Documentary Adjourned


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A Lusaka High Court adjourned on Monday hearing of an interim injunction granted to former President Kenneth Kaunda seeking to stop the airing of a documentary on him by the Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation.

Kaunda's lawyer, Mwangala Zaloumis, told reporters Monday that the court had refused her application to review the anti-Kaunda documentary, "A Trail of Deceit", before hearing of the injunction resumes Dec 23. 

The corporation was restrained last week from televising the show after Kaunda won an injunction to stay the broadcast.

The corporation had earlier run excerpts of the film to show that Kaunda had, in conjunction with the independent daily "Post" newspaper, waged a smear campaign among the donor community against the Movement for Multiparty Democracy government of President Frederick Chiluba.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


399 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


Nigeria;
Lagos Military Administrator Escapes Bomb Blast


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Lagos state administrator, Col. Muhammed Marwa, escaped unhurt when a suspected time bomb exploded Monday on a busy Lagos road, wounding two people in his convoy.

Police have arrested six suspects in connection with the incident, which occurred near the Sheraton Hotel, in the Ikeja district of Lagos. Part of the hotel's window was shattered by the blast.

Lagos State Commissioner of Police Abubakar Tsva confirmed that "the administrator was not injured."

He told journalists that the explosion, suspected to be a time-bomb, had been planted under a stone beside the road.

The device exploded at about 7.20 a.m. (0620 GMT), as Marwa past that section of the road on his way to the office at the Lagos State Government Secretariat.

Tsva said the last vehicle in the convoy, a peugeot, was damaged and two of its occupants seriously wounded. Police and army bomb experts are investigating the blast.

Police Deputy Superintendent Goni Gogo said there was a striking similarity between the device and the Nov 14. explosion near the Murtala Muhammed International Airport which killed three people, among them the airport's chief security officer.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


400 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 16, 1996


East Africa;
Crucial Great Lakes Summit Opens


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

NAIROBI, Nairobi (PANA) - The second summit of heads of state and government on the volatile Great Lakes Region began Monday in Nairobi without two key players, Burundi and Zaire.

Opening the two-day meeting attended by nine heads of state and government, Kenyan President Daniel Arap Moi described the non-participation of Zaire as regrettable because he had done everything possible to ensure that Zaire, torn by civil strife, was represented.

Burundian military leader Pierre Buyoya, who seized power July 25, was not invited because his government is not recognized. Moreover, regional countries have enforced an economic blockade against Bujumbura. 

Describing the situation in Zaire as sensitive, Moi said he was in contact with Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko up to Monday and that he had promised to send his prime minister, "I have not received any positive response".

Moi added: "It would have been useful and helpful if Zaire had accepted my invitation in order to explain to this summit their perception of the problem they face and how they expect to be assisted."

Moi probably set the tone of the summit when he said the "Zairean problem is a sensitive and internal matter to that country", emphasizing the need for respect for territorial integrity and calling for the withdrawal of any foreign forces inside Zaire.

The Kinshasa government has accused Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda of supporting Tutsi-led rebels who have conquered much of eastern Zaire. Meanwhile, the Zairean parliament has passed a law barring the country's participation in meetings such as the current regional summit as long as Zairean territory is occupied by "foreign troops".

Moi said since the last regional summit in Nairobi on November 5, there had been further incursions into Zaire. Such actions, he said, would only serve to prolong the problem.

"This calls for a change to our approach to the crisis and our emphasis should, therefore, shift to helping Zaire," Moi said, in an appeal to the international community and humanitarian organizations.

Although Moi said "virtually all" the estimated half a million Rwandan refugees who were in Zaire were now back home, relief agencies say there are another 500,000 people on the move in eastern Zaire, running away from an offensive by rebels determined to topple the government in Kinshasa.

The presidents of South Africa and Zimbabwe, Nelson Mandela and Robert Mugabe are attending the summit for the first time in their capacities as chairmen of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and of the SADC organ in Politics, Defence and Security, respectively.

Other heads of state and government attending are Presidents Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania, Frederick Chiluba of Zambia, Isaias Afeworki of Eritrea as well as Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi. The Organization of African Unity (O.A.U.) secretary-general, Salim Ahmed Salim, and former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere who is acting as mediator on Burundi are also attending.

Cameroon, which chairs the O.A.U., was represented by a senior government official.

Given the floor at the opening ceremony as he had to return home the same day, Mandela described the Zairean situation as sensitive and that he would rather reserve his comments for a meeting of heads of state.

However, he said that Mugabe, as head of the SADC organ on Politics, Defence and Security, would be able to articulate the region's position on the crisis in the Great Lakes.

Sources close to the summit said the leaders were expected to adopt a communique which would call on Zaire to recognize the inalienable right to citizenship and nationality of all people within its boundaries. This is a direct reference to the mainly Tutsi population that moved to eastern Zaire some 200 years ago and are now being forced to return to the original homes of their ancestors in Rwanda.


LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


401 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


Zimbabwe;
New Zimbabwe Airline Prepares To Fly


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's latest privately-owned airline, Expedition Airways, will take delivery of the first of its three planes bought from the United States on December 28, Managing Director Denver Hornsby said Tuesday.

Captain Hornsby said the 19-passenger Beechcraft 1900c is scheduled to leave Kansas, United States on Dec. 26. 

The inaugural flight is expected at the Dec 31.

Expedition Airways will service tertiary markets such as Harare, Bulawayo, Masvingo, Gweru, Chiredzi, Victoria Falls, Hwange and Mutare on a charter.

"Our objective is to bring air service to Zimbabwe's major center and make the once neglected smaller towns accessible by air.

"This will open up unique investment opportunities for the business person and allow the tourist to see a different side of Zimbabwe," Hornsby said.

The airline has trained six pilots in New York City. Three maintenance engineers are currently undergoing training in Kansas.

The airline held successful demonstration flights in Harare, Gweru and Chiredzi earlier in 1996.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 17, 1996


South Africa;
Taiwan Cuts Air Links With South Africa


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The Republic of China, or Taiwan, has suspended air links with South Africa, in retaliation against Pretoria's decision to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from the end of 1997.

Officials announced Monday in Johannesburg and in Taipei that South African Airways (SAA) had been ordered to stop flying to Taipei from Feb. 15, 1997. 

"We give SAA two months to prepare to stop flights. But the flights can resume once we have achieved a satisfactory framework for our future ties," Taiwan Foreign Minister Chang Hsiao-Yen said.

Confirming this Tuesday, a SAA spokesman said the company was studying the relevant documentation. The normal cancellation period for landing rights was 12 months.

The spokesman added that passengers would soon be informed about the implications of the decision to suspend air links. At the moment SAA operates two flights a week from Johannesburg to Taipei.

The air pact is the first of a total of 26 government treaties with South Africa that Taiwan is suspending. It is also ending 17 cooperation projects worth almost 4.5 billion U.S. dollars.

Taiwan has also recalled its ambassador to South Africa -- I-Cheng Loh. He left Sunday.

On his departure, he told the media that he hoped to return to South Africa in 1997 to take part in negotiations aimed at developing a framework for future relations between the two countries.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 17, 1996


Zambia;
Some One Million Zambian Children Work As Laborers


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia has about one million children working as domestic laborers and who are also vulnerable to sexual and physical abuse, the UNICEF representative in Zambia, Mark Stirling, said Tuesday. 

He challenged the Zambian government to investigate the magnitude of child labour and set measures to curb this nation-wide.

Speaking at the official launching of the 1997 State of the World's Children report, Stirling said estimates were that one million children in Zambia aged 5-14 years work as domestic laborers.

He said a growing number of child sex workers in the country were also vulnerable to HIV infection, the virus that leads to AIDS.

Africa News


December 17, 1996


East Africa;
Canadian Troops Leave Uganda For Home


BYLINE: Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Half of the 300 Canadian troops in Uganda as part of a humanitarian multinational force for Zaire will have left for home by the end of Tuesday, a spokesman for the troops has said.

The official, Lt. Col. Rejean Duschesneau, said the first 51 soldiers left Monday. 

"Another 100 soldiers will leave for home on Friday," he said.

All troops will be home by Dec 31.

The decision to end the mission was taken Saturday by the United Nations steering group set up to resolve the problem. The force, headquartered in Kampala, was initially meant to ensure delivery of food supplies to Rwandan refugees in war-torn eastern Zaire, until March 1997. While Uganda welcomed the mission, Rwanda and Zaire expressed reservations about its role.

The multinational force headquarters in Kampala said Canada informed the United Nations that it believed that the military mission was "no longer the most appropriate means to address the humanitarian situation in eastern Zaire.

Canada's decision to return its troops home was based on the report of the first-hand assessment presented to the steering group by the commander of multinational force, Lt. Gen. Maurice Baril of Canada.

Baril was quoted as saying that the force's mission to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian aid had been overtaken by the voluntary return of Rwandan refugees. He said that humanitarian relief agencies and local authorities could help refugees who remain in eastern Zaire.

Canada's focus will now shift to coordinating international efforts under civilian leadership, which it believes will resolve to address the political problems in the central African region.

Baril said that Uganda had given "outstanding support" to the multinational force during its one-month stay in the country.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


405 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


East Africa;
Summit Sets Up Committee To Solve Great Lakes Crisis


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - African leaders have set up a four-man committee from among their number to work out ways to end fighting in the Great Lakes region in East Africa.

The leaders meet Monday in Nairobi to review the situation in the region and chose the presidents of Cameroon, Kenya, Zimbabwe and South Africa to spearhead the peace mission.

Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe attended the Great Lakes summit for the first time in his capacity as the chairman of the Southern African Development Community organ on Politics, Defence and Security. South African President Nelson Mandela attended as the community's chairman. 

Mugabe told journalists on his return to Harare that the committee would include the secretary-general of the Organization of African Unity, Salim Ahmed Salim. Mugabe said that Salim would contact leaders in the directly concerned with the crisis with a view to finding a lasting end to the fighting.

"We should get into action as soon as circumstances allow," Mugabe said.

He said that one of the leaders who will be consulted is Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko, who arrived in Kinshasa Tuesday after prolonged treatment in Switzerland for prostrate cancer.

Zaire has boycotted both summits on the crisis as his parliament has passed a law forbidding participation in any meetings for as long as part of the country was occupied by "foreign forces."

Mugabe said while some Western countries, particularly the United States, had their own ideas about handling the situation in the region, regional players still held the key to achieving peace and stability.

The committee has been set up at a time when political analysts say Zaire is building up its forces to counter the offensive by Tutsi-led Zairian rebels who have conquered a substantial part of eastern part of the country.

At the same time Kinshasa has accused Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda of supporting the rebels, known as the Banyamurenge. The anti-government forces have intensified their offensive and are reportedly determined to topple the Kinshasa government.

Mobutu has been recovering in France from a prostrate cancer operation in Switzerland Aug. 22.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December 17, 1996


Zaire;
Mobutu Returns To Kinshasa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko returned home to Kinshasa Thursday amid high expectations that he would end the rebellion that has engulfed most of his country's east.

Mobutu is expected to make a nationwide radio and television address later in the day, officials in the president's office said. 

He expected to announce a new army chief of staff, ways he intends to deal with the rebellion and methods by which Zaire can complete the country's long transition to democracy.

Mobutu flew home from France where he was recuperating after surgery four months ago for prostrate cancer, in a Swiss clinic.

During his absence, fighting erupted between the Zairian army and Zairian Tutsi anti-government forces known as the Banyamulenge, or Banyamurenge. These anti-government forces have been resisting expulsion from the country where they have lived for some 200 years. The fighting has led to a massive flight of Hutu refugees from eastern Zaire to Rwanda. Hutu refugees initially fled their country after Tutsi-led forces defeated the largely Hutu-led government in Kigali following the 1994 genocide against the Tutsi.

Now, thousands of Zairians have also been displaced in the rebellion- affected Kivu province.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


407 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Global Warming Does Not Bode Well For Africa


BYLINE: David Hecht, ENDA Press Service (Dakar)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1640 words


 

Dakar - Not only will global warming hurt Africa more than any other region, so too may attempts to reduce and compensate for the pollution that causes it. The Subsidiary Body for Scientific and Technological Advice to the Convention on Climate Change are meeting in Geneva this month to work out arrangements which are expected to be made international law by the end of 1997.

The arrangements will likely be a combination of two proposals. One, put forward by the United States, is for the right to pollute carbon dioxide, which is the main reason for the climate change, to be bought and sold like shares, otherwise called 'tradable permits'. (This is based on a 'pollution' stock market that already exists in the US for sulphur dioxide, the cause of acid rain.) The other, proposed by Nordic countries, is for polluting industries to compensate for their pollution in the third world where costs are cheap. That way, advocates claim, poor and under-industrialised countries can also benefit with more foreign investments, the transfer of new technologies, and jobs. This scheme is called ''joint implementation.'' 

But both proposals may only add to Africa's burdens, claims African energy specialist Youba Sokona of the Senegalese based NGO Enda-Energy. With the 'tradable permit' scheme he claims that when cash strapped Africa governments sell their right to pollute they also lose the right to industrialise in the future, and if they ever buy the right back it will be at a much higher price. With joint implementation, Sokona warns that when peasants get paid to grow trees to absorb the carbon dioxide they will stop growing food to feed themselves. The plan, he says, is for ''Africa to get paid to get poorer.''

With the election behind them, the US now appears eager to turn the talk into action. In November, US President Bill Clinton said "I call upon the community of nations to agree to legally binding commitments to fight climate change". Timothy Wirth, US undersecretary of state for global affairs, also said that ''developed countries must take up the lead because we are the people primarily responsible for fouling up the nest.''

Indeed the nest is getting fouler. According to an intergovernmental assessment of scientists, the emission of 21.6 billion tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere in 1990 will, if left unchecked, rise 50 percent by the year 2010. The assessment states that the emissions are largely responsible for having warmed the earth's temperature by 0.3C so far this century, and predicts there will likely be greater extremes of both hot and cold in the near future, with the greatest temperature changes in the northern latitudes, where it will become colder. Effects on human society include higher energy consumption, lower crop yields and, in the third world, more malnutrition and famine.

Thomas Downing of Oxford University's Environmental Change Unit, who recently edited a series of papers called ''Climate Change and World Food Security,'' singles out Sub-Saharan Africa as ''the most threatened'' region in terms of food security. There, ''adverse climatic variations'' are expected to combine with an already ''fragile environment, poor economic growth, (and) rapid population growth,'' he reports.

No one is suggesting that the pollution can be stopped. Rather, at the 1992 Summit on Environment and Development in Rio de Janeiro, 191 countries signed the Convention on Climate Change in which they made a commitment to keep carbon dioxide emissions at the 1990 level. The current round of negotiations are on how to do that. So far, $2 billion has been put forward by governments, via the Global Environmental Facility but experts say that will not even begin to address the problem. They estimate that the cost will be more like $200 billion and that can only be achieved with the participation of the private sector.

The Convention recognizes that industries cannot pay the massive cost of reducing their emissions on their own. Overly strict regulations inhibit industrial growth, as would excessive taxes on polluters and the consensus is that a healthy environment and economic prosperity must go hand in hand. So negotiators have been trying to think up ingenious incentives that share the burden so that everyone can gain.

By turning the right to emit into stocks that governments can sell, poor, unindustrialised countries will probably have more stocks than they need and sell them off to industries in developed countries where there will likely be a shortage of stocks. Or also, the industries may provide anti-pollution technology to help poor countries reduce emissions caused by inefficient burning of fossil fuels and, in return, they can skim off some of the extra stocks for themselves. Beyond growing forests, joint implementation could also include the draining of wetlands, which could also lower carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere, or various other actions that only indirectly reduce the emissions. An international body will be set up to judge each activity and credit the industry with the right to then emit a certain amount of pollution itself.

Sokona makes the point that the carbon dioxide emitted from all of Sub- Saharan Africa is less than that of New York state and questions an approach that allows big industry to reduce the emissions of others so that it can keep pumping it out.

Even advocates agree that joint implementation depends on the disparities between rich and poor countries but they say that if it is well negotiated it should not undermine poor countries attempts to produce food or industrialise. Rather, they say, the plan will encourage the West to do what Africans have long been asking them to do -- invest in them. They say it is even possible that, in exchange for polluting, industries could get credit for assisting poor countries with actions that have little impact on carbon dioxide emissions such as alleviating poverty or improving health services.

But Dr R. S. Maya, an expert at the Southern Centre in Zimbabwe, describes joint implementation as ''environmental colonialism.'' He warns that the plan could allow Western industries to grab all the cheap ways to reduce carbon dioxide while leaving mostly high cost options for the industrial late-comers in the third world. Maya also says that for Western companies to cheaply fulfill their obligations in joint implementation they could probably dumping unwanted or unproven technologies on the third world, and notes recent past experiences with Western companies dumping toxic waste in Africa.

A recent policy note prepared by the Norwegian Centre of International Climate and Energy Research in Oslo, disagrees, claiming that joint implementation could be the thing to stop Africa's growing marginalisation from the rest of the world. The region has had no major inter-regional trade agreements as has happened between Western powers and Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe and analysis of the new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) suggests that Africa has missed out there too.

But Maya says he doubts that industrialised nations will suddenly have a ''change of heart'' in Africa. The world needs a dumping ground and Maya even suggests that joint implementation could be used as a way for Western companies to circumvent GATT's already weak anti-dumping regulations. He cites a pilot project Norway is currently implementing in Mexico that involves the manufacture and marketing of experimental, energy-efficient fluorescent lamps. In his view, the lamps are only marketable as long as they are subsidised, and in the meantime the project is undermining local production of conventional lamps.

Sokona also wonders whether big industries will be interested in joint implementation in Africa. ''They will want to reduce emissions in India and China, which have hugely inefficient industries, than working in Africa that has very little and that is also politically and economically unstable,'' he says. China is currently the third largest consumer of energy in the world.

Sokona admits that the privatisation schemes are the only way to reduce the so called greenhouse effect and says that the plan could work ''in theory''. But in practice, African governments are ''over-burdened, under-staffed and inexperienced and do not have the capacity to think long term, '' he says. ''Most are not even aware of the risks.'' Bilateral arrangements are expected to begin next year. ''When it proves cheap for rich countries and profitable in the short term for poor ones everyone will likely jump on the bandwagon,'' says Sokona.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


408 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


Zambia;
Squeeze Aid To Zambia


BYLINE: Matsautso Phiri and Milimo Moyo, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Lusaka - A prominent Zambian law professor has called on Paris Club countries to take "a strong stand on the question of democracy and "maintain their aid squeeze"on Zambia.

Professor Muna Ndulo, formerly dean of the School of Law at the University of Zambia made the call ahead of the donors consultative meeting at the Paris Club next February.

But nominated member of parliament Christopher Chawinga has dismissed Ndulo as a loud mouthed and unpatriotic Zambian who does not care about the poor people of Zambia.

Ndulo observed that the November 18 elections "cannot be free and fair" and the holding of these elections "will damage Zambia's image" throughout the democratic world. 

"We hope the donor countries will maintain their aid squeeze. It is important that the forthcoming annual Paris Club meeting on Zambia takes a very strong stand on the question of democracy in Zambia," writes Professor Ndulo.

Chawinga does not agree.

"How can a Zambian advocate such a bad thing for his country? Muna Ndulo ran away from this country and has not come back to develop it. He is content with his good education and does not care about poor Zambians who will suffer if Zambia is denied international aid", Chawinga said in an interview last night.

He added that Zambia did not deserve an aid squeeze as it has had the best democratic record on the African continent.

And AFRONET director Ngande Mwananjiti was non committal on the aid squeeze but said donors should consider matters of governance when they reviewed Zambia's position at the next Paris Club meeting.

"We do not want a situation where those in power do whatever they want. We also want human rights to be respected; so donors should be consistent with their earlier statements regarding democratic governance in Zambia," Mwananjiti said in an interview last night.

The Zambian law professor, who has also worked for the United Nations and is now with Cornell university in the United States of America however says the country has failed "miserably" to satisfy internationally accepted standards on elections.

"The concept of 'free and fair' elections is about the entire electoral process and not about the conduct of voting on election day as many in the MMD seem to think," Ndulo writes, adding. "The term 'free and fair' has attained a clear and precise meaning in international practice. It injects substance into the principle with regard to the right to democratic governance established by article 21 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights."

Ndulo, who lists six factors which must be satisfied if elections are to be internationally accepted as being free and fair, says the November 18 elections "miserably" failed to meet these standards.

He cites lack of equal participation in standing for office caused by the 1996 constitution as one ground.

"The amendments to the constitution are clearly discriminatory. They restrict the right of Zambians to stand for elective office of the president as well as restrict the right of traditional rulers to stand for elective political office and thereby deny their right to participate in the political life of the country," Ndulo writes pointing out that this is against article 26 of the Declaration of Human Rights

Other grounds are lack of equal access "to government controlled media as is the case in Zambia today. No one in Zambia, who is in their right mind, would deny that the Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation, Zambia Daily Mail and the Times Of Zambia are partisan institutions."

The Nikuv voter registration too "does not meet international standards".

"In free and fair elections it is important that universal suffrage be the basis of the elections but universal suffrage is only one element of fairness. Another is the concept of equal suffrage. This is the idea traditionally expressed in the phrase 'one person one vote'", Ndulo says, adding that the Nikuv register undermines these internationally accepted standards.

But Ndulo also examines the electoral commission and its members who must be appointed by consensus of "the political parties contesting the elections."

"There can be little doubt that the Zambian Elections Commission is partisan. It is not sufficient, as Justice Bwalya seems to think, that the law creating it says it is independent. This kind of analysis befits a villager and not a properly trained lawyer. It belongs to the world of the Sata's where fact and fiction are interchangeable," Ndulo says.

"That fact alone would never qualify a person for appointment to an electoral commission in any decent system. Is it any wonder that Justice Bwalya's reaction to the story of ghost voters on voters roll is not to promise investigation into the matter as any independent commission would do, but in true fashion of a partisan chairperson dismiss the allegations without any investigation," Ndulo says.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


409 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


Zambia;
Opposition Condemn MMD Polls 'Support' Demonstration


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri and Milimo Moyo, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - The Opposition Alliance has condemned plans by the ruling Movement for Multi-party Democracy (MMD) to hold a solidarity march to State House this Saturday.

The match has been called in support of the just ended elections.

But the MMD has defended its right to hold the demonstration. 

Alliance chairman Roger Chongwe said in an interview yesterday that the march was organised to "hoodwink people of Zambia that President Chiluba was popularly elected".

"It's the same thing Chiluba did when he signed the constitution. So this will also be an MMD affair," Chongwe said, in reference to a similar match in solidarity of Chiluba's assent to the controversial 1996 Constitution.

"This will not make people of this country recognise the Chiluba government as having been elected legitimately," Chongwe said.

MMD have been running advertisements in both the print and electronic state media over the last week on the demonstration.

And Minister of Science, Technology and Vocational Training Enoch Kavindele has defended his party's planned march saying MMD members also had a right to march whenever they saw the need to.

"We have had no objections whenever the opposition have had their little marches even if these have not been successful, so I do not see any reason why our members cannot march when they feel there is a need to march," Kavindele said in an interview last night.

Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) president Alfred Zulu advised the government to concentrate on resolving the problems in the entire electoral process.

"The process of demonstrations and celebrations is not acceptable.What should happen now is to resolve the differences surrounding the elections," Zulu said.

He said the electoral process in terms of technicality was a total flop as a few Zambians participated in the elections because of omissions and other mistakes.

"Solidarity with who because even the people who participated in the elections are saying they were fraudulent," Zulu asked.

LANGUAGE: English

410 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


Science and Health;
6.2m Condoms Sold This Year In Zambia


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda and Milimo Moyo, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - A total of 6.2 million "safe sex" condoms have been sold this year alone and another 20 million dished out free by government, the distributors Zambia Social Marketing Project have said.

And a liquid condom has been invented in South Africa.

Speaking in an interview yesterday, director of contraceptive social marketing, Sanjay Changanti however bemoaned the contribution to safe sex being made by his organisation saying it was very negligible. 

"Our objective is to provide affordable contraceptives and also to change people's attitudes.When you compare the sales to the number of condoms required you realise that we don't even manage to provide three condoms to all sexually active adults," Changati said.

In view of this ZSMP has launched a month long study to ascertain the impact of its four year programme. ZSMP concentrates on condom use and behavioral changes among the people.

Changati further said the study, depending on how people responded, would determine whether the Maximum Condom brand or packaging should be changed.

"It has taken us four years to build the identity of maximum which was after a lot of study," he said adding: "But it would not be changed on frivolous grounds."

He further disclosed that the government had also contributed largely to the distribution of condoms as it was giving out a total of 20 million condoms annually.

Meanwhile, a South African company Condomania has produced a new Liquid condom called Liquidom which has to be applied to the male organ before copulation.

The condom takes five to seven minutes to apply the liquidom after which it immediately forms a protective sheath that shields against pregnancy and STDs.

But some Zambian men interviewed have shunned the liquidom saying it took too long to apply and this could spoil the sexual act.

"Seven minutes is too long to pause during the act; I mean one could easily lose one's erection in that period," Nelson Siwale, a Lusaka accountant said.

Another Lusaka businessman, Michael Chabwera said the liquidom would make the sexual act more awkward than the condom did.

Others believe the liquid is a risk too high to take in view of the HIV- AIDS.

The liquid condom was invented by an Australian scientist and Condomania undertook to market it after carrying numerous successful tests on thousands of volunteers all over the world.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


411 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


Science and Health;
500 Women Contract Hiv Daily In Zambia


BYLINE: Masauso Lungu, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - At least 500 hundred young women in Zambia are daily getting infected with the HIV virus that causes AIDS, disclosed Youth and Child Development deputy minister Mutale Chitika in Lusaka yesterday.

Chitika said this when she officially closed a week long National Youth Conference whose theme was: "Behaviour Change, An Essential Strategy to the fight Against HIV/AIDS" at the University of Zambia. 

And other statistics made available to the delegates to the conference on HIV/AIDS indicate that in the age group of 15- 39 there are about 700,000 people in Zambia infected with the HIV virus.

She said the Zambian population has about 70 per cent youths who are at great risk of contracting the HIV/AIDS and need protection.

"It is therefore a matter of utmost importance and greatest urgency that the young are protected from this deadly disease AIDS. The spread of HIV/AIDS however seems to be on the increase especially among young women with an estimated infection rate of 500 or so new cases per day,'' Chitika said.

"It is therefore imperative that the youth are assisted to understand this disease and to develop heathy living habits," she added.

Chitika called on the youths to discuss and reach a consensus on how to deal with the disease in a manner which is meaningful and acceptable to all young people and look at abstinence as a means of preventing the spread of HIV/AIDS.

And a youth delegate Brill Edwards urged the youths to change behaviour as it is the most essential strategy to fight HIV/AIDS.

Africa News


December 17, 1996


East Africa;
Amnesty: Tanzania & UNHCR Must Respect International Law


BYLINE: Human Rights Watch (New York)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

New York - Human Rights Watch/Africa today called on the Tanzanian government and UNHCR to stop forcing the Rwandan refugees to repatriate and to lift their demand that all Rwandan refugees return by December 31, 1996.

The human rights organization stated that the reported use of teargas and sticks by Tanzanian authorities to herd refugees towards the border is coercion which violates international refugee law. Moreover, the decision to apply an arbitrary deadline to all refugees without distinction takes no account of persecution of legitimate refugees. In addition, the Tanzanian government has restricted all access to the camps, lending credence to reports of intimidation being used indiscriminately against refugees. 

"The Tanzanian government's use of force to drive Rwandan refugees over the border is a blot on their traditionally good record in respect of refugee rights," noted Peter Takirambudde, Executive Director of Human Rights Watch/Africa. "Moreover, the United Nations High Commission on Refugees (UNHCR) has shamefully abandoned its responsibility to protect refugees." This is the third instance this year of forced repatriation of Rwandan refugees that UNHCR and the international community have watched with little protest. In July and August, Burundi forcibly returned some 80,000 Rwandan refugees, and in October and November, the Rwandan refugee camps in eastern Zaire were forcibly dispersed by Zairian rebel groups, with the support of the Rwandan government.

The refugee camps in Tanzania and in Zaire have been under the control of the former Rwandan army and militia, which have launched military incursions over the border into Rwanda as well as used terror and force to prevent voluntary repatriation. Since the refugee camps were created over two years ago, the international community has never been willing to devote the necessary political or financial resources to screen out combatants or those suspected of genocide.

Under refugee law, those suspected of genocide and crimes against humanity, like those involved in military activity against their home government, have no right to the status of refugee and should have been excluded from such status. Had the international community provided the necessary assistance to undertake such a task at the outset, then those who wished to return could have done so and legitimate refugees would have been assured of the protection promised by law.

The international community has barely disguised its satisfaction at seeing the refugee camps around Rwanda forcibly disbanded. But merely moving the refugees from one side of the border to the other will not offer any lasting solution without justice for genocide victims and improved respect for human rights by the Rwandan government.

The Rwandan judiciary is still not functioning, over two years later, and over 85,000 prisoners are being held in inhumane conditions without trial. The government must begin trials of those accused of genocide and provide concrete information about the proceedings. To address refugee fears of attacks by the Rwandan military once they return to their home communes, the government must acknowledge and condemn killings by the military and begin investigation and prosecution of those responsible. The government has scheduled a court martial of Col. Fred Ibingira for December 19 in connection with the killing of displaced persons in Kibeho in April 1995.

A fair and rigorous trial would reassure refugees and demonstrate to the international community its commitment to bring to justice soldiers responsible for human rights abuses. Returning refugees also fear that they will have no home or no fields to plant if they return. Legitimate fears exists that they may be imprisoned on false charges of genocide if they attempt to regain their occupied property. The government must take steps to ensure that property disputes are dealt with equitably and fairly.

Those legitimate refugees who choose to remain in Tanzania must be provided with protection and assistance by UNHCR. Simultaneously, the international community must provide the funds needed by the United Nations Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda to continue long-term monitoring of the refugees who have returned to Rwanda. Whatever the cost of this operation, it is far less than what would be needed to provide continuing assistance for people too fearful of persecution to return home. The international community must also renew its commitment to bring perpetrators of genocide to book under the jurisdiction of the U.N. International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, which was created in 1994 to hold genocide perpetrators accountable in an international procedure.

RECOMMENDATIONS

To the Government of Tanzania:

Immediately end the use of force against Rwandan refugees.

Lift the arbitrary return deadline of December 31, 1996 for all Rwandan refugees to return.

Permit journalists and other observers access to areas around the refugee camps.

Guarantee protection to legitimate refugees to remain in Tanzania and permit international humanitarian organizations to provide relief to them.

To the International Community:

Guarantee the right of legitimate refugees to protection from forcible repatriation and ensure that humanitarian supplies are provided in Tanzania and Zaire for those legitimate refugees who decide not to return to Rwanda.

Institute screening procedures to exclude from refugee status any combatants or those suspected of genocide or crimes against humanity.

Pressure the Tanzanian government to ensure that returning refugees are protected from coercion.

Pressure the Rwandan government to continue to ensure the rights of returning refugees and to put the judicial system into operation.

Provide financial and political support for the work of the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda and the U.N. Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda.

Provide the resources necessary for the resettlement of all refugees, whether the old case load or those recently returned.

To the Government of Rwanda:

Ensure that full protection of the law is assured to all Rwandans, including those refugees who have just returned.

Begin the trials of those accused of genocide and provide concrete information about the proceedings and provisions being made for defense counsel.

Acknowledge and condemn killings by the military and immediately begin investigation and prosecution of those responsible.

Ensure that resources for resettlement are fairly and equitably used to resettle all refugees, whether the old case load or those recently returned.

Human Rights Watch 485 Fifth Avenue New York, NY 10017-6104 TEL: 212/972- 8400 FAX: 212/972-0905 E-mail: hrwnyc@hrw.org. 1522 K Street, N.W. Washington D.C. 20005 TEL: 202/371-6592 FAX: 202/371-0124 E-mail: hrwdc@hrw.org


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

413 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


United States and Africa;
White House Statement on New UN Secretary General


BYLINE: White House


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Washington - Text of statement by President Clinton on the election of Kofi Annan of Ghana as the new secretary general of the United Nations.

I'm delighted by today's vote in the United Nations Security Council, selecting Kofi Annan of Ghana to be the new UN Secretary General. We are hopeful that the General Assembly will concur with the Security Council early next week. 

Through his decades of work at the United Nations and in the international arena, Kofi Annan has established excellent working relations with many countries, including the United States. Over the last four years as UN Undersecretary for Peacekeeping, and throughout his impressive career, he has proven himself an able and energetic manager -- professional, impartial, well- versed in the issues at hand, and a true proponent of reform. We are confident he will take concrete steps to inspire the world to support the UN, inspire the UN to live up to its ideals, and transform those ideals into action.

Since its founding more than half a century ago, the United Nations has been a vehicle for peace and progress that has served the interests of America and the world. Since taking office, I have worked hard with Congress to sustain America's support for the United Nations.

Precisely because we believe in the United Nations, my Administration has also led the fight for far-reaching UN reform. To meet the challenges of the 21st century, the UN must keep pace with the times -achieving its work with fewer people and resources, reducing waste and rationalizing priorities, and producing better results at lower costs. The world community needs a United Nations that spends less on overhead and outdated agencies and more on services that directly benefit people's daily lives.

I believe the United Nations must have a leader who is committed to these goals. That is why I decided we needed a new Secretary General. I knew this would be a controversial decision, but it was the right thing to do.

The outgoing UN Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, is an honorable man who has led a great career -- from the breakthrough for Middle East peace at Camp David to his leadership of the United Nations as it celebrated its 50th anniversary. Now, we must prepare the United Nations for the demands of the next 50 years. I am confident Kofi Annan will rise to this task with conviction.

I am committed to work closely with the Congress to meet America's obligations to the United Nations and to make good on our arrears. And I am sure that my nominee for our UN Ambassador, Bill Richardson, will work effectively with the new Secretary General to renew and revitalize this historic organization to take on the challenges of the future.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


414 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


Zimbabwe;
New Zimbabwe Airline Prepares To Fly


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 835 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's latest privately-owned airline, Expedition Airways, will take delivery of the first of its three planes bought from the United States on December 28, Managing Director Denver Hornsby said Tuesday.

Captain Hornsby said the 19-passenger Beechcraft 1900c is scheduled to leave Kansas, United States on Dec. 26. 

The inaugural flight is expected at the Dec 31.

Expedition Airways will service tertiary markets such as Harare, Bulawayo, Masvingo, Gweru, Chiredzi, Victoria Falls, Hwange and Mutare on a charter.

"Our objective is to bring air service to Zimbabwe's major center and make the once neglected smaller towns accessible by air.

"This will open up unique investment opportunities for the business person and allow the tourist to see a different side of Zimbabwe," Hornsby said.

The airline has trained six pilots in New York City. Three maintenance engineers are currently undergoing training in Kansas.

The airline held successful demonstration flights in Harare, Gweru and Chiredzi earlier in 1996.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


415 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


South Africa;
Taiwan Cuts Air Links With South Africa


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The Republic of China, or Taiwan, has suspended air links with South Africa, in retaliation against Pretoria's decision to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from the end of 1997.

Officials announced Monday in Johannesburg and in Taipei that South African Airways (SAA) had been ordered to stop flying to Taipei from Feb. 15, 1997. 

"We give SAA two months to prepare to stop flights. But the flights can resume once we have achieved a satisfactory framework for our future ties," Taiwan Foreign Minister Chang Hsiao-Yen said.

Confirming this Tuesday, a SAA spokesman said the company was studying the relevant documentation. The normal cancellation period for landing rights was 12 months.

The spokesman added that passengers would soon be informed about the implications of the decision to suspend air links. At the moment SAA operates two flights a week from Johannesburg to Taipei.

The air pact is the first of a total of 26 government treaties with South Africa that Taiwan is suspending. It is also ending 17 cooperation projects worth almost 4.5 billion U.S. dollars.

Taiwan has also recalled its ambassador to South Africa -- I-Cheng Loh. He left Sunday.

On his departure, he told the media that he hoped to return to South Africa in 1997 to take part in negotiations aimed at developing a framework for future relations between the two countries.


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December 17, 1996


Zambia;
Some One Million Zambian Children Work As Laborers


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia has about one million children working as domestic laborers and who are also vulnerable to sexual and physical abuse, the UNICEF representative in Zambia, Mark Stirling, said Tuesday. 

He challenged the Zambian government to investigate the magnitude of child labour and set measures to curb this nation-wide.

Speaking at the official launching of the 1997 State of the World's Children report, Stirling said estimates were that one million children in Zambia aged 5-14 years work as domestic laborers.

He said a growing number of child sex workers in the country were also vulnerable to HIV infection, the virus that leads to AIDS.

417 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


East Africa;
Canadian Troops Leave Uganda For Home


BYLINE: Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Half of the 300 Canadian troops in Uganda as part of a humanitarian multinational force for Zaire will have left for home by the end of Tuesday, a spokesman for the troops has said.

The official, Lt. Col. Rejean Duschesneau, said the first 51 soldiers left Monday. 

"Another 100 soldiers will leave for home on Friday," he said.

All troops will be home by Dec 31.

The decision to end the mission was taken Saturday by the United Nations steering group set up to resolve the problem. The force, headquartered in Kampala, was initially meant to ensure delivery of food supplies to Rwandan refugees in war-torn eastern Zaire, until March 1997. While Uganda welcomed the mission, Rwanda and Zaire expressed reservations about its role.

The multinational force headquarters in Kampala said Canada informed the United Nations that it believed that the military mission was "no longer the most appropriate means to address the humanitarian situation in eastern Zaire.

Canada's decision to return its troops home was based on the report of the first-hand assessment presented to the steering group by the commander of multinational force, Lt. Gen. Maurice Baril of Canada.

Baril was quoted as saying that the force's mission to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian aid had been overtaken by the voluntary return of Rwandan refugees. He said that humanitarian relief agencies and local authorities could help refugees who remain in eastern Zaire.

Canada's focus will now shift to coordinating international efforts under civilian leadership, which it believes will resolve to address the political problems in the central African region.

Baril said that Uganda had given "outstanding support" to the multinational force during its one-month stay in the country.


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


418 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


East Africa;
Summit Sets Up Committee To Solve Great Lakes Crisis


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - African leaders have set up a four-man committee from among their number to work out ways to end fighting in the Great Lakes region in East Africa.

The leaders meet Monday in Nairobi to review the situation in the region and chose the presidents of Cameroon, Kenya, Zimbabwe and South Africa to spearhead the peace mission.

Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe attended the Great Lakes summit for the first time in his capacity as the chairman of the Southern African Development Community organ on Politics, Defence and Security. South African President Nelson Mandela attended as the community's chairman. 

Mugabe told journalists on his return to Harare that the committee would include the secretary-general of the Organization of African Unity, Salim Ahmed Salim. Mugabe said that Salim would contact leaders in the directly concerned with the crisis with a view to finding a lasting end to the fighting.

"We should get into action as soon as circumstances allow," Mugabe said.

He said that one of the leaders who will be consulted is Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko, who arrived in Kinshasa Tuesday after prolonged treatment in Switzerland for prostrate cancer.

Zaire has boycotted both summits on the crisis as his parliament has passed a law forbidding participation in any meetings for as long as part of the country was occupied by "foreign forces."

Mugabe said while some Western countries, particularly the United States, had their own ideas about handling the situation in the region, regional players still held the key to achieving peace and stability.

The committee has been set up at a time when political analysts say Zaire is building up its forces to counter the offensive by Tutsi-led Zairian rebels who have conquered a substantial part of eastern part of the country.

At the same time Kinshasa has accused Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda of supporting the rebels, known as the Banyamurenge. The anti-government forces have intensified their offensive and are reportedly determined to topple the Kinshasa government.

Mobutu has been recovering in France from a prostrate cancer operation in Switzerland Aug. 22.


LOAD-DATE: December 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


419 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 17, 1996


Zaire;
Mobutu Returns To Kinshasa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko returned home to Kinshasa Thursday amid high expectations that he would end the rebellion that has engulfed most of his country's east.

Mobutu is expected to make a nationwide radio and television address later in the day, officials in the president's office said. 

He expected to announce a new army chief of staff, ways he intends to deal with the rebellion and methods by which Zaire can complete the country's long transition to democracy.

Mobutu flew home from France where he was recuperating after surgery four months ago for prostrate cancer, in a Swiss clinic.

During his absence, fighting erupted between the Zairian army and Zairian Tutsi anti-government forces known as the Banyamulenge, or Banyamurenge. These anti-government forces have been resisting expulsion from the country where they have lived for some 200 years. The fighting has led to a massive flight of Hutu refugees from eastern Zaire to Rwanda. Hutu refugees initially fled their country after Tutsi-led forces defeated the largely Hutu-led government in Kigali following the 1994 genocide against the Tutsi.

Now, thousands of Zairians have also been displaced in the rebellion- affected Kivu province.

LANGUAGE: English
