Africa News


December 18, 1996


East Africa;
WFP Great Lakes Situation Report No. 40


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Rome - ZAIRE: WFP started the airlift into Kisangani of 120 mt of food items using a Boeing 707 aircraft leased from a Zairean transporter. Today 80 mt of food commodities, including 20 mt of high-energy biscuits, are being airlifted into Kisangani. The transportation of food onwards to Lubutu/Tingi Tingi, to assist the estimated 120,000 refugees and IDPs in need in this area, will be carried out in collaboration with La Procure (the logistics service branch of the Catholic Church) with vehicles and/or using available small aircraft.

A WFP mission with the Regional Manager of the Great Lakes Region is visiting Kisangani and Lubutu today and tomorrow. The mission traveled with the aircraft carrying the first 40 mt of food items to Kisangani. In Lubutu/Tingi-Tingi, the mission will examine the distributions being carried out by La Procure, MSF France, NCA/LWF, the International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies and CARITAS. 

An inter-agency UN mission, with the Regional Humanitarian Coordinator and the WFP Country Director in Kinshasa, is scheduled to travel today to Kisangani, Lubutu and Shabunda out of Kinshasa.

RWANDA:

Some 84,000 Rwandan refugees returned from Tanzania on 17 December. The cumulative number from 14 to 17 December is estimated at some 227,500. The returnee inflow continues.

Most returnees continue to walk the first 20 km from the Rusumo border point however some vulnerable returnees are receiving transportation.

WFP continues to distribute high-energy biscuits to returnees at strategic way stations along the route to their home communes.

From 11 to 16 December, some 9,000 returnees arrived in Rwanda from Zaire via the Gisenyi border crossing point.

TANZANIA:

Except for some 2,000 Rwandan refugees returning to Rwanda from the Karagwe region in Tanzania, all returnees have been arriving from the Ngara camps. The repatriation exercise from the Karagwe camps is expected to begin tomorrow with the estimated arrival of some returnees at Rusumo border crossing point as early as this weekend. The estimated number of Rwandan refugees remaining in or near the Karagwe camps is 120,000. Way stations are being set up with the intention to provide essential services from Karagwe to the Rusumo border point.

At Karagwe camps, WFP is carrying out a two-week distribution of maizemeal and a one-week distribution of vegetable oil and pulses today and tomorrow.

Food distributions continue for Burundian refugees in Ngara camps.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


421 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Algeria;
Algeria Bans Official Use Of French


BYLINE: Ali Dellali, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Algeria has announced a ban on the use of the French language in the country's administration and other public sectors. The measure becomes effective July 5, 1998.

The National Algerian Transitional Council adopted on Tuesday the decree banning French in two years and calling for the widespread use of Arabic in this former French colony. 

Council has given Algerian universities until July 5, 2000 when they must switch to teaching only in Arabic.

The ban on French is part of the Arabization policy adopted after the country's independence from France on July 5, 1962.

Since then, implementation of this decision has had to be abandoned several times.

For example, in 1994 the decree was suspended due to the conflict between Arabophils and Francophils. The struggle between these two groups for linguistic dominance has still not abated.

The decree was adopted the same day the Ministerial Conference of French- speaking Countries began their meeting in Marrakesh, Morocco.

The use of Arabic should be widespread by July 5, 1998 and by July 5, 2000 it should be compulsory in all the political, economic and social sectors in Algeria.

Thereafter no political statement, speech, or correspondence can be in French neither can any conference or lecture be given in this language. Television programmes and oral communications will be made in Arabic.

Any public official writing documents in a language other than Arabic -- apart from contracts with international firms -- will be liable to a fine of 5,000 dinars (about 90 US dollars).

It is uncertain to what degree Algerians will heed this edict, although some 75 percent of the country's 26.6 million people are Arabs. Algerians have failed to obey orders to conduct government business exclusively in Arabic over the past 34 years. Moreover, some 25 percent of the population are Berbers who want their language, the indigenous language, to be given greater official recognition by the government.

Some opposition parties see the decree as a concession by President Liamine Zeroual to militant Moslem groups. The country has been embroiled in violence between the secular government and radical Moslem organizations.

The new decree also makes provision for the creation of a High Council for Arabic Language chaired by the Algerian head of state.

In a similar move, the present French government of Prime Minister Jacque Touvon has passed a law compelling radio stations in the country to play a certain percentage of their music in French and not English. French ultra- nationalists have been complaining that too many English words were in current use in French.

However, despite or because of its former French colonial status, Algeria has said that English, and not French, will be the first and most important foreign language taught in its schools.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


422 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Zambia;
Chiluba Asks His Ministers To Declare Assets


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba has given his newly appointed ministers till Jan. 2, 1997 to declare their assets and liabilities.

During the swearing-in of two ministers Wednesday, Chiluba said that none of the new ministers had made public their assets and liabilities. 

Under Zambian law, certain categories of public office holders must declare their assets. This requirement is intended to portray a transparent image of government leaders.

Chiluba, recently re-elected to a second term of office, declared in October that he had four vehicles, owned three homes in both high and low cost residential areas of Ndola, a mining town in the northern Copperbelt region.

He has no other source of income, apart from his salary and the rents he draws from his homes. He declared two bank accounts with a combined total of 2.8 million kwacha (about 2,333 U.S. dollars).

Africa News


December 18, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambian Government Seizes Control Of Soccer Finances


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The government in Lusaka has taken full charge of the finances of the Football Association of Zambia, the country's supreme soccer-governing body, to help streamline administration of the national soccer team, Sports Minister Samuel Miyanda said Wednesday.

The measure followed a revolt Tuesday by players of the national soccer team players, who abandoned their camp in the capital in protest against unpaid allowances. 

The team had just returned from Kenya where it played two friendly matches against that country's national soccer side. The Zambian team is due to leave Thursday for Zimbabwe for similar warm up matches in readiness for the Jan. 12, 1997 second World Cup qualifying match against South Africa.

Miyanda said at his news conference that he had ordered fresh elections early in 1997 for a fully-fledged National Executive Committee of the association. It will replace the current interim body.

Two years ago government dismissed the association's chairman, Jabes Zulu, and his deputy, Wilfrid Wonani, for alleged misappropriation of funds.

The association relies solely on government money and some fund raising activities to meet its needs.

Africa News


December 18, 1996


Zaire;
UN Food Agency Airlifts Urgent Supplies To Eastern Zaire


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - A World Food Programme chartered Boeing 707 cargo jet arrived in Kisangani, eastern Zaire, Wednesday with 38.5 metric tons of urgently needed food supplies for Rwandan and Burundian refugees in Lubutu, the agency said.

From it headquarters in Rome, the agency said the flight was the first of three that will bring a total of 120 ton of high protein biscuits, maize meal, beans and oil to refugees in Lubutu, some 200 kilometers (about 124 miles) south of Kisangani. 

The remaining flights are expected within the next 48 hours. The deliveries will feed 120,000 people for four to five days.

Field officials for the agency report that the food situation in the area is critical and that many children show signs of severe dehydration. The refugees walked for almost one month before reaching Lubutu, surviving on wild food.

The refugees fled fighting in the eastern Zairean towns of Goma and Bukavu. Zairians displaced by the war are also among the refugees.

Africa News


December 18, 1996


Zambia;
Broadcast Company Advisers Former Director


BYLINE: Milimo Moyo, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - Those who live in glass houses should not through stones, ZNBC advised its former director of programmes, Frank Mutubila, in a letter to The Post yesterday.

ZNBC public relations manager, Keith Nalumango, yesterday warned Mutubila not to throw stones at the corporation because he himself lived in a glass house and advised him to keep the organisation out of talk about his departure. 

Nalumango was reacting to an article in the Monday edition of The Post which quoted Mutubila as saying the programmes he produced for the station earned ZNBC K54 million per quarter.

"Your readers may surely wish to know what professional differences Mr Mutubila had with his employers. They will also be interested to know that the corporation makes much more than K54 million per quarter and that no one at ZNBC has claimed individual success for this, for all corporation programmes are the result of collective staff efforts," Nalumango said, adding: "Management would like to advise Mr Mutubila to desist from dragging the Corporation into a public debate over his departure from the corporation as this would not help matters. People who live in glass houses should not throw stones."

Efforts to get Mutubila to comment on the letter from management last night failed as his residential telephone was constantly engaged.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


426 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Zambia;
Women Lobby Group Declare Polls Not Free


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - The Women Lobby Group has joined other Non governmental organisations in declaring the November 18 general and presidential elections not free and fair.

Group Executive director Molly Mwafulilwa said in an interview yesterday that the Women Lobby Group reached its conclusion after carefully analysing all circumstances prior to and after the elections. 

"The November 18 elections can not be declared free and fair because the whole electoral process was fraudulent, some prominent aspiring candidates were eliminated from the race by the constitution, the state media coverage was biased towards the ruling party, campaign activities were so unbalanced and time given to participants to campaign was so short," Mwafulilwa said. " The voting day was generally peaceful but after considering all circumstances leading to the elections there is no way you can say that the elections were free and fair."

And Mwafulilwa whose organisation held a forum last week to analyse the performance of women candidates in the last elections said the lobby will support all women who want to petition against the results.

"We are supporting the issue of petitioning against the elections because most of the people who lost feel that they were unfairly treated," Mwafulilwa said adding: " We shall encourage and support all women losing candidates who want to seek court redress on the principle that their rights were violated."

The Women Lobby becomes the fourth Non-governmental Organisation to declare the November elections not free and fair.

Foundation for Democratic Process (FODEP), Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) and Committee for Clean Campaign (CCC) also declared the polls not free and fair citing a fraudulent electoral process, political differences prior to the elections and various other malpractices.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


427 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Sports - General;
Squash: Zambian Championship On


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Squash Open championship which has not been held for the past two years finally gets underway today at Lusaka Squash Club with the organisers promising sparks during the five-day event.

Tournament organiser, Patson Bluseke, said in an interview yesterday that all the professional Zambian squash players such as Robbie Lingashi, Masambo Selisho, defending women's champion Victoria Chishimba, UK-based Earnest Chisenga and Collins Musonda have all comfirmed participation. 

"We are expecting 22 players from the Copperbelt. They will be beefed up by the midlands players to make it a 32-man draw," Bluseke said adding that international players from Kenya, South Africa, Botswana, Egypt, Nigeria, Tanzania, Uganda and Zimbabwe have indicated willingness to attend.

Lusaka Squash Club chairman, John Musonda, said his club was ready to host the squash extravaganza.

"The tournament is set. The courts are ready and there should be alot of good fun," Musonda said, noting: "We haven't had a tournament of this magnitude for two years and we expect alot of sparks."

According to Bluseke, the preliminaries will commence at 14:00 hours today.

"The second round will be held on Thursday starting at 17:00 hours while the quarter finals will be on Friday," he said.

The semi-finals are expected to be held on Saturday while the ladies finals will commence at 14:00 hours with the men's finals following at 16:00 hours.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

428 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Zaire;
Mobutu's Challenge (Editorial)


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Lusaka - The return to Zaire of President Mobutu Sese Seko should give impectus to the search for a solution to the armed insurrection in Eastern Zaire.His prolonged absence created a void which was probably a factor in the rebel's decision to take up arms and left the authorities in Kinshasa humstrung, unable to take strong action or clear initiatives on the problem

Mobutu's return should change all that. He undoubtedly will have to provide leadership and work to bring to an end the insurrection. The issue is undoubtedly emotive, no country would watch its territory dismembered with arms folded yet a violent response or one merely aimed at regaining lost territory may not necessarily be the best. There is need for a more considered approach. 

African countries cannot afford wars not just because of the drain on meagre resources but largely also because there has been enough slaughter of and suffering among the civilian population as a result of such wars. Many of them have in any case been the result of individual ambitions and not the popular will.

The ordinary people in eastern Zaire will again be the losers if the problem is approached in the old way.

It is hardly reassuring however that the Zairean government through its Information minister is already seeing conspirancies against that country in meetings that concerned African leaders have held to try and find ways out of the impasse. The suggestion that English speaking African countries do not have the interest of French -speaking Africans can only please those quarters bent on dividing Africa. It is pretty omnious too coming as it does shortly after another display of the same attitude in the election of a new Secretary- General of the United Nations

It does seem as though a new era of Africa being a pawn in other peoples games is beginning to the detriment of the continent.There should really be nothing controvesial about African countries whether French or English speaking meeting to discuss a problem of the proportions of the Great Lakes region one. Such meetings in fact should be a source of hope that African, and therefore hopefully more realistic, solutions will be found.The contest betweeen French and English speaking areas seems out of place .

Perhaps Zaire would be disabused of this notion or at least have a clearer view of the motivations of its sister countries if it attended instead of boycotting such meetings. Zaire has consistently stayed away. Despite the emotive nature of the issue, there is a definite place and role for Zaire which is the aggrieved party .

Certainly her participation even as an observer can help eliminate lingering suspicions about the true purpose and spirit of the meetings. Her present stance can only frustrate what can turn out to be constructive African initiatives and serve as invitation to some quarters who may still not be averse to using the continent as a pawn in their contest for spheres of influence.

The problem is an African one and attempts to create a certain consensus among concerned African countries could be the best source of realistic peace initiatives. The involvement of African countries should therefore not be discouraged or looked down upon.

Now, with the return of the Zairean leader that country's attitude and policies towards the problem should crystallise and they should be better founded than the mere belief that English speaking Africa is conspiring against the French speaking countries

. The problem is real. The Rebels in Eastern Zaire are in control of a sizeable part of the country and efforts to dislodge them have so far not succeeded and they have certainly had time to consolidate their military hold on the area. So even by military means it is a by no means easy problem to solve.

It is a real problem requiring considered approaches. Zaire will need to widen and not narrow down consultations on the matter.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


429 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Madagascar;
Madagascar: One Step Forward, Two Backward?


BYLINE: A. Rakotondrandria, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

Nairobi - Unexpectedly, two former presidents, Amdmiral Didier Ratsiraka and Prof. Albert Zafy, will again compete to lead Malagasy as they did in 1993. But this time round, the former military ruler is most likely to recapture the highest office and have his revenge. If elected, he promises a new constitution. But then the whole democratization process will have to be started from scratch again.

The final round of the early presidential elections in Madagascar is due on December 29, 1996, pitting former military ruler Admiral Didier Ratsiraka against his immediate successor, former president Prof. Albert Zafy. Campaigns began earnestly on the island on December 8.

The date was announced in the capital, Antananarivo, at the end of a cabinet meeting held on December 5 after the High Constitutional Court (HCC) rejected a government request that the elections be delayed. 

The two former presidents emerged with the largest number of votes but without the required absolute majority from the first ballot held on November 3. Ratsiraka led with 36 per cent, followed by Zafy with 23 per cent in the race that attracted 15 presidential candidates.

The early presidential elections were convened after Albert Zafy was impeached in September by the Parliament on the ground that he had violated the constitution on several occasions.

Already in 1993, the two men were the final contenders of another early presidential election prompted by popular demand for a more democratic regime. Zafy, then backed by a large section of the Malagasy political community, civil society and Church, won against Ratsiraka, thereby reviving hope for a better life in an impoverished country where mere survival is, in certain areas, a real achievement.

But unlike in 1993, Ratsiraka has this time round in front of him not only a weakened and less popular Zafy but also a divided and hesitant front of potential opponents left, with little time to re- unite again.

Indeed Zafy was impeached not only by opposition members (most of them hostile to Ratsiraka too) but also by some of his staunchest supporters who accused him of favouring his own political party at the expense of th other political factions which brought him to power.

As a result, they have now some difficulties in backing Zafy openly and sincerely again - three months only after ousting him - without undermining badly their own credibility.

The Church, which was instrumental in the country's transition to a democratic era that brought the same Zafy to power, seems to have decided now to confine itself strictly to its prophetic role and has kept a lower profile during the current developments.

But Zafy's poor economic performances and perceived offhand way of handling national affairs (He was widely criticized for being evasive in major issues), seem to have alienated almost half of his voters. Indeed in a similar first ballot in 1992, he won 45 per cent while now he is left with only 23 per cent.

Political observers say very complex negotiations and manoeuvres are in fact under way behind the scenes in the Malagasy capital, to counter Ratsiraka's bid to return to power. But the anti-Ratsiraka coalition which brought Zafy to power in 1993, divided by factional interests and short-term gains after the fall of the common enemy, is not likely to rebuild and demonstrate in less than a month's time, the same unity which took them two years to build a few years ago.

Unless, of course, they come up with a "shortcut". One of such shortcuts and which is reported to be currently envisaged by a section of anti- Ratsiraka politicians as an ultimate weapon is to prevent the former military ruler from running December 29 final round on health-related grounds.

For some time, persistent rumours were circulating that Ratsiraka, who was in France for medical reasons, had become blind. But against all expectations and political calculations, he cut short his stay in France after 18 months and returned home to stand for the early presidential elections. The rumours in question proved to be unfounded until Malagasy urban voters were puzzled to watch the man, on their television screens, having real difficulties in putting his ballot paper in the ballot box.

But that was already after the closure of the polling stations and Ratsiraka had by then already gathered his decisive 36 per cent of the votes.

Meanwhile, the former military ruler has continued to gather more support. Herizo Razafimahaleo, the rising star of the Malagasy business and political communities and ranked third with 15 per cent of the votes in the first ballot of the current early presidential elections, decided to back him.

Aged 41, wealthy, competent, popular among the youth and relatively experienced (he was a former economic adviser to Ratsiraka and an industry minister of Zafy), his declared support to Ratsiraka was a deadly blow to Zafy's camp, causing its first cracks followed by the series of spectacular defections and U-turns which have always characterized the behaviour of Malagasy politicians in general.

Indeed, driven by a sort of blind survival instinct, most of Malagasy political party leaders, regardless of whatever principles or ideologies they have been professing or preaching, would at one time unscrupulously disown everything to join the winning camp, believing (with some reason probably) that the only way to survive as a career politician in this country, is first to remain at any cost, part of the ruling clique or the leadership.

The game has become so cynical that most of major political parties usually end up being split in two at each trying time -- one faction becoming part of the leadership and another faction remaining in the "opposition" until better times prompt them to "reconcile" pompously later on. The acrobatic feat was once described perfectly by a local journalist as the "politics of presence".

For nearly two decades now, Malagasy political party leaders have played this sort of game in a very subtle and crafty manner. But the trick has begun to run out of steam. In voting for the two former presidents, Malagasy voters, in a way, showed that they were tired of zigzaging and unprincipled politicians. And that they craved now for "principled" politicians, who are more loyal to themselves and the people they are supposed to serve, no matter how "bad" or "incompetent" they had been in the past.

A profile which, to a certain extent, fits both Ratsiraka and Zafy. And this is precisely the underlying reason for the unexpected resurfacing of the two former presidents.

Whatever the case however, whether Ratsiraka or Zafy (or perhaps another candidate should Ratsiraka be disqualified on health grounds) is to become the next Malagasy president, the whole democratization process initiated painfully with the adoption of a new constitution in 1992 will have to be started from scratch again.

Indeed Ratsiraka, blaming all the current problems in Madagascar on an inadequate constitution, promised, if elected, to submit at least two types of constitution for referendum: a unitary and a federal one. While Zafy, for his part, will not fail to approve major "improvements" to the present constitution.

In both cases, a "new" constitution therefore has to emerge. Which supposes another lengthy and costly process including the adoption of either the new or amended constitution, the establishment of the ensuing institutions through a series of elections and time- consuming political squabblings, bargainings and compromises driven by the dynamics of the very "politics of presence" described earlier on, not to mention the unavoidable subsequent informal "transitional" and "learning" phases.

In brief, it may take at least another two or three years again before this Indian Ocean island can perhaps fully fulfil its potential of a major touristic destination and foreign investment haven.

In fact, things seem to happen as if the one-step-forward-two-steps- backward tempo has always been a permanent feature of the contemporary history of the peace-loving but a little too perfectionist Malagasy people.

Another regular retarding factor is the series of cyclones which claim their heavy toll annually, especially at this particular period of the year.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


430 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe's Stepchild


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1720 words


 

Nairobi - Africa is fast producing orphans or single-parent children, due to multiple scourges of disease and war. Many of these children are under the care of step-parents, and frequently suffer traumatic conditions. APS Correspondent Tim Chigodo gives a sampling of the situation from Harare.

It is lunch time and family members rush to the dining table with salivating mouths, all looking forward to the day's meal. But for a seven- year-old boy (whose identity will remain anonymous), it is time for yet another nightmare - he has to share the same plate with the family dog.

Between September 1994 and July 1995, the boy's father Gedeon Munyanyi (37) and stepmother Abigail Dzangare of Chief Ndang's area in Shurugwi, central Zimbabwe, repeatedly assaulted him with sticks and open hands. His stepmother also forced him to eat from the same plate with the family dog. 

A concerned neighbour alerted authorities of the continued abuse and the two were arrested and sentenced to 15 months in jail, five of which were conditionally suspended for five years.

This is the plight of many who are under the care of step-parents. They are subjected to all kinds of physical, emotional and at times even sexual abuse by the step-parents who are supposed to be looking after them.

Cases of child abuse have come to light over the past few years, with the Child Protection Society in Zimbabwe saying it now gets at least five reports every week. However, the reported incidences "are just a tip of the iceberg" as most cases go unreported mainly because the perpetrators are related to the victims.

"Only a very small fraction of the cases are reported to us because of the cultural connotations where the perpetrator is related to the victim. More than half of the cases of physical or sexual abuse occur between very closely knit families...child abusers are rarely outsiders. This makes it difficult for anybody to report and unless concerned neighbours do so, the perpetrators continue abusing the child without being brought to justice," says the chairman of the Child Protection Society, Mr. Percy Molife.

This is in spite of the fact that the society was given more powers to intervene in such cases following the amendment of Zimbabwe's Child Protection and Adoption Act. This was after the controversy a decade ago, when the society under the chairmanship of the late Willie Musarurwa took away a girl who had been "given" as payment of ngozi (evil spirits of a deceased person) in Murewa.

Child abuse comes in two main forms, the common and perhaps widely perpetrated physical abuse and the now prevalent sexual abuse, which was the subject of a recent world congress against the commercial sexual exploitation of children in Sweden.

However, psychologists say both abuses lead to emotional upheaval that leaves permanent scars on the victim. These children, they say, later become abusers as adults.

Poverty, which has been worsened by growing economic difficulties, now results in some parents "taking out the steam" by beating up or abusing their children.

"Transferred aggression is now a common phenomenon in most families. Although there are various causes of child abuse, the overriding one is that somewhere in the home there is unhappiness. It could be because of poverty, marital problems between husband and wife, or relationships with extended family members. Victims do not come out of a vacuum, they come from a home or a situation where you should find a home but do not because the home is in disarray," said a psychologist, Dr. Tommie-Marie Samkange.

With divorce cases soaring due to various socio-economic factors like the breakdown of the family unit, many second marriages have emerged with children being caught up in the middle. As a result, stepmothers are taking care of the children from another marriage, usually after the father wins custody of them.

Research has revealed that most children under the care of stepmothers suffer untold hardships. Stepmothers have been accused of denying stepsons/daughters basic needs like food and clothing. In other cases, the stepchild is expected to supplement the family income by vending. Some stepsons have attended school in tattered and torn clothes. Children who grow under the care of stepmothers equate their ordeal to "that of a prison".

"I remember it was friends and fellow students who would give me food at school after coming to school on an empty stomach. I worked twice as hard, and more clothes were given to me as gifts by relatives while my stepmother's blood children enjoyed every care and attention," said a victim of child abuse, who is now a secretary with a private doctor in Harare.

But like many others, she could not report the abuse to her father. The few times that she tried it led to verbal scolding and at worst heavy beating. Hence, people are getting away with extremes of child abuse, a situation that psychologists say creates a fatal vicious cycle since research has established that most child abusers have at one time in their lives been victims of abuse.

However, in most cases, women's organizations and activists see 'red' the moment the subject is raised, saying that instead of taking a holistic approach, society points accusing fingers at stepmothers alone, "who are surviving against all odds in a stressful environment that perpetuates violence and aggression".

An official of the Women's Action Group said stepmothers were not the issue. She said such mothers were toiling looking after stepsons and even if they discipline the child in good faith "people will always be over-critical of them."

However, one women's organization did research which corroborates the sentiments that stepmothers abuse their stepchildren. But the organization has refused to have the findings made public "as they will cause chaos and despondency in society."

Said Tsitsi Nzira of the Women and Law in Southern Africa Research Trust: " What concerns us is the issue of painting stepmothers as evil...There is more to this topic and people should not base their judgement on the few reported cases. While we do not condone the problem, several questions have to be asked, like what was the role of the father? Was he providing enough food? Our research has revealed that the child is better off left in the care of his real mother.

"You see men are worsening the problem because they do not want to pay maintenance for their children and therefore apply for custody, but leave the children at the mercy of the stepmother."

In Zimbabwean society, children in the custody of their mother from a previous marriage are labelled illegitimate (mubvandiripo). Thus traditionally on

remarrying, this woman in some cases refuses to take her children to her new home. Others will identify their child as a young sister, or their sister's child, for them to be accepted into the marriage. In most cases the children are left in the care of grandparents.

"This is where the mother will abuse the stepchildren because you will be expecting too much from her. Surely, how can I be nice to someone else's children, when mine are probably suffering? You can't expect her to have automatic bonding; it can only come if the marital relationship is pure or problem free, which in most cases never happens," said Nzira.

The cultural view that children were an investment, and the tradition that they would look after their parents after landing good jobs, has brought in the factor of personal interest. Some stepmothers mistreat stepchildren on the belief that they will turn against them when they become adults, and then remember their real mothers.

"That is our perennial fear. You see a child never forgets his/her real mother no matter what. After nurturing a stepson, doing everything for him, it pains you when he resorts to his biological mother," said Mrs. Irene Sibanda, who is taking care of a stepson Chitungwiza.

But as society trades counter accusations, the Department of Social Welfare in Zimbabwe carries the burden of dealing with victims of child abuse, and taking care of individual cases either financially or morally. The department refers scores of cases to children's homes and where necessary, the police. At the homes, the department pays a certain amount towards the upkeep of that child, spending millions of dollars.

Perhaps Nzira had a point when she suggested that a national or even continental conference on child abuse should be convened urgently where solutions to the growing problems will be mooted.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


431 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
African Christians Speak On Mission, Evangelism


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2080 words


 

Nairobi - Salvador, Brazil's north-eastern coastal city, recently hosted one of the most significant conventions in the ecumenical movement. African churches represented at the meeting highlighted several issues that concern Christians in the continent, as reported by APS Writer Wanjugu Mumia who participated in the conference.

Against a multi-cultural background and a challenging theme, Called to One Hope, the Gospel in Diverse Cultures, the 11th conference on World Mission and Evangelism (CWME) from November 24 to December 23 brought together member churches of the World Council of Churches (WCC) to discuss the meaning and role of mission in diverse cultural settings.

One of the key endeavours of the conference was to provide input into a new ecumenical statement on the churches' calling to mission and evangelism. A text of the statement is expected to be presented to the WCC Central Committee in September 1997 and to the Eighth WCC Assembly to be held in Harare, Zimbabwe in September 1998. 

The new statement would supplement the landmark document, Mission and Evangelism: An Ecumenical Affirmation, adopted by the WCC Central Committee in 1982, after intensive consultation with member churches and related mission boards and agencies as well as Roman Catholic and Evangelical theologians and missionaries.

The 1982 statement explores seven elements of an ecumenical perception of Christian mission namely, the call to conversion, the church's right and obligation to witness to the Lordship of Christ in all realms of life, unity in mission, mission in Christ's way, the Gospel as good news to the poor, the fact that mission is addressed to every part of the world and witness among people of living faiths.

However, the new statement would have to acknowledge that events and trends since its adoption in the early 1980s have clearly created a new context for Christian mission. These include political upheavals in Eastern Europe, the end of apartheid in South Africa, and the outbreak of numerous conflicts worldwide and Africa in particular due to resurgent ethnic identity, among other concerns.

Speaking to the plenary discussion on the new WCC Mission Statement, Kenyan Methodist pastor and youth representative, Mary Nkirote Mwirabua, informed the CWME delegates that the church in Africa is taking seriously mission and evangelism, particularly through the formation of missionary associations.

However, she noted, the number of Africans sent outside the continent to do missionary work is very small, whereas many foreigners come to Africa as missionaries, "hence the perception that mission is accomplished when people come from foreign lands as opposed to the same work being done by local people themselves."

Emphasizing a concern voiced in other group and plenary discussions, Rev. Nkirote told the CWME meeting to bear in mind the psychological attitude brought about by the way in which the early missionaries presented Christianity to Africans. "They undermined the African culture, hence detaching themselves from people they were evangelising," she explained.

But, one should keep in mind one factor according to Rev. Nkirote; " Africans never lost hope in the good news because they were convinced one could be a Christian without denouncing one's culture."

Guided by the theme of the conference, Called to One Hope -- The Gospel in Diverse

Cultures, the Kenyan Methodist clergy said that involvement in mission requires the church to work in solidarity not only with its own members but those of Christian denominations that may differ in styles of thought, customs and theologies among others. "Through our own solidarity and similar collaboration with others, we are able to share together cultural and human strengths to attain life in its fullness," she explained.

She cited one of the characteristics of the church as sharing gifts, saying this should be emulated in order to strengthen the work of Christ.

In an interview with APS after her presentation, Rev. Nkirote pointed out that generally, Africans have allowed forces of division to dominate amongst them because they often fail to speak with one voice, even though their concerns are similar.

She noted that much as Africa was awash with problems, there was still hope in the one Gospel of Jesus Christ as evidenced in the growth of Christianity in many countries in the region.

Acknowledging that the church faces many challenges especially when one looks at the fate of innocent human beings caught up in civil wars in Burundi, Rwanda, Sudan, Somalia, Liberia and other countries, Rev. Nkirote said the church needs to critically address its mission so as to continue to involve its members in the process of enhancing peaceful co-existence in societies representing diverse cultures.

Addressing a press conference here, Rev. Samuel Adoa of the Presbyterian Church in the Sudan, welcomed the hosting of the CWME, but raised concern that the conference had not set a task to address the frustrating issues affecting the people in the South generally.

He cited his own country Sudan, where civil war for the last 13 years had caused untold suffering to the people despite appeals by churches for intervention. Rev. Adoa said he expected the just ended conference to address strongly the issues that "are consuming many people of our nations...That this conference would influence our nations and their partners in trade to come to their senses on the sale and purchase of arms, whose consequences are seriously affecting displaced and hungry people in our regions. But this seems not to have been the case," he told APS in an interview here.

Rev. Adoa's opinion was not necessarily shared by all other participants from the South. Some felt the mandate of the CWME was to address the concept of gospel and culture and not provide answers to concerns such as the one the Sudanese delegate had raised. He however emphasized in the interview with APS that the Christians and other people in Sudan would be interested to know what major commitment the meeting had made to their country.

"The fact that people from different cultures all over the world can meet in Brazil, a place of diverse cultures and religions, is in its own way a success, but I do not feel the issues that affect members of the churches at home, fellow Sudanese, and other Africans on a daily basis, were given the adequate attention in this conference," he added.

For Ms. D. Namwembe from the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate in Uganda, the message based on theme of the conference was challenging, but she hoped that even in a small way, the outcome of the CWME would help in the process of bringing peace to her home in northern Uganda, an area wracked by insurrection by rebel soldiers fighting the government of President Yoweri Museveni.

A youth delegate, Namwembe said even in a war situation, the youth in this East African country are exposed to the various challenges facing young people in a global context. She was however concerned that the youth seem caught up between two worlds -- that of a Western culture that they cannot run away from and identify within their own cultures "which seem not to accommodate or understand them anymore."

Another youth delegate Mr. Ntsane Moriana from the Lesotho Evangelical Church said there are many issues suppressing the youth today especially in developing countries where the young people are marginalised in decision making processes that would otherwise contribute to their individual and communal development.

On the place of the youth in the church, Moriana said in their encontro (detailed presentation), the youth presented a true picture on how young people all over the world are affected by developments they have little control over and how they turn to the church to seek answers.

In a colourful show by some of the 76 youth delegates at the meeting, one issue that came out strongly was the influence of globalisation on the young people, irrespective of whether they came from the North or South.

Through presentations that symbolized the "jeans and T-shirt" and "Coca Cola culture" overtaking young persons worldwide, youth delegates to the CWME meeting argued that they were becoming more and more removed from their cultural settings and identities but also challenged the church that it cannot run away from the fact that modern day communication and transport technology is turning the world into "a global village."

"No matter what, globalisation cannot be avoided. Everyday the world is moving closer to being a global village, but at the same time marginalising more and more people who cannot afford to keep up with the modern communication technology and computer age that is synonymous with globalisation," Moriana told APS in an interview here.

Much as the youth from Lesotho is convinced there is hope in the one Gospel of Jesus Christ, he challenged young people particularly to work as a team in the local, national and international levels in order to seek ways in which they can influence the various authorities to meet their needs in a world where trends are changing very fast. He however noted that this is the same world that has youth playing soldiers and child soldiers in civil wars in countries like Sudan, Liberia, Rwanda, Somalia and northern Uganda among other nations in Africa.

For Mrs Raga Bereberei from the Episcopal Church of the Sudan, the Brazil conference was an enriching encounter that exposed her to peoples of different cultures and denominations. Particularly interesting for her, was the interaction with other Africans from the diaspora whose concerns, she realised, were similar although not at the same level with those of her people in the Sudan and the rest of Africa.

She told APS that she sees and believes in the promise of hope as presented in the Gospel but could not help asking: "Why are blacks everywhere suffering up to now? It is true God is God of justice, but I ask myself, when Africa has so many Christians, why do people in Rwanda, Sudan, Liberia and other countries continue to suffer the way they do?"

Her questions were a reflection of similar ones raised by fellow delegates in a regional meeting for the 50 Africans attending the CWME. Concerns raised by representatives of various churches from West, North, Central, Eastern and Southern Africa, ranged from the crisis in Rwanda and Burundi, civil war in Sudan and other countries, the sale and purchase of arms, to the growing threat of Islamic fundamentalism in Africa.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


432 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Zaire;
Archbishop Pleads For Assistance In Zaire


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

KISANGANI, ZAIRE (APS) DECEMBER 16 - In his capacity as the Archbishop of the Catholic Archdiocese of Kisangani in Upper Zaire, Archbishop Laurent Mosengwo Pasinya, former President of the High Council of the Republic in Zaire has made "a desperate appeal' to the world to help the suffering people in Kisangani, North and South Kivu areas of Eastern Zaire.

"I am making a desperate appeal to the powers of this world and political decision makers all over the world, to assist the population of Kisangani in Upper Zaire as well as the hundreds of thousands of Rwandese refugees and other Zaireans in North and South Kivu," Archbishop Pasinya said in a statement on December 9.

Lamenting that after a month of prevarication and hesitation nothing has come of the multinational force mandated by the United Nations to provide security for relief agencies, the Archbishop said, "this evasion and hesitation have led to flux of refugees, displaced people and panic stricken populations towards Kisangani or deeper within the forest which will only lead to further insecurity in the region."

In his statement, the Archbishop said a famine of "unimaginalable proportions" awaits Kisangani if the world does not help soon. 

The Tutsi dominated Banyamulenge rebels who have seized a huge tract of territory in Eastern Zaire, say Kisangani on the banks of River Zaire is their next target. They say they hope to use River Zaire to travel further inland and eventually seize the capital of Zaire, Kinshasa, more than 1000 kilometres downstream.

Other religious sources in Kisangani have confirmed the gravity of the humanitarian crisis facing more than 600,000 persons in Kisangani and its surroundings.

Catholic missionaries who fled Eastern Zaire say a secret civil war has become more and more of a possibility. Already there is a ban on river barges entering Kisangani and food was running out. The access roads into the city are closed. With the fall of Beni- Butembo and the sacking of Bunia, both sources of food for Kisangani, starvation by stages is imminent.

"There is hunger, people are only eating every two days, it is death by stages. The soldiers are also hungry. This increases the risk of disorder and insecurity, particularly after the systematic looting at Bunia, Mamabasa, Nduya, and of missions in the north of the diocese of Mahagi and Butembo.

"In another month," warned Catholic missionary sources "there will be widespread starvation."

Religious missionary sources asserted that it is important for the world television networks to tell the world "what is happening in Kisangani and on the road from Lubutu to Walikale."

Meanwhile according to the Action by Churches Together (ACT - a network of churches and their related agencies meeting human need through co-ordinated emergency response and common identity), the situation in Eastern Zaire remains quite fluid.

There are reports of troop movement around Bunia, Kindu and Kisangani while a group of Interahamwe and former Rwanda Army troops have been identified near Walikale. ACT, quoting Christian AID, says in the Bukavu area of Eastern Zaire, the local population is leaving in fear of the Banyamulenge rebels.

Further disturbing news about the mass exodus of Rwandese refugees in Western Tanzania have come from international relief bodies.

A source at the International Federation of the Red Cross (IFRC) said on December 12 that Ngara and Benaco camps which previously held as many as 300, 000 Rwandese refugees, are now virtually empty.

Rwandese refugees are fleeing Tanzania following a government ultimatum that they return to Rwanda by December 31, 1996.

The Rwandese are reportedly headed north to Uganda, Kenya and southwards to Zambia and Malawi. Only a relatively small group of about 15,000 Muslim Hutu refugees have made up their minds to return home to Rwanda. Reliable sources say the Muslim Hutus are not scared of the fate awaiting them in Rwanda since "very few Muslim Hutus participated in the genocide of 1994."


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


433 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


South Africa;
Amnesty For First Apartheid Police Killer;


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA (APS) DECEMBER 16 - Killer apartheid policeman Brian

Mitchell, serving a 30-year jail term for his role in a 1988 massacre in which 11 people died, has been granted amnesty by South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

The truth body's amnesty committee said in a statement on December 10 it was satisfied that the killings were associated with a political objective and had ordered his release.

Prison authorities said an elated Mitchell was freed late the same day from the prison in Pietermaritzburg, former capital of Kwa-Zulu- Natal province, where he had been held since April 1992.

He was met, according to prison official Colin van der Merwe, by his ex- wife, who divorced him while he was in prison. It is believed the couple plan to make an attempt at reconciliation. 

Mitchell is the fourth person and the first former member of the apartheid security forces to be granted amnesty by the truth commission since it began its work last April.

The commission, which is probing human rights abuses committed during the apartheid era, is compelled to grant amnesty to perpetrators who make full confessions and show that their deeds were politically motivated.

The former police captain headed a death squad which launched an attack on a home in Trust Feed rural area outside Pietermaritzburg on December 3, 1988.

Although he did not take part in the actual attack, Mitchell identified the target and gave instructions to lower-ranked policemen to carry out the attack.

At the time, he believed the house was occupied by activists of Nelson Mandela's then-outlawed African National Congress (ANC), which police regarded as enemies of the apartheid state.

In fact those killed were mourners attending an all-night vigil and were supporters of the ANC's archrivals and the organisation at the time being supported by police, the Zulu nationalist Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP).

Mitchell was sentenced to death in 1992 for the killings but when the death sentence was abolished in South Africa last year, his sentence was commuted to 30 years in jail.

He was one of th first former security force members to appear before the amnesty committee, telling it he had been following orders "from the top" in ordering attacks on ANC targets.

He said he deeply regretted the deeds and offered to make restitution to the families of the victims.

The amnesty committee said in its statement that Mitchell had complied with all the requirements to qualify for amnesty.

It noted that four police constables who were convicted with Mitchell were granted amnesty and released in 1992 under a deal between the ANC and the former apartheid government in which all political prisoners were freed.

The deal smoothed the way for an eventual negotiated political settlement in South Africa.

Meanwhile, former cadres of the now-defunct armed wing of Mandela's ANC have begun applying to the commission for amnesty, an ANC spokesman said in Johannesburg on December 8.

ANC spokesman Ronnie Mamoepa declined to identify those who had applied for amnesty, telling the domestic SAPA news agency that names would only be available later.

But the Sunday Independent newspaper claimed Defence Minister Joel Modise, his deputy Ronnie Kasrils and a senior ANC military commander, Aboobaker Ismail, were among those who were applying.

Until then, ANC cadres have been reluctant to join thousands of former white police officers and soldiers who have applied for amnesty, claiming that because they opposed an unjust system, they should be treated differently to those who defended it.

Mpumalanga province premier Mathews Phosa, a senior ANC official, went further, saying that for an ANC cadre to apply for amnesty was like Moses applying for amnesty for having led the Israelites out of Egypt.

The comment earned him a sharp rebuke from commission chairman, former Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who has been overseeing the truth commission since it was set up in April.

With state prosecutors getting ready to launch a series of trials of ANC members, the cadres now are running scared and are rushing to beat a December 14 deadline for amnesty applications, the Sunday Independent reported.

The newspaper said that among a number of cases being investigated by police is a 1983 car bomb explosion outside air-force headquarters in Pretoria which killed 17 people.

The ANC, which became a guerrilla movement during the time it was banned -- from 1960 until 1990 -- claimed responsibility for the blast, as well as for a number of other attacks on "soft" targets.

Some former members of the ANC's armed wing -- Umkhonto we Sizwe (Spear of the Nation, or MK) -- told the newspaper they had received little support from their seniors and were not sure who would be paying for their legal costs.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


434 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Sudan;
United Voices For Peace In Sudan


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

MARIDI, SUDAN (APS) DECEMBER 16 - The Episcopal Church of Sudan (ECS) recently organized a four-day workshop here to discuss the basic concept of peace and biblical perspectives in the Old and New Testament.

The November 25 to 28 workshop in this Western Equatorial town, southern Sudan, had as its principal objectives the setting up of a peace and reconciliation forum and dialogue among the different groups in order to encourage both military and political leaders, local authorities, elders and chiefs to be conscious about their role in peace making.

It also hoped to encourage, especially local commanders, to support grassroots peace initiatives and promote a culture of peace at local and regional levels as well as develop mechanisms of conflict resolutions. 

The model of Jesus Christ as peacemaker was discussed. Other topics included obstacles to peace in southern Sudan, politics and religion, the main difficulties in church/political relationships, the United Nations convention on human rights and international convention on the rights of the child, traditional methods of peacemaking and inter-tribal relations.

In its four-day deliberations, the workshop recommended that the position of chaplaincy be created in the army, called for continuous dialogue at all levels including elders, chiefs, commanders, local authorities and NGOs. Also that similar workshops should be organized to follow-up implementation of the resolutions reached.

Some 150 delegates, who included church and political leaders, local authorities administrators and forces' commanders, talked of the revival of traditional ways of conflict resolution at family and community levels, with the involvement of both women and youth in the peace process, as well as non- use of force in child recruitment into the armed forces.

The loss of moral values in the society was a recurrent subject in the workshop.

The participants were concerned that the value of morals should be restored in society to make children respect elders, giving parents the opportunity to educate their children (as they should) on how to become responsible persons in their communities.

Participants also talked of cases of chiefs being beaten by their own soldiers in the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), and said this should be discouraged by all means if peace is to be achieved at grassroots level.

Mr. Ufulle Gaaro, justice and peace facilitator at the Nairobi-based New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC) of which ECS is a member, told APS Sudanese are concerned that the centre of natural wisdom among leaders and chiefs seems to have been disrupted in one way or another. "This is a very dangerous and serious issue which has affected our society and eventually peace as well, " he said.

"Without unity, we cannot have real peace. Those of us who are fighting against injustice and oppression should be agents of peace, but not oppress for the second time," he added.

The participants also admitted at the workshop that there is serious conflict among southern Sudanese themselves, which needs to be immediately addressed if dialogue with different factions is to be maintained.

The workshop was initiated and organized by the Diocesan Bishop of Maridi Joseph Marona and facilitated by Churches Ecumenical Action for Sudan (CEAS) and the local Catholic church.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


435 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


South Africa;
Constitution Ushers New Era For South Africans


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

SHARPEVILLE, SOUTH AFRICA (APS) DECEMBER 16 - South African President Nelson Mandela on December 10 signed the country's new constitution into law, officially ending the period of multiparty powersharing in South Africa's political transition.

Mandela hailed the basic law document as the embodiment of "our nation's highest aspirations."

Described as one of the most liberal in the world, the constitution outlaws racial discrimination, guarantees full rights for homosexuals, provides for abortion-on-demand and forbids capital punishment.

It entrenches South Africa's new political order, by scrapping the interim multi-party government, but guarantees multi-party parliamentary elections and a host of basic rights, while restructuring and streamlining parliamentary structures, paving the way for the country's next elections, due in 1999. 

More than 15,000 members of the public and invited dignitaries gathered under a heavy police and army presence in a football stadium in this township south of Johannesburg to witness the ceremony, held to coincide with International Human Rights Day.

In 1960, the township was the scene of the Sharpeville massacre, when apartheid police gunned down 69 unarmed black civil rights protestors.

On December 10 however, it was the scene of celebration as some of the country's leading musicians and dancers entertained the crowd from a massive, colourfully decorated stage during the ceremony that was broadcast live on state television.

Among the spectators sitting in the baking sun, were a small group of people who survived the Sharpeville killings.

Mandela said the constitution is a monument to those "whose blood drenched the soil of Sharpeville and elsewhere in our country."

"As we close ... a chapter of heroic struggle, we reaffirm our determination to build a society which each of us can be proud of as South Africans, as Africans, and as citizens of the world.

"In writing the words which today have become South Africa's fundamental law, our elected representatives have faithfully heard the voice of the people," he said, referring to the 490-member Constitutional Assembly which drafted the constitution.

As Mandela spoke, six airforce helicopters flew over the stadium, each towing the national flag.

The new constitution took 18 months, thousands of public submissions and numerous lengthy closed door meetings between Mandela's African National Congress (ANC) and the former ruling National Party.

The document was passed by the assembly with the required two-thirds majority on May 10 this year, the second anniversary of Mandela's inauguration.

The Constitutional Court, the country's most powerful judicial body, initially sent eight sections of the document back to the assembly for redrafting before it was finally approved.

Cyrill Ramaphosa, the ANC chief negotiator during the drafting process, told the crowd that the signing marked the end of an era and the beginning of a new one.

"It is the end of 350 years struggle for national unity," he said referring to the date European settlers first colonised South Africa.

"Today marks the legal transition to a constitution that represents a will of the overwhelming majority of the people of this country," Ramaphosa said. " It is one law for one nation."

Ramaphosa, along with his NP counterpart Roelf Meyer are regarded as the main architects of the new document, which replaces the interim constitution that was negotiated prior to the 1994 poll.

Seated on the podium near Mandela was NP leader and former president, Fredrick de Klerk, who withdrew his party from Mandela's cabinet shortly before the new constitution was passed by the assembly.

Conspicuous by their absence, however, were representatives of the Zulu- nationalist Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP), the country's third largest, which walked out of the constitutional negotiations in March 1995.

The IFP, which has repeatedly demanded greater autonomy for its Kwa- Zulu- Natal province stronghold and accused the ANC of breaching a pre-election promise to submit disputed issues to international mediation, has threatened it will not recognise the constitution.

The party had gone on record as opposing the sections it did not like, such as the one which reduced provincial powers.

"We are not a revolutionary party. We will live by the country's constitution even as we seek all legal means to try to change aspects of it that we don't agree with," Jiyane said.

Despite the IFP's rejection of the document, Mandela diverted from the text prepared speech to say that there were "good men and women in all parties ... including the Inkatha Freedom Party."

Legislators will begin implementing several aspects of the constitution early next year, starting with the restructuring of the national parliament.

The constitution's signing into law opens the way for the next general election, which although scheduled in May 1999, could now be held earlier.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


436 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Inevitable Problems In Nation Building


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

ACCRA (APS) DECEMBER 16 - The process of nation building brings with it certain inevitable problems because of the non-homogeneity among the people involved, a week-long journalists seminar here was told.

Delivering a key note speech at the symposium held from November 25 to 29, former commander of the United Nations Peace Keeping Force in the Middle East, Lt.Gen. Emmanuel A. Erskine appealed to African people to always seek amicable solutions to their conflicts as these led to massive destruction of property and a lot of suffering particularly to women and children.

Gen. Erskine, a Ghanaian, who served in the Ghana army for many years before joining the UN forces, identified some of the major causes of conflicts as ethnic and religious differences and ideological incompatibilities which in certain countries find expression in brutal civil wars as has happened in Nigeria, Sudan, Rwanda and Burundi. 

Other conflicts, noted Erskine, were avoidable and preventable as they emanated from certain individuals' unbridled greed for power, total disregard for the rule of law and violent overthrow of democratically elected civil governments.

The seminar which was titled Media: Conflict Resolution and Peace in Africa, was sponsored by a British Non-Governmental Organization, Panos. It was designed to bring together two media practitioners each from Liberia, Niger, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Burundi, Rwanda and Sudan which are currently experiencing civil strife. Three other journalists, (one each) came from Chad, Uganda, Mali and Senegal, countries where there has been some relative resolution of conflict, to exchange their experiences.

Dr. Bonnah Koomson of the School of Communication Studies, University of Ghana, noted that conflict situations bring with them their own peculiar challenges to journalists. "One notorious failing forjournalist is how to deal with the truth in many instances, the truth becomes a casualty sacrificed on the altar of propaganda, misrepresentation, disinformation and exaggeration," he said.

Dr. Koomson advised journalists to always stick to the ideals of their professional calling, noting that, "ethical standards are not formulated with any pre-conditions/circumstances. Rather they are standards to be applicable at all times especially during conflict coverage. "It is precisely during the moments of crisis that we as mortal individuals are most valuable and need the support of professional standards as reference points.

Mr. Millius Palayiwa of International Alert, which brokered the peace talks in Sierra Leone, presented a paper titled: Sierra Leone Peace Talks: Reports and Reflections.

The peace agreement between Sierra Leonean President Alhaji Ahmed Kabbah and the leader of the Revolutionary United Front of Sierra Leone, Corporal Foday Saybana Sankoh, was signed on November 29. With the agreement, it is hoped that the brutal war that has claimed many lives and brought misery to hundreds of thousands in the West African state will be a thing of the past.

Other notable personalities at the seminar were Prof. Kwame Karikari of the School of Communication Studies, University of Accra, Dr. Pauline Otti of University of Jos, Nigeria, Dr. Hamidou Magassa, a socio-economic consultant in Bamako, Mali and Dr. Jibrin Ibrahim of the department of political science, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria.

Panos hopes to organise a similar gathering within the next six months in the Great Lakes region of Eastern and Central Africa. The organisation also hopes to launch an award scheme for both print and electronic media journalists who do exceptional work in covering conflict situations.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


437 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Mission: The 21st Century Church


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

SALVADOR, BRAZIL (APS) DECEMBER 16 - The 11th Conference on World Mission and Evangelism (CWME) ended here on December 3 with emphasis for the church to hold on to two realities -- its distinctiveness from, and its commitment to the culture in which it is set.

The section work of the CWME, organized by the World Council of Churches (WCC) Unit II under the theme, Called to One Hope-The Gospel in Diverse Cultures, was informed by the preparatory Gospel and Cultures process, preparatory papers, the Rainbow-Festival of Gospel in Cultures exhibition, Econtros (series of in-depth presentations) with reports from many countries and regions of the world, Bible studies and the plenary sessions.

The theme was studied in four inter-related sections namely, Authentic Witness within each Culture, Gospel and Identity in Community, Local Congregations in Pluralist Societies and One Gospel - Diverse Expressions.

Each of these highlighted one element of the theme, attempting to inter- relate the two parts--one hope in the context of diverse cultures.

The November 24 to December 3 meeting, which brought together more than 600 participants drawn from WCC member churches worldwide, sought to expose delegates, visitors, observers and members of the press to the diverse ways in which the Gospel has been experienced and expressed through cultures around the world. 

At the end of the meeting, participants committed themselves and the churches, groups and agencies they represented to fresh missionary obedience and to take new directions in mission in the next millennium.

By adoption of the conference message, the eleventh CWME emphasized that local congregations are called to be places of hope, providing spaces of safety and trust wherein different peoples can be embraced and affirmed, thus manifesting the inclusive love of God.

The conference also underscored the inclusion of all cultural groups which make up the community, including those which are marginalised and despised. Several such groups had been cited in earlier discussions in the section plenaries, sub-sections and small group sessions.

Acknowledging the need to constantly seek the insight of the Holy Spirit in helping Christians discern better where the Gospel challenges, endorses or transforms a particular culture, the CWME participants noted that by identifying with the two realities of the church mentioned earlier on the gospel neither becomes captive to a culture nor becomes alienated from it, but challenges and is illuminated by it.

The conference message further described small steps which involve risk and courage as factors that can break through barriers and create new relationships. "They can be the miracle which changes a church or a community's self image and enables new God-given life to break," added the CWME message.

On the place and role of relationships between a church and churches of other traditions and cultures, the conference singled out competitiveness as the surest way to undermine Christian mission, adding that aggressive evangelism that does not respect the culture of a people, is unlikely to reflect effectively the gracious love and challenge of the gospel.

In its conference message, the CWME which had a first-hand experience of seeing and hearing voices of Christians from many diverse cultures, expressing their struggles and hopes, was optimistic that the last great mission conference of the 20th century had clearly illuminated that the gospel, in order to be most fruitful needs to be both true to itself, and incarnated or rooted in the culture of a people.

The conference heard stories of disaster, civil war, disease and poverty from speakers from Africa and marveled at the strength of Christian women in particular, to share the pain of their people, fight despair and sow the seeds of hope and food for nourishment.

Young Christians from all over the world made it clear to the just ended Conference on World Mission and Evangelism, that they desired to be full partners in the work of mission especially in relating their faith to the energy and aspirations of youth culture today as opposed to being relegated to the position of objects of the church's mission.

The meeting also heard the anger of African, Afro-Caribbean and Afro-Latino people at the horror of slavery and the way in which the faith, though presented to them in distorted forms, became the hope of liberation.

It was a conference that admired the determination of these people not to be trapped in the lament of history but to cooperate together in a strengthened partnership between African people and people of the African diaspora.

From Christians in the Middle East, the meeting heard stories about

people living with the privilege and pain of life in a "holy land" torn apart by division and injustice, and their indignation at the way in which biblical texts are misinterpreted so that their culture is blemished and some are made to feel strangers in their own land.

Delegates also heard reports of growing localism among North American churches which, while strengthening their commitment to mission and evangelism in their own context, may lead to an isolation and insulation from global realities.

The post-modern culture influencing much of Western Europe was also highlighted in the just ended mission conference, with emphasis on how churches are engaging with those turning from traditional faith and seemingly seeking a private "pick and mix" spirituality.

The CWME also shared the concern of many at how the world is not only facing a free economic market which seems to exercise sovereign power over even strong governments, but is also exposed to a free media market where images and messages of every description are influencing -- and some believe, undermining community and faith.

It also heard how Christians in many places around the globe are engaging in serious dialogue with those of other faiths, thereby gaining a clearer and richer understanding of their own faith and also helping to build a " community of communities" to benefit all.

Between each World Council of Churches assembly, Unit II is responsible for organizing a Conference on World Mission and Evangelism.

One of four WCC programmatic units, the department focusses on equipping and strengthening churches in mission. In turn, the churches are called to make clear God's loving, eternal purpose to heal and reconcile all people to God in Jesus Christ and to restore wholeness to all creation.

The main task of the CWME is to provide opportunities for churches, mission agencies, groups and national and regional councils concerned with Christian mission to meet together for reflection and consultation leading to common witness.

The first World Mission conference was held in Edinburgh, United Kingdom in 1910, others have met as follows; Jerusalem (1928), Tambaram/Madras, India (1938); Witby, Canada (1947); Willingen, Germany (1952); Achimota, Ghana (1957/8); Mexico City, Mexico (1963); Bangkok, Thailand (1972/3); Melbourne, Australia (1980) and San Antonio, Texas, USA (1989).

Brazil, with its population of 160 million people is a cornucopia of cultures. With their long history of colonization, forced importation of Africans as slaves and subsequent waves of immigration, Brazilians are one of the most racially and culturally mixed peoples in the world.

Further, about 90 per cent of its population is Roman Catholic, but Pentecostal churches and churches of charismatic traditions are growing at a phenomenal rate. There is also a variety of expressions of popular religiosity, born out of a rich blend of Christian, Afro-Brazilian and indigenous heritages.

Also, Salvador in Bahia, the first city to be founded in Brazil and the country's first capital, is a reminder of the enslavement of those who were brought from Africa and their "christianization" by force.

However, Bahia, as well as the whole of Brazil, stands as testimony to the survival power of the Afro-Brazilians and the persistence of their religious- culture.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


438 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Zaire;
ICRC Update No. 15 on the Zairian Crisis


BYLINE: International Committee of the Red Cross


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Geneva - The humanitarian situation in Shabunda, a settlement about mid-way between Bukavu and Kindu, is slowly becoming critical. ICRC activities are hampered by poor infrastructure, heavy rains and difficult access to the refugee site. Relief supplies are flown to Kindu from Nairobi in a Hercules cargo plane and then on to Shabunda by DC-3. 

From the runway, which is often water-logged, relief has to be transported to a river, transferred by dugout, and carried by bicycle to the site four kilometres from the river. Faced with ever increasing numbers of Rwandan and Burundian refugees, ICRC staff are struggling to provide basic food and medical assistance. Most recent refugee counts show that some 40,000 people have by now arrived in Shabunda, and continue to pour in at the rate of 3,000- 5,000 a day.

As these refugees are becoming increasingly settled at the site, urgent action is required to find a long-term solution, such as repatriation, before new camps are established. The ICRC has met with UNHCR representatives in Kinshasa and has offered air transport to Shabunda to make it possible to gather first-hand information.

Owing to heavy rain, the ICRC flight to Lubutu had to be cancelled. The ICRC has been in contact with Midecins sans Frontihres (MSF), which is working in Lubutu hospital.
