MSF has said that there are some 30,000 refugees in Tingitingi, seven kilometres west of Lubutu, and tens of thousands more along the road between Walikale and Lubutu.

In Kalemie, the ICRC has started to distribute food rations to 4,400 Zairian displaced and 800 refugees.

Access to areas around Goma and in North Kivu is still not possible, and the ICRC has no information about the victims of the conflict in this area.

However, delegates have been given greater access to the areas around Bukavu, and the local authorities have accepted the use of Red Cross messages in the areas they control. An ICRC team and a representative of the German Red Cross went to Uvira to evaluate the situation at the hospital and the possibility of resuming activities there.

On 13 December, eleven Zairian border guards and 14 family members were repatriated to Kinshasa from Uganda in an ICRC-chartered Hercules plane.

A further source of concern for the ICRC has been recent Rwandan refugee movements in and out of camps in Tanzania. Refugees who had left their camps and moved deeper into Tanzania were returned to their camps. However, as of yesterday, a steady tide of Rwandan refugees has been returning to Rwanda via the Rusumo border post. The ICRC has set up two waystations along the Tanzanian road to the border to provide refugees with clean water. The ICRC also took care of 400 unaccompanied children found along the road. By the end of the day, 100 of these children had not yet been reunited with their families. On the Rwandan side of the border, four ICRC water engineers are providing safe drinking water using mobile treatment equipment and water tankers.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


439 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 61 on the Great Lakes (12/18)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

Nairobi - Zaire's President Mobutu, who returned to the country yesterday, said he had come back against medical advice to take personal charge of the situation. In an address over state radio and television, he accused Zaire's " enemies" of choosing to "stab him in the back" when he was unwell and out of the country.

He assured the people he had never "retreated" when the country was under threat, and he would not retreat this time. But he added that "our enemies' provocation should not make us fall into the trap of blind xenophobia against the foreigners who have lived for years in our country without violating the laws of the republic." A US State Department spokesman said yesterday Mobutu should move towards establishing "real democracy" in Zaire. According to AFP, spokesman Glyn Davies said that "after 56 years of promises, there really needs to be some action on the political front." He added it would be difficult to know what the country's future could be if Mobutu "decides not to open the political system." "The bottom line for the United States is that Zaire remains a single nation," he said. 

Sources in Goma said Mobutu's return had heightened fears among the local population of a counter-offensive by the Zairean army. On Monday, the ADFL rebels - seeking to weaken army morale ahead of Mobutu's arrival - appealed to Zairean soldiers to switch sides, Reuters reported. The appeal was contained in two documents signed by two Zairean officers who had apparently gone over to the rebels.

UNICEF warned yesterday that thousands of Rwandan refugees in Zaire could die before Christmas unless aid agencies launch a huge emergency relief operation to get food to more than 100,000 people who have arrived in Lubutu recently. Many of the refugees have arrived from the Mugunga camp near Goma, a distance of some 300kms.

An article in the Belgian daily 'De Morgen' over the weekend said aid workers were making an initial assessment of the situation in the Goma region, following a ceasefire announcement by rebel leader Laurent Kabila. They found 5,500 bodies, mostly in pit latrines of the former refugee camps. Some of them "had an expression of pain on their faces," the newspaper reported. It added that they were probably slaughtered by retreating Interahamwe militia, saying that dumping bodies in latrines was practised by the Interahamwe during the Rwandan genocide of 1994.

Some 200,000 refugees have returned to Rwanda from Tanzania and more are said to be emerging from hiding to join the exodus. Most of the Ngara camps are now empty, but the Tanzanian authorities have allowed aid workers back into the camps to help any remaining refugees. UNHCR said some 2,300 Burundian refugees still in the Benaco, Musuhura and Lumasi camps were being regrouped with 20,000 Burundians in Lukole camp. Aid workers, quoted by AFP, said a Rwandan soldier last night fired several shots at a convoy bringing home refugees.

WFP said it was planning to cut food rations by 70 percent after the first month of assistance to the Rwandan returnees. It was aiming to prevent dependency on external food assistance and encourage the returnees to become self-sufficient. WFP will assist with reintegration through work-for-food programmes.

WFP also reported that 2,400 Rwandan refugees from the Karagwe camps in northwest Tanzania had been registered at Orutshinga (Orukinga??)in Uganda, while 200 Zairean refugees had arrived at Nebbi in northwest Uganda. WFP said more could be expected in the event of a further advance northwards by rebels in eastern Zaire. Further south in Tanzania, at Kigoma, UNHCR reported that refugees from Burundi and Zaire were continuing to arrive and that by mid- December there was a total of 174,500 refugees in the area. Of these, 2,120 were Rwandans. UNHCR said there was a problem regarding Zairean refugees who refused to be transferred from the town to the newly opened Nyarususu camp.

Two Roman Catholic priests said they had been deported by the Tanzanian authorities for opposing the repatriation of Rwandan refugees. The priests, from Spain and Italy, told reporters in Nairobi yesterday that the refugees did not want to return to Rwanda but that their pleas fell on deaf ears. Human Rights Watch yesterday called on the Tanzanian government and UNHCR to " stop forcing Rwandan refugees to repatriate." "The Tanzanian government's use of force to drive Rwandan refugees over the border is a blot on their traditionally good record in respect of refugee rights," HRW said. "Moreover, the UNHCR has shamefully abandoned its responsibility to protect refugees." HRW went on to say that the international community had "barely disguised its satisfaction at seeing the refugee camps around Rwanda forcibly disbanded. But moving the refugees from one side of the border to the other will not offer any lasting solution without justice for genocide victims and improved respect for human rights by the Rwandan government."

Rwandan radio said last night that a new regional summit could soon be held to discuss the situation in Burundi. The Burundi conflict did not figure in a communique released by regional leaders after their summit in Nairobi this week. According to the radio, a report was given to the heads of state which " noted that negotiations have not yet effectively begun" between the Tutsi- dominated authorities in Bujumbura and Hutu rebels, and that leaders would meet soon to discuss the issue in depth. Burundi's foreign ministry issued a statement describing as "shameful" the fact that Burundi had not been invited to the Nairobi summit. The statement, broadcast by Burundi radio on Monday, said that if the summit did not call for lifting economic sanctions against the country, then Burundians should unite "with the knowledge that sanctions are another war which must be fought." "Warmongers and their supporters are spreading falsehoods so that the Nairobi meeting does not reach any meaningful resolution on Burundi," the statement added. "The ministry reminds the international community that peace is slowly returning to many places in the country and citizens are dropping their support for the armed groups." Rwandan President Pasteur Bizimungu, quoted by Rwandan radio, said the presence of a Burundian delegation at the Nairobi summit "might have made a positive contribution."

The UN Secretary-General's outgoing Special Envoy for the Great Lakes region has made several proposals for the future of the mission. In a report to the UN Security Council, Raymond Chretien suggested appointing an envoy who either lives in Nairobi or somewhere close to the region, a roving envoy with no fixed home base for several months until a working relationship with regional leaders is established or an envoy who would visit the region as and when needed. In his opinion, the last option was the preferred one in order to build on the goodwill and momentum generated by his mission.

Nairobi, 18 December 1996, 13:30 gmt (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


440 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Great Lakes Situation Report No. 13


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3627 words


 

Washington DC - U.S. Agency For International Development, Bureau for Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) . GREAT LAKES - Complex Emergency Situation Report No. 13 Fiscal Year (FY) 1997, December 17, 1996. Note: The last situation report was dated December 12, 1996.

Overview

The Banyamulenge and the Banyarwanda people, who are Tutsi of Rwandan origin, settled in the Mulenge hills of South Kivu, Zaire, and the Masisi region of North Kivu, Zaire, more than 200 years ago. Sporadic ethnic violence in the Masisi region has occurred since 1959, but it again escalated in the fall of 1995 as the former Rwandan army (the ex-FAR) and the Rwandan Hutu militia (the Interahamwe) targeted Banyarwanda Tutsi in an apparent attempt to create an area of Hutu control. In September 1996, the situation in the Uvira region of South Kivu began to resemble that of the Masisi region, as government-sanctioned harassment of Banyamulenge Tutsis intensified. 

On October 8, 1996, the South Kivu Deputy Governor declared that Banyamulenge residents should leave the area within seven days or risk treatment as rebels. On October 14, fighting broke out between the Banyamulenge rebels and the Zairian Army (FAZ) near Runingo refugee camp, in South Kivu, forcing the roughly 220,000 refugees to flee. The Banyamulenge joined forces with other Zairian rebels to form the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL), and the fighting spread, moving up the eastern border of Zaire from Uvira to Bukavu, and south from Rutshuru (North Kivu) to Goma.

As a result of shelling from Rwanda on October 26 and November 1, hundreds of thousands of refugees from Kibumba, Katale, and Kahindo camps near Goma, fled to Mugunga camp. Both the ex-FAR and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)-financed Zairian Camp Security Contingent (CZSC), became involved in the fighting. After suffering defeat, the FAZ and CZSC retreated to the west, looting villages and displacing Zairians from Goma town and surrounding areas. Following Hutu attacks from Mugunga camp on Goma town, the ADFL counter-attacked on November 14, forcing the ex-FAR and Interahamwe to retreat to the west and compelling hundreds of thousands of refugees to flee.

U.S. Government (USG) Humanitarian Assistance for Fiscal Year (FY) 1997 (to date)$85,457,688

Numbers Affected

Rwandan refugees from eastern Zaire: An estimated 600,000 Rwandan refugees have returned from the Goma area camps to Rwanda. Most of the Rwandan refugees from the Bukavu and Uvira camps remain unaccounted for. Zambia reports 1,000 new Rwandan refugees, and Tanzania reports 1,200 new Rwandan refugees.

Burundian refugees: Of the 143,000 Burundian refugees originally in the Uvira area, some 62,000 refugees have returned to Burundi and about 13,500 have arrived in Tanzania.

Newly Displaced: Fleeing continued fighting in Burundi, a new caseload of about 100,000 Burundian refugees has entered Tanzania. Approximately 35,000 Zairians have fled to Tanzania. Some 800 Rwandan and Zairian Tutsis remain in the Congo and 11,500 Zairians are reported in Uganda. The U.S. Embassy in Zaire estimates that 170,000 Zairians have been displaced by the conflict in eastern Zaire, including 20,000 from Uvira, 60,000 from Bukavu, 40,000 from Goma, and 50,000 from rural areas.

Rwandan Refugees from Tanzania: Of the 535,000 Rwandan refugees originally in Tanzania, about 6,500 returned to Rwanda between September 10 and December 12, and 175,000 returned from December 14 - 17.

Unknown Populations: The U.S. military estimates there are 225,000 to 285, 000 people on the move within Zaire. UNHCR believes that there still may be as many as 400,000. It is uncertain whether these are displaced Zairians, Rwandan or Burundian refugees or former Rwandan militia.

Current Situation

The United Nations (U.N.) Department of Humanitarian Affairs (UNDHA) reports that as of the evening of December 17, some 175,000 Rwandan refugees have returned from Tanzania since December 14. Refugees continue to cross the border at a rate of up to 15,000 per hour. A member of USAID's Disaster Assistance Response Team (USAID/DART) reported on December 17 that a column of refugees extends 12 km on either side of the Tanzanian border.

The Action of Churches Together (ACT) reports it has located 60,000 to 80, 000 Burundi and Rwandan refugees and 25,000 displaced Zairians in Lubutu, 300 km west of the Zaire-Rwanda border. ACT is airlifting supplies from Nairobi to Kisangani, for overland transport to Lubutu. A U.N. mission to the Lubutu on December 16 estimated there are approximately 120,000 refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs) in the Lubutu area. Although the adults are reportedly in good condition, some of the children show signs of malnutrition and severe dehydration. Humanitarian agencies established a Coordination Committee in Kisangani to coordinate relief assistance to this population. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) delivered 10 metric tons (MT) of relief supplies to Kisangani for refugees and displaced persons on December 15.

On December 17, ICRC reported that an estimated 40,000 Rwandan and Burundian refugees, reportedly from the Uvira camps, have arrived in the Shabunda region of eastern Zaire, 175 km west of Bukavu. Refugees continue to flow into Shabunda town at the rate of 3,000 to 5,000 per day. Most of the refugees are reportedly in bad condition, suffering from diarrhea, malaria, and malnutrition. ICRC is using Kindu as a base to pre-position supplies for transport to Shabunda, where they are providing protein biscuits and health assistance to the refugees.

Political/Military Situation Clashes continue in eastern Zaire, between ADFL and FAZ forces. The ADFL claims to have captured towns along a 550 mile front. According to U.N. sources in Kinshasa, Kisangani is currently calm and Zairian Special Presidential Division troops reportedly control the town. Uvira, Bukavu, and Goma remain calm and under ADFL control.

In response to U.N. Security Council Resolution 1080, a Canadian-led multinational force (MNF) was formed to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian assistance and the repatriation of refugees. The 14-nation steering group overseeing the MNF met in New York on December 13. Canada proposed termination of the MNF effective December 31 at the recommendation of General Maurice Baril, the force commander, who recently completed extensive consultations and a study of the situation on the ground. The USG will continue to use diplomatic means to gain full access for humanitarian organizations in eastern Zaire.

Relief Efforts The Government of Canada hosted a multi-donor meeting in Kigali on December 13 on the reintegration of Rwandan refugees, as a follow- on to the meeting held in Geneva on November 23. Representatives from 12 countries, the European Union, U.N. agencies, and the Government of Rwanda (GOR) met to discuss developments since the refugees began returning on November 15, to present GOR priorities, to review donor programs, and to discuss donor coordination efforts. The GOR reiterated its priorities of housing, security, justice and human resource development and called on donors to support whole communities, including returnees and existing residents alike. Shelter remains the highest priority, with the GOR reporting that populations have doubled or tripled in certain high impact communes, such as Kibuye where over 20,000 people returned.

Uvira: Access to Uvira town is now authorized and relief organizations report that markets have re-opened and are well-stocked, the nearby refugee camps are deserted, water treatment supplies and equipment are available and the health structure is largely intact.

Bukavu: On December 11, some 400 refugees returned via the Bukavu/Cyangugu corridor. Since mid-October, about 9,000 refugees have crossed at Cyangugu. Returnees pass through the Nyagatere transit center and several way stations upon crossing the border, and water, sanitation, and food distribution systems are well established. Non- governmental organizations (NGOs) currently working in Bukavu include Concern International, Medecins Sans Frontieres/International (MSF/I), International Rescue Committee (IRC), Save the Children Fund/UK (SCF/UK), Christian Aid, Oxfam, and Caritas. U.N agencies and ICRC are also working in Bukavu.

Goma: USAID/DART reports that an average of 1,000 Rwandan refugees have been crossing daily at the Gisenyi border crossing.

UNHCR reports it has assisted in the repatriation of 35,000 refugees who have emerged from hiding in the Virunga National Park near Goma since November 19. WFP reports that the northern axis from Goma is closed to all humanitarian personnel. Access to the western and southern routes is permitted as far as Kalungo, about 50 km west of Goma. The U.N. has undertaken assessment missions as far as Kitchungu, half-way between Sake and Masisi, however the area is now deemed unsafe for further travel, due to unknown terrain and possible pockets of resistance. The following relief organizations are currently operating in Goma: American Refugee Committee (ARC), Merlin, Trocaire, SCF/UK, Concern International, Catholic Relief Services (CRS)/Caritas, Oxfam, MSF/I, ICRC, UNHCR, and WFP.

Rwanda: Following a December 4, meeting in Kibungo involving GOR, UNHCR, NGO and USAID/DART representatives, NGOs established water points, health posts and biscuit distributions along the route refugees returning from Tanzania were expected to take -- from Rusumo at the border to Rwamagana, 107 km inside the border.

To reduce congestion, the GOR is allowing only the National Red Cross to provide assistance at way stations between the border and Rwenteru, 18 km inside Rwanda. Most returnees walk from Rusumo to Rwenteru, where relief agencies are distributing high-energy biscuits and on December 14 and 15, relief agencies transported returnees from Rwenteru to their home communes. Returnees are reportedly in good condition, as there was low malnutrition in the camps, most refugees have been vaccinated and they are carrying shelter materials with them. As of December 12, WFP had pre-positioned 1,200 MT of mixed food commodities and 70 MT of biscuits in Kibungo Prefecture, where the majority of the Rwanda refugees will repatriate. Pre-positioning of food stocks is also taking place in Byumba and Mutara prefectures.

According to UNHCR figures released on December 12, local authorities in the communes registered over 470,000 Rwandans returning from eastern Zaire during the month of November. UNHCR reports that most of the returnees are in good condition. Food distribution is ongoing in all prefectures of Rwanda. From November 15 to December 12, WFP and NGO partners distributed about 9,700 MT of food commodities, representing over 580,000 people assisted with monthly rations. In addition, over one million high-protein biscuits were distributed. WFP reports that all who returned with the large influx in mid- November have received their initial seven-day ration at the commune level and most are now receiving monthly rations.

The U.N. Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (HRFOR) reports that while property disputes exist, most returnees are finding temporary accomodation with relatives, neighbors, or friends. In some cases where returnees have found their houses occupied, the two parties have made informal arrangements to live together temporarily. Officially, the GOR has given squatters two weeks to vacate dwellings belonging to returnees but implementation of this policy appears fairly loose at the commune level. In Karago Commune, Gisenyi Prefecture, old case load returnees are permitted to stay in homes belonging to new returnees until the harvest in late January.

HRFOR reported that the GOR has detained at least 162 returnees since November 15, some for their own protection. Of the 4,331 former soldiers who registered with the GOR, 12 have been arrested.

Burundi: U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights, Jose Ayala Lasso reported on December 11 that more than 1,000 people were massacred in Burundi between late October and late November. WFP reports that Kayanza and Bujumbura Rural provinces are insecure and the situation has deteriorated in Bubanza province. Many parts of Bururi, Muramvya, Gitega, and Karuzi provinces continue to be unsafe.

WFP food reserves in Burundi are depleting rapidly. Moving food by road from Isaka, Tanzania to Ngozi, Burundi, WFP can import 1700 MT of food per month, leaving a shortfall of 800 MT. WFP has requested approval from the Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee and the Tanzanian National Sanctions Committee to transport food across Lake Tanganyika which is more efficient and less expensive than road routes.

UNHCR reports that of the 62,000 Burundian refugees who have returned to Burundi from Zaire, about 45,000 spontaneously repatriated to Cibitoke province and 15,000 arrived through the Gatumba transit center outside Bujumbura. WFP is distributing returnee packages to both populations. According to UNDHA, there were virtually no new arrivals at the Gatumba transit center between November 28 and December 10. The U.N. Human Rights Field Operation in Burundi , UNHCR, and NGOs are monitoring returns to insecure areas. UNHCR reports that about 38,000 of the returnees to Cibitoke have settled in 10 government sites.

Tanzania: In early December the Government of Tanzania (GOT) called for the repatriation of all Rwandan refugees by December 31 but declared that no forced repatriation would occur.

On December 12, Rwandan refugees began to pour out of the Ngara refugee camps in Western Tanzania. Most refugees initially moved east, but were blocked by Tanzanian military troops. Those intercepted turned around and headed back towards the camps, and towards the border with Rwanda. On December 13, UNHCR stated that the Ngara camps would not be reconstituted and as of December 16, Lumasi, Benaco, Kitali, and Mushuhuru camps were virtually empty. On December 17, USAID/DART reported that the GOT allowed NGOs access to the Ngara camps to seek out vulnerable groups who remained behind and to provide needed assistance. The GOT had restricted most relief agencies from accessing the Ngara area. Some 20,000 Burundian refugees remain in two camps in Ngara.

UNHCR also reported that of the estimated 124,000 Rwandan refugees in the Karagwe area camps (north of Ngara), from 90,000 to 100,000 remain in the camps while about 30,000 are moving around the countryside. Of the 30,000, roughly 20,000 have moved southeast into the Burigi game reserve, some have crossed into Uganda and others have moved east toward Bukoba. USAID/DART staff will be traveling to the Ugandan border on December 18 to monitor returnee movements. UNHCR is working with the GOT to facilitate the repatriation of those remaining in the Karagwe camps.

Refugee camps in Kigoma and Kibondo region are still filled with Burundian and Zairian refugees. The U.S. Embassy in Tanzania reports that there are 500 - 1000 new arrivals daily. Mtendeli Camp in the Kibondo region has expanded beyond its capacity, housing almost 70,000 Burundians. UNHCR plans to transfer about 20,000 to the newly opened Nduta Camp.

USG Assistance On October 26, BHR/OFDA deployed a USAID/DART to Kigali, Rwanda, to conduct assessments, report on the situation, and provide funding to NGOs, U.N. agencies, and international organizations for programs to assist with repatriation efforts. On November 7, 1996, U.S. Ambassador to Rwanda, Robert Gribbin, declared a disaster, noting that the refugee crisis in eastern Zaire poses a humanitarian emergency for Rwanda. On November 12, U. S. Ambassador Daniel Simpson declared a disaster in Zaire, as a result of the violent break-up of refugee camps in eastern Zaire.

On November 18, the USG pledged $140 million in humanitarian and development assistance to address needs in the Great Lakes region.

USG FY 1997 Assistance (to date):

BHR/OFDA Assistance

To date, BHR/OFDA funding has been obligated as follows:

Grant to ICRC for assistance to Rwandan refugees and displaced persons in eastern Zaire . $5,000,000

Grant to IRC for water/sanitation/health in Cyangugu and Kibungo Prefectures . $1,000,000

Grant to World Relief International for shelter in urban Kigali . $624,295 Grant to ARC for water/sanitation/health in Byumba Prefecture . $2,795,893

Grant to SCF/UK for unaccompanied children . $468,612

Grant to African Medical and Research Foundation for health in Byumba Prefecture . $212,129

Grant to WVRD for health and unaccompanied children in Ruhengeri, Byumba, and Cyangugu Prefectures . $858,704

Grant to Christian Reformed World Relief Committee for food security in Kibuye and Kisenyi Prefectures . $650,189

Grant to UNDHA for information coordination . $151,178

Plastic sheeting, blankets for UNHCR . $493,675

Emergency health kits for the GOR's Ministry of Health . $205,013

Airlift of relief supplies to Rwanda for UNICEF . $90,000

In addition, BHR/OFDA is procuring communications equipment for the GOR and is in the process of obligating additional funds.

BHR/OFDA Assistance . $12,549,688

BHR/OTI Assistance

BHR's Office of Transition Initiatives (BHR/OTI) has provided a total of $375,000 to the Women in Transition project and to fund visits by local reporters to the Tribunal in Arusha. BHR/OTI also funded experts to travel to Rwanda to conduct an evaluation on the genocide trials.

BHR/OTI Assistance . $408,000

BHR/FFP Assistance

In FY 1997, BHR's Office of Food for Peace (BHR/FFP) has committed 96,000 MT of P.L. 480 emergency Title II commodities for WFP. These commodities, valued at $72,500,000, will assist refugees and displaced persons in Rwanda, Zaire, Burundi, and Tanzania.

BHR/FFP Assistance .$72,500,000

TOTAL USG FY 1997 HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE (to date). .$85,457,688


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997

441 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Sports - General;
Haile Stars in Hollywood Film


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - A team of famous film makers are preparing a Hollywood film called 'Endurance' on the life story of the world beating Haile Gebre- Silassie, whose achievements have changed the negative impression of many outsiders towards Ethiopia.

Leslie Woodhead, the director of the film told reporters here yesterday that, "Endurance is a positive film and will counteract the negative image by which Ethiopia is often portrayed outside of Africa as a land of drought and starvation, deserts and war."

The wide - screen 35mm Hollywood feature cinema portrays the triumph of the Ethiopian spirit casting about 20 members of Haile's extended family. 

The film begins with Haile as a child with his family in a tukul in a village of Dara near Assela of Arsi Zone and ends in Atlanta when he triumphs against the rest of the world, Mr. Woodhead said. The cinema also features the other victories of the 1996 Olympics hero, major Haile Gebre-Selassie.

"In Endurance, ... We will show a land where there still exists a true society, ... Ethiopia has much to teach and we in the West have much to learn, " the director remarked.

The Co-producer of 'Endurance' Miss Sally Roy said Haile is chosen for the film because he reversed the world expectation that the victory in the 10,000 meters Olympic game would go to the other East African countries.

Endurance will be screened this time next year in various parts of the world. The team has now completed a ten week shooting in Ethiopia.

The acclaimed Hollywood executives Terence Malick, Edward R. Pressma and Hanz Zimmer are the other makers of the film in pictures and music composition respectively.

Among Ethiopian members of the team are Mohammed Idris, who has worked with Laslie Woodhead over many years and Tafari Wossen of Waag Communications. the film crew also includes talented Ethiopian film makers Yilma Belay, Abebe Ketsela and Abebe Mergia.

Leslie Woodhead commended the close cooperation of the Ministry of Information and Culture, the police force, the Ministry of Education, the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, the Ethiopian Airlines, the Civil Aviation Authority and the Ministry of Defence.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


442 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Ethiopia;
House Endorses Agreements


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The House of Peoples' Representatives yesterday approved three agreements that would enable the facilitation of development cooperation.

The 17th regular meeting of the House began its deliberations by accepting the proposals of the Legal Affairs Standing Committee and unanimously endorsed the amended Lome IV Convention, the Ethio-Austrian development cooperation agreement as well as the protocol agreement enabling Austria, Finland and Sweden to be signatories to the Lome IV Convention. 

The proclamation which endorsed the Lome IV Convention enables Ethiopia to get access to free aid provided every five year by countries of the European Union for the execution of different development projects.

The endorsed agreement also enables the country to obtain soft loan and free assistance fund as export compensation from the European Investment Bank.

The proclamation stipulates that Ethiopia benefits from free aid provided by the European community for economic reform programmes directly and from financial aid to the region through development activities carried out in cooperation with neighbouring countries.

The country would also benefit from the emergency food aid and rehabilitation assistance of the European community, according to the proclamation.

The Lome IV Convention as amended on November 4, 1995 in Mauritius provides for assistance by the European Community for the promotion of human rights, democracy and the strengthening of the private sector of the economy.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


443 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Ethiopia;
Prime Minister Meles Returns Home


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - Prime Minister Meles Zenawi returned here yesterday after attending a regional summit on the crisis in the Great Lakes Region held in Nairobi, Kenya.

According to a press statement, the summit reviewed recent developments in the Great Lakes region and noted the easing of the refugees problem in Eastern Zaire. "It, however, expressed concern that the security situation had deteriorated further since the Nairobi summit of 5th of November, 1996," it added. 

The statement said the summit noted with regret that the cease-fire called in Eastern Zaire by the fifth of November, 1996 summit had not been effected.

It called upon the parties to the conflict to commit themselves to a negotiated peaceful settlement, the statement said, adding the summit directed the ministers for foreign affairs to establish a follow-up mechanism.

It also reiterated its commitment to the territorial integrity of Zaire in accordance with the OAU Charter and in particular, the Cairo Declaration of 1964 on territorial integrity and inviolability of national boundaries as inherited at independence and caned for non-intervention and an end to cross- border incursions.

The summit welcomed the assurance by President Mobuto Sese Seko of Zaire to the foreign ministers mandated to convey the decisions of the Nairobi summit, that the government of Zaire recognizes the inalienable right to citizenship and nationality of all people within its internationally recognized boundaries, as stipulated in the OAU Charter and other relevant international convention.

"The summit considers this assurance as a significant step in the search for a lasting solutions to the crisis," the statement said.

It expressed regret that the united Nations Security council Resolution No. 1078 of 1996 failed to consider the decisions of the Nairobi summit of last month and Monday's summit and meeting of the OAU Central Organ on conflict Prevention, Management and Resolution on the deployment of a multinational force in Eastern Zaire.

The summit observed that a large number of Rwandese refugees in Eastern Zaire had returned to Rwanda for settlement and expressed appreciation to the international community to continue to support efforts to resettle, rehabilitate and reintegrate the returnees.

The summit also called on the international community to provide substantial assistance for refugees who have returned to Rwanda and to encourage the return to their respective countries of the remaining bona fide refugees still in Zaire as well as those in Tanzania.

The one-day Nairobi summit was attended by Prime Minister Meles of Ethiopia, President Daniel Arap Moi of Kenya (host), presidents of Eritrea, Zimbabwe, Uganda, Zambia, South Africa, Tanzania and Rwanda, according to a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The spokesman said President Moi expressed dissatisfaction over the absence of Zairian president from the November 5 and Monday s summit.

On arrival, Prime Minister Meles was welcomed by ministers and senior government officials.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


444 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia - The Week In Brief


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - Donors pledge 2.5 bln. dollars

Overtly impressed by the government's ongoing efforts to reduce poverty, the donor community which attended the consultative group (CG) meeting recently, pledged to provide Ethiopia with US $2.5 billion over the next three-year period. The greater part of the sum was reportedly a grant and the balance loans on highly concessional terms.

Briefing reporters on the outcome of the meeting here, World Bank Regional Vice President for Africa, Callisto E.Madavo said that the two and a half-day discussion was a great success. He described the pledge as "indicator of a tremendous vote of confidence". 

"We had a very good discussion in three priority areas - food security, education and health - and we were honoured to have Prime Minister Meles Zenawi with us to the meeting who unusually enriched our discussion. He was so forthright. it is a pleasure to see this kind of leadership on African soil," Mr. Madavo said.

It is to be recalled that Finance Minister Sufian Ahmed said at the opening session that the medium-term requires a financial intake of US 2 billion.

Anti-polio vaccination launched

The second round sub-national anti-polio immunization was launched for three consecutive days beginning on last Friday with President Negasso Gidada vaccinating the first child at the Ba ata Clinic in Addis.

Speaking on the occasion, Dr. Negasso said conducting national and sub- national immunization days is a university accepted key strategy to eradicate poliomyelitis by the year 2,000.

As part of the international community, Ethiopia is engaged in the activities to eradicate polio from the country by the year 1993 E.C., the President said, recalling the achievements made during the first round programme when about 270,000 of the planned 300,000 children were vaccinated with the coverage of 92 per cent.

House endorses agreement

The House of Peoples' Representatives recently endorsed the seven million dollars loan agreement signed between Ethiopia and the International Development Fund of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) to build teachers' training institutions in three national regional states.

The institutions to be built in Oromia, Southern Peoples and Afar national regional states will have dormitories for students and residential quarters for teachers.

Gold smuggling

The Adola Gold Development Enterprise, disclosed that 1,000 kilograms of gold is smuggled into neighbouring countries every year from Odo Shakisso Woreda, Borena zone, Ato Abdu Bezabeh, head of occupational safety and environmental protection service of the enterprise, said studies conducted since 1993 indicated that gold, which is taken away to neighbouring countries is produced by 30-40 thousand illegal individuals.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


445 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Ethiopia;
Israel Makes Donation to Health


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 107 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The Ministry of Health (MOH) yesterday received antibiotics and medical equipment in donation from the Government of Israel. 

Israeli Ambassador to Ethiopia Mr. Avi A. Granot has handed over the medicines and the equipment to Dr. Lamisso Hayisso, vice minister of MOH.

The vice minister said at the handing over ceremony that the donation made upon the request of the ministry would have significant contributions.

Sources in the ministry said the donation is worth about 20,000 dollars.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


446 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Ethiopia;
Guraghe Zone Offers Agricultural Investment Opportunities


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

WOLKITE- There is vast opportunity for the involvement of investors in the agricultural sector in Guraghe zone, zonal council chairman said.

In a remark he made at the zonal investment workshop on Saturday, Ato Yasin Mohammed said over 16,000 hectare of arable land is available in three woredas alone of which 13 per cent is irrigable.

Over 4,000 square meters open space in Wolkite and Butajira towns is still awaiting entrepreneurs, besides the availability of raw materials including minerals necessary in the industry sector. 

He said 29 investors with a total capital of 99 million have been issued with licenses since 1993.

According to the chairman, of the 15,643 hectares of land granted to the investors, only 1,000 hectares has so far been cultivated.

Opening the workshop, Ato Abate Kisho, head of the Southern Peoples Regional State, called on investors to intensify their participation taking into advantage of the directives and working procedures the region has implemented.

Native investors of the zone have raised questions and pin-pointed shortcomings during discussion aimed at addressing entrepreneurs.

A pictorial exhibition depicting the natural resource of the zone was also visited by workshop participants.

At the end of the workshop the zonal council announced that it will strive investment constraints executives of the zone said work permits will be issued to prospective investors within a short period following presentation of applications.

According to the executives, the zone will exert unstinted efforts to expand existing infrastructures, one of deterrent factors for the intensification of investment in the zone.

Ato Yasin Mohammed said investors could easily get plots of land now that the lease regulation issued by the zone has become practical.

Some entrepreneurs who are undertaking investment activities in the zone said they are carrying out their projects smoothly owing to encouraging support from the zonal council.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


447 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
Amin Exhibition Displayed


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

BAHIR DAR, Ethiopia - A photographic exhibition displaying some selected works of the late frontline cameraman, Mohammed Amin, was exhibited here on Sunday and yesterday.

One hundred selected works of the famous journalist, including a video film depicting some activities of the Kenya-born photographer, were displayed to public during the two-day event. 

Jointly organized by the Amhara State and Region 14 branch office of the Ethiopian Journalists Association(EJA) and cosponsored by the Amhara Development Association and the Lake Tana Transport Organization, the exhibition was formally opened by Ato Ahmed Seid, a representative of the Amhara State Council. Ato Tabor Gebre Medhin Chairman of the Amhara State branch EJA, said that Mo s works would inspire other journalist, those of Ethiopia, in particular.

'Mo' was killed in the tragic crash that befell Ethiopian Airlines jet liner last November.

It was to be recalled that the Region 14 branch EJA organized a similar exhibition which drew a huge public admiration.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


448 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Ethiopia;
Supporters Pledge TO Development Associaton


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - Supporters of the Harari Relief and Development Association (HARDA) have pledged 1,020,000 birr to the association at a fund-raising gala dinner held at the Hilton Hotel Saturday.

Major contributors at the event were the multi million investor Mohammed Hussien Alamoudi who pledged 100,000 dollars and the International Trading and manufacturing Enterprise which gave 30,000 birr. 

This fiscal year, the association plans to undertake a 7.4 million birr water supply project to provide potable water to 37,000 rural people and expand six primary schools in Jegol an area in the walled medieval town of Harar, at the cost of more than 754,000 birr, Ato Mohammed Sherif, General Manager of the association said.

HARDA is a nonegovernmental organization that aims to provide emergency assistance to victims of man-made and natural disaster, and collaborate with the federal and regional government in the effort to extend various services to the people of the regional state.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


449 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Algeria;
Algeria Bans Official Use Of French


BYLINE: Ali Dellali, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 909 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Algeria has announced a ban on the use of the French language in the country's administration and other public sectors. The measure becomes effective July 5, 1998.

The National Algerian Transitional Council adopted on Tuesday the decree banning French in two years and calling for the widespread use of Arabic in this former French colony. 

Council has given Algerian universities until July 5, 2000 when they must switch to teaching only in Arabic.

The ban on French is part of the Arabization policy adopted after the country's independence from France on July 5, 1962.

Since then, implementation of this decision has had to be abandoned several times.

For example, in 1994 the decree was suspended due to the conflict between Arabophils and Francophils. The struggle between these two groups for linguistic dominance has still not abated.

The decree was adopted the same day the Ministerial Conference of French- speaking Countries began their meeting in Marrakesh, Morocco.

The use of Arabic should be widespread by July 5, 1998 and by July 5, 2000 it should be compulsory in all the political, economic and social sectors in Algeria.

Thereafter no political statement, speech, or correspondence can be in French neither can any conference or lecture be given in this language. Television programmes and oral communications will be made in Arabic.

Any public official writing documents in a language other than Arabic -- apart from contracts with international firms -- will be liable to a fine of 5,000 dinars (about 90 US dollars).

It is uncertain to what degree Algerians will heed this edict, although some 75 percent of the country's 26.6 million people are Arabs. Algerians have failed to obey orders to conduct government business exclusively in Arabic over the past 34 years. Moreover, some 25 percent of the population are Berbers who want their language, the indigenous language, to be given greater official recognition by the government.

Some opposition parties see the decree as a concession by President Liamine Zeroual to militant Moslem groups. The country has been embroiled in violence between the secular government and radical Moslem organizations.

The new decree also makes provision for the creation of a High Council for Arabic Language chaired by the Algerian head of state.

In a similar move, the present French government of Prime Minister Jacque Touvon has passed a law compelling radio stations in the country to play a certain percentage of their music in French and not English. French ultra- nationalists have been complaining that too many English words were in current use in French.

However, despite or because of its former French colonial status, Algeria has said that English, and not French, will be the first and most important foreign language taught in its schools.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


450 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Zambia;
Chiluba Asks His Ministers To Declare Assets


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba has given his newly appointed ministers till Jan. 2, 1997 to declare their assets and liabilities.

During the swearing-in of two ministers Wednesday, Chiluba said that none of the new ministers had made public their assets and liabilities. 

Under Zambian law, certain categories of public office holders must declare their assets. This requirement is intended to portray a transparent image of government leaders.

Chiluba, recently re-elected to a second term of office, declared in October that he had four vehicles, owned three homes in both high and low cost residential areas of Ndola, a mining town in the northern Copperbelt region.

He has no other source of income, apart from his salary and the rents he draws from his homes. He declared two bank accounts with a combined total of 2.8 million kwacha (about 2,333 U.S. dollars).


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


451 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambian Government Seizes Control Of Country's Soccer Finances


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The government in Lusaka has taken full charge of the finances of the Football Association of Zambia, the country's supreme soccer-governing body, to help streamline administration of the national soccer team, Sports Minister Samuel Miyanda said Wednesday.

The measure followed a revolt Tuesday by players of the national soccer team players, who abandoned their camp in the capital in protest against unpaid allowances. 

The team had just returned from Kenya where it played two friendly matches against that country's national soccer side. The Zambian team is due to leave Thursday for Zimbabwe for similar warm up matches in readiness for the Jan. 12, 1997 second World Cup qualifying match against South Africa.

Miyanda said at his news conference that he had ordered fresh elections early in 1997 for a fully-fledged National Executive Committee of the association. It will replace the current interim body.

Two years ago government dismissed the association's chairman, Jabes Zulu, and his deputy, Wilfrid Wonani, for alleged misappropriation of funds.

The association relies solely on government money and some fund raising activities to meet its needs.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


452 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 18, 1996


Zaire;
UN Food Agency Airlifts Urgent Supplies To Eastern Zaire


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - A World Food Programme chartered Boeing 707 cargo jet arrived in Kisangani, eastern Zaire, Wednesday with 38.5 metric tons of urgently needed food supplies for Rwandan and Burundian refugees in Lubutu, the agency said.

From it headquarters in Rome, the agency said the flight was the first of three that will bring a total of 120 ton of high protein biscuits, maize meal, beans and oil to refugees in Lubutu, some 200 kilometers (about 124 miles) south of Kisangani. 

The remaining flights are expected within the next 48 hours. The deliveries will feed 120,000 people for four to five days.

Field officials for the agency report that the food situation in the area is critical and that many children show signs of severe dehydration. The refugees walked for almost one month before reaching Lubutu, surviving on wild food.

The refugees fled fighting in the eastern Zairean towns of Goma and Bukavu. Zairians displaced by the war are also among the refugees.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


453 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 19, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe's Agriculture Grows Impressively


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Due to increased production of grain, Zimbabwe's agricultural sector is expected to grow by 49 percent by the end of the year, President Robert Mugabe said Thursday in Harare.

"Grain crops made a significant contribution to this growth with maize production increasing from 839,000 tons in 1994/95 season to 2,609,000 tons while wheat production increased from 65,000 to 250,000 tons," he told parliament in his annual state of the union address. 

Tobacco production also rose during the same period from 198,000 to 209,716 tons. Cotton also registered its third best harvest with 275, 000 tons, up from the previous 104,700 tons.

Agriculture contributes 11 percent to 14 percent of Zimbabwe's gross domestic product, producing about 60 percent of all raw materials.

"Horticulture remains the most buoyant and the fastest growing industry, growth over the past 10 years has been consistent and has risen in value terms from 30,000 dollars to a projected 120 million dollars in the coming year," Mugabe said.

Horticulture is Zimbabwe's second largest single foreign currency earner to tobacco.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


454 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 19, 1996


Science and Health;
Zimbabwe To Pass Law To Protect HIV-Positive Workers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Faced with the predicament of having over one million people with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) that causes AIDS, the Zimbabwean government says it will introduce a code of practice prohibiting any form of discrimination against HIV/AIDS-infected workers.

This was announced Thursday in Harare by President Robert Mugabe in his annual state of the nation address before parliament.

He told the 150-seat house that the code of practice identified the responsibilities of government, employers and workers regarding people infected with the killer disease. 

People infected with HIV or suffering from full-blown AIDS, he said, should never be discriminated against at the workplace.

"In the face of growing unemployment, insecurity and discrimination faced by workers with HIV/AIDS, a national code of practice on AIDS and employment has been drafted after an extensive multi-sectoral consultative process and now awaits gazetting for it to become a statutory instrument to our labor relations act," Mugabe said.

Government, he said, was concerned about the HIV/AIDS pandemic which continued to claim thousands of lives each year and was causing immense stress on the existing health facilities.

Zimbabwean health authorities say that at least 54,744 AIDS cases have been recorded since 1987 when the first case was reported in the country. It is estimated that 600,000 children would be orphaned by AIDS by the year 2,000.

"Appropriate behavioral change remains the cornerstone of HIV/AIDS prevention and control," he said. "In line with this, education programmes emphasizing family values, self-respect and positive cultural practices have been targeted at youths in and out of school, men and women in the workplace and the public at large."

He said another cause of concern was the continuing increase in tuberculosis cases. These have risen from 5,233 in 1986 to 30,831 in 1995.

Medical experts here say most of these cases are related to AIDS.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


455 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 19, 1996


Burundi;
Burundians To Contribute Towards War Effort


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Burundian public workers will effective January 1997 have to contribute 6 percent of their monthly wages toward the ongoing civil war, which has engulfed the country since October 1993.

In a statement issued after a cabinet meeting in Bujumbura, the government said the measure will affect workers in the public, and private firms. 

It added that rural dwellers will be required to pay 1,000 Burundian francs, the equivalent of three U.S. dollars, per household.

On Nov. 26, the government ordered a general mobilization of the population to contribute towards the war, which erupted in October 1993, after the democratically-elected Hutu President, Melchior Ndadaye, was assassinated in an abortive coup fomented by soldiers from the minority Tutsi ethnic group.

Under the mobilization the office of military ruler, Maj. Pierre Buyoya, said that all able-bodied Burundians who make an income from their activities should contribute to a national solidarity fund created for the purpose.

Effective December, cabinet ministers and other high-ranking personalities with similar status are required to pay 25,000 Burundian francs per month (about 77 dollars) to set an example.

In addition, the military government in Bujumbura also introduced compulsory national service of two months for all Burundians who complete secondary and university education.

According to the Tutsi-dominated administration in Bujumbura, these measures are expected to calm the charged ethnic tension, which has led to the death of at least 150,000 people since 1993.

The deaths occurred in revenge attacks between the majority Hutu ethnic group, to which Ndadaye belonged, and the Tutsi, whose rogue soldiers reportedly assassinated him.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


456 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 19, 1996


Burundi;
More Than 70 Killed In Southern Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - At least 78 people have been killed in Kizuka, southern Burundi, 70 kilometers from Bujumbura, army spokesman Col. Longin Minani announced Thursday. 

The killings, described here as a massacre, was discovered by soldiers pursuing extremist Hutu rebels who had been active in the area.

He said that an enquiry had been opened to identify those responsible for the attack who, he added, will be "very severely punished."

Jean Minani, the exiled chairman of the Hutu-dominated Front for Democracy in Burundi, Jean Minani -- not to be confused with the colonel -- announced Wednesday that over 4,000 civilians had been killed in daily clashes between the Tutsi-dominated army and armed Hutu gangs in the past four months.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


457 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 19, 1996


Zaire;
Mobutu Appoints Gen. Mahele Chief Of Staff


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - Zaire President Mobutu Sese Seko appointed Lt. Gen. Mahele Bokungu Lieko as chief of staff Thursday, in a military leadership change designed to regain territory lost to anti-government forces in the eastern part of the country and instill discipline in the army.

Mahele replaces army General Eluki Monga Aundi who was dismissed in November for publicly criticizing the government's handling of the crisis.

Now, Mahele accepted the job on condition that he control the entire military establishment, especially the Presidential Division and Civil Guard which have been outside direct army command. 

These two units have been provide with superior quantities and quality of arms, equipment, and with more privileges.

Gen. Mahele headed of the army from 1991 to 1993. His recall to the General Army Headquarters comes the day after Mobutu returned from four months of medical treatment in Switzerland and recuperation in France.

Mahele graduated from the Higher War Academy of Paris. He commanded the 311th Paratroop Battalion which seized the mining town of Kolwezi in the 1978 Katangese rebellion in Shaba Province, recapturing the airport from former Katangese gendarmes.

He was promoted to colonel and subsequently to brigadier a few years later. He was also appointed commander of the 1st Military Region with headquarters in Lubumbashi, Zaire's south-eastern province of Shaba. Later, he took command of the Military Intelligence Service, the SARM, in Kinshasa.

He commanded the Zairian expeditionary corps in Rwanda, in 1990, at the beginning of the civil war which was rekindled by the death of President Juvenal Habyarimana in April 1994, four months before Tutsi anti-government forces, called the Rwandan Patriotic Front, defeated the largely Hutu government in July 1994.

Mahele was appointed army chief of staff and promoted to Lieutenant General in 1991, following the mutiny which degenerated into looting in the Zairean capital.

Two years later, after ruthlessly repressing the mutiny and the looting in Kinshasa, he resigned his command, allowing Gen. Eluki to take over the army.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


458 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 19, 1996


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 62 on the Great Lakes (12/19)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1760 words


 

Nairobi - Zaire named a new army chief yesterday as reports mounted of preparations for a counter-offensive against the rebels in eastern Zaire. Zairean television said General Mahele Bokoungo Lieko had been appointed army chief by presidential decree to restructure the armed forces "with a view to putting them on a war footing and improving their efficiency".

Gen. Mahele, who held the post in 1991 and 1992 and who is said to be popular in Zaire, will also head the crack Special Presidential Division (DSP) troops as well as the civil guard and gendarmerie. The current civil guard chief, General Baramato Kpama, had been acting army chief and it is not known what role he will now play. Mobutu was due to meet political leaders today, according to state television.

Reuters reported that hundreds of residents were fleeing Goma, fearful of a counter-attack by the Zairean army. Residents told Reuters they believed French troops were based at Kisangani and would bombard Goma from the air, but there has been no confirmation of this. In a speech to the nation late Tuesday, Mobutu vowed to take personal control of the rebellion in the east. A spokesman for opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi described Mobutu's message as "generally satisfactory". Tshisekedi's Union for Democracy and Social Progress plans to hold an emergency congress on Saturday. 

Eastern Zaire rebels announced they were ready for any counter-offensive, saying Mobutu's return changed nothing. Rebel leader Laurent Kabila called on Mobutu to resign and hand over power to the ADFL. "We are well prepared, morale of our troops is high and the population supports their liberation from slavery," he told Reuters. "Either he (Mobutu) engages himself in negotiations with the alliance to solve the political crisis or he has to face the law of force," Kabila said. In further remarks, broadcast by rebel Star Radio today, he assured civilians that they were safe and urged them not to flee rebel-held areas.

A possible standoff between rebels and Zairean troops in Bunia was gaining momentum as Zairean reinforcements were flown into the town, while sources on the ground reported that rebels were in control of villages around the town, including Boga, Geti and Mambasa. Eight to ten planeloads of Zairean soldiers have reportedly been flown to Bunia from Kisangani, and troops are arriving from Kinshasa to beef up forces in Kisangani.

WFP began airlifting food aid into Kisangani yesterday for onward distribution to Lubutu where missionary sources confirmed the presence of up to 150,000 mostly Rwandan and Burundian refugees at Tingi-Tingi just outside the town. They were said to be faring better than some 50,000 displaced people further south in Katshungu who were in very poor shape. WFP however, said the children in Lubutu were particularly vulnerable, many of them showing signs of severe dehydration. There has been speculation - so far unconfirmed - that the Lubutu refugees may comprise ex-FAR/Interahamwe elements.

ICRC said it was providing assistance for almost 50,000 Rwandan and Burundian refugees who had gathered near the town of Shabunda. There were several thousand new arrivals very day at the temporary site deep in the forest. ICRC said the aid operation was being conducted in extremely arduous conditions because of the nature of the terrain and heavy rainfall. Supplies were first airlifted by heavy transport plane from Nairobi to Kindu, then transferred to lighter aircraft which can land at Shabunda. There they were loaded onto dugout canoes, and bicycles were used for the last part of the journey.

Kenya lashed out at Zaire yesterday, saying it took great exception to comments by Zairean Information Minister Boguo Makele that the second Nairobi Great Lakes summit was a plot by anglophone countries to destabilise Zaire. " It is regrettable that Zaire does not appreciate efforts by the leaders of the subregion to find solutions to the crisis in Zaire," said a statement, signed the permanent secretary in the information ministry, Samuel Ambuka. Media reports point out that the Nairobi summit strengthened Kenyan President Moi's hand in the region by successfully including President Mandela to handle a crisis outside his immediate region.

Rwandan returnees from Tanzania's Ngara camps today were put at 20,000 as of 10:30 local time, while an estimated 225,000 had arrived by yesterday. A UN spokesman confirmed that a Rwandan soldier had fired on a vehicle in a UNHCR convoy yesterday. No injuries were reported, but night-time operations were suspended as a result. Way stations are being set up for about 120,000 refugees expected to start the long trek from the Karagwe camps to the Rusumo border crossing in the next few days. Tanzanian Foreign Minister Jakaya Kikwete reiterated that all Rwandan refugees must return, despite criticisms of human rights violations. "We won't listen, we won't apologise to anyone. Let them talk until they get tired and keep quiet," he said. Allowing the refugees to remain in Tanzania would just provide a haven for ex- FAR/Interahamwe groups, he added. Kikwete also said his government would hand over an undisclosed number of Rwandan refugees indicted by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda. These included some of the refugees rounded up last week for intimidating fellow refugees, he told a news conference. "We will send them to the Arusha tribunal to face charges of genocide in Rwanda," he said.

Uganda yesterday refused to host some 2,000 Rwandan refugees who crossed into its territory from camps in Tanzania. In an interview with the state- owned 'New Vision" newspaper, Local Government Minister Bidandi Ssali said the refugees, who were sheltering at the Oruchinga camp in Mbarara district, would either have to go home, or back to Tanzania. "We are not prepared to accept them here, not because they are Hutus, but because they have contravened the UN convention on refugees," he said. Malawi also said it would not offer asylum to Rwandans escaping repatriation from Zaire and Tanzania, saying it had suffered badly from environmental problems when it had hosted Mozambican refugees.

A report in Kenya's 'East African Standard' today claimed at least 100 Hutu refugees had secretly crossed into Kenya from Tanzania over the last four days. The newspaper cited sources as saying the refugees from camps in the Ngara region, had entered Kenya through the Isebania border area in Kuria district using secret routes to avoid immigration procedures.

Rwanda reported that some 5,500 Zairean refugees in the Gisenyi area began returning home yesterday. According to Rwandan radio, monitored by the BBC, the refugees had been living at the university compound in Mudende, Mutura commune. Local authorities concluded there was no reason for the refugees to continue living under sheeting when their home areas were peaceful, the radio said. Meanwhile, according to UN figures, 446 Burundians, fleeing fighting in Cibitoke province, entered Rwanda via Cyangugu between 13-16 December. They are being housed at a camp for Burundian refugees near Bugarama.

Burundi's main Hutu party FRODEBU yesterday accused the military of killing 4,000 Hutu refugees who had returned to Burundi from Zaire. The claim was made by party leader Jean Minani in an interview with Radio France Internationale from Arusha, Tanzania. A UN human rights report a week ago said 1,000 people had been massacred between end October-end November, mostly by soldiers.

The Vatican on Tuesday said it had convened a meeting of Roman Catholic bishops from the Great Lakes to discuss the crisis in the region, the first such meeting in four years. The four-day meeting begins today in Nairobi, and comprises bishops from Rwanda, Burundi, Zaire and church representatives from Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania. The Vatican said the meeting was aimed at showing ecclesiastical solidarity in the region and identifying the Church's priorities and actions.

Uganda and Sudan are to meet in Kampala this week for peace talks brokered by Iran, although President Museveni said he did not expect huge progress to be made. "I have agreed that talks should take place here," he told a news conference late Tuesday. "But of course we have not broken any ground with (Sudanese Islamic leader) Mr al-Tourabi's people." Museveni said Uganda was still searching for a military solution to the rebellion in the north, which it says is backed by Sudan. "We must get a solution to al-Tourabi's blackmail, a military solution," Museveni said. "I am not going to invade al-Tourabi. Al-Tourabi has enough enemies who will take care of him." Sudan accuses Uganda of supporting the rebel Sudanese People's Liberation Army in the south.

Nairobi, 19 December 1996, 15:00 gmt (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe's Agriculture Grows Impressively


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 850 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Due to increased production of grain, Zimbabwe's agricultural sector is expected to grow by 49 percent by the end of the year, President Robert Mugabe said Thursday in Harare.

"Grain crops made a significant contribution to this growth with maize production increasing from 839,000 tons in 1994/95 season to 2,609,000 tons while wheat production increased from 65,000 to 250,000 tons," he told parliament in his annual state of the union address. 

Tobacco production also rose during the same period from 198,000 to 209,716 tons. Cotton also registered its third best harvest with 275, 000 tons, up from the previous 104,700 tons.

Agriculture contributes 11 percent to 14 percent of Zimbabwe's gross domestic product, producing about 60 percent of all raw materials.

"Horticulture remains the most buoyant and the fastest growing industry, growth over the past 10 years has been consistent and has risen in value terms from 30,000 dollars to a projected 120 million dollars in the coming year," Mugabe said.

Horticulture is Zimbabwe's second largest single foreign currency earner to tobacco.

Science and Health;
Zimbabwe To Pass Law To Protect HIV-Positive Workers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words

This was announced Thursday in Harare by President Robert Mugabe in his annual state of the nation address before parliament.

Africa News


December 19, 1996


Burundi;
Burundians To Contribute Towards War Effort


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Burundian public workers will effective January 1997 have to contribute 6 percent of their monthly wages toward the ongoing civil war, which has engulfed the country since October 1993.

In a statement issued after a cabinet meeting in Bujumbura, the government said the measure will affect workers in the public, and private firms. 

It added that rural dwellers will be required to pay 1,000 Burundian francs, the equivalent of three U.S. dollars, per household.

On Nov. 26, the government ordered a general mobilization of the population to contribute towards the war, which erupted in October 1993, after the democratically-elected Hutu President, Melchior Ndadaye, was assassinated in an abortive coup fomented by soldiers from the minority Tutsi ethnic group.

Under the mobilization the office of military ruler, Maj. Pierre Buyoya, said that all able-bodied Burundians who make an income from their activities should contribute to a national solidarity fund created for the purpose.

Effective December, cabinet ministers and other high-ranking personalities with similar status are required to pay 25,000 Burundian francs per month (about 77 dollars) to set an example.

In addition, the military government in Bujumbura also introduced compulsory national service of two months for all Burundians who complete secondary and university education.

According to the Tutsi-dominated administration in Bujumbura, these measures are expected to calm the charged ethnic tension, which has led to the death of at least 150,000 people since 1993.

The deaths occurred in revenge attacks between the majority Hutu ethnic group, to which Ndadaye belonged, and the Tutsi, whose rogue soldiers reportedly assassinated him.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


462 of 708 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 19, 1996


Burundi;
More Than 70 Killed In Southern Burundi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - At least 78 people have been killed in Kizuka, southern Burundi, 70 kilometers from Bujumbura, army spokesman Col. Longin Minani announced Thursday. 

The killings, described here as a massacre, was discovered by soldiers pursuing extremist Hutu rebels who had been active in the area.

He said that an enquiry had been opened to identify those responsible for the attack who, he added, will be "very severely punished."

Jean Minani, the exiled chairman of the Hutu-dominated Front for Democracy in Burundi, Jean Minani -- not to be confused with the colonel -- announced Wednesday that over 4,000 civilians had been killed in daily clashes between the Tutsi-dominated army and armed Hutu gangs in the past four months.

LANGUAGE: English
